Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'COVID-19 (Update)' by Mass-Observer S6835.;The Directive 'COVID-19 (Update)' was issued on 27 April 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their experiences of the COVID-19 pandemic, in particular 'health'; 'the government'; 'news'; 'work and home life'; 'technology'; 'shopping and food'; 'entertainment and leisure'; 'personal hygiene' and 'sleep'.
Contents: Part 2: Covid 19 (Update) Health So far, I’ve onlyhad one urgent ‘health’ issue: a rubber dome from a hearing aid lodged in my ear! I had to drive to the urgent treatment centre in the nearest hospital in order to have it extracted. The ‘operation’ took aminute and I waited onlyfive minutes. But it was alittle unnerving tomix with people for the first time for weeks even though there were relatively few day patients around. My underlying conditions – low level diabetes, risk of heart atrial fibrillation, tendency to high blood pressure and mild COPD are largely managed with medication. During the crisis, however, I have been told by my GP practice not to attend the surgery for routine appointments or monitoring tests which have been placed on hold until the lockdown ends. My one current problem is the sudden deterioration in my hearing which makes conversation and, especially, using the phone all the more difficult – and increases the sense of isolation. Just before the lockdown, I planned appointments to have this seen to but now I have to wait until normality returns. My emotions vary. Being almost totally isolated, as instructed by the NHS, due to age and underlying medical conditions, does, inevitably, induce feelings of loneliness and anxiety and sometimes lethargy. Most of the time I manage to cope by keeping busy or diverted and keeping in touch with family and friends by email and text etc. My emotions are, though, still affected by grief over the death of my wife of 50 years about three years ago. The sense of her absence makes isolation all the harder to live with. If we were still together, we would have found isolation much easier, even though we might have worried about each other, other people and the state of the world. We could have found enjoyment in doing things together and just securityin each other’s presence. Enjoyment and joy – very much in short supply these days. Increasing age doesn’t help either. I suppose this all amounts to a mild form of depression but at least I know why that is – it is not an inherent condition. And it helps a little to know that I am isolating to keep myself as safe as possible and to help protect others. Iamdoing ‘my bit’. I was made doubly aware recently of the seriousness of Covid-19 and the danger it poses when for some reason (possibly stress caused by technology) I suddenly felt hot and feared for a moment thought it could be the virus. Thankfully, when I checked mytemperature with aforehead thermometer, Ilearned that it was normal. Maybeit was nature’s way of reminding me to stay indoors. The Government It seems strange how a small news report about a virus outbreak in one part of a large country thousands of miles away (in January I think) has suddenly taken over and threatened and disrupted our lives. It seems that is often the unexpected dangers, the ones from the blind side, that cause the most harm. Certainly, the government didn’t see this one coming. During the early period when the virus began to spread, the government was still obsessed with leaving the European Community (‘Getting Brexit done’) and were late in the dayin taking action. The crisis has brought brough problems which would be almost insurmountable for any government but the present Tory administration could have done and could still do much better. We have not been well served, compared with other countries like Germany and South Korea. It is difficult to know where to start. I suppose with the fact that a wiser prime minister than a narcissist who thought that it was enough to sound like Churchill, instead of acting like him, would have chosen a more talented and less subservient cabinet. A better government would have coordinated public information more tightly so that the vital information it gave out was more consistent and less confusing. And an over reliance on saying that they are led by the science brushes over the fact that, as is necessary, scientists do not always agree with each other. Praising the NHS every five minutes is no substitute for acting effectively and in a timely fashion and presenting care workers with a badge is insulting when they are among those most at risk and up to now the least protected. Other concerns are: . A contingency planning exercise in 2017 seems to have largely been ignored which has prevented adequate stockpiling of medical supplies and personal protection. . The plight of residents and staff in care homes, especially vulnerable, has been virtually ignored until recently resulting in a high death rate which could have been prevented. . Anearlybeliefin the theoryof ‘herd immunity’ (allowing less vulnerable people to be infected and to mix so that they helped spread immunity) delayed the onset of social distancing measures, lagging behind other countries. . An inability to initiate testing for the virus early enough. . Confusion and inconsistency in the selection of ‘vulnerable’ people for ‘shielded’ isolation (as I am when I know older people than me with more serious conditions have not been selected) . The earlier cuts to health and social care funding of previous Tory administrations. As a result, the UK has recorded the highest total death rate in Europe (as I write we have just topped 30,000) and almost in the world. And, the UK economy and all local communities will suffer all the more damage. I think the government has now realised what is at stake and is probably acting in a more coherent and cautious manner. They have to find a way to balance managing the social distancing policy with the desperate need to re-start the economy. Relaxing the former too soon could risk the spread of the virus starting up again, forcing a second lockdown. But delaying economic regeneration too long could do even greater damage to the long term economic and social fabric of the country than it has already done. And if course, continue to increase the huge cost of supporting business and workers and the enormous public financial debt. It will not have helped to have left the European Community, of course – international cooperation has never been more needed. Now the government has their eye on the ball at last, I think (or maybe hope) that they will manage to restore normality gradually, using sound information and advice. News I read The Guardian daily – as I have done for 60 years and often monitor the news on the various news websites on my i-phone. In addition, I watch BBC News bulletins and their news channel almost obsessively. It is depressing but not so depressing and anger inducing as the daily TV news briefings on BBC TV which do little but to demonstrate the inadequacies of a singularly weak set of cabinet ministers. Most of what is said by government representatives is little more than cliché and waffle, learned by rote almost. The useful element is usually the contribution of scientific and medical advisors and their visual aids. I know no-one who has trouble accessing the news but many who don’t watch the news because they feel it is too depressing. Having hearing impairment, I always use the subtitles and I find that adequate. I am not sure if signing is also essential but have an open mind. Work and Home Life Being long retired I don’t, of course, work but before the lockdown I spent a good deal of time as a volunteer: as a befriender to vulnerable people and as a trustee and secretary of a small charity. The befriending is suspended. I am still doing a little work for the charity with writing and editing policy documents and promotional literature and will be joining meetings via video conferencing (Zoom). Much of the work and information is conveyed by email. Home life has changed a good deal in that all life is confined to the home: no visits to friends and family, no outside walks, reliance for exercise on an exercise bike, no pub visits (though those were infrequent anyway), more watching TV, a little more reading. My world has shrunk. One significant change has been the evolution of a strict daily routine to get me through the day, based on meals, writing, emailing people, exercise and treats (tea and biscuits, coffee, wine). One problem which I know is common to a lot of people in isolation, is not knowing what day it is. To solve that I have just bought a digital clock which displays time, date, and day. Technology Before the lockdown, I was already using a variety of online technology: email, text, WhatsApp, and Instagram (the latter only for sharing photos with family members). I do not (and still do not use) Facebook, Twitter etc. A distant friend uses WhatsApp for a weekly video call but I have not yet attempted to find out how to use that. I am having to learn to use Zoom for the charity but have found it difficult so far – I am getting to my limit in learning new technology. It does not come naturally! Shopping and Food My daughter has been very helpful and brings me small amounts of food and other essentials (I originally moved to live near her but never imagined quite how useful that would be). And several friends have offered to get me things. But for most food I use the Iceland delivery service online. I do though have great trouble in finding available delivery slots. I am told that the time to do this is at or after midnight but that so far has been a step too far. I have never managed to find a Tesco delivery slot. Many local shops now deliver but have limited resources. If all fails, my daughter will add to her normal weekly shop for me. She has one of my bank cards to use or for cash. But I have a full freezer and most of the time a reasonably full food covered. I have had to learn how to plan my needs a week or two ahead. My cooking has not changed a good deal. I am vegetarian (with occasional fish and chips). I am not a keen cook and no longer use recipes though I have learned some basics from my late wife who was a superb veggie cook. For about three or four days’evening meals I make a large pan of pasta sauce or other mixture of vegetables, meat substitute (eg Quorn) with herbs etc and make it last with variations – eg with pasta, rice, potatoes. This saves time and trouble. Breakfast and lunch are still pretty minimal if healthy. I know that is all the wrong way round (breakfast should be larger, tea smaller) but habits stay fixed after many years. Entertainment and Leisure This area has taken the biggest hit, not necessarily because of the lockdown but since my bereavement. I have not felt able to do anything new – I have dabbled in many things in the past and most,thanks to mypermanent state of ‘aloneness’, I no longer have the motivation to attempt: poetry writing, painting and drawing. I do write in a notebook – ideas for poems which never come about or observations and, of course, Mass Observation writing which has been helpful in giving my writing a purpose. One new activity is entering writing and photography competitions, many for the over 70s in isolation. Photography is now limited by having to stay indoors, though I still take phone photos of skies and interior images and now and then have the chance to photograph birds in the adjacent trees. But I have always done that. DIY is now unnecessary: there are things in the flat I could improve but I can live without them – ‘its only me’. Ss already noted I try to stick to a session on my exercise bike every day now with some floor exercises – this as a substitute for daily walking around town. Myabilityto concentrate is now limited, even affecting myTV watching: if a programme doesn’t grip my attention then I’m off channel hopping, looking for something better or, like a teenager, looking at news or You Tube on my i-phone. But there are times when a programme holds me. One recent example which I have seen through twice is a new serial drama about the on/off love affair between two teenagers / students set in Ireland. SallyRooney’s ‘NormalPeople’ (adapted from her novel) has received critical acclaim and I can see why. The acting and direction and spare script are remarkable and sometimes almost make the viewer hold their breath. If this is still available in fifty years’ time, it maywell be a classic. I watched it twice in quick succession using the BBC iplayer catch up service on the digital TV. There are few programmes of that quality and the virus crisis has caused the creation of many new programmes to be suspended, meaning more repeats for the next year or so. Already I am seeking out older programmes but there is, frankly, a lot of dross to wade through to find the odd gem. Currently, as well was the BBC i-player, I have access to Netflix, More Four (Channel Four archive), ITV Hub and Amazon Prime. But most of what is on offer does not appeal. I have noticed that, during isolation, I am instinctively drawn less to crime dramas and more towards family dramas, even comedies – ‘people stories’, seemingly a kind ofsubstitute for meeting real people in the flesh. And subtitles are essential to catch all the dialogue. I do read a little more than I did before isolation, preferably sitting outside in the sun, though I often fall asleep! Day time reading is non-fiction: history, politics, biography, art etc. Friends have lent me books and I have returned the favour. I read novels, mainly on my Kindle e-reader in bed before trying to sleep. I can become lost in them. I have been reading a lot of books about bereavement – somehow this helps, especially in isolation, but reminding me that I am not alone in my experience ofgrief: one impressive novelin these lines is Sebastian Barry’s ‘Secret Scripture’, set in Ireland and centred on a 100 year-old woman in a mental hospital and the hospital director who has recently lost his wife. It reflects many of my feelings and experiences in losing my wife. Grief has become a fascinating subject recently. I no longer listen to radio since my hearing impairment makes this too much of a strain. Personal Hygiene In the light of health advice, I have been washing my hands more often and for longer. As a result the skin on my hands has aged, dry and creased! I now use a barrier cream to try to offset this. Just before the lockdown started, a friend advised me to get a haircut before it was too late. I managed this with a day or two to spare. It should last me another month at least – I try to keep it a little trim using an electric shaver. But I do not want to cut any more drastically than that. So, if I emerge from isolation with shoulder length hair, so be it. I have thought of growing a beard. I wore one for most of my working years and shaved it off, at mywife’s insistence when I retired, asymbolof a new life. But electric shaving is no trouble and is an entrenched habit so at present I will stick with the status quo. Sleep I have had sleep problems for several years – mainly waking up two or three times a night needing the toilet, as a result of an enlarged prostate. Bereavement has made this a little worse. And my hearing impairment makes listening to the radio with earphones, which used to help send me off again, less effective. There has been little difference in isolation – I can normally get between six and eight hours sleep (in instalments). I have recently developed a routine to help go to sleep initially – to read, then relax and then run through in my mind the events and activity of the previous day and what I need or want to do the following day. I tend to go to bed later now and sometimes I do sleep or doze late – with no incentive to get up. But I think most of this is common to a lot of people. I rarely remember dreams. Those I do recall – waking up in the middle -often feature my wife as if all is as it was. She is sometimes warning me about something or telling me something. So far, no nightmares though. But I have had such dreams ever since she died. Isolation has made little if any difference.

Living Arrangement Free Text: Although happily married for several years my spouse and I choose to keep our own homes. I spend about half the week at her place . Some people think it's odd but it works really well. We have our own finances but have a joint kitty for all social events. We don't argue and are happy. Regular FaceTime contact makes it easy to stay in touch.
Keywords: COVID-19 pandemic (2020-);Lifestyle, health and well-being;Family life;Reproductive health;Food;Schools;Adolescence;Family members;Personal hygiene;Emotional states;Personal appearance;LGBTQI+;Employment and occupations;Police services and policing;Mental health;Bereavement;Holidays;Society and social behaviour;
Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing'. Mass-Observer H7512 describes themself as 'a 53 year old woman married to another woman'; retired detective police officer.;The Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing' was issued on 27 November 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their opinions on and experiences of health and wellbeing, in particular 'health, wellbeing and the healthy body'; 'identity'; 'growing up and learning about health and wellbeing'; 'growing older'; 'health, wellbeing and appearance'; 'getting ready to leave the house'.
Contents: H7512. AUTUMN DIRECTIVE . HEALTH AND WELLBEING. I am a 53 year old woman married to another woman. I live in a small village in Saddleworth near Oldham. I am a retired Detective Police Officer. What does health mean to me. I suppose it means that you are not in pain,not in hospital or needing medical treatment. Not over or underweight.taking some exercise ,nourished ,hydrated . Getting enough sleep. Wellbeing means to me more about how you feel mentally and emotionally and around stress . Both have a connection and a poor situation in one affects the other. What do I imagine when I think healthy body first 5 words….Strong ,able bodied,medium build,nourished,rested. My identity is based upon a Northern,working class background. My parents were both from very working class origins,both starting work in cotton mills aged 14 so they could only pass on their life knowledge to that extent. Knowledge of different food and cultures was very limited in my childhood years due to my social class and poverty but in my adult years totally reversed as my massive interest in travel and since my mid 20,s in cooking has increased my awareness of all types of foods and ways to live as I have travelled extensively. Being female has made a difference in that I had years and years of difficult periods and eventually a hysterectomy in my late 40,s which was well overdue. Growing up and learning about health and wellbeing when and where first aware? I grew up in a 3 bedroom council house . Before my parents divorced aged 9 we were working class but better off and after when my mum was alone we were a lot poorer. There was no spare money . In relation to food we didn't identify it as it is now with either proteins,fat,carbohydrates etc it was either meat or fish,vegetables,potatoes or pasta,fruit or cheese. We knew that it was healthy to eat vegetables but no mention of 5 a day growing up. (I was born 1967 ). having 2 veg was considered acceptable. Salad was a healthy option but we mostly had what I would describe as Northern staple,stodge and filling type dishes. We would have a Sunday roast usually lamb or beef with Yorkshire pudding,roast potatoes veg and gravy but not every week and it was a treat. We had things like meat and potato pie with a suet crust or cheese and onion plate pies. Beef mince broth with dumplings. My Mum had a limited cooking repertoire and taught me the basic things she knew. School home economics didn't really teach me much more . It was only in my mid 2,s when I had 2 close friends who were chefs that I started to learn a lot more and became really into cooking and a self described foodie. Chocolate and sweets were regarded as a treat and bad for your teeth if you ate too many. School dinners were dreadful and put me off some foods but they served a purpose . Milk was seen as healthy for strong bones and my first role of responsibility at junior school was to be milk monitor. I fondly remember the cute little bottles and in the winter they would freeze at the top and bubble over the rim when they iced up or sometimes the birds would peck them. I always enjoyed my bottle of milk with my straw. There was no mention of full fat milk or semi skimmed /skimmed options…it was just milk. Probably not until my late teens early 20,s that concept became more popular and I only started drinking semi skimmed milk later on in life. My parents were responsible for my care when I was younger until about 9 years old when they divorced acrimoniously and then it was my mum who I lived with and an older brother. She took care of me for any medical appointments of which there weren't many as I have always been quite healthy .She had a universal bottle of TCP for any scrapes and grazes . H7512 I cant recall my parents talking about it much at all. Perhaps only that you needed to eat enough so you weren't starving and fruit and veg so you were healthy. Never any conversation about mental wellbeing with them. I gained more education as I grew older from sport mostly. I swam competitively so that gave me more information.I knew that sporting activity was good for you. As far as key moments adolescence puberty I can remember having to get my first bra aged 13 and I was mortified. I was quite happy playing football or cricket with the local bunch of lads as I was a tomboy and the appearance of small breasts marked a difference I really didn't want as it made me different. Mum took me to marks and spencer for a proper bra measurement as was the respectable practice and done thing. A nice older lady helped measure me and I knew it was seen as a milestone event. I found the new item of clothing to be less comfortable than just having a vest or T shirt on and to be honest I would have rather not bothered. As for my first period. I can still cringe with embarrassment and blush at the thought and memory. I started my period unexpectedly when I was 13 . I was away on holiday with my mum staying at a hotel in Bournemouth. When I realised I went to speak to my mum who was in conversation with a group of women in the lounge. I tried to whisper quietly what had happened and wanted to die on the spot when she loudly and proudly announced to the assembled knitting circle that I had started my period. They all made proud remarks about it. I was really embarrassed as I didn't want a load of strange people knowing in public. So she dragged me off to the nearest chemists and I was bought some really old fashioned and massive sanitary towels. The sort with big loops on that were really thick . My mum probably used them and in her day they were the thing . For that week of the holiday I had no choice as they were the solution but for me as a regular competitive swimmer in the pool almost every day they were not practical . The towels were also massive and less than discreet . I knew my friends used tampax so for the next period I got some myself bravely marching into Boots and buying them .My mum didn't want me to use them as she thought they could be bad for young girls. I think she had some odd idea that my virginity was in question using them but I was adamant i was not using the towels she gave me. This week in 2020 I see the Scottish government has announced free sanitary products for all . Good for them. I could never understand why they were always taxed why ?when 50 % of the population are female. Starting your periods is seen as a milestone and also raises the concept of pregnancy. My mum gave me a book about sexual education. It was handed over in an embarrassed fashion and I was invited to read it . It wasn't a big book and was very medical ,with biological instructions about how people breed. She wasn't comfortable having a conversation with me and to be fair neither was I. I cant remember ever talking about it with my Dad at all. School sex education was equally limited. We had THE class in biology and it was old fashioned medical descriptions about pregnancy . No real instructions about condoms or how to use them properly . The pill being mentioned as contraception and absolutely no discussion about sex being for any solely pleasurable reason. No mention of STD,s and absolutely no mention of same sex relations. So for me as a gay woman, a less than expansive educational experience. Amongst my female friends there was conversation about the topic and I think the lads had what would have been described then as dirty magazines but they were an illicit thing. Not like now where young people have so much internet porn access its scary. H7512 I have never,unlike many of my female friends ,dieted. I like my food and I have a sort of resistance to dieting to suit other peoples expectations. I don't like the problem of anorexia you see in society and see it as a slow way to kill yourself. People who are too thin worry me.So I have probably always been a bit heavier than ideal BMI weight but still strong active and able to do sports . Also working horrendous shifts for 32 years you end up eating crap at odd times and its hard to eat healthy at 3am sometimes. I have never liked going to the gym and hate the posing lycra gym bunny types. I have always enjoyed team sports and played football,squash then badminton until my knees started creaking too much .Now as I,m growing older I do exercise at home or go for a walk. I know that taking some exercise is good for me but I don't do that much . I have a variety of foods and try to eat plenty of fresh vegetables in my cooking. I would say now people generally are much more aware of being healthy and much more emphasis is given to it. In future years my expectations are that I will be less strong and will have to take more gentle exercise . As for how people relate to external appearance I can see that being fit ,thin and athletic,suntanned etc is popular . Across all types of media the modern image of women in particular is not something I like. The pouty selfies and lip fillers etc in my opinion look dreadful and it must be hard for young women coping with the perceived pressures of how to look. For me I have never been that bothered with fashions and decided a long time ago I will dress in a way I ,m comfortable with. So i,m usually in jeans,combat pants or walking type gear. I have never worn make up and I don't want to comply with the stereotype box of how a woman should look. I suppose in a way I don't care. Partly my sexuality has influenced that as Ive never felt comfortable being girly . My desert island item would be a hammock with a mosquito net attached as I get bitten to death by them and at least I could sleep at night and hopefully use my watching of Tv about Ray Mears or Bear Gryls would have given me the other skills to live my castaway life . In getting ready to leave the house rituals. My parents would have always made sure they were washed,hair brushed and clean clothes before leaving the house. Dad would have always shaved and applied aftershave like Old Spice or Brut…yes I know…how cliched but true. I am the same in that I would have a shower ,dry my hair ,apply deodorant and some perfume . Clean clothes always before leaving the house. My regime would be speedy though and practical. Especially when I was working I had perfected getting up at stupid o clock times and a whirlwind of throwing myself in the shower,dressed,coffee quick breakfast and out. WELLBEING. I think these days there is so much more knowledge about the importance of it and impact on our lives. Growing up it was the opposite. Perhaps peoples attitudes were more stoic and just got on with it or just didn't know. H7512 Particularly through my work I know the importance of wellbeing. I have lost count of how many suicides I have seen in any manner you can imagine. Grisly,nasty and tragic. I cant imagine ever feeling that bad and I feel really sorry for the family and friends left behind with guilt and unanswered questions. I have seen people who are just broken including,sadly ,several colleagues who have taken their own lives. I have always had a strong thought that I never want to be like that and want to take care of myself. Through work in 32 years the effect of stress is well known to me . I have operated in very high and sustained levels of it. I believe some stress is healthy and can drive you to perform but too much can have some very bad results. I have seen many people just burn out from it. Fortunately I am an emotional person and if something is wrong I have to deal wth it and get it out. I wear my heart on my sleeve. The downside to that is you care and you feel things deeply. The upside ,in my opinion, is that I process it in one way or another instead of bottling it up. I worked as a family liaison officer on homicides and natural disasters or accidents. Part of the role and training prepares you for the difficulties , it is a demanding and emotionally challenging role. We had a mandatory yearly counselling session as a welfare check as well as the opportunity to request counselling at any stage if we needed to. In my role investigating homicides we also had a system where some or all of the team would be automatically referred if it was a particularly bad case.This probably happened 6 or 7 times for me. I never felt overwhelmed or that I had problems with these cases,bad though they were as I saw it as my job. On 2 separate occasions I have felt overwhelmed and that I needed some counselling for trauma and they both involved the sudden,random and unexpected murder of 3 colleagues on duty. The first happened when I was 22 and resulted in 1 of my colleagues being shot dead and another very seriously injured but he survived. I was present in the immediate aftermath to help them and it was undoubtably traumatising. What I found hard was the realisation that someone could kill them and worse perhaps me. It made me feel generally unsafe going forward doing my job. I had some PTSD dealing with the sights and emotions of the night . Guilt that I couldn't save them,anger that it had happened and fear that it might happen again. I had some counselling sessions whilst still working and they were helpful but in hindsight I always had an unresolved fear and memory of the event for years after. Then it happened again 24 years later …totally out of the blue . This time 2 young female colleagues shot dead. I knew both to say hello to and was based at the same location. This time I wasn't present. I was actually on holiday in Devon and when I heard I drove back home to offer my help to the staff. This event just magnified my feelings from the first time and I sought counselling sessions again as it hit me really hard even though I wasn't present this time. It brought up all the same emotions . Attending both funerals was the worst experience and it hit us all really hard. About 300 staff based at the location and our shifts were very kindly covered by colleagues from all over the UK so we could attend the funerals. That was so nice of them. I had several counselling sessions and eventually I felt better. My stress inbox had reached its limit and needed help. I was not ashamed to admit it. I kept working the whole time and it was a bad and difficult period. I feel if I hadn't sought some help it would have been bad for me. Sadly a couple of years later one of our colleagues took his own life on the anniversary. He filled in his own death report and left it in his pocket. Tragic and awful in equal measure. When I retired a couple of years later I felt glad that I had done so relatively intact . I know so many people who drink heavily have multiple divorces and are damaged and a lot of it involves stress and lack of wellbeing. I had long planned a big retirement trip and I took the unusual option of taking a freighter ship from Hong Kong to New Zealand via China. 25 days at sea. It was the best thing ever. I read 9 books . My only responsibility was to attend meals and safety drills and the crew looked after me really well as their only passenger. I got the idea from watching Around the world in 80 days and researched how to arrange it. H7512 During the trip I let go of and deleted loads of thoughts,memories etc. I took it as an opportunity to let go. The end of a long hard working career and the start of my new life. It did me the world of good. Since retiring my wellbeing balance is in my opinion very good. I have very little stress now,only normal life admin things .I sleep and eat well at normal times . I have time to relax and do things I enjoy . I think in our modern lives things go so quickly and we are almost always connected there is no off switch and its a bad thing. Attaining a good work life balance is almost impossible .For women with families I think that challenge is even harder.Being a great mum and having a great career are often at odds and I have seen many female cops who did not complete a full career and concentrated their efforts on family but they were very capable in work . In the future I think the focus will change and I think they will look back and ask what the hell were you all doing to yourselves? it was too much…but that will take a long time I suspect. At 53 I feel Ive learned over the years that you need to look after yourself and you only live once . 30.11.20

Ethnicity Free Text: Dutch, English, Polish, Jewish and French.
Partners Occupation Free Text: Associate Director for commercial bank - works from home
Keywords: COVID-19 pandemic (2020-);Lifestyle, health and well-being;Family life;Family members;Adolescence;Emotional states;Mental health;Health services and medical care;Personal appearance;
Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing'. Mass-Observer P7500 describes themself as female; age 53; 'Student / unemployed former Retail Banking Assistant'.;The Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing' was issued on 27 November 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their opinions on and experiences of health and wellbeing, in particular 'health, wellbeing and the healthy body'; 'identity'; 'growing up and learning about health and wellbeing'; 'growing older'; 'health, wellbeing and appearance'; 'getting ready to leave the house'.
Contents: Autumn Directive 2020 P7500 Female Ross-on-Wye Student/unemployed former Retail Banking Assistant Part 2: Everyday Health and Wellbeing Health wellbeing and the healthy body Health means physically and mentally able to live a normal life. To be able to work, look after your family and enjoy recreation. It is maintaining this by making healthy choices. Keeping fit and eating a good diet. Since Covid it also means staying fit and well in difficult circumstances including social distancing. Well-being is how you feel about your life. It is acceptance, contentment, positivity, having a purpose in life. It is also preventative action such as enough sleep, healthy eating and exercising. Again, since the start of the pandemic, it means taking preventive measures against catching the virus. “A healthy body” – strong, slim, flexible, muscular, positive walk. The image of a person who is able to move without pain. Is smiling and positive to others. Clear skin, shiny hair. Good posture. Healthy weight for height. Dressed in clean clothes. Looks alert and interested in life. Identity I think gender has played a part in my experience of health and wellbeing because women read a lot more about healthy choices, as the physical attributes of a healthy body tend to involve weight, fitness, and diet. Also there are a number of press articles on healthy choices, alternative medicine and preventative action largely aimed at women. Attractive women are healthy women. I think social class has also influenced me as many places which promote healthy exercises (e.g. Gym, swimming pool) are expensive and so are not somewhere I could imagine myself going to regularly. Growing up and learning about health and well-being Health was something I became aware of whilst growing up by the things my mother taught me regarding healthy choices. I was also influenced by my father’s ill health; he suffered a serious heart attack when I was a child. I learnt about wellbeing as an adult – when I had reached burnout myself. Before receiving advice, I thought of well-being as a luxury. I now see it is something we all need to think about. P7500 My mother looked after my health. Conversations about health were generally about illness at the time of the illness e.g. what to do if you suffered a cold, stomach-ache etc. I do not remember any conversations about why. I think the conversations were about practical action. We did learn about puberty and some information about health in our biology lessons. Sometimes there were health education lessons. I have learnt a great deal from magazine articles, NHS website and the internet generally. Key moments My mother gave me a book about puberty. She never talked to me about bras or periods (or childbirth or the menopause). I felt embarrassed and it was not something to be spoken about. I am not sure about what specific rituals would be, it was not something I experienced. Growing older Due to past physical illnesses, I have tried to keep a healthy weight, eat a healthy diet, and get enough sleep. I think this has become more important during the pandemic. Mental health – I am in recovery from a mental illness. I sought help when thing got very difficult and received therapy privately for several years as there was very little short-term help available on the NHS. I was taught various ways to maintain good mental health which I regularly practise. Before seeking help, I did  not think there was anything I would be able to do to help myself. It changed the way I live. At present I get information from trusted medical internet sites and medical professionals. I am more aware of my physical and mental health now as I know how important it is to maintain good health all the time, not just when things go wrong. In future years I expect to slightly adjust my expectations as my body gets older but continue to maintain good health to the best of my ability. It is about living the best life you can. Health, wellbeing, and appearance I think the media encourage us to believe appearance, health and wellbeing are all interconnected in a particular way. This usually involving youthfulness and good looks. I think they are interconnected but  visible in expression, positivity, and curiosity rather than popular ideals of beauty. When I was in my 20s, I was influenced by popular ideals of beauty and worked hard to try to achieve a certain image. I believed looking ‘healthy’ would mean I was liked and popular. This was not about healthy eating, healthy exercise, or good mental health. The inner beauty this can give is far more important throughout life. P7500 My mother was always worried about my weight when I was a child. She was very slim all her life and ate very little. Even in her 90s she was worried about her hair and gaining weight. I do not think she ever stopped worrying about her appearance during her entire life. She read a lot of health magazines, but these were about looking good rather than a healthy lifestyle. Perhaps this was indicative of the times she grew up in (1920s), when women were valued almost entirely for their appearance. The only health product I couldn’t live without is my Fitbit. It ensures I am aware on a regular basis of exercise, sleep, and diet, which I find really useful. I would take it to a desert island with me, provided I could charge it! Getting ready to leave the house I particularly remember my mother leaving the house. She would always brush her hair and put on some more make-up. There was always a full length mirror in the hall so she could check her outfit before leaving the house. Even as an elderly lady she would always check in the mirror before leaving the house. My routine has changed over time. Before having children, I would do something similar to my mother. I would not be happy to leave the house without makeup and hair being right and having makeup etc in my handbag. After children I did not have time to check my appearance as much, there wasn’t time. I would only change into a different outfit if I was going out somewhere very nice. Since my children have left home, I am more likely to get changed and put on makeup again and check myself in the mirror. However, since the COVID 19 pandemic I hardly go out and the lack of socialising means again in my life I rarely bother with makeup or to change my outfit before leaving the house. When I look around me, I think I am not alone in this! I expect I will again become more careful about my appearance before leaving the house when the pandemic and social distancing ends.

Keywords: COVID-19 pandemic (2020-);Lifestyle, health and well-being;Partners (personal);Family life;Adolescence;Reproductive health;Emotional states;Personal appearance;
Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing'. Mass-Observer F7091 describes themself as female; age 68; married; retired professional librarian.;The Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing' was issued on 27 November 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their opinions on and experiences of health and wellbeing, in particular 'health, wellbeing and the healthy body'; 'identity'; 'growing up and learning about health and wellbeing'; 'growing older'; 'health, wellbeing and appearance'; 'getting ready to leave the house'.
Contents: F7091 Female Age 68 Married Brockley, London Retired professional librarian Health, wellbeing and the healthy body What does “health” mean to you? What does “wellbeing” mean to you? How do you define these words? Health means being fit enough to do all the things that I want to do – run, walk, gardening, going out, being comfortable in my own body at all times. Wellbeing is more of a mental state, accompanying health. What do you think about when you imagine “a healthy body”? Please share the first five words that come to your mind when you think of this term. Strong, slim, active, toned, blooming Is there a particular person or image that comes to mind? Please describe, or draw, this person. A female athlete like Serena Williams or Jessica Ennis Hill. Identity How do you think that your own experience of health and wellbeing has been influenced by your gender, ethnicity, social class, or sexual orientation? It has been influenced by social class in that I can afford to buy myself quality foods and access support networks such as masseurs, trainers to help me keep fit. Do you think your experience of health has been influenced by these or other aspects of your identity at all? I have been influenced by my husband in that he has always been a committed amateur athlete. Growing up and learning about health and wellbeing When and where did you first become aware of “health” or of “wellbeing”? In my twenties when I took up running. At the same time I read an article in the Guardian about animal welfare and decided to become a vegetarian which I remain. Wellbeing is a more recent construct. I tried meditating but could not settle to it. I have been doing yoga for twenty years. Who had responsibility for looking after your health and wellbeing when you were younger? My mother Do you remember your parents, or other caregivers, talking to you about health? No. I can remember my mother going on a diet – The Drinking Man’s Diet – when she was in her mid-thirties. If so, what did they talk to you about? Where did these conversations take place? There was much talk in the family about the diet as it impacted on our meals. Other than that there was no discussion of health or wellbeing. Did you receive any education about health in school? No And/or did you learn about health and wellbeing in other ways – from friends, magazines, or the internet, for example? Magazines of the day – Jackie – discussed skin, teeth, body odour etc Key moments As an adolescent, when did you first become aware of bodily changes associated with puberty? When I was eleven Are there any moments or rituals that you think are particularly important for young women or men? These might include, but are not limited to, first period, voice breaking, buying the first bra, or shaving, for example? For young women their first period. How did you feel about these moments if/when they happened to you? I was very frightened. My mother had warned me but it was worse than I had expected. None of my friends ever talked about it so I was clueless. I remember the paraphernalia surrounding periods was a real bind. Growing older Throughout your life, what if anything, have you done to actively maintain your health both physically and mentally? I have had a regular routine of running four or five times a week since I was in my mid-twenties. I did several marathons and triatholons. My most recent marathon was when I was 66. Before I had children I cycled to and from work every day and swam twice a week. I have been vegetarian for forty years. I now do yoga every day. Has this changed at all over the years? If so, was this due to a particular event in your life? Having children meant I curtailed some of my activities. I would say I am still as active but at not such a high level as in my twenties. I do set myself goals and enjoy that aspect of running. I am fortunate in that I still maintain the same healthy weight as I had as a young woman Where do you get information about health and wellbeing now? The Guardian and online. Would you say you are you more or less aware of your body now? Why do you think this is? More aware as I can feel I am slowing down. I am more anxious about falling over when running. In future years how do you expect your approach to health and wellbeing to change? Only in as much as my body might not let me do so much. Health, wellbeing and appearance In your view, how are health and wellbeing related to external appearance? There is a tendency to equate health and wellbeing with a certain body type, a certain agility of movement and demeanour. Have you ever been influenced by popular ideals of beauty or physical appearance? I don’t think so. Do you think your parents were influenced by these kinds of ideals? If so, in what way? Not at all. Are there any health or beauty products (excluding medicines) that you couldn’t live without? Lip balm which I make myself. What would be your Desert Island item? E45 cream. Getting ready to leave the house Do you remember your mother or father getting ready to go out for work, or for the evening? If so, can you describe their rituals? None come to mind and I have asked my siblings if they remember anything. Our parents never went out in the evening as far as we can recall. What is your own routine when getting ready to go out for work or for socialising? Has this routine changed over time? Keys, mobile – check. Front door – push against it to be sure it’s shut. Look back at the house from the street to check the windows are closed. Only became this security conscious after being burgled. Otherwise no other routines now that I am retired and have more time for things.

Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'COVID-19 (Update)'. Mass-Observer F7091 describes themself as female; age 68; married; retired professional librarian.;The Directive 'COVID-19 (Update)' was issued on 27 April 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their experiences of the COVID-19 pandemic, in particular 'health'; 'the government'; 'news'; 'work and home life'; 'technology'; 'shopping and food'; 'entertainment and leisure'; 'personal hygiene' and 'sleep'.
Contents: F7091 Female Age 68 Married Brockley, London Retired professional librarian Spring Directive Part 2: Covid19 (Update) Health Both D. and I believe we have had the virus. D.’s symptoms were more long-lasting than mine – I would say he has taken a month to recover and only now is saying his chest is no longer tight. I tried to get medical help for D. but the doctor’s number was always busy and we were advised to use NHS 111, which I did. I took their advice and it seemed effective. If anything I have felt better mentally and emotionally than I was expecting. I am enjoying the slower pace of life, and feel that while have I a garden and allotment and company of D. then all is well. I miss my daughters but have been able to see them at a distance when they deliver food. The Government I am totally exasperated by the Government as they seem utterly inept in comparison with Germany, New Zealand or even Scotland. I realise these are countries all led by women but they seem so much more competent and rational. We seem to be being softened up for a considerable relaxation of the lockdown rules to save the economy. I will not be following them unless I am convinced that they are right for me and D. as he is in the vulnerable category. News I am listening to the daily briefing via Radio 4’s PM programme. In the beginning I watched them live on TV, then switched to radio. I feel it is disrespectful to send out minor politicians to front up the briefings. They seem to b e completely out of their comfort zone and just mouthing platitudes. I have only seen Johnson do one since he returned from sick leave. We need a leader with gravitas and dignity. Sadly he has neither. The media, with a few exceptions, seems unable or unwilling to challenge the narrative that is being formulated from Number 10. I would feel much happier if Cummings and his entourage were removed totally from the seat of power but the waffle we are given at these briefings seems to come direct from them. I think that using BSL at these briefings is a good idea. I read the Guardian every day. I subscribe to the Politico daily emails and I have found them very useful. I look at Twitter less and less. Work and home life I am retired and my daughters do not live with me. My home life has not been impacted adversely. Technology I have been using Zoom to do my yoga and exercise classes, my bookgroups and family/friend meetups. I have found the experience very rewarding, especially with the yoga classes. I am doing three a week instead of my normal once. In my bookgroup the participant who normally tends to dominate the discussions has let everyone have a go and this is an improvement. Family ones have been a godsend. We have a quiz, a meal and some drinks for about two hours. We have done this twice so far. Houseparty – we used this at first but now I speak to my daughters on WhatsApp video call. I don’t use Facebook. I play Words with Friends 2 with my sister every afternoon and we then chatt for about half an hour .on WhatsApp. We did this before lockdown. Shopping and food In the first week of lockdown the handle broke on my oven and it is impossible to get a repair or replacement oven at the moment. So I found an old oven from when we went camping and am using that if absolutely necessary. It has meant I am not doing all the baking that others are doing. The shortage of flour (I make my own bread) has been a problem but I have now ordered a 16kg bag from a mill in the Cotswolds. I heard about the problems with flour on Farming Today and the millers national association has put a useful set of links to local millers on their website. I have only been shopping locally. I have not been to a supermarket since mid March. Our local Budgens has almost everything I need. We have been ordering alcohol from the local brewery who deliver the same day. I think prices have gone up but I accept that and am not spending my money on anything else. We are eating and cooking much the same as before – apart from not being able to use an oven. Entertainment and Leisure I have been watching much less television as has D. (no sport). I have been listening to much more radio. I am working my way through Neil MacGregor’s History of the World in 100 objects; listening to the Gresham lectures when I go for a walk; going through the Drama category on BBC Sounds and listening to one of those a day. Music – I am not a music lover but have been playing Bob Dylan’s Murder most Foul several times every day. I watch the live streamed National Theatre productions every Thursday evening. I was a regular theatregoer before the lockdown. I have continued to run every other day – I was due to do a 10K race this month but that has been put on hold so I just keep ticking over doing no more than 20 miles a week. I do yoga every morning – Yoga with Adrienne on YouTube and three days a week I do a Zoom session with my regular yoga teacher. I also do an exercise class once a week with my regular exercise teacher. Reading – I find it difficult to concentrate. I have read the books that my book groups are doing. I started the latest Hilary Mantell but finding it hard to read a complex, multi-layered book. I had a pile of books set aside to read when the lockdown started but not one has been touched. I do some crochet every day. I am making Twiddle Muffs for the elderly from odds and ends of wool that I have left over. Personal hygiene I am lucky in that my hair is completely grey so I’m not worried about my roots but I could really do with a hair cut. I may have to attack my fringe before very long. Apart from that my hygiene routines have not really changed. Sleep My sleep has surprisingly been better than normal. I usually have real trouble with insomnia but have hardly had any problems for the whole time. I wake early – 5 – put on the radio and listen until six when I get up. I go to bed at 10.

Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing'. Mass-Observer S6976 describes themself as female; age 45; single; stage manager.;The Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing' was issued on 27 November 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their opinions on and experiences of health and wellbeing, in particular 'health, wellbeing and the healthy body'; 'identity'; 'growing up and learning about health and wellbeing'; 'growing older'; 'health, wellbeing and appearance'; 'getting ready to leave the house'.
Contents: Part 2: Everyday health and wellbeing Health, wellbeing and the healthy body “Health” seems contrasted with “sickness”, whether that be physical or mental. “Wellbeing” seems more general, more of a sense of “all being well with the world”, although also maybe is connected with mental health. “A healthy body” brings to mind someone who is strong, fit, and robust. I don’t know who comes to mind when I think of a healthy body. Perhaps my friend S who is very keen on exercise. She does yoga, runs in 10k runs regularly and also volunteers for a scheme called “Good Gym”, where you run several miles to meet up with other volunteers, carry out a good deed, like doing shopping for an elderly person or clearing up leaves in a park, then you run home again. A really good idea. If only I enjoyed exercise... I really don’t get the endorphin rush which everyone talks about and I just end up feeling uncomfortable and overheated. Identity I’mnotaware ofmy healthand wellbeing being affected by gender, class,sexuality orethnicity. Growing up and learning about health and wellbeing I don’t know when I first became aware of health and wellbeing. I don’t think of it as being very prominent as I was growing up, although my mum always struggled with her weight, as does my sister, so there were always low-fat versions of food around, or “Slimfast” products.  My mum doesn’t enjoy cooking someals would be quite simple. I rememberher nagging my grandparents a lot about eating too much fried food, and she even went round and confiscated their frying pan on one occasion! So she certainly had an awareness of health, even ifI’m not aware of her doing proper nutritional balancing of ingredients or anything.  My dad has honey and cider vinegar every morning and believes it is good for a lot of ailments. I have just remembered that they used to buy health supplements from a company called Shaklee quite regularly – I think perhaps some friends of theirs were salespeople for the company. I suppose my first awareness of health would be through my grandparents –apart from the fried food, my grandad had a number of heart attacks and was a smoker, and my grandma had a stroke, so these would have been the first people I knew who had serious health problems. I’m sure my parents must have a healthier lifestyle than my grandparents did. Awareness is much better now. Key moments For girls, the key moments suggested – buying a bra and the first period – spring to mind as significant. I have a vague memory of being in a changing cubicle with my mum when buying a bra, but don’t remember any conversations about the subject. I expect we would both have found it embarrassing. To teach me “the facts of life” I was given an Usborne book called something like “How YourBody Works” – Usborne books were (are?) excellent at explaining all kinds of subjects clearly and accessibly, and of course it avoided us having to have a conversation about it!  My mum asked if I had any questions after I’d read it and I said no.   When I got my first period I think I struggled by myself for a while, going to the corner shop to buy sanitary towels etc, before finally justleaving a note on my mum’s bedside table to tell her (and again, to avoid an embarrassing conversation).  After that, she bought sanitary towels for me.   Female, 45, single, Walthamstow, stage manager Growing older I have been vegetarian since I was 9, although this was motivated by animal welfare concerns rather than by health considerations. I feel likeI’mvery mainstreamnowthatvegandiets have come to such prominence, but when I first went vegetarian there were very few choices when it came to prepared food and eating out in cafes or restaurants. My mum is not a great home cook so I ate a lot of microwaved veggie lasagnes when I was growing up. Nowadays I do not have a microwave and eat very few processed meals (perhaps a microwave meal during a busy week at work occasionally, but it’s possible to get much healthieroptions now). Iamconscious of eating healthily but itis also what I naturally like. I don’t have a particularly sweet tooth so it is quite easy to avoid too much of those things. I usually have oats with almond milk, chia seeds and a banana for breakfast, and other regular meals include rice noodles with veg, or a stew made with root veg, lentils, pearl barley, tinned tomatoes and various spices. Very easy but also healthy and cheap. There is an excellent cheap veg market near me where I get all my fresh food, and also a vegan “refill shop” has opened this year, where I get all my dry goods and discover new products.   I used to drink regularly and probably too much because theatre is a very sociable profession, but I more or less gave up nearly two years ago. I just wasn’t enjoying it as much and would often get a headache after one or two drinks so there didn't seem any point in having any. I have tried many non-alcoholic alternatives and now buy a range of alcohol-free beers from an online company called Dry Drinker or sometimes I will just have tonic with a dash of angostura bitters – delicious! I was more aware of drinking being an unhealthy habit as I got older, and it was easy to stop once I’d made the decision.   I am probably more aware of my body now, but also more relaxed about it and happier with it. I used to be bothered by the fact that I didn't have a flat stomach, even though I am a fairly “normal” weight, and I would try to do exercises for this, but now I accept that that will never happen. People have different natural shapes and that is still not publicised, in spite of backlashes from time to time against the beauty industry. I think it’s irresponsible of magazine articles orinstructors onfitness videos to say things like “do this and you’ll have aflat stomach in six weeks” whenactuallythat may be beyondsomeone’s capability,depending ontheir body shape and metabolism. Now I can accept my body shape and just choose clothes to suit it. I expectasI get older I will carry ondoing what I’mdoing with diet etc, and itwill become even more important. As I said earlier, I dislike exercise so that is one thing I could do to be healthier. Perhaps as I get older I will be more aware of being active and at least go out for walks quite regularly. I do have a deep fear of health problems and how serious things can arise with no symptoms, even in people who live a so-called healthy life. I try to put these things out of my mind but I imagine this fear could get worse as I get older.   Health, wellbeing and appearance People can perhaps feel more confident if they know they are well-presented or if they are wearing a flattering item of clothing. Perhaps if someone has got into a rut, a change of hairstyle or wardrobe can give them a boost, but there has to be some change under the surface as well. I don’t think I am at all influenced by popular ideals of beauty and appearance. I don’t read beauty magazines and actually get quite riled if I do see one of these magazines which just has endless pages of beauty products or expensive fashion items. I think people waste so much money on products and procedures which aren’t necessary – colouring their hair, having nails done, pricey skincare products. I do not have a Desert Island beauty item! The only products in my bathroom are shampoo, aqueous cream washing bar (soap equivalent for eczema), toothpaste, and Aveeno moisturiser. Perhaps this partly comes from my upbringing, although I just don’t think it’s in my character to prioritise things like that. My sister is slightly gothic and wears a bit of eyeliner and also experiments with different hair colours (currently purple!). My mum and aunty never wear makeup or perfume and nor did my grandma. My grandma always used to say “Nice faces don’t need makeup”. My mum is the least vain person I can think of and I wouldn’t say she was influenced by beauty ideals at all, but she did dye her hair for a long time. I’m not sure when she actually started going grey, because for as longas I can remember she always used a wash-in brown dye which she did at home. She only stopped doing that a few years ago (she is now 80). On the other hand, I have started going grey and have no intention of starting to dye my hair. Once you start, how do you ever stop? And it wouldn’t feel that I was being “authentic” if I did that. I think more women should be open about the colour of their hair, otherwise nobody thinks that it’s normal to start finding grey hairs in your 20s/30s/40s, which it is. After all the hairdressers closed down earlier this year there was a backlash against hair dye but I fear that it won’t last and people will go back to dyeing their hair very soon, if they haven’t already. Getting ready to leave the house My dad worked as a plasterer so the time he left for work would vary depending on where he had to drive to. He wore work trousers and jacket, work shirt and boots and didn't have a particular routine in the morning, but when he got home he would always wash his hands with Swarfega – there was always a pot of this green gel by the sink and the smell of it is one of the pervading scents of my childhood. He also had a shower every evening rather than in the morning, and got changed into corduroy/moleskin trousers, a checked shirt and a jumper.   My parents often went out in the evening but didn't have a particular routine. They didn't usually go somewhere which involved getting dressed up so once they had eaten their evening meal at 6pm they would be ready to go out if they were just going to a folk club or a ceilidh. My mum sings in a choir so if she was performing in a concert that would involve putting on smarter clothes – a blouse and a long skirt – and perhaps going as far as to put some lipstick on! (This is the only occasion I can think of her using any sort of makeup.) Female, 45, single, Walthamstow, stage manager I don’t have a complicated routine for getting ready for work or to go out – just get dressed, have breakfast and go. I prefer to have a shower in the evenings so I can let my hair dry naturally rather than faffing with wet hair in the mornings, so it doesn’t take me long to get ready.

Religion Free Text: Christian, but I am not baptised and I don't go to church. I prefer to have a direct relationship with God. Vicars just get in the way.
Living Arrangement Free Text: I've lived with my husband for 14 years. We lived together virtually from the start. We have always lived in [REDACTED] which is a tiny rural hamlet, population 60. From the age of 19 to 29 I lived with my first boyfriend, including all but my first year of university, which now strikes me as crazy young but we were very in love and his parents had just split up and he had no family home.
Relationship Status Free Text: Married 2010. I met my husband at work.
Occupation 2020 Free Text: Carers Wellbeing Officer for a small charity, currently working home from due to pandemic, providing phone based emotional support and guidance to unpaid family carers
Current Occupation Free Text: Carers Wellbeing Officer for a small charity, currently working home from due to pandemic, providing phone based emotional support and guidance to unpaid family carers
Partners Occupation Free Text: Head of Partnerships in the Strategy team at a large teaching hospital

Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing'. Mass-Observer C5847 describes themself as 'I am 43, married, no kids ... work 3 days a week for a charity'.;The Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing' was issued on 27 November 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their opinions on and experiences of health and wellbeing, in particular 'health, wellbeing and the healthy body'; 'identity'; 'growing up and learning about health and wellbeing'; 'growing older'; 'health, wellbeing and appearance'; 'getting ready to leave the house'.
Contents: MOA Autumn Directive 2020 Part 2 – Everyday health and wellbeing To me ‘health’ means a functioning, relatively painless body that stands a good chance of achieving the average human life expectancy.  ‘Wellbeing’ is a bit more nebulous and possibly more performative. Look at me on Instagram drinking 2 litres of water a day. When I imagine a healthy body I imagine someone who is a healthy weight, has no skin lesions, a full head of hair, is smiling and is standing upright. I guess Claudia Winkleman? I can’t think when I first heard the word “healthy” -I suppose as a child it was “Eat this, it is good for you.” My parents were very attentive and put a lot of effort into me, giving me a good home cooked diet and taking me for walks and bike rides. Unfortunately I ended up quite plump as a child – for the time, which was the 1980s. I was always . My parents had both been skinny children and were not especially sympathetic. When I was 8, my class teacher said to me “H-----, you are too fat!” As he was virtually spherical himself, this seemed rich. I can just imagine the furore if a teacher said that to a child per now.  One of my information books contained a height and weight chart which I used to look at in horror as I was way over what it claimed I ought to be. Among today’s children, I would be relatively thin – I look back at photos of myself and don’t know what I was worrying about. As described in the first part of this directive I did not go through a normal puberty due to a condition called XX gonadal dysgenesis. When everyone else began developing, I managed to persuade my mum to buy me a 32AA bra that I wouldn’t actually need for several years! Finally diagnosed, I went on HRT when I was 17 and had my first “period” a month later. I found it messy and uncomfortable and still do. Growing older A year ago I was taken to hospital with a suspected TIA and that was the first time I really realised that one day, something in my body will go wrong and kill me. I expressed this thought to my younger sister and she replied “Don’t worry! You don’t look anything near your age!” but that wasn’t the point I was making. I have never been reckless with my health, or anything else really. I’ve never done drugs, and I’ve had fewer than 50 cigarettes in my life. I spent my 30s drinking half a bottle of wine a might but then introduced one dry night a week which is now two or three nights, and my example has persuaded my husband to do the same. I eat plenty of fruit and veg, I don’t have a sweet tooth and my weight hovers round the top end of normal BMI. I have never liked exercise though. I don’t go to the gym or do anything that makes me out of breath. I won the class running race at 5 because I was a head taller than anyone else, but that was the pinnacle of my sporting career. I’ve never had much aerobic capacity. That said, I walk fast, and I walk the dog twice every day. When I turned 40 I started going to vinyasa flow yoga which is hard work, and did that diligently until covid struck. I have done one such class since March 2020 and was so out of shape that I felt like I was wearing a suit of armour. I don’t have the discipline to do it at home with a YouTube video. I worry a lot about my health in future years because I work with family carers, so I have a skewed view of what level of health people can be expect to be in when they’re older. I have to specifically remind myself that not every 76 year old has dementia and two knee replacements. I worry about MOA C5847. I am 43, married, no kids, live rurally in Leics and work 3 days a week for a charity. getting rheumatoid arthritis, which my mum suffers with, as I don’t have much of a pain threshold. My husband calls me “flimsy”. Last time I went for routine bloods, a year ago, I was almost pre-diabetic, which seemed mightily unfair as I have a normal BMI and don’t eat much sugar. Covid means they are not doing routine blood tests at the moment so I have no idea of my current blood sugar level. I am cross about my teeth too.  I only have one filling but it has caused me a lot of gyp and will probably need crowning. At the moment I can’t chew much on that side. My oral hygiene has always been at least silver, so again it seems unfair. For all that the government doles out health advice I think it’s largely the luck of the draw, genetic destiny. We lost my dad unexpectedly earlier this year to a cardiac arrest which shouldn’t have happened. He was only 66, still working, gave up smoking at 38 and was in good health. He had prawn sandwiches for Sunday lunch then basically died on the sofa. OK he was rather fond of processed meat and whiskey, but I see men who are much older, fatter and l than him and they are still walking (waddling) around. It is not fair.  Health is the modern day Puritanism – you may not worry about the state of your immortal soul but you sure as hell worry about your body fat percentage. I used to work with a woman who, along with her husband, was obsessed with the body beautiful. It was quite tragic really, they were so vain, in the gym at 6:30 every day and very controlled with food – although she’d sometimes go mad and eat an entire cheesecake in one go. She is a size 8-10 at most. She once found her husband crying over his reflection because he didn’t look as good as he used to, and once she dieted before going on holiday because she didn’t want to look fat in a bikini next to her son’s girlfriend. If you’re 55 and trying to look as good as a 25 year old you have a problem. My cousin is a recovering alcoholic who found the gym two years ago and seems to be smaller and tighter every time I see her. It has done great things for her mental health. I’m not anti-exericse, I just don’t like it myself. Health, wellbeing and appearance When people say they want to be healthy what they often mean is that they want to look thin in photos. We all know models smoke to suppress their appetite. Of course I have been influenced by popular ideals of beauty, that is inevitable in any culture. However I think I am more inclined than most to decide what looks good to me and dress to that aesthetic. I like to look like a rag doll, or a Tim Burton creation, so I have found the shops and manufacturers that work for that – I would never go to Next or Zara. I hate the outfits I see in magazines. I don’t know anybody else who looks like me. I have a great interest in skincare, it is a hobby really, as the leaning towers of beauty boxes by my bed will attest. I love buying toiletries and I’m knowledgeable, it’s a shame I can’t turn it into a career. If I stopped buying products tomorrow I would literally be okay for 3 or 4 years – sometimes it is a race to use things up before they go off. I have worn make up on and off since I was 8. I used to race to the school library to get to “The Usborne Guide to Make Up and Beauty”, I’d kill for a copy now. I had awful skin in my 20s, really bad acne (this was before I got into skincare) for which full coverage foundation was a lifesaver: I wouldn’t have even walked to the papershop without covering up my spots. Unfortunately, my make up is now again to conceal as much as enhance. Objectively I have great skin but also dark MOA C5847. I am 43, married, no kids, live rurally in Leics and work 3 days a week for a charity. circles, hooded eyelids, invisible eyebrows and the beginning of barcode lines on my upper lip (yet again I will use the word “unfair” as I shouldn’t have barcode lines when I don’t smoke!) I find it quite interesting that my husband, while nobly pretending not to mind either way, prefers how I look with a lot of make up on. (I don’t mean Ru Paul’s drag race, I mean “office” make up as opposed to “Sunday” make up. This has not been the case with previous partners. Getting ready to leave the house is infinitely variable in terms of make-up and clothes. Some days I look lovely and some days I look like Worzel Gummidge. The non-variables are that I will shower, wash my hair, clean my teeth, moisturise my face and body, and use deodorant. My mum, who considers anything more than a quick strip wash immorally self-indulgent, is bemused that my husband and I never ever skip a morning shower, and is aghast that I use body lotion every day or as she puts it “go through this rigmarole”! I would never go camping as I would feel gross all day if I wasn’t properly clean. MOA C5847. I am 43, married, no kids, live rurally in Leics and work 3 days a week for a charity.

Sexuality Free Text: I'm not asexual in the sense that I'm not sexually attracted to people, I just find the idea of sex so daunting I'd prefer not to. I don't know if that's a sexuality or more of a sexual preference though.
Disability Free Text: I have bipolar affective disorder, which was only diagnosed in my mid-30s but which was strongly suspected for a while before that. I'm not sure I count it as a disability, it is how I am. I can see that others might see it as a disability though - I function, but not always especially well and my life is a lot more difficult and unhappy than it would be if I didn't have the disorder. Personally, I think of it more as a madness or a lunacy than a disability or a mental disorder; I think that's a more accurate way of characterising it. (As far as I can tell though, my manic/depressive cycles don't follow the lunar cycle. So I'm not an actual lunatic, sadly.)
Living Arrangement Free Text: My house has a blue front door.
Occupation 2020 Free Text: I work part time for a very small charity which works to reduce the risk of sexual offending and sexual harm. My job title is 'researcher', which means I'm responsible for writing and updating the training programmes we deliver, and supporting the  people and organisations we work with in dealing with practical questions around policy, the law, academic knowledge and whatever. Because we're so small though, I also look after the finances, manage the IT, do odd bits of legal compliance as they crop up, and generally pick up around the place. So it's a portfolio job, I guess. I do it 3 days a week for little enough money that I don't need to make student loan repayments, which is enough for me to live on. I used to work two jobs, so it's nice to have time - I prefer that to having the money. I also do freelance statistical work and teaching, but not in any organised sort of a way.
