Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing'. Mass-Observer J5734 describes themself as male; age 35; single; 'charity worker (p/t)'.;The Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing' was issued on 27 November 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their opinions on and experiences of health and wellbeing, in particular 'health, wellbeing and the healthy body'; 'identity'; 'growing up and learning about health and wellbeing'; 'growing older'; 'health, wellbeing and appearance'; 'getting ready to leave the house'.
Contents: MO#: J5734 Sex: Male Age: 35 Marital Status: Single Where I live: Newcastle-upon-Tyne Occupation: Charity worker (p/t) Mass Observation Archive: Autumn 2020 Directive Part 2: Everyday health and well-being Health, wellbeing and the healthy body What does “health” mean to you? What does “wellbeing” mean to you? How do you define these words? What do you think about when you imagine “a healthy body”? Please share the first five words that come to your mind when you think of this term. Is there a particular person or image that comes to mind? Please describe, or draw, this person. ‘Health’is an absence of illness, ‘well-being’ takes into account your circumstances. So I can be healthy, but if I’m in a stressful job, or lack material resources, or am not respected, then my well­being is suffering. I think there’s a slightly forced nature to the terminology though -‘well-being’ is something which we talk about in normal discourse but which isn’t normally defined. We can have meaningful conversations about it (“I am concerned for their well-being”) without the term ever being specified. The recent ‘well-being agenda’, particularly as expressed statistically (by the ONS, OECD, Eurostat, various think-tanks and charities, and by academics) is a political manipulation of language. It takes this vague but common term and specifies it in ways which serve those wielding the term but very few others. ‘Well-being’ is one of those terms which itis almost impossible to oppose –so when ‘well-being as defined’ becomes ‘well-being’, it becomes impossible to protest the definition without appearing to protest the concept. The same is true of ‘health’ but to a lesser extent, partly because the discourses around ‘health’, and so the fixedness of its definition, is more established. That can partly be seen in the fact we don’t really have antonyms for either term. Ruskin had ‘illth’, which encompassed things like pollution or materialism – the things which capitalism foists on us for its own survival –and had a vague moral sense. It’s harder to fill out ‘ill-being’ though – and if we’re not sure what that means, then I don’t think we can be confident that we really have any grasp on what its opposite means. A healthy body is one free of illness and impairment. That’s going to take any number of shapes – from the taught muscles of yoga practitioners through soft comfortableness of people who are active but not overly concerned about social norms of ‘beauty’. Having said that, one of the first words that came to mind when you said ‘healthy body’ was “celery”, so clearly I lean towards the ascetic rather than the comfortable. Identity How do you think that your own experience of health and wellbeing has been influenced by your gender, ethnicity, social class, or sexual orientation? Do you think your experience of health has been influenced by these or other aspects of your identity at all? J5734 I definitely hold in my head ideas about the way I am ‘meant to’ look. I’ve always run to skinny, and used to run regularly to maintain that. Now I use a gym, partly to keep my body within the dimensions I’m used to, and partly now to build muscle. I’m slightly embarrassed by that, but what definition I have gained has made me a little more secure in my own skin. I’m still pretty puny, but I feel a bit more ‘normally’ shaped. I think that might be a gender thing – the guys on the cover of ‘Men’s Health’were always svelte and muscular (and not at all unlike the ones on the covers of gay magazines), shot in sexy starkly lit black and white. Everyone knows the Hollywood trope of the ‘ugly’ girl taking off her glasses and letting her hair down to be transformed into the ‘beautiful’ girl at the end of the film – but there’s a corresponding trope that even the nerdy men fall within a range ofmuscularity. That’s not, in any way, to compare the masculine pressures around body shape or beauty to those of women – there is a difference of many degrees between the two –but it is something which I’ve always been conscious of. I’m not so sure aboutethnicity, social class or sexual orientation. I think given my positions on those – white, middle class, cis and mainly straight –I’m allowed a wide range of possibilities within that broad hierarchy of bodies. Growing up and learning about health and wellbeing When and where did you first become aware of “health” or of “wellbeing”? Who had responsibility for looking after your health and wellbeing when you were younger? Do you remember your parents, or other caregivers, talking to you about health? If so, what did they talk to you about? Where did these conversations take place? Did you receive any education about health in school? And/or did you learn about health and wellbeing in other ways – from friends, magazines, or the internet, for example? My mum always made us eat fresh veg and salad. Carrots for our eyes, lettuce because it was good for us, that sort of thing. That was a normalised thing, we never really questioned it (there’d be no point in questioning it anyway, we’d still have to eat it), and so by the time I was feeding myself it was just common sense. I don’t think there was anything in school, maybe something vague in science. As a teenager, I wanted to take Home Economics as a GCSE, but my school didn’t offer it and my efforts to do it on my own petered out quite quickly. I can’t really remember why I wanted to do it(apart from an argument with the school over an additional GCSE I was taking), beyond thinking it was probably an important set of life skills. Health more broadly wasn’t really a subject we discussed. We had to be properly ill to get a day off school – generally the sense was we should power through and stop being such a wimp about things. It’s taken me years to get that out of my system and to take days off when I’m ill, and I still don’t feel comfortable about it. I will have done so much poor work and infected so many people over the years because of that. There wasn’t really any pressure on us to be physically active either. We weren’t really allowed junk food, so it wasn’t like we had weightpiling on us anyway. I was always pretty bad at PE because my co-ordination wasn’t great and I wasn’t getting the practice of running around in my spare time. Doing sportdidn’t really interest me, and nor did watching it until I was much older. I did develop an eating disorder when I was a teenager, but I think that was more a result of my J5734 mental health generally than anything to do with my body image. (I stopped eating because eating made me feel nauseous. It wasn’t a conscious thing, I don’t think, I certainly wasn’t trying to control my weight.) I’ve always taken  daily vitamin supplements since then, just to make sure I’m getting enough of everything. Key moments As an adolescent, when did you first become aware of bodily changes associated with puberty? Are there any moments or rituals that you think are particularly important for young women or men? These might include, but are not limited to, first period, voice breaking, buying the first bra, or shaving, for example? How did you feel about these moments if/when they happened to you? I don’t know when I first became aware. I did start shaving quite early, because my dad had a load of the kits they used to give him flying business class, and because I found the fluffy early facial hair quite unattractive. I’ve never really had bad acne, although even in my 30s I still have bad enough skin thatI regularly get spots. I’ve tried doing things about that over the years, but nothing has ever really worked (or maybe I’m not actually worried enough that the cleansing regime has seemed worth the  time commitment). I do remember the first time I was embarrassed about my body in public – me and some friends had been playing a ball game topless when we were about 12 or 13 and a group of girls walked past. It was too late at that point, but I put my shirt back on to make me feel less exposed. I wouldn’t even sunbathe in my own garden topless now –I’d still feel very vulnerable. There are situations in public when I become aware that I don’t have an attractive body –I’m not unattractive, but I’m nowhere near the ideal. I feel uncomfortable around attractive people for that reason, which is ridiculous. Growing older Throughout your life, what if anything, have you done to actively maintain your health both physically and mentally? Has this changed at all over the years? If so, was this due to a particular event in your life? Where do you get information about health and wellbeing now? Would you say you are you more or less aware of your body now? Why do you think this is? In future years how do you expect your approach to health and wellbeing to change? I used a gym as a teenager, I think as a means of trying to achieve a more ‘normal’ body – less rangy, less puny. It didn’t really work, I don’t think – potentially a metabolism thing, potentially a lack of protein thing, probably a not really knowing what I was doing thing. I was always never really working towards that sort of hyper-muscled body, I always thought people like that looked a bit freakish, and were a bit sad for having devoted so much time to something superficial. So probably I was going at things half-arsed Intermittently I’ve run. I did that when I was a uni studentthe first time – university felt very structured around appearance. In hindsight, I’m not sure who I thought I was impressing, but I suppose I was hoping that there would be someone. Later I ran with a group to make friends, and stopped as soon as I moved away. I never enjoyed running, and I think by now it’s probably messed up my knees, but it felt like something I should be doing. Returning to the gym as an adult was largely about burning off excess energy – I was doing it for my mental health rather than anything else. I think that mental health has benefited from the changes in my physique now. I have a set of tattoos I got when I moved to my new house, because J5734 the mirror on the bathroom cabinet was opposite the shower, and I had to see myself every morning. Having the tattoos gave me something better to look at than my body. I’m a lot more comfortable with that reflection now though – it still looks pretty puny by most standards, but it seems a bit more human-looking. Now the gyms are shut again for another COVID lockdown, I’m doing yoga every day. That doesn’t really feel like exercise, but does feel like I’m at least making an effort and not letting myself slide completely. I’m still careful about getting my vitamins –that’s partly because I’m a vegan, and want to make sure I’m not losing anything. Now I’m using the gym, I’m also taking a protein supplement to make the gym a bit less purposeless. I think this is probably something I’ll keep doing for the rest of my life. I don’t want to end up with a beer gut, or struggling to walk up the hill to my house. It’s not anything excessive –I’m not going to start running marathons or getting into competitive sport – but is more a maintenance of the sort of body I’m used to having. Health, wellbeing and appearance In your view, how are health and wellbeing related to external appearance? Have you ever been influenced by popular ideals of beauty or physical appearance? Do you think your parents were influenced by these kinds of ideals? If so, in what way? Are there any health or beauty products (excluding medicines) that you couldn’t live without? What would be your Desert Island item? I think the relation between health and wellbeing and appearance is probably quite loose. At the extremes – obese, anorectic or bulimic, hyper-muscular bodies; the over and dried-out sun-tanned – unhealth can be read from the appearance, but most people fall in a range of ‘good enough’, hiding whatever else they’re doing (the lung cancer, the sclerotic arteries, the gin-soaked liver, or whatever). I’m not sure what my parents thought abouttheir bodies –I’m not really sure I ever saw them as having that sort of internal life. (Like, it’s obvious that your parents are thoughtful and caring individuals, but it doesn’t really occur to you as a child thatthey think or care about similar things to you. Their mental life is alien and largely unreflected on, I think.) My dad now walks his 10,000 steps a day, largely as part of a calorie control against the beer that he drinks, so he’s clearly concerned about his physical condition. That, I think, is probably to do with his fear of age and mortality, which seems reasonable. I don’t think there are any health or beauty products I could do without. I use face masks, but that’s more about taking 20 minutes out of my week to not do anything than the skincare benefits. (Which would be nice, but at this point in my life I’ve sort of given up on the idea that my skin will be anything other than occasionally eruptive.) I think if you’re stuck on a desert island, skincare is probably the least of your worries. At that point, maybe, a yoga mat, just to give me a flat surface to exercise on. Getting ready to leave the house Do you remember your mother or father getting ready to go out for work, or for the evening? If so, can you describe their rituals? What is your own routine when getting ready to go out for work or for socialising? Has this routine changed over time? J5734 My mum worked at home, and my dad worked away a lot, so I don’t really remember them going out much. When I worked in an office or in university teaching, I always wore a shirt – I think I thought it made me look more ‘professional’-and often glasses to make myself look ‘clever’. My current job is a lot more informal, and now we’re working at home in the middle of winter, I’ve got to the point where I’ll do Zoom calls while wearing a blanket. Beyond that, I don’t think there’s anything special I do – I think if I were going out for a meal I might dress up, but only if there was a risk I couldn’t get in dressed normally. I’ve reached the pointin my life where I’ll wear trainers with a suit and only keep a pair of shoes for funerals. I have a set of clothes I feel comfortable in (primarily jeans, slightly baggy t-shirts and hoodies), and I wear them for all occasions.

Keywords: COVID-19 pandemic (2020-);Lifestyle, health and well-being;Society and social behaviour;Gender inequality;Family life;Emotional states;Schools;Reproductive health;Personal appearance;Family members;Personal hygiene;Employment and occupations;
Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing'. Mass-Observer W5975 describes themself as female; age 35; married; admissions officer.;The Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing' was issued on 27 November 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their opinions on and experiences of health and wellbeing, in particular 'health, wellbeing and the healthy body'; 'identity'; 'growing up and learning about health and wellbeing'; 'growing older'; 'health, wellbeing and appearance'; 'getting ready to leave the house'.
Contents: W5975 Female, 45 Married Cambridge Admissions Officer Autumn Directive 2020  Part 2 Everyday health and wellbeing  Health means feeling well, no illness, no aches.  Wellbeing includes good mental health, healthy weight good sleep. Healthy body – slim, fit, good mental health  I think of how I looked 10 years ago and of slim celebrities.  Identity Gender – as female sexual harassment, attacked aged 12, have to be careful where you walk and when and how you dress. Patronised by Lib Dems.  White so not experienced racism. Working class – looked down on by Tories.  Cheaper to get crisps, cake, and biscuits than 6 pack of apples at £3.  Alcoholic violet father – looked down on by EVERYONE. Frightened a lot. Health – female pain treated less than male pain.  On prescriptions now for monthly pain W5975 Female, 45 Married Cambridge Admissions Officer Growing up and hearing about health and wellbeing  School – Health and safety modules, first aid, sports leaders award, gymnastics Mum (NOT Dad). Learned about sex and periods in school. Also books. No internet really when I was at school. Key moments Aged 10 when started periods. Awful pain.  Got put on pill 15-35 years of age. Do not remember first bra. Probably more comfortable with than not. Growing older Ran half marathon when 40 (2 hours 46). Run 5 and 10K races for Subway and Town/Gown. Had long hair cut off to make wigs for kids with cancer. Try and lose weight.  Give blood as rare blood group B RH neg and it is used for babies. Read books and internet a lot. More aware as more aches and body cracks when get up! Will try and maintain activity and weight and brain activity. Heath well-being and appearance I think you feel better if you are a healthy weight and try and look after skin and hair. I am 5ft 2 and not fashionable.  Often wish had a flatter stomach. Models do not even look like that as they airbrush them. No Dad drank heavily and smoked (ex squaddie) Mum just tried to keep us safe and fed. I think my desert island would have to be hairbrush as my hair is half way down my back and preferably some nice shampoo. W5975 Female, 45 Married Cambridge Admissions Officer Getting ready to leave house Dad would get into security officer gear and take pack up.  Often he would take our Alsatian Lady on patrol – people think twice before attacking if there is a dog. Mum did cleaning/cloakroom work to help finances. I have to pack up my office, get my laptop, headset, lunch, phone and earphones and catch the bus to the new temporary office 13 miles away. I put my hair up. I do not use makeup for work but sometimes paint nails. I always carry a first aid kit and antihistamines.

Keywords: COVID-19 Pandemic (2020-);COVID-19--restrictions--lockdown;Employment and occupations;COVID-19--working from home;Personal appearance;Money and finance;Shopping and retail;Partners (personal);Leisure time and social activities;Family members;Communication;Health services and medical care;COVID-19--key workers;
Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'COVID-19 and Time'. Mass-Observer W5975 describes themself as female; married; admissions officer.;The Directive 'COVID-19 and Time' was issued on 7 August 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their experiences of the COVID-19 pandemic and lockdown in relation to the 'rhythm and routine of the day'; 'home life'; use of 'media and technology'; their experiences of 'waiting'.
Contents: Cambridge  Admissions Officer Part 1. Covid 19 and time March to August I was working on the bed apart from one day a week when I went into the office to collect and process the post.   In August I took an extended DSE (Desktop assessment) and was given permission to return full time.   I explained that MDW was also teaching from home, with video and there was no more space for another desk and chair that I was having to take meetings and calls in the bathroom, for security and privacy, since the students could hear me, and that my back was hurting.   The boss made it clear the other 3 officers and 5 assistants should continue to work from home, and that I had to jump through a lot of hoops to return.  At the start I was shopping once a fortnight in gloves and mask; this changed to once a week.  MDW did not go into a shop till about September. I did not always take the daily exercise since by the river, where we live was very busy.  Homelife I had never worked at home before lockdown. The VPN was a pain, and much slower working on one screen rather than the business need which is 2. There was no clear airlock between work and home. Normally the 25 minute walk back with music, is my chill out time.  I did take my full hour break, rather than working through as usual, since I was preparing a mid day meal for MDW.  As we live in a studio flat, it is quite cramped.  I bought a special, very heavy bag, to store my work stuff at home.  The summer was when we could not go out, our friends from Sweden had to cancel their visit, once I was back the weather turned.  Lots of rain.  Very cold.  Married Cambridge Admissions Officer Now I am back to work, I carry all my folders on my back and have to carry the laptop in my hand. There are 38 steep stairs to my office, the lift is out of order. The heating is turned off as apparently this does not meet covid requirements so very cold in the office.  I have been wearing 2 cardigans and a scarf - but still better than working at home. I am up and down the stairs all the time. The cafe nearby, Area, is open so I mask up to get my takeaway lunch - a hot chocolate with plant milk, and a grilled mozzarella, tomato and basil sandwich on brown bread. MDW is my priority - he had first dibs on the workspace as teachers always do a lot of work at home even in normal times, prepping lessons and marking. His school is in the top 1% of the top 1%.   My office meets 3 x a week on Skype, no video to check in on workload and everyone.  However we chat throughout the day for work related matters on pop up Skype messages.  Appraisals, which I administered to TC and PA for the first time, and my own were done on Skype meetings.  The same is true for 121s.  We MUST have 4 a year though pre covid it was once a month.  As my line managees are part time I do theirs every 6 weeks.  Homelife  When I was working at home for 5 months I logged in at 9, and took full lunch break 1-2. Then finished work 5-5.30 and started tea. I did do less laundry, as we went out less and I could wear an outfit for more than 1 day, as I have a new outfit every day at work.  This is just as well as when I went to the bank for change for the laundrette, I was in the queue for 2 hours.  I was not impressed.  Even now the only bank open on a Saturday will not give out change.  26 years a customer and they refuse change which I know they have.When the shutdown first happened there were a lot of shortages - could not get flour, eggs, pasta or toilet rolls.  Even when supermarkets put restrictions on them.  TC brought me eggs and flour in exchange for an Ipad cover.  This must have been what it was like at the start of WW2 before rationing.  I spent ages going to shop to shop for items.  Married Cambridge Admissions Officer At least TC meant I could bake my own cake in May. We have not saved money as instead of being able to borrow library books every week I bought them from Ebay and Amazon. Also other things we could not get in the shops.  Mealtimes are mostly set by me but also to fit with lessons breaks for MDW. We only had a couple of arguments.  Luckily we get on well so much - many of our friends are divorced. I read and he games or we watch Netflix or Amazon Prime. Our favourite restaurant near work has closed forever. They did amazing steaks for him and salmon for me.  My brother in law, nephew and niece all lost their jobs.  The latter 2 are young and have got some work now.  Our best man, who has a high flying job, was unemployed for 10 months.  Media and technology Yes.  Skype meetings only for work.  Have not seen the majority of my colleagues since March and those that came in for IT since August were for 10 minutes.  So weird not to hug them.  PKA was fed up so I posted nail varnish set to her for her birthday. VPN log in when WAH. Online medical appointments do not work for things that need to be looked at e.g. cancer, injuries.Also I pay for flu jabs and cannot get one for love or money. Shopping online OK for Iceland but not for other shops - cannot get slots/prefer to shop in person/do not like their substitutions.  I always use a paper diary, I made more notes from calls, I use notepads to log the books I read, and I have a gratitude diary.  I am not a fan of working at home - I get that if you travel a lot to work, it is a big saving on time, and petrol.  But I walk.  I am also the first aider and deputy evacuation controller.  On the first day in August I was called to a collapsed female.  She only needed to go home, as it was faint.  But if I had not been in, work would have called 999 - as they would not take a chance.   Most of my call outs involve ambulances, or A and E/GP visits.  Cambridge  Admissions Officer It is rare only a plaster or Icepack is needed. Waiting  Yes - very much so.  Not seen mother in law since last Christmas - we would normally have seen her at least 2 or 3 times and taken her to the coast.  We afraid in case we take the virus to her. Saw my mother twice - short train journey away.  But not my 5 year old nephew whose party was just Mum and Dad. MDW has been to the pub a few times with a workmate - I am too afraid to join them.  We are waiting to see if we will go to tier 2, as the students have had parties/not distancing and are up to 180 cases per 100, 000.  Before term started it was 43. Waiting for a virus vaccine. Waiting, always waiting. Delays in getting drs and hospital appointment. NM is in hospital - do not think she would be if had been seen in time.  I need some painkillers but such a pain to get through and then get phone call back.  There were huge queues for Tesco at the start BUT they had a second queue for keyworkers, which I am and have the card, so got in sooner.  The bank - horrendous queues.

Keywords: COVID-19 pandemic (2020-);Lifestyle, health and well-being;Mental health;Family life;Family members;Schools;Adolescence;Older people;Personal appearance;Reproductive health;
Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing'. Mass-Observer B5725 describes themself as female; age 60; married; 'retired FE lecturer, now Co-Director of archaeology company, family and local historian'.;The Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing' was issued on 27 November 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their opinions on and experiences of health and wellbeing, in particular 'health, wellbeing and the healthy body'; 'identity'; 'growing up and learning about health and wellbeing'; 'growing older'; 'health, wellbeing and appearance'; 'getting ready to leave the house'.
Contents: Autumn Directive 2020 MO number: B5725 Female aged 60, married, living in Chester, retired FE lecturer, now Co-Director of archaeology company, family and local historian Part 2: When I think of the word ‘health’, a vision of being free from physical illness, disease or injury initially comes to mind. However, after 2020, I am even more aware of the importance of mental health. So many people have struggled with mental health issues during 2020, particularly during periods of lockdown. I hope this will highlight to the government the need to invest more in NHS mental health services. The word ‘wellbeing’ seems to encompass both physical and mental health and one’s ability to lead a contented life. ‘A healthy body’ conjures up the image of not just a body free of disease but a strong and physically fit physique. The first five words which comes to mind to describe a healthy body are: muscular, toned, powerful, fit, disease-free. These words make me think of the children’s PE guru Joe Wicks. My parents had responsibility for looking after my health and wellbeing when I was young. This was done in a perfunctory manner and certainly didn’t cover feelings or mental health. I suspect I picked up most information from the wide range of books I read as a child. The only information about health given at school was a series of three sex education lessons at the age of 13. I was left pretty much none the wiser afterwards. I went to an all girls’ school and we were taught about the reproduction of rabbits and then told the same applied to humans! I received a book for Christmas from my parents about growing up and sex when I was 13. I read this in private and absorbed the information, but there were no conversations about it with anyone. Puberty was not discussed with my parents, so I just accepted it and got on with it. I have always tried to actively maintain my mental and physical health via yoga, Pilates and frequent walks. I suspect this is why I am told I don’t look my age. I am a healthy weight and physically very mobile, although not an athlete. I would say I am just as aware of my body as ever. My parents were physically fit when they were younger and often played tennis as adults. However, now at 88, they are not physically strong, having not maintained their fitness levels during their middle or later lives. They don’t understand why my husband and I enjoy long walks in the outdoors and think we are wasting our time. I’m struggling to think of a health or beauty product that I couldn’t live without. I guess, because I suffer from very dry skin, it would have to be a heavy-duty moisturiser. As for getting ready to go out for work, I do remember my parents’ routines. My father would get up and cook himself bacon and egg at 7pm. (If anyone else wanted a cooked breakfast, they had to make it themselves). He would follow this with toast and marmalade which would be so liberally applied, the marmalade would ooze out onto the plate. Radio 4 would be on the radio and my father would have his head buried in the newspaper (usually the Telegraph). My mother, who was a teacher and not a morning person, would surface around 8.15 am, drink a strong coffee, smoke a cigarette, then speed off to work in the car in a foul mood. She was so grumpy in the mornings that my brother and I were not allowed and did not dare speak to her. My parents rarely went out in the evenings but when they did (for formal dinners or dinner dances) my mother locked herself in the bathroom for an inordinately long time beforehand and invariably emerged in a glamorous ballgown, high heels and plenty of makeup.  My routine for going to work or socialising is taking a shower, choosing comfortable and appropriate clothing and putting on makeup if I remember. I have never owned a ballroom gown and have no desire for one.

Disability Free Text: Degenerative bone calcification in both feet due to Osteoarthritis - now walk with a stick as balance is  precarious. ME/Chronic Fatigue 20+ years. High functioning so not bed bound nor need a wheel chair.
Living Arrangement Free Text: Our only child, aged 21, has returned to live at home after taking a break from university studies due to Pandemic.
Partners Occupation Free Text: Consultant legal draughting lawyer for government department
Other Adult Occupation Free Text: part-time library assistant at local public library

Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing'. Mass-Observer G6209 describes themself as female; age 57; married; 'Access to Art & Design Student / Homemaker - former Magazine Advertisement Production Manager'.;The Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing' was issued on 27 November 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their opinions on and experiences of health and wellbeing, in particular 'health, wellbeing and the healthy body'; 'identity'; 'growing up and learning about health and wellbeing'; 'growing older'; 'health, wellbeing and appearance'; 'getting ready to leave the house'.
Contents: Part 2: Everyday Health and Wellbeing The challenges of COVID-19 mean that in recent months, there has been a lot of reflection on health and wellbeing in unprecedented circumstances. But what about health and wellbeing in everyday life? We learn about health in many different ways, and it can mean different things to different people depending on their circumstances. In this Directive, we want to find out what health and wellbeing means to you (and what it meant before COVID-19) but particularly where your ideas about health and wellbeing came from, and what has influenced your own experiences of health and wellbeing in everyday life. Health, wellbeing and the healthy body What does “health” mean to you? What does “wellbeing” mean to you? How do you define these words? Health – your body being in the best physical and mental shape it can be according to your personal circumstances – assisted by whatever intervention is necessary to achieve that eg medication, aids, therapies or support network. Wellbeing – treating yourself as well as possible within your financial constraints – nutritionally, physically and mentally What do you think about when you imagine “a healthy body”? Please share the first five words that come to your mind when you think of this term. Body type, ethnicity, age, life-style, maintenance, accepting Is there a particular person or image that comes to mind? Please describe, or draw, this person. Gaby Logan (Yorath) springs to mind. I realised she is possibly fine-tuned by a team to look presentable on screen but she always looks radiant, clean and bright with a great haircut well presented. Nor does she look starving and deranged like she spends her life trying to keep up her image and appearance with countless preachy fitness videos. Naturally attractive with no signs of plastic surgery or other surgical intervention. It’s possible that in reality she might have to put in a lot of effort to maintain her look. Identity How do you think that your own experience of health and wellbeing has been influenced by your gender, ethnicity, social class, or sexual orientation? I continue to be astounded that medical charts such as the BMI chart illustrate the expectations based on one racial and body type. I have never been a waif and in my youth, I competed in 100m for my school and played on the netball team. Different ethnicities come in a variety of body shapes and sizes eg afro-Caribbean women, like myself, tend to have quite shapely bottoms a Caucasian woman the same height and weight as me is likely to look a completely different shape from me. One health professional presumed that I must consume large quantities of rich and oily Caribbean food and suggested I “control my portions” better and, of course, do more exercise. She certainly looked more “stout” than me I barely managed to hold my tongue. Do you think your experience of health has been influenced by these or other aspects of your identity at all? Yes, most of my siblings and lots of their children are diabetic. It is a condition that is rampant in Afro-Caribbean and Asian cultures and is quite often hereditary. I am probably the heaviest person in my family and became diabetic in my 40’s whereas my x2 string-bean, former nurse sister’s became diabetic in their 20’s. One profile certainly does not fit all. My eventual diagnosis with diabetes was probably pre­determined and starving myself was never going to prevent it or make it disappear. At a local level (I live in an area with a negligible non-Caucasian community) my diabetic health professionals stick rigidly to the generic guidelines. This is not the case for other family members living in more ethnic diverse areas. Growing up and learning about health and wellbeing When and where did you first become aware of “health” or of “wellbeing”? My father was a diabetic as far back as I can remember and three of my siblings were nurses. We were aware of healthy eating and living from an early age and played outdoors lots. We grew all our own fruit and vegetables – as my parents also did in Jamacia. There was usually a minimum of 8 of us living at home so our diet was heavily plant biased. Both of my parents were factory workers so we did not have a huge income to buy treats such as sweets, crisps and pop we knew that these were only for treats like Bank Holidays, or when other children were visiting, as they were not good for people with ‘sugar diabetes’ in the family. We did not have a car so walked everywhere. We knew we were living a pretty healthy lifestyle and didn’t question it. Who had responsibility for looking after your health and wellbeing when you were younger? My parents and older siblings – there’s about an 18­year age gap between me and my eldest sibling. Do you remember your parents, or other caregivers, talking to you about health? If so, what did they talk to you about? Where did these conversations take place? Not very often. Mostly on feasting occasions when there might be treats eg Christmas with chocolates and sweets around. Warnings about diabetes and danger of over indulgence. These talks would take place at home when the goodies were being handed out. Did you receive any education about health in school? I remember primary school lessons about food groups, drawing plates of food in portion sizes, drinking milk advice, eating up our school dinners etc In Biology at senior school lessons on vitamins and nutrition and video on health and hygiene and sexual health. And/or did you learn about health and wellbeing in other ways – from friends, magazines, or the internet, for example? Jackie and Cosmopolitan magazines shared in groups at school – spots and breath freshening advice in preparation for kissing. Key moments As an adolescent, when did you first become aware of bodily changes associated with puberty? I’d already started getting pubic hair in year 6 at Primary School so I knew that changes were afoot. Started my periods at about 12. I first registered I had breasts when I was walking across ‘The Gap’ between the girls’ school and the boys’ school across the lane one lunchtime in my netball kit. I heard a boy shout “cor look at her tits” I looked around and there was no-one else in the lane but me. I looked down and there they were. I think they must have manifested over-night. I implored my mum to take me to buy and bra that weekend. Are there any moments or rituals that you think are particularly important for young women or men? These might include, but are not limited to, first period, voice breaking, buying the first bra, or shaving, for example? First period. Exciting information to share with friends – comparing notes etc as is modelling of first bra. How did you feel about these moments if/when they happened to you? My younger sister is almost one year younger than me we shared a bedroom until I left home at 19 and are very close. She had her first period the week after me and my mother bought us both our first bra on the same shopping trip. Identical but different colours (mine was a slightly larger cup though). I felt cheated and devastated at both of these. Yet another thing I had to share with my little sister! Growing older Throughout your life, what if anything, have you done to actively maintain your health both physically and mentally? Shopped for, cooked and eaten good quality food. Do no drive so I have always done a lot of walking. Gave up smoking but continued drinking – in moderation. Enjoyed myself and lived a busy varied social life and kept good close friends. I was prescribed anti-depressants when I had depression after my father died unexpectedly. I also welcomed the opportunity to have counselling and CBT which was very helpful and came off the anti­depressants after about a year. Has this changed at all over the years? If so, was this due to a particular event in your life? Continue to buy the best quality food I can afford. Have taken and adjusted accordingly health supplements over the years. I have had bouts of anaemia so sometimes have to take extra iron which can be hard on the guts. I became very anaemic at the time I needed a hysterectomy. After my surgery I went into full medical menopause and have had to use HRT patches since then – I was having hot flushes every 30 minutes 24/7 and was exhausted and felt terribly ill. I tried to reduce the strength of patches and the flushes returned almost immediately. I continue to wear the patches as this holds them at bay and keeps my sanity. Where do you get information about health and wellbeing now? NHS Choices on the internet. Would you say you are you more or less aware of your body now? Why do you think this is? More aware of my body now. This is because there have been significant physical changes with age. I now have osteoarthritis in my both hands and both feet which are now all mis-shaped and constantly painful – which I am now accustomed to. I am waiting for a series of steroid injections in my right foot and potential surgery for my left and I now walk with a stick since my balance is so precarious and I am not able to walk great distances and now have a Disabled Blue Badge. The important thing is that none of this is life-threatening it’s annoying. In future years how do you expect your approach to health and wellbeing to change? Not much different. I have some of my consultations with health professionals on-line via video-calls. I hope that I can occasionally see someone in real-life. I think that demonstrating flexibility of limbs online doesn’t always present a full picture. Health, wellbeing and appearance In your view, how are health and wellbeing related to external appearance? I tend to shuffle more when I am in a lot of discomfort. I always try to dress smartly and try to walk with purpose and confidence when I go out and am beyond being embarrassed about my stick. When parking in a Disabled parking bay there is nearly always someone who ‘tuts’ as they assume only wheel chair users can use these spaces. This either makes me feel livid or embarrassed depending on my mood and the volume of the ‘tut’. I always insist we park in the bay furthest from the entrance/exit to wherever we are headed. Have you ever been influenced by popular ideals of beauty or physical appearance? Nope. Do you think your parents were influenced by these kinds of ideals? If so, in what way? My parents were always very well turned out. They felt it was equally important that we were dressed smartly and cleanly in public. As Ethnic minorities they did not want Caucasian people to be able to find any fault with us or any reason to be hostile ie to be able to call us dirty and slovenly. Are there any health or beauty products (excluding medicines) that you couldn’t live without? Aldi Lacura day Q10 Day Cream. Palmers Fragrance Free Body Lotion. What would be your Desert Island item? Palmers Fragrance Free Body Lotion. Getting ready to leave the house Do you remember your mother or father getting ready to go out for work, or for the evening? If so, can you describe their rituals? Mum getting ready for work – headscarf tied under the chin, looking in the lounge mirror and putting on lipstick usually and aubergine/brownish shade from Avon. Popped her lipstick in the bag. Does up the clasp with a click then out the door for her lift-share to work. Dad getting ready for work -jacket on, polish of glasses put them on then popping on his flat cap. Work bag over his head and across his body off out the door for his lift outside the front of the house. What is your own routine when getting ready to go out for work or for socialising? Has this routine changed over time? Taking for ever to decide what to wear. Go downstairs. Decide which shoes are likely to be the most comfortable to wear that day. Change over any insoles as necessary. Gather bag. Pack spare disposable mask. Check Disabled parking bag is in the bag. Take glasses off and position mask adjusting nose wire for comfort and elastic around ears. Glasses back on. Glasses back on and demist as many times as necessary. Head out the door. Back in the door. Collect walking stick. Back out of the door and start journey.

Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing'. Mass-Observer M5645 describes themself as female; age 47; married; 'Library Assistant & Writer. Also currently staff at Community Hub'.;The Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing' was issued on 27 November 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their opinions on and experiences of health and wellbeing, in particular 'health, wellbeing and the healthy body'; 'identity'; 'growing up and learning about health and wellbeing'; 'growing older'; 'health, wellbeing and appearance'; 'getting ready to leave the house'.
Contents: MO number: M5645 Sex: Female Autumn 2020 Age: 47 Marital status: Married Location: Largs Everyday Health Occupation: Library Assistant & Writer. Also currently staff at and Wellbeing Community Hub Health, wellbeing and the healthy body Health means to me the status of being fit and well, or possibly of moving toward that. Wellbeing means to me more esoteric striving towards contentment, quelling of anxiety, prioritising things which are good for the soul or the spirit. A healthy body: . Fit . Young . Able . Thin . Regimented. The person that comes to mind when I think of a healthy body is a sort of aryan, smiling person, white skinned and blonde haired and with no extra flesh, no strangeness, perhaps no personality. The sort of person who would be a cheerleader in an American film. Kind of vacuous but smiling, always smiling, with bouncing hair. If it was a man they’d be gay and muscular, the woman would be adoring, either of them would go out with someone called Brad or Chad or something. Identity My experience of health and wellbeing has been influenced by my identity. I was a fat kid and am a fat adult. This was always blamed on some deficiency, rather than a natural aspect of my gene expression (which seems more likely, looking at my family). I would be belittled in PE class and started skiving off to avoid it at middle school (around age 12). Any part of showing my body made me fair game for bullies. When I was a kid I used to love cycling and do it a lot. People don’t get time to comment on your body as you whizz past them. More recently bikes fall apart when I try to ride them. I’m 17 stone or thereabouts. There are plenty of people who are my weight, and we’re told we should be exercising, so why aren’t bikes and exercise machines built to take our weight? Anyway, I was very unhappy as a teen and lost a lot of weight, also becoming a goth. So far as I could see, goths didn’t exercise (although later I had a boyfriend who was a skater goth, which was weird!). A couple of years ago I joined a local gym. I was so scared to go that it had taken me that many years to join. I was terrified to go in, but glad that I did because nobody mentioned a thing, it was fine. As for wellbeing, my dad was a buddhist, so I came across meditation early, although I found it quite dull. I myself was a pagan as a young adult and so didmeditation with others. I enjoyed it, but I won’t generally put myself forward for anything I feel like others will be looking at me and judging me at. Growing up and learning about health and wellbeing I remember my parents had a book of exercises -Canadian airforce I think, I did those when I was really hating on my body, and lots of running on the spot in my bedroom. Earlier my mother gave me a keep fit album for my tenth Christmas, which was kinda crap of her. We had gone to a lodgers keep fit classes before that, but that was to support her, rather than health. Wellbeing I think I learned about from conversations at the buddhist commune my dad took us to. I don’t remember ourparents talking to us about health or wellbeing, although I do remember my mother praising my brother for wanting to keep fit by playing tennis with his friends. Key moments I remember a girl at middle school getting boobs ahead of everyone else and everyone talking about her, how the showers were supervised by a teacher who pointed out armpit hair and the like. I did not want my body to be subject to the gaze of others. My first period started when I was off school with tummy ache. I now suspect my mother must have known, I knew when my daughter was going to start. I remember the humiliation of starting when I was wearing the wrong day of the week pants. I told my mother and she told the neighbour and I was mortified. I remember my dad wouldn’t buy me pads and only sluts used tampons according to what people said in my school. My dad said that men didn’t buy things like that. One time I started at his house and my brother said he’d go because my dad wouldn’t.I remember a boy at middle school’s voice breaking while he was doing the assembly and everyone laughing at him. I went with my mum to buy my first bra, I don’t remember it being a big deal, but I took one to my dad’s house to wear for school and it caused me to come out in an itchy rash. Obviously I couldn’t talk to dad about it, but I talkedto mum when I was back at her house and we had to change our detergent, I’m not sure why it caused such a reaction though -something the shop had coated it with or just me being stressed? I remember my mum making a big fuss about my brother shaving. Actually she was passing remarks to my fifteen year old son last time we saw her, saying he should shave. I feel I’m a lotlessjudgey than my mum, although I judge her for being judgemental. My son doesn’t need to shave if he doesn’t want to, and he doesn’t want to.Other people’s mother’s have told my daughter that she should shave her oxters! I found that stunning, and told them to back the fuck off, and they laughed and said that all that feminist nonsense wasn’t suitable for young girls. What the actual fuck? My daughter didn’t want to shave her oxters before that point. Now she does. I feel she’s been worn down by daft bitches.Health, wellbeing and appearance Health and wellbeing might be somewhat related to external appearance, although I know you can be fitand fat, it’s bloody hard to be. That said, being unfit seems to be a stick to beat people with in our society and that to me seems ableist, and classist. Have I been influenced by popular ideals of beauty or physical appearance? Of course! I live in this society. I spend my life fighting against these ideals and failing. I dislike myself vehemently for not conforming to these ideals even while I say the ideals are nonsense. I have a friend with multiple disabilities who fell down the stairs and did herself many harms. Now she has a massive scar seaming her face, as well as being fat and having an electric wheelchair. The first time I saw her I felt scared, which isn’t fair, but we all internalise these associations of ugliness and evil.She gets prescribedmakeup to cover the scar, that’s how important beauty isto our society. But to be honest, her only child has grown and left home now, if I was in her shoes I think I would have killed myself. It’s a terrible thing to admit, but I don’t think I could get through the days.My parents are of course influenced by these ideals too. My mother doesn’teat carbs until she’shad a few drinks, in an effort to stay slim.It works. She goes on holiday and tops up her tan. That works too. My dad, whenever he speaks of a woman, starts off by telling me whether he finds her attractive or not. Last time I spoke to him he was talking about Olivia Colman. He doesn’tfind her attractive. I told him I don’t think she cares what he thinks, but I guess it constantly being the first thing has made me really consider it. I would hate to not have access to makeup and hairdye. I tried to stop dying my hair when lockdown started, and managed for months, all my dye faded and my hair was a drab beigy grey. It was so nice when I got given some purple dye from a friend to colour it. I guess if I was on a desert island I could live without dying my hair, and without many other things, but I would like to keep a good eyeliner. Getting ready to leave the house My mother would put her hair up before she went to work, twisting it up into a chignon and putting a comb in to keep it in place. If she was going out she’d put on a bit of lippy and some eyeshadow. She wasn’t very good at it, she hardly ever wore / wears makeup. My dad would put on his jacket, check he’sgot his keys and walk out. If I’m going to work I’ll make sure my hair is not too frizzy, sometimes I put it up,tonight I’m going to wash it ready for work tomorrow. I will wear BB cream, eyeliner, sometimes some eyeshadow and always earrings. I usually do my eyebrows too, so that they better match my hair. I do the same kind of thing if I’m going out. Although I hardly ever go out. If I’mdoing a poetry reading I get my nails done with shellac beforehand, something dark. I make sure my hair is good and definitely wear makeup. I have certain clothes which are my poet clothes -they’re more expensive and more voluminous. It’s freaking terrifying being on stage in the first seconds, I find it easier if I get into a fabulous poet character. This hasn’t changed much. When I was younger I would wear more makeup, especially in my teens when I was depressed, I wouldn’t leavethe house withoutlots of makeup and a fabulous dress.

Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'COVID-19 (Update)'. Mass-Observer M5645 describes themself as woman; age 46; married; 'Library Assistant (libraries currently closed) & Writer. Currently staff at Community Hub'.;The Directive 'COVID-19 (Update)' was issued on 27 April 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their experiences of the COVID-19 pandemic, in particular 'health'; 'the government'; 'news'; 'work and home life'; 'technology'; 'shopping and food'; 'entertainment and leisure'; 'personal hygiene' and 'sleep'.
Contents: MO number: M5645 Gender: Woman Spring 2020 Age: 46 Marital status: Married Location: Largs Covid19 (Update) Occupation: Library Assistant (libraries currently closed) & Writer. Currently staff at Community Hub. Health Physical We’ve had runny noses, I’m finally beginning to think I must have some sensitivity to pollen because what else could it be? It’s not going away. I’ve always put it down to spring colds before. My daughter seemed to get a sickness bug, although where from I don’t know. She is general quite anxious, and I wondered if that played into it, particularly as it came at the beginning of the new term (of homeschool) which is always a difficult time for her. Mental I had a period of feeling pretty down when the lockdown started. I was dismayed at being so powerless in the face of things, and feeling like my employer wasn’t concerned about my safety. I had a little while of not wanting to get out of bed, but a neighbour noticed and made me up a care package and reached out to me, really sweetly, and that made me feel like people did care. I talked to people at work about how I was feeling and that helped too -nothing much changed, but it was good to know that other people were feeling similarly powerless and just doing what they could, and also my colleague pointed out things that I did well and that really helped. Me speaking up about how I was feeling ended up leading to a workplace where we all spoke up. It’s been weird. I’m not working with any of my former colleagues, although I’m in the same place. I miss the regular library stuff! All the kids have periods of anxiety (especially my youngest (9) who has developed a morbid fear of dying and is often needing a lot of extra support. We have all been grumpy sometimes, and we’ve all found ways of carving out our own space. Often for us that means going on screens, and I think that’s OK. I’m a bit worried about my husband who has been very angry lately. He had a month during which he couldn’t work, and he really stepped up to help the kids with their schoolwork. He did great, although he does have a tendency to micromanage! Anyway, last week he finally got his secure computer set up so he can work, and he’s really fed up about it. I don’t think it seems to him like there’s much point in anything he can do, mainly because he can’t do much while he’s at home. I can hear his frustration in his very loud phone calls, and he keeps on shouting at inanimate objects, and at us. He is sleeping badly, but he often sleeps badly, usually of course, we all get a break from each other. The Government To be honest, I thought that the herd immunity thing was quite sensible. I had an argument with a friend about it. She has health issues, and she felt like the Tories were just trying to kill off the sick and the old. I might have agreed with her that they’d be happy to have a bunch of sick people killed off, but it’s the old people that vote for them! Anyway, I could understand the decision to delay lockdown, and it has resulted in more deaths, but I can’t see that the deaths are going to stop when lockdown ends, we just need to keep them as low as possible, and keep working on treatments and hopefully immunisation. What will they do next? I think there’s an app in the offing that will trace who we come in contact with. Obviously there are lots of people who will feel that that breaches their liberty and lots of people who don’t have the tech savvy to use an app. I see there are loads of jobs associated with this, but I don’t know what they’ll look like yet. I think things will open up but in a different way. So much is going to be different. I hope that the government will no longer be able to rest so much on capitalism, which is failing all of us. I hope that they continue giving people decent financial help and that this leads to a universal basic income, also I hope that the way we work will change so more people can be based at home. In the next year or so I imagine there will be a lot of change, distressing change, I can’t imagine how schools are going to work with social distancing, I guess we will find new normals, and I guess like with a baby that everytime we think we’ve got it it’ll change again. We’re kind of used to things always changing at work now. I hope the libraries open up again. Hopefully we’ll have to live like this for a year or so and then we’ll find a vaccine. Hopefully the governments will not follow this avenue they seem to be latching on to of blaming people, and will take the opportunity to make massive changes to improve our society for everyone. It’s a shame there’s a Tory government, but that’s what we’ve got. News I’m getting my news through what Google feels the need to tell me, what I’m told through my work, Simple Politics on Instagram, and I check the Scottish stats daily on an article in The Courier (which is for the East of Scotland, but the stats cover the whole country). I use that article because it’s updated daily and is very clear about what could be improved about the stats. I haven’t watched daily Government briefings at 5pm. I thought the daily briefings were at 2pm? I have no problem with access to the news, except there is too much of it, I’ve stopped listening to podcasts on the coronavirus, it just stresses me out and there’s no point in that. You mentioned a petition for a sign language interpreter. It is beyond my ken why the English government wouldn’t have such a simple thing, but they do seem to be biased against people who aren’t rich white men so that might explain that. I’m sorry, but the English government doesn’t seem especially relevant to me. Hopefully the elections will go ahead as planned and we will be able to move on with independence. Work and home life The library has obviously closed to the public. One of my colleagues was in the process of leaving to go somewhere else, but she had been waiting on a start date, now she’s just been sent home and told to take her stuff. I guess I won’t work with her again. Another colleague has asthma. I was at work with her when we all got told to immediately report if we had any health conditions. I didn’t. She was having to fill out forms about her health. I’ve not seen or heard from her since. I guess she’s at home. Since the library closed it re-opened, although not to the public. It’s now a community hub. People call us if they need help with anything during the coronavirus ‘situation’, and we do various things to help out. We get a lot of random nonsense calls, which we’ve always had at the library. People basically asking us to google things for them. As library staff I’ve always just done that. That’s part of what we’re for. However now we have more phone lines and more staff. I’m not working with any of my old colleagues, but more senior staff from across the council who do stuff around communities and schools. If they answer the phone to one of the old dears asking something random they tell them to google it and then laugh at them when they’ve put the phone down. I guess that helps them look after each other, and they’re not used to public facing roles. I’m used to just doing eye rolls to the wall, lol. A lot of what we do is helping people who are poor or self-isolating and so have trouble getting access to food or medicines. Here in Largs we have lots of wonderful volunteers, who are actually organised by Miss 9’s teacher, who has really stepped up in the situation. If someone needs some shopping picked up, or some medicine getting we pass their details on to the volunteer coordinators who get it sorted out. We’ve managed to arrange fresh food deliveries to the island of Cumbrae with the help of a minister and the ferry people (not the company, the people), we’ve made sure that all the people who got free school meals now get at least the equivalent in food delivered. We also have free food deliveries for people who are self isolating, shielding (that’s when they have a condition which means their doctor says they should stay at home and not go out for three months), or who are struggling. We have a mini food bank too, so that we can get emergency supplies to people while they’re waiting for other things to get into place. Yesterday I helped a family with four kids to get sorted for regular supplies and got them an emergency drop of provisions including nappies. I’m also using the counselling training I did many years ago when I worked at a university, helping people to calm down and feel listened to. Lots of people are just scared and overwhelmed. At home we’re homeschooling. The big kids are pretty good at getting on with it. This morning they’re particularly motivated as it’s the last day of S1 & S3 for them. Miss 12 is just doing the last check ins with teachers now. She started early this morning to get schoolwork done. Mr 14 is already getting a ramping up of work, but this is his last day of doing languages, and he’s delighted about that! Miss 9 needs a lot of attention and is feeling pretty rubbish about school work. She’s very clingy and is sitting next to me now. She’s on BBC Bitesize now because I was getting really annoyed with her, and I love how the BBC have gameified learning so she doesn’t really feel she’s doing work. This morning she’s done art, hairdressing (on me), and checked in with her teachers. She’s also found out how to extract DNA from strawberries (thanks Glasgow Science Centre)! We haven’t had much contact with friends, mostly, although K--has been chatting with his friends a lot, us not so much. Me and the kids are all hanging out (quietly) together. Technology I’ve learned to use Zoom lately -I used it a lot early on in the lockdown for the Stay at Home Literary Festival. We had a few trolls, but it was mostly fine (although one of the poets got upset because of some racist trolling). Usually at work I’d do writing workshops and the like so I’ve been trying to do those online, in keeping with the rules I have to follow for work, which are annoying. I’ve done one of these just as a video to the computer camera, and others I’ve used iMovie, which has involved lots of going to and fro between my computer and work’s really annoying ipad, which is not up to date and I’m not allowed to update. I swear, sometimes the security rules make things so much worse. I’ve also (for work) being doing iDEA training courses, which are incredibly boring. K-- has been using Zoom to talk to his family a lot. I find it somewhat tedious. They are nice enough but I don’t get the in jokes. I’ve been using WhatsApp video calls to speak to my siblings, especially since my brother’s job was under threat. That has been nice. You get to really speak to them, connect better. I do feel like a teenager though! I’ve been using Instagram quite a lot (and Facebook and Twitter too, but mostly Insta). During April I shared a poem a day. I’ve stepped back from that a bit now. I think I need to stop being so outward looking. Shopping and Food. We haven’t tried to buy groceries online because there’s a big waiting list and there are so many people who actually need to do online shops. You have to factor in a lot of time for a shop these days and the First Minister says you should wear a mask (although I feel ridiculous, so although I’ve made masks and taken them with me I haven’t worn one yet. You have to queue to get into the shop and then when you’re in there’s a lot of waiting for people to finish looking at things, and having old men either push past you or barrel into you while they completely neglect to respect social distancing. It’s not just me being sexist, my husband agrees it’s old men who are hopeless at it. I am really bored of making food. K--is doing a lot of it, and so am I but it’s so boring. I really miss eating out. Neither of us want to go to the shops for the most part (although I volunteered to drive to Irvine to pick up his parents shopping for them -a big long drive by myself with my music? Get in!) so we leave it as long as we can to see who buckles first. He’s very controlling about how and where I should get shopping, which I try to just ignore, but it’s hard work. Also, when he’s making tea he’ll make a big fuss about how he’s going to do it and then ask me what he should make and what should go with it. He is old enough to work it out for himself! I mean, if he can’t be bothered to work out what to make why say he’s going to make it? We did get fish and chips on Sunday, but we’d had to book that in a five minute slot on Monday morning. I say we -I asked everyone what they wanted, and then booked it and then they changed their minds when it was too late, and then K--pulled a strop about how he just wouldn’t eat any of it so I had to get in touch with the manager to find out all the ingredients of the batter. Also I had to go pick it up, with my daughter because K--had gone out at the precise time on Sunday. Tbh I am beginning to see why I’m bored of cooking. K-- is being a dick. Entertainment and leisure Through April I’ve written a poem a day, I’m not sure if that counts as leisure, except I don’t get paid for it, but I’ve got a poetry book coming out in a couple of weeks so I wanted to get some poetical attention in the lead up to that! I’ve been watching things on BBC iplayer (Noughts & Crosses, Normal People), which I didn’t before, and prioritising taking breaks for myself seeing as I’m not getting breaks. I think this is good. It shows the kids that I deserve a break too. We have all been spending time on our separate screens. K--is learning programming, my son has set up his own Minecraft server to do a project with his cousin, and my daughters are enjoying playing and watching TV (YouTube for kids and Netflix) on their tablets. I know Miss 9 is watching Free Rein, Miss 12 watched a French film on YouTube for French and has watched a few more that came up. Mr 14 is watching the first series of Stranger Things with me in the evenings. In addition there have been things online which would have been physical events before. Because I never know when K-- is actually going to be here and he has a tendency to go out when I’m supposed to be going out, I hardly ever get to go to any literary events, and I’ve loved being able to go to loads from the comfort of my desk. If he insists that I don’t do that right now I can listen on a surreptitious earbud and make sure my video is off! It has been amazing to be able to talk with some of my inspirations, and I feel my poetry has benefitted. There’s another literary festival this weekend, so hopefully I’ll get to do that too. Personal hygiene We have to wash our hands when we come in from daily exercise or anything else. This is tedious and exacerbates my eczema. When I get to work I have to wash my hands, I also clean all the door handles after everyone’s come in, wipe down all the workstations (before they get there or while they’re faffing), and I have to wear gloves all day. When I’m preparing food parcels I wear gloves and an apron and it’s really hot. I wash all my clothes every time I get back from the hub. They’re sweaty but it’s not just that. Because we’re always in, and the cleaners aren’t coming any more we always seem to be cleaning. We get the kids to do some, but I’ve cleaned the kitchen twice already today and I’ll be cleaning it again before the day’s done. My hair is growing out somewhat. I actually do have hair dye, but I’m not sure I want to use it or just grow it out. My neighbour, who cares a lot about appearances, is distraught because she has her hair dyed two different colours by her hairdresser and now she’s got grey roots. I offered her my hair dye but she doesn’t want to mess up the hairdresser’s hard work. Hairdressers have killed my hair so many times I’m wondering if it’s not a good thing we’re having to do it ourselves. Sleep I’m doing fine with sleep. My husband is not, but he never sleeps well. Actually he sleeps OK, but whenever he wakes up instead of going back to sleep he throws a strop about waking up and looks at his phone. He will not countenance not doing this stupid activity. Miss 9 is also getting very stressed out and having trouble sleeping sometimes, I’m trying to counter that by making sure to spend a long time with her in the evening calming her down and trying to get her to bed earlier than K--says she should go. A lot of it is down to her being so tired that every little thing gets monstrous in her mind. I haven’t had any interesting dreams, sorry!

Ethnicity Free Text: The conventional tick-box form has me in the box 'white-British', but I feel very much 'European' - my family are either EU citizens or have dual nationality.
Disability Free Text: I strongly suspect I'm autistic. It's undiagnosed, but both children have a diagnosis and there is huge overlap in our childhood experiences. I know that my local health board doesn't diagnose adults, so I can't say for sure, but I very much feel that I meet the diagnosis criteria.
Occupation 2020 Free Text: Archaeology MA Student on a 4 year course
