Keywords: COVID-19 pandemic (2020-);Lifestyle, health and well-being;Adolescence;Neurodevelopmental conditions;Partners (personal);LGBTQI+;Family life;Schools;Reproductive health;Leisure time and social activities;Personal appearance;Emotional states;
Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing'. Mass-Observer M6759 describes themself as female; age 34; married; former healthcare assistant.;The Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing' was issued on 27 November 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their opinions on and experiences of health and wellbeing, in particular 'health, wellbeing and the healthy body'; 'identity'; 'growing up and learning about health and wellbeing'; 'growing older'; 'health, wellbeing and appearance'; 'getting ready to leave the house'.
Contents: Health, wellbeing and the healthy body For me, the word ‘health’ has very physical connotations. Wellbeing – whilst partially concerned with physical health – feels like a less corporeal concept. The first five words I think of when I imagine a healthy body are: strong, fit, muscular, happy, and robust. Having grown up in a community of rotund farmers, I’m very much aware that health does not equal thin, in terms of body image. Often that’s quite the opposite. Health, for me, is very much tied up in fitness, in the outdoors and fresh air. It consists of hearty meals and flushed cheeks – all very Enid Blyton stories. Identity I think that my idea of what constitutes a healthy body has changed over the years. Growing up, it was very much as I described above, but as I reached my adolescence, outside influences very much took over and – like my peers – I began to try and achieve the very thin bodies which were prevalent in fashion and advertising during the 1990s and early 2000s. As I’ve grown older and my sphere of influence has altered, I’ve sort of reverted back to my original thoughts regarding health and my body. I would rather feed myself good, wholesome foods and spend my time exercising than I would participate in diet culture, even if the later doesn’t result in the type of physique I’ve always been told is beautiful. I’ve mentioned before that my children have/are undergoing a diagnosis for autism, but I believe that this has been especially influential in regards to my own identity in the past few years. I strongly suspect that I am autistic – I met a great number of the criteria of my eldest child’s diagnosis. Since I began reading works by autistic writers, and watching autistic content creators, I’ve come to a better understanding of myself. I wish I’d had these tools for self-knowledge years ago. I didn’t know how to read myself, and I didn’t see enough models of relationships that weren’t heterosexual whilst growing up that it took until long after I was married to realise that I’m actually bisexual/pansexual. And coming to terms with the fact that my monogamous partnership means that I won’t necessarily be able to explore that side of my sexuality hasn’t been easy.  I do think that my parents’ attitudes to homosexuality – which weren’t overtly hostile, but weren’t exactly supportive either – definitely influenced my view of myself growing up. I very much pushed aside feelings and thoughts which didn’t align with the expected heterosexual relationships I was expected to cultivate. I mentioned in part one of this directive that my parents came from a very working class background, and I do believe that they had a very specific lifestyle in mind for me, as I was growing up. It was well-meant, but very much not me. Had I known these things about myself earlier, I think I would have been a far happier, far healthier individual. I know that at least one particularly bad bout of depression could have been avoided, and a good few friendships – which, hindsight tells me were thwarted romantic attempts – might have blossomed into something more, or been salvaged for what they were. Growing up and learning about health and wellbeing I first became aware of needing to look after myself at the point between primary and secondary school. I made the transition between systems in 1997, and it felt as though we were bombarded in that final year with All The Information about sex and drugs. I believe that it was thought that if we learned all this before we went into secondary school that we would be prepared for the types of socialising there, but it was too much at once. I remember feeling as though I was entering a lions’ den after my rural, country school. I think the way that my own children are being taught is far better – sex education begins in their earliest years and ideas regarding consent and healthy relationships are drip fed through the curriculum. The same is true about drugs – primary school tackling cigarettes, alcohol, and prescription medicine. Up until secondary school, what I learned about health was done vicariously through the world around me – Sesame Street, the food my mum made, the people in my life, and the way I felt in the fresh air. I didn’t ever feel like my well-being was anyone’s responsibility, which is the privilege of someone whose wellbeing is protected. My mum and dad were always rather blunt when it came to questions about sex – they answered honestly but were never forthcoming and tended to speak in metaphors. “Don’t go paddling without your wellies,” was frequently yelled by my mum when I went to parties with friends, whilst, “You breed it, you feed it,” was my dad’s favourite addition. I learned a lot from magazines, which wasn’t particularly healthy given our teenage propensity for reading things intended for fully-grown women. Cosmopolitan was a common source of information, but so were the boys we spent time with – their own source being the fledgling world of internet porn. We learned largely by doing – eating fad diets at lunch times when we could control our own food, and by fumbling around with the boys we were ‘dating’. I’m not sure I’d recommend such a piecemeal approach, but I soon learned that I like eating far more than I like being thin (not that I’m ‘fat’ at a 12, but this was the 90s…), and I like sex far more when I’ve been with someone long enough to trust them and for them to learn how my body works. I found the pop-culture staple of one-night-stands were largely unsatisfying and it wasn’t a lesson that took me long to learn. Key moments I remember my first period – my mum was away on a trip with the school she worked at. Panicked, because of the aforementioned deluge of information which concluded my primary education, I was convinced that the anaemic discharge of said first period was a vaginal infection. My nan was looking after my brother and I while my mum was away and I didn’t dare tell her because I was ashamed – she was my idol. About twenty minutes after my mum returned, I cornered her and made her look at the marks in my pants. She was dismissive – appearing bored – and simply said, “What? It’s your period. What did you think it would look like?” That was an interesting question – I’d been told I’d bleed, but never how much. The lack of drama involved was something of an anti-climax and I didn’t really know at the time how to deal with the very nonplussed reaction. The rest of puberty seemed to happen in the space of around a month and a half afterwards – though was probably longer! I was nearing my 14th birthday when I got my first period, and by the time I was a few months into my 14th year, I was already wearing the size of bra I still use now. I still have t-shirts and sweaters from this time which fit today. To be honest, my experience of puberty was baffling. It happened so quickly that I didn’t really have time to take it all in. If I’m honest, there are aspects – such as my sexuality that I mentioned above – which I’m still trying to sort my way through. Growing older Until I started reading magazines that were much too old for me, I didn’t really do anything specific to maintain my health, and even then, it wasn’t so much my health that I was maintaining but a super-thin waist. I worked in a dog kennel over the weekends from the age of 13 and sort of subconsciously decided that since I was outside all the time, walking dogs, that I didn’t need to think about things like ‘health’. The first few years after university, in which I suddenly had access to my own car for the first time, was when I started considering my fitness seriously. Now that walking wasn’t my job or primary mode of transportation, I started to feel increasingly unfit and resolved to do something about it. I initially started by taking up yoga classes when we lived near Cambridge, but when we moved to the North East of Scotland, there didn’t seem to be too many available. I now try and walk the dog regularly (my husband getting up before me so doing most of the morning walks alone), and prior to the pandemic, I was volunteering at my local library so would walk to the local village – about an hour away – as a way to exercise. In the first lockdown, I really enjoyed participating in the Joe Wicks exercises but as they’re no longer live, I’ve fallen into the trap of ‘the videos are online, I’ll do one later’. I try to listen to my body and – trite as it sounds – my heart, these days. If I feel unfit when walking up the hill, I try to work more walking into my life – parking as far from the supermarket as I can, for example, or (virus allowing), arriving at school early and taking a walk alone before collecting my children. Or staying for a walk after I’ve collected them. And when I feel low, I know I need to begin cutting my time online. I’ve deleted my Facebook account – a birthday present to myself in 2018, which is possibly the best decision I’ve made in recent years. I’ve also not touched Twitter since the start of December – it’s now mid-January – and that seems to be helping. I feel like my bubble of “anti-Brexit, anti-Tory, climate-crisis” feeds is just too full of jeopardy to be healthy in any sustained way. I also try and seek out literature and crafts which assuage my sense of powerlessness. The Craftivist Collective, the book ‘Factfulness’ by Hans Rosling, and anything by Jack Monroe has been a massive relief through all of this.  Like everyone, I think, I’d like to believe that I’m going to stay healthy. I like to think that the things I’m doing now will carry me fit-and-well into old age. Whether or not that’s the case remains to be seen – I might have drawn a genetic short straw and be predisposed to cancer, or have a weak heart which hasn’t yet been discovered. Or any other number of things. For the most part, I’m happy just continuing to listen to my body and my soul, and see where that takes me. Health, wellbeing and appearance I think that at various points in time, different physical appearances have been attached to the idea of health. In times gone by, when food was scarcer than it is now, carrying a little extra weight was perceived as healthy. Now, as obesity comes to signify poor health, we perceive thinner bodies as being better looked after. As I touched on above, I wanted to fit in during my teenage years. I wanted to be like the other girls in whatever way I was able – recognising what I now know to be autistic traits as peculiar, following the trend of my adolescence for dieting was a way to fit in. I tried to make myself ‘thin’ to be accepted, but not for any of the usual reasons. My one ‘vanity’ – my Desert Island item – isn’t so much of a cosmetic thing to me, though it’s often classed as one. My contact lenses help a lot with sensory issues – the feeling of wearing glasses constantly is a real drain. I also worry about having to drive in glasses, due to the fact that my vision is so bad that anything viewed out with the frame might as well be seen through a cloud of Vaseline. The thought of missing something to the side of me really fills me with dread. Getting ready to leave the house I remember my mum and dad would get up before we did as children. My mum – without fail – stood at the living room window every morning so that when my dad reversed around the corner and out of the drive, she could wave at him. When we were up in time, we would join her in waving at the window. My mum worked lunch times at a school in the next village over, so we would usually leave the house before she did, or she would leave at the same time as us. It was rare that there was no one there when we arrived home, something I’m increasingly thankful for as I get older. I actually hate leaving my house. I love being out, but the act of stepping through the door really stresses me out. My husband calls it the ‘doorstep mile’ though I don’t know if this is a recognised phrase or not. I have a little checklist in my head – ‘phone, purse, keys’, which has been added to over the years. It now includes ‘mask’, but in the past has featured things like ‘baby’ and ‘passport’. It’s not that I think I’ll forget the items if I don’t do this, but it’s a way to reassure myself that I’ll be fine in the world – if I have all of these items, I can make my way.

Living Arrangement Free Text: Lived in same house 54 years

Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing'. Mass-Observer L7594 describes themself as female; age 82; married; retired infants teacher and Ofsted nursery inspector.;The Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing' was issued on 27 November 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their opinions on and experiences of health and wellbeing, in particular 'health, wellbeing and the healthy body'; 'identity'; 'growing up and learning about health and wellbeing'; 'growing older'; 'health, wellbeing and appearance'; 'getting ready to leave the house'.
Contents: No L7594 Female age 82 Married 59 years Benfleet Essex Retired Infants Teacher and Ofsted Nursery Inspector Part 2 Everyday health and Wellbeing Health, wellbeing and the healthy body To me health means being free from illness. Wellbeing means being healthy, happy and satisfied with life. A healthy body makes me think of someone fit, strong, agile, energetic and mentally alert. Identity I think that my own experience of health has been influenced by education and gender. Being female means there are so many reproductive organs to go awry.  Social class will have played a part inasmuch as it affects good housing, good diet, the good or bad influences of family and friends. My husband and I have been faithful partners for 59 years so there has never been a worry of picking up sexual diseases. We have never been part of the permissive society of the 60’s. I saw the effects of that on the children I taught. Growing up and learning about health and well being My mother and I lived alone through the war so she had the main influence on me. She listened to the Radio Doctor. We would do exercise together such as standing tall like a tree and touching toes. She gave me cod liver oil and malt throughout the winter and I wore long socks and a liberty bodice. We used to get cod liver oil and orange juice from the clinic and I had a bottle of milk at school. She loved eating greens and cooked every day. She used to grow runner beans, potatoes and tomatoes and put eggs in isinglass to preserve them. I inherited her Kilner jars and still use them. I didn’t like school dinners and would usually cycle the 3miles home and eat a cooked meal with my mother and father. Every year she would make jam and bottle apples, tomatoes, any fruit she could get. We went regularly to the dentist. When I was young you had to pay the doctor and my parents were members of the Manchester Unity Independent Order of Odd Fellows who provided sick pay and benevolent grants. My mother was more health conscious the older she got. She would eat honey, yogurt, fresh eggs and anything green because she thought it was good for her. She sprinkled Bemax on her pies. No-one else in the family did but now I am old I find I do the same. Some of her phrases have been with me all my life. Stand up straight. Put your shoulders back. Friday night is Syrup of Figs night. Gargle with Sanitas after cleaning your teeth. Don’t go outside after a hot bath. Don’t go swimming after a meal. An apple a day keep the doctor away. Put a saucepan out to catch rainwater to wash your face. It’s good for your skin. We had health education in the third year of my grammar school. It was also part of the examined course at my teacher training college. We had to study Education and Health by Gamlin. I still have that book. I read books from the health section of the library and magazines. Now I use the Internet for information on specific health problems. When I was 21 I read a book about the benefits of apple cider vinegar. I don’t like instant coffee so at playtime when the staff had coffee I would have a mug of apple cider vinegar in hot water.  They all hated the smell of it but it’s supposed to prevent arthritis and now 60 years later they have pains that I don ‘t suffer from it but still daily drink my home made apple cider vinegar. Another book that has influenced me has been about natural beauty products. I try to use my own, made from garden plants such as marigolds and rose water. I add essential oils to my own marigold oil to make essential oil remedies for all the family. No L7594 Female age 82 Married 59 years Benfleet Essex Retired Infants Teacher and Ofsted Nursery Inspector For my families’ wellbeing my husband grows our fruit and vegetables. I freeze or bottle, make jams and chutneys, make elderflower and elderberry syrup and cook our meals from scratch. We don’t drink alcohol. My daughters lead the same life style and we are all healthy. Key Moments I can’t remember much about it. I was a small child so a late developer as far as wearing a bra and periods were concerned. I suppose they are important moments but I can’t say it meant anything special to me. Just something that I knew would happen. Growing older I can remember looking at old people when I was a teenager and thinking that I didn’t ever want to be old. I started going to yoga when I was 30 and have kept it up ever since. I think it is important to keep mobile. I used to do PE with my class daily joining them with skipping 100 steps. When I retired I joined a Keep Fit class and have only stopped because of the Covid lockdown but will return to that. I do yoga classes on Zoom. I wear a Fit Bit and try to do 10.000 steps a day. My husband and I go for a walk, about 3 miles, every day. I continue to get health books from the library, read newspaper and magazine articles and use the Internet. I am more aware of the parts of my body that ache sometimes. I get more muscular pain especially when doing something different. I expect to get less mobile as I get older but am doing my best to resist it. Health, wellbeing and appearance. I think appearance is very much associated with health and wellbeing. If you are in the correct attire for what you are doing it gives you confidence and you will be more accepted by the social group you are with. It is important to be dressed correctly for various types of weather. I think good posture is connected to health and wellbeing. Also taking good general care of yourself. When I was a teenager it was the accepted ideal to have a 36 inch bust, 24 inch waist 36 inch hips. I used to strive to have a smaller waist. It was the days of support underwear, thankfully long past. The film stars of the 30’s probably had an influence on my mother. She was quite glamourous and well dressed and corseted. I have learnt to do without any of the things that become unavailable. I think it’s silly to think of them as life threatening.  A Desert Island item might be a pair of tweezers but I would need a mirror with them.  Getting ready to leave the house. My father had his own plumbing and heating business. He always shaved every morning, had a short haircut and wore clean overalls and a collar and tie. He was concerned about the state of his hands and would smother them in Swarfega. My mother would take a long time preparing to go out of an evening. She wore powder and lipstick but eyeshadow wasn’t really in vogue. She would put Vaseline on her brows and lashes. She went to the hairdressers weekly and had one perm after another all her life. She had a good head of thick dark hair. If it was an evening dinner and dance she would start with a beaten egg white on her face. She also put strips of cucumber on her face whenever she sliced one. She was proud of her figure and wore Spirella corsets. I have been with her when they were being fitted. When they went out in evening dress they were a very handsome couple and greatly admired. I wear much less make up now I am old. I use face cream made from my daughter’s beeswax. Just powder and light lipstick and mascara. I go to the hairdressers weekly and like to have longer hair that can be turned into a variety of styles. In my youth it would take me a while to get ready but now it’s very quick. I do have a facial, massage and pedicure every 3 months when Covid permits.

Keywords: COVID-19 pandemic (2020-);Lifestyle, health and well-being;Family life;Food;Money and finance;Personal appearance;Physical health conditions;Mental health;Emotional states;
Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing'. Mass-Observer P3373 describes themself as female; age 44; married; police officer.;The Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing' was issued on 27 November 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their opinions on and experiences of health and wellbeing, in particular 'health, wellbeing and the healthy body'; 'identity'; 'growing up and learning about health and wellbeing'; 'growing older'; 'health, wellbeing and appearance'; 'getting ready to leave the house'.
Contents: P3373 MO no P3373 Sex: Female Age: 44 Marital Status: Married Town: Cwmbran Occupation: Police Officer Part 2: Everyday health and  Wellbeing Health and wellbeing. Two words that conjure up different parts of the body. The health, the body as such and the wellbeing, well, your brain I guess. Healthy bodies have meant different things over the years. Years ago, we didn’t really think about it too much. It was more a case of if you were fat, you weren’t healthy but if you were slim, didn’t smoke etc then you were. In the 80s growing up and throughout generations even now I guess, if your parents can’t afford to feed you the so called healthy food then you won’t get it. When we were kids, yes we had veg but food was home cooked or whatever you’re mum had in the cupboard. It wasn’t always the healthiest food. My mum grew up on bread and jam and not a lot else. Her siblings suffered with their teeth because of it. However, my Nanhadnomoney,shesimplycouldn’taffordit.Rationingwasalsostillonforsomeyearssothefoodwasn’t available. Even now, if you were to do two trolleys. Fill one with frozen convenience meals and the other with all the ingredients to make the same meals. Which one will cost more? The second one that’s the one. Where’s the incentive to try and cook from scratch when it costs you double? A lot of houses either don’t have the time or just don’t have the money to fill their trolley with fresh food. It may be unhealthy but if it means that the kids eat then so be it. Ask most parents. All they want for their kids is for them to be fed and happy and healthy. But when you ask them what they mean by healthy, we mostly mean that we don’t want the kids to have any nasty diseases / cancer etc. we don’t mean that we want them to have a BMI of minus 6. Nowadays healthy bodies means a whole host of things.from people going to the gym to work out, not smoking, suddenly becoming vegan, juicing, taking 6000 vitamin pills a day. All ridiculous really. You can get hit by a bus later on in the day. Each to their own I say Ive tried all the stupid diets. I lost a couple of stone on slimming world. Put it all back on and more now though. Lost nothing on slim fast bar the will to live. Lost nothing on the eggs and grapefruit diet, nothing on slimming pills etc etc. A lot of it I guess is just down to cutting out the shit and moving your arse around more. P3373 I used to be a bit of a bean pole. A 5 ft. tall bean pole but I was an 8 to 10. I used to do a lot of dancing several times a week which kept me fit. Then the old bones started to grate, ligaments stretched. Then having a baby knackered the hips up even more and so now on doctors advice, Ive had to give up the high impact stuff I used to do. Can’t do yoga or Pilates etc as “you are stretching the ligaments that are already overstretched” (diagnosed with hypermobility – osteo arthritis and fibromyalgia) so now im 5 ft., in my words chunky (size large 14) and not happy with it. Im not over eating. only have 3 meals a day and don’t buy cakes or biccies etc. don’t smoke etc. so god knows. No im not running 10 miles a day. Would you consider me unhealthy??? Probably. However, I never fry food. Rarely have take out . Don’t smoke. Drink in moderation. Run around after the dogandkids,always cleaning thehouse andgenerallydon’tstop. So maybe imactuallyquite healthy. Idon’t know. How do you quantify health??? As for wellbeing. I always see that as being your mental state. All of a sudden we are being taught “mindfulness “ and living “ in the moment” twenty years ago if you were living in the moment and feeling the world around you then you were either considered a hippy or irresponsible. Now you are basically encouraged to do it I guess though a lot of it IS in the mind. Healthy mind healthy body eh?? If you’re going to be a morose moaning old hag, then your bodies going to reflect it. I guess you’re going to be depressed, sluggish etc. you’ll certainly depress everyone else so that’s not healthy. A lot of things are positive thought. Ive now got to the point in life where I just need to feel content with myself. Im 46 for god’s sake. Im menopausal. Got droopy tits, a cake shelf belly and chunky thunder thighs. Im no longer a 20 something size 8 with pert little 32 b boobies, cute little ass etc. who am I trying to kid? The only fellas im going to attract now is going to be the ones over 40-50-60. Im not going to attract 20 yr. olds so why should I pressure myself. I need to live the age I am. Not that I mean to act like a little old lady cos I don’t feel that I am one. I just need to have the acceptance that people change, your body changes, your personality changes. Im a completely different person to the one I was 25 yrs. ago. Why should I feel guilty for eating a slice of pizza or cake? Why should I die hungry?? It’s always constant pressure when you diet or whatever you want to call it. You feel awful and regretful when you eat “something you shouldn’t “and although you feel good and “what a good girl I am “because you can count your daily calories on one hand you are also left with the feeling of deprivation when you see the rest of the family in a restaurant enjoying their burger or steak followed by apple pie and all you’ve had is a glass of water and a bowl of salad leaves. Die happy and full. Don’t die hungry. Maybe healthy body does mean having a healthier mind-set. Maybe one assists the other. Accept that you are who you are, you aren’t going to be the person you were all those years ago. I’ll get off my soap box now

Keywords: COVID-19 pandemic (2020-);COVID-19--restrictions--lockdown;Family life;Communication;COVID-19--working from home;COVID-19--school--home learning;Emotional states;Children;Society and social behaviour;COVID-19--UK government and policy;Life events;News and current affairs;Leisure time and social activities;Shopping and retail;Police services and policing;Personal hygiene;Personal appearance;Sleep;
Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'COVID-19 (Update)'. Mass-Observer P3373 describes themself as female; age 44; married; police officer.;The Directive 'COVID-19 (Update)' was issued on 27 April 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their experiences of the COVID-19 pandemic, in particular 'health'; 'the government'; 'news'; 'work and home life'; 'technology'; 'shopping and food'; 'entertainment and leisure'; 'personal hygiene' and 'sleep'.
Contents: MO no P3373 Sex: Female Age: 44 Marital Status: Married Town: Cwmbran Occupation: Police Officer Part 2: Covid19 (Update) COVID has been awful. It’s so sad the way that it’s affected so many people. Thank god that so far, it hasn’t affected anyone in my family. We are all ok. Ive been fine. Im currently working from home / juggling that with home schooling and keeping the housework done. And do you know something? Im absolutely loving it. Im sooooooo chilled. I get up, get my son up. He sets up doing his school work at the dining table. I sit in the living room doing my work. Ill intersperse this with a bit of housework when I start to get fed up and that’s that. I don’t want to have to go back to work however they will want me back at some point. Shame. Ive never used Skype or Microsoft teams so much. In fact, I’d never heard of Microsoft teams before the lockdown. Now Im on such meetings every week. Its fine actually. It’s quite nice to have a chat to people and see them through the screen. My workload is so much easier to get through not having constant interruptions in work though. It’s great. Our household has been pretty chilled. We are still all getting on. None of us has buried the other under the patio and we haven’t had one decent row which im sure is rare in most households. Initially our son had a meltdown when he saw the amount of schoolwork that the school sent him. He couldn’t understand how he was expected to do work that they haven’t yet covered in school. I had to try and explain that the school didn’t know how long they would be off. Of course it hadn’t been covered yet, they couldn’t see into the future and that it was a case of using technology more to find out what was needed. The school are in regular contact. The kids have access to teacher’s emails. Google is great to assist them in finding out info and in all honesty his school couldn’t do anymore. They even have staff on board to speak to kids who are struggling with stress or can’t cope. Don’t know about the mothers though…. Maybe theres free access to gin. !!! I’ll have to look into that. I don’t want my son to go back to school as yet though they’ve been off since March. It’s now June. Im happy for him to stay off until the September term is due to start. What’s the point in going back for a few weeks? It’s so much safer for them to stay at home safe for a few more weeks a couple of children over in England have already contracted it this past week after their schools went back. if you are wary of reopening shops and bars / restaurants etc, then why are you happy to send children back when you know that they won’t social distance, they will gather closely together. You are basically treating them as guinea pigs. Sorry, however this mother doesn’t want her child to be a human guinea pig I’d like to be able to go out and have a coffee or something though. Apart from that though, im fine. theres so many people moaning about it though saying that we shouldn’t be made to stay at home, it’s against human rights etc. for god’s sake, you are being asked to be sensible. Stay at home. Don’t pass a deadly virus around by going out and about as usual. (For most unemployed lazy buggers it won’t make any difference. They have been practising for years). We aren’t being bombed out of our homes. We aren’t being rationed. We don’t have to send our children away to strangers etc. It’s not like living through a war. It’s for a couple of months. Not 5 yrs. People haven’t got a clue. People are so bloody selfish nowadays. How WOULD they cope if it was WW3? I dread to think Im a bit dubious about the government decisions at the moment. Is he having a breakdown? He was late putting lockdown in. then late with the procedures of how to deal with those breaching the lockdown. Then Boris was really ill himself. But then when he came back, he was all for reopening everything. Hang on a minute, you nearly died. Your girlfriend was about to drop a baby, then she showed signs of it and yet you then wanted life to get back to normal??? Is he having a breakdown?? God knows what’s going on. This is the new normal for a while though. If it means that we have to wear face masks when out and about shopping etc, in parks etc or that there are less tables in bars and restaurants so that tables are away from each other for a while then so be it. At least they can start to re-open and get some money in. I don’t think anyone would mind having to wear a mask out in public for a few months if it meant getting back to some normality Obviously, you can’t eat with a mask on. But the staff can have theirs on and as long as you are 6 ft. away from the next table while you eat, it shouldn’t be a problem. We are due to have our marriage blessed in September. I know its still 10 weeks away and im being selfish but I really don’t want to cancel it. Theres only 16 of us. Im hoping it can still go ahead. England is ahead of wales at the moment. They are opening. It’s happening in England. If they want the 16 of us to wear masks during the service, that’s fine. As long as I can take it off outside for a couple of photos and then put it back on. I just don’t want to reschedule it as I know so many others who have had to. I’ve been trying to not watch the news to be honest. It’s too depressing. I don’t want a daily update of deaths. I get so confused with what you can and can’t do. Just decide what and can’t be done, announce it on a pre-organised time and day so everyone can be made aware and leave it at that. Ive got too much else to do than sit watching the TV for updates. Family and friends have taken to either face timing or whatsapping. It’s good. On a Saturday, we’ve invented the “polcon arms “which is our virtual pub. We and our mates decide what time to be ready and then we all log on, with our booze and chat the night away. 4 or 5 hrs. Later, all suitably pissed, we all log off and go to bed. No taxis, no pub prices, can go to the fridge to get munchies when you want. Bloody ideal. You can even do it in your Jim jams. Even my parents whatsapp our son every week to speak to him. They would never have done that before. They didn’t know how to. The only thing I do find stressful is the weekly shop at the moment. Luckily I shop at aldi and as they have their “ all day every day “ preference for emergency services, I don’t have to cue as I can flash the warrant card and go straight in. however, although im quite used to the social distancing In the shop, with the 2 metre squares, a lot aren’t. So many times Ive been heard to say “for F**ks sake Mrs, get out my square “as some silly cow reaches across me to grab a bunch of bananas. Oh it really winds me up. Or you get the peruses. The ones who going shopping is their weekly highlight. So they just stand there and look at the shelves, for ages, then move 2 ft. to the left and do the same. Then again. You are waiting for them to move on so you can move on but no. then they walk on without choosing anything. Stop dawdling, get in, and get out. That’s my motto. Then I had the row with the fella last week who didn’t think I should be allowed in with my warrant card if I wasn’t in work!!! I therefore told him in front of the queue which made him look like a dick that “if I was in work, then I wouldn’t be here trying to do my weekly shop would I dickhead?? “. Honestly some people. Can you imagine if I’d gone in in uniform? Parked up in full police car, blue lights going with a shopping trolley to do a full shop. Oh sorry not just a full shop, a shop also for my parents as they are isolating due to health issues. Trying to separate two lots of shopping in one trolley and going from two separate lists as you move your way along the 2mtr squares is a nightmare I can tell you. But sorry, next time, I’ll do it in full uniform rather than in shorts shall I?? That’s the only thing that’s really winding me up, stupid people! What I can’t understand is those who aren’t getting dressed though or keeping up with hygiene. What so because you aren’t going out in public as such, that means that you don’t need to wash / brush your teeth / do your hair or dress?? Ok, so we all need a good hair colour. Embrace the grey …not. Thank god for amazon prime for both hair colour and gin. I still get dressed, brush my teeth etc even if im not leaving the house. I always have. It’s like my mum said at the beginning of this, “to get dressed makes you feel better. It makes you feel more normal. “Ive always been brought up to come downstairs once dressed. I never do anything otherwise. Apart from Xmas day. That’s the exception. I will, allow myself to open pressies in my jammies. That’s because I may have new Xmas clothes. I can then dress in them for the day and have a new outfit on in time to cook Xmas dinner. Yay. That’s the only time though. Even if I don’t feel well, I still get dressed and go downstairs, even if I end up ill and going back to bed. At least I’ve made the effort. The only difference during lockdown is, im not wearing my magnetic eyelashes ( my natural ones are weak and fall out so I look like an alien ) or draw on / fill in my eyebrows ( my eyebrows have a light tattooing, same reason as the lashes, they fell out ). AND wait for it…. Im not always wearing a bra shock horror. These bad boys are rocking and rolling in my tops, in a bid for freedom. Hey im not going anywhere. The furthest I’ve gone is the back garden. Who needs to sit in a sweaty bra in the sun? Although I was embarrassed when an incident happened in the street which brought all the residents out. I went out to sort it out and came back in realising my girls had been bouncing around in my top free as a bird. Oh god, I hope no one noticed. It wasn’t cold out there I don’t think! Sleep wise im fine. A lot of people are saying that they aren’t sleeping properly possibly due to the stress of it all. Fortunately for me, that doesn’t seem to be an issue. I can sleep anywhere, anytime, standing up, laying down. No strange dreams other than the normal crap. Ive not really been affected in this way. I know my mum has though but then shes never been a great sleeper. I don’t know why it’s affecting so many like this. I think I’ve got to the point that I can’t change anything. Im doing what I can to stay and keep myself and family safe and therefore im not pondering on it too much. Theres no point in worrying about things either you can’t change or that have already happened. A few years ago I wouldn’t have been able to say that. I was one of those who worried if they didn’t have anything to worry about. Now I just can’t be arsed. It’s too much, it gives me a headache

Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing'. Mass-Observer M3055 describes themself as female; age 46; married; 'wife & mother'.;The Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing' was issued on 27 November 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their opinions on and experiences of health and wellbeing, in particular 'health, wellbeing and the healthy body'; 'identity'; 'growing up and learning about health and wellbeing'; 'growing older'; 'health, wellbeing and appearance'; 'getting ready to leave the house'.
Contents: MARRIED MARLOW, BUCKINGHAMSHIRE WIFE & MOTHER Part 2: Everyday Health and Wellbeing The challenges of COVID-19 mean that in recent months, there has been a lot of reflec,on on health and wellbeing in unprecedented circumstances. But what about health and wellbeing in everyday life? We learn about health in many different ways, and it can mean different things to different people depending on their circumstances. In this Direc,ve, we want to find out what health and wellbeing means to you (and what it meant before COVID-19) but par,cularly where your ideas about health and wellbeing came from, and what has influenced your own experiences of health and wellbeing in everyday life. Health, wellbeing and the healthy body What does “health” mean to you? What does “wellbeing” mean to you? How do you define these words? Health I think means to be well physically without disease.  Wellbeing means feeling good about yourself. I think you can have either separately or both together. What do you think about when you imagine “a healthy body”? Please share the first five words that come to your mind when you think of this term. clean, slim, fresh faced, pure, exercise Is there a par=cular person or image that comes to mind? Please describe, or draw, this person.  I just did a Google search for a suitable picture and there are hundreds of lycra glad, smiling, slim toned creatures to chose from! Iden,ty How do you think that your own experience of health and wellbeing has been influenced by your gender, ethnicity, social class, or sexual orienta=on? Do you think your experience of health has been influenced by these or other aspects of your iden=ty at all? A lot of my friends have got the fitness bug where they are addicted to exercise.  I like to think I am stronger than that, but really I have never been tempted.  There is so many other things that I would rather do. I did like getting fitter in the first lock down but we have a puppy now so walks are not hard exercise.  I am not a natural mover and until I had children I ddin’t really have to think to hard about staying slim. My mother was a dietician so taught us to eat the right things.  So, I think that by virtue of my being a white, middle class, straight female has influenced my view that healthy is slim and fit.  All media I watch reinforces that and so has my education-both  personal and institutional.   However I accept I can not be considered slim and fit at this point and therfore this has a negative impact on my wellbeing  Growing up and learning about health and wellbeing MARRIED MARLOW, BUCKINGHAMSHIRE WIFE & MOTHER When and where did you first become aware of “health” or of “wellbeing”? I think I have always been aware of the importance of being healthy but wellbeing feels a recent concept.  Or something that we now verbalise regularly but I don’t remember anyone talking about wellbeing in that holistic way.  Who had responsibility for looking aSer your health and wellbeing when you were younger? I guess my parents.  I went to boarding school so my teachers or myself?  I don’t think wellbeing was really an issue.  But we had a different life which was less pressurised and freer than it is now-even before covid 19.  Do you remember your parents, or other caregivers, talking to you about health? If so, what did they talk to you about? Where did these conversa=ons take place? Being healthy was really about eating well, my mother always cooked everything, we didn’t really have sweets very much.  Interestingly we lived in the Middle East for a bit and we had loads of coke and fanta and orange Tang and my sister and I had hundred of fillings.  My children don’t have any at all! Did you receive any educa=on about health in school? And/or did you learn about health and wellbeing in other ways – from friends, magazines, or the internet, for example? We were definitely told to be outside and exercise-play games/ sports. Not smoke and drink or take drugs. But there was certainly not the obsession with how you look that exists now because of social media.  We had Just 17 once a week but we were only interested in the pin ups!  I think it is very different now and it is of no surprise to me that so many young girls and boys have eating disorders.  We have become soooo narcissistic and there is almost no escape from it.  Key moments As an adolescent, when did you first become aware of bodily changes associated with puberty? I went to boarding school soon after I had turned 11 so I was quite a way behind some of the girls turing 12 and so I really found out about the changes with all the girls at school and it was really nice to share the horrors and hilarity of it. We were quite horrified by pubic hair and tried to cut it off and taught each other how to put in tampons.  My period started on holiday when I was at home, I guess I was 13 /14 and it was still such a tremendous shock to me!   Are there any moments or rituals that you think are par=cularly important for young women or men? These might include, but are not limited to, first period, voice breaking, buying the first bra, or shaving, for example? I don’t remember many other moments apart from getting my first period.  In general I found it a distressing time because there wasn’t an awful lot of information around.  Now there are books and we are more open about things. I remember the excruciating conversation or one way talk my mother had with me about periods and sex.  I think I am already having period conversations MARRIED MARLOW, BUCKINGHAMSHIRE WIFE & MOTHER with my children and referring to sex (we live on a farm) so I hope they will have more background knowledge, but no one can stop the great confusion that hormones make you feel -isolated, alone etc.  apart from making sure they know that is normal… How did you feel about these moments if/when they happened to you? Growing older Throughout your life, what if anything, have you done to ac=vely maintain your health both physically and mentally? Has this changed at all over the years? If so, was this due to a par=cular event in your life? As I mentioned earlier I am not a perfect healthy specimen. I used to smoke and drink too much and not do very much exercise.  In my 20s I did yoga for a few years and loved it but that kind of stopped.  Then I used to walk a lot. I never had a problem with my weight until I had children and then nothing shifted.  I had started to shift it in the first lock down to my children’s delight!  But it has crept back up in the last couple of months and I recognise how doing regular exercise helped me a lot in the fist lock down and I think I should try and do more than the dog walks, but when? Where do you get informa=on about health and wellbeing now? You can’t escape it can you.  What I find is there is a lot of dubious information bandied about by people which I know is incorrect but is accepted as true and accurate-but that is the same for all information in this internet age. Would you say you are you more or less aware of your body now? Why do you think this is? Having children makes you more aware of your body and what it can do.  In future years how do you expect your approach to health and wellbeing to change? I think we definitely are trying to be healthier due to covid and recognise that being healthy is important for your wellbeing generally. Health, wellbeing and appearance In your view, how are health and wellbeing related to external appearance? I think they go hand in hand but not necessarily Have you ever been influenced by popular ideals of beauty or physical appearance? I think it would be hard not too.  Received ideas of beauty are quite pervasive but so is the idea that we should be more open to ideas of beauty, which I think we try to but it is very hard not to think that dress would look much better if I was slimmer and taller (and 20 years younger)! MARRIED MARLOW, BUCKINGHAMSHIRE WIFE & MOTHER Do you think your parents were influenced by these kinds of ideals? If so, in what way? No, my parents were not hung up on this stuff at all,  they were interested in having a good and interesting time.  They are lucky to be so long lived!  But they are very careful about what they eat. Are there any health or beauty products (excluding medicines) that you couldn’t live without? What would be your Desert Island item? I guess face cream is the only thing I use every day that is a beauty product.  Perfume and mascara would be a luxury. Ge[ng ready to leave the house Do you remember your mother or father geXng ready to go out for work, or for the evening? If so, can you describe their rituals? I don’t really remember my father getting ready he would appear dressed and looking smart and my mother would do tie/ cravat/ bow tie.  For her there was the dressing, the shoes, contact lenses, jewellery, make up, and lastly masses of perfume. It was always fun. What is your own rou=ne when geXng ready to go out for work or for socialising? Has this rou=ne changed over =me? I don’t really have a routine but it is a long the lines above.  The children find it a bit disconcerting when I wear full make up as I don’t wear it very much.  And I don’t think they can remember it happening for a while!  It hasn’t changed a lot.

Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing'. Mass-Observer M6756 describes themself as male; age 70; 'living separately'; 'retired finance'.;The Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing' was issued on 27 November 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their opinions on and experiences of health and wellbeing, in particular 'health, wellbeing and the healthy body'; 'identity'; 'growing up and learning about health and wellbeing'; 'growing older'; 'health, wellbeing and appearance'; 'getting ready to leave the house'.
Contents: M6756 Male 70 Living Separately Bideford Retired Finance Part 2: Everyday Health and Wellbeing Health, wellbeing and the healthy body Health is a physical ability to function and perform desired tasks to maintain my own life. Wellbeing is the mental ability to be able to think clearly to reason, consider and decide activities to maintain myself, loved ones and society in general. “A healthy body” suggests: Fitness – Trimness – Attractiveness – Functional – There is no one individual who represents this image for me. Identity My reactions to being healthy have been influenced by everything and everyone around me in varying ways throughout my life. After all my identity including my experience of health and wellbeing is an accumulation of all the influences that have created the person I now am. Growing up and learning about health and wellbeing I had no concept of “health” or of “wellbeing” while I was growing up. My parents were responsible for ensuring as far as possible that I was not ill and that I returned to being well if I became sick. I have no recollection of anyone talking about “health” only how to keep myself well and fit. Such conversations simply occurred in the course of ordinary life to address specific occurrences. There was never any reference to what my parents would have referred to as “mental problems”. Similarly in school there was no direct reference to health only to maintaining our physical safety and fitness by way of PE and Games. M6756 Male 70 Living Separately Bideford Retired Finance Key moments As an adolescent I was never aware of changes regarding puberty. There were never any particular moments I can remember just a gradual acceptance of manhood. Having had daughters I believe that the physical changes at puberty are much more pronounced for girls and they do need more understanding and guidance. Growing older Throughout my life I have struggled with my weight and have tried all sorts of diets and physical exercise to reduce my size and feel fitter. None of these were successful in achieving my aims. However more recently my Partner introduced me to Slimming World and as a result I have reduced my weight to a level acceptable to me while improving my fitness. Following my Brain Haemorrhage in 2002 the resulting Brain Damage has affected my thinking and emotions. As a result of great efforts I have learnt to control my reactions better and continue to function well under most conditions. Health and wellbeing information is predominantly acquired from my Partner and Daughters. I am more aware of my body now than I have ever been before and am much care fuller to maintain what I feel is a healthy balance. Equally due to my experiences I am now very conscious of my thought processes and emotions (both of which on occasions I have to work hard to control!) There appears to be no need to make any major changes in my approach to health and wellbeing other than those brought on by increasing old age (which are preferable to the alternative!) M6756 Male 70 Living Separately Bideford Retired Finance Health, wellbeing and appearance I believe that people’s appearance invariably reflects their unwellness both physically and mentally. Yes like the vast majority of people I have been influenced by societies ideals and images. It is a normal reaction to wish to look and feel able to attract mates to reproduce. My parents were influenced by exactly the same kinds of ideals. Beauty products are more about monetary profits than any real advantages and good food provides all that we need to be physically healthy. My Desert Island item would be my Family Photos. Getting ready to leave the house My father was immaculate even as a Chimney Sweep! He always shaved every day and dressed smartly with a collar and tie. There are very few memories of him not having a tie on on any occasion outside the home. Having spent my working life in formal professional organisations I was happy to be seen in 3-piece suit, collar and tie. In fact I found it quite difficult to adapt to “dress-down Fridays”! It was also a problem for me mentally to adapt to less formal clothes after my Brain Haemorrhage. Socialising is more comfortable for me if wearing a collar and tie including any formal occasion requiring Dinner Suits! Even now I feel better wearing a collar and tie and do so regularly to feel comfortable.

Contents: M6756 Male 69 Living Separately Bideford Retired Finance Spring 2020 Directive Part 2: Covid19 Health The situation has not affected my health. I have continued to suffer short periods of instability but they result from my pre-existing condition. My emotions have been subject to short periods of extremes but again these are ongoing and not caused by the current situation. Government Given the unprecedented situation I believe that the Government has done it’s best to protect and support the population, maintain health services and minimise the effect on the economy. With hindsight the timing of actions could have been different with only limited variation in the outcomes. Lifting the “lockdown” must not be rushed and hopefully the Government will not give in to the attitudes of self-serving minorities who would endanger us all. Boris Johnson has shown a more Statesman like approach than I believed he would and has provided greater leadership and confidence than a majority of our politicians. Opposition Parties (supported by the media) create illusory problems for their own ends rather than support decisive constructive approaches. News Gleaned from Local and National Radio, BBC Reporting and to a lesser extent news reporting on the Internet. I have watched most of the Daily Briefings. Have in the main provided dependable information and gave confidence that the situation was being well handled. The Scientific and Medical Advisors have consistently presented a competent and knowledgeable attitude. Some of the Government Spokesmen are confident and present themselves well (eg Matt Hancock; Dominic Raab) but unfortunately one or two others are clearly out of their depth and struggling. I haven’t had any problems with access to the news. M6756 Male 69 Living Separately Bideford Retired Finance The use of BSL Interpreters is not necessary and would simply provide further distraction and confusion. There is already extensive use of sub-titles which are as easily seen as BSL Interpretation and actually contribute to the information supply rather than detracting from it. Work & home life Having Retired on ill-health grounds almost 20 years ago and as a result of living most of that time alone there has been little change. Technology I was already to using Skype and WhatsApp on a daily basis and have now also used Microsoft Teams, FaceTime and Zoom to keep in touch with family and to maintain contact with others ie Tai Chi and Exercise I have also deliberately telephoned people I would be seeing regularly normally and others who I haven’t been in contact with for too long a time. Social media platforms I consider to be anathema to real life contacts and degrading. I therefore have as little to do with them as possible. Shopping & Food There have been no changes to my diet but the enforcement of “social distancing” rules has in fact made supermarket shopping much more enjoyable ie less people and ease of finding items Entertainment & Leisure Increased time spent on my Allotment has been rewarding both physically and mentally TV broadcasting has continued in the main to provide the same rubbish that has been dominate for some time. Have increased time listening to Radio programmes especially Plays and traditional comedies. Also listened to my music more than I have for many years.. I have taken the opportunity to review my will, investments, bank accounts and to sort through lots of old paperwork, photos, family items etc and decide what to keep and what to discard. Started an on-line Course to learn to Draw better. Reading as much as ever and in particular: Jane Eyre, Tale of Two Cities, Sherlock Holmes, Book of Nothing, Children of Time and various Science Fiction and my usual Magazines: Focus, Freemasonry Today, Banking World and RHS. M6756 Male 69 Living Separately Bideford Retired Finance Not swimming daily, attending Freemasonic Meetings or seeing friends. I have taken time to consider how I spend my time normally and start to decide how I will do so in future. Personal Hygiene My handwashing has increased substantially and not swimming daily are the only changes. I have had a beard all of my adult life but it and my hair are the longest they have been for more than twenty years! I am seriously considering keeping the length and style of my hair and beard longer and different than I have done previously! Sleep There haven’t been any changes in my normal sleep patterns. At my age it is unusual to sleep through the night without “having to answer the call of nature” more than once. It is also necessary for me to rest most afternoons.

Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'COVID-19 and Time'. Mass-Observer M6756 describes themself as male; age 70; living separately; 'retired finance'.;The Directive 'COVID-19 and Time' was issued on 7 August 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their experiences of the COVID-19 pandemic and lockdown in relation to the 'rhythm and routine of the day'; 'homelife'; use of 'media and technology'; their experiences of 'waiting'.
Contents: Summer 2020 Directive Part 1: Covid-19 and Time Rhythm and routine of the day Daily life not been disrupted as much as others believe. Having lived alone for the best part of 16 years’ seclusion was not a great problem for me.  Just prior to the lockdown I was due to visit my Partner at her home in Parkstone but by mutual agreement we felt it was safer not to do so.  The immediate effect of the lockdown was to curtail my usual activities which was annoying but was not a problem as I could take my daily exercise working on my allotment and otherwise only going out to do essential shopping. At that stage there was no change in my perception of time. Although as we have progressed it has been a little harder to keep track of days occasionally. I have found that shopping in the evenings is a much pleasanter experience with staff out numbering customers! Checkout operators are also more willing to chat. So that’s a change to my routine I will continue with.  Like many others I spent some time sorting and clearing out my possessions, papers and family records. I have also taken the opportunity to start an on-line course in Drawing (my Partner is an accomplished water colour artist) which has taken up much of my free time and I am finding highly enjoyable.  The time spent on my allotment has resulted in it looking better than it had done for probably five years! There has in addition been a distinct increase in the presence of birds in the vicinity. During the period of the initial lockdown the reduction in traffic and people generally around the town was delightful and very peaceful. Unfortunately, that did not continue once the lockdown started to be eased and it has now caused me to feel uncomfortable with numbers of people around me.  As lockdown has eased I have started to visit and see various friends again. Also my Daughters and Granddaughters were able to visit me to celebrate my 70th Birthday which was particularly enjoyable. Otherwise as I do not believe it is yet safe I have made a conscious decision not to return to my previous activities until probably 2021 and possibly not even then!     Homelife In some ways having lived on my own for so long my routines have changed little: I tend not to get up early to go swimming but mealtimes and other routines have remained much the same.  Currently I do not foresee any changes to my present patterns of life.  Media and technology The use of Zoom to stay in touch with my Daughters and Granddaughters (living in Solihull and Oxford) has certainly helped to alleviate feelings of loss and remoteness. My Partner and I had been using Skype daily to stay in touch for a long time previously.  I have tried Zoom for Tai Chi, U3A, CHSW, Exercise and Freemasonry but other than the later have found the results indifferent at best.  Having used a Diary all of my adult life I have continued to refer to it with a lot less relevance in the current situation. I do continue to write my Journal daily as I have done since my Brain Haemorrhage 18 years ago!  My previous reluctance to use GP Appointments/Prescriptions on-line and internet Banking have been offset by experience and I will be maintaining it in future.  Waiting My usual pattern of life would be to visit my Daughters, Granddaughters and Partner at least every couple of months. This has not been possible and I feel that as my families’ safety is paramount its unlikely to happen very soon.  Although I took the opportunity to allow my hair to grow longer than in recent times I was glad to get it tidied up when my hairdresser reopened. Dentist and optician appointments have been put off but are currently no problem. Medical appointments have easily been combined.  On the very few occasions there was a queue outside a shop I needed to visit I simply walked away and went back later. My thinking was that if there was a queue the numbers inside the shop would be more than what I would feel was comfortable. In addition, I now feel less inclined to browse anywhere.
