Mass-Observer R7210 describes themself as female; age 17; single; high school student.;The Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing' was issued on 27 November 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their opinions on and experiences of health and wellbeing, in particular 'health, wellbeing and the healthy body'; 'identity'; 'growing up and learning about health and wellbeing'; 'growing older'; 'health, wellbeing and appearance'; 'getting ready to leave the house'.
Contents: Autumn Directive 2020 MO Number: R7210 Gender: Female Age: 17 Marital Status: Single Place of Residence: Cardiff, Wales Occupation: High School Student 10th January 2021 Part 2: Health and Wellbeing Health, wellbeing and the healthy body To me, “health” is the state of your body and your mind. “Wellbeing” is, if you swap the two inner words which form this compound word, essentially “being well” in both body and mind. The first five words that come to me when I think of a healthy body are: “well­formed,” “happy,” “unrestricted,” “beautiful” and “fresh.” Two of my cousins come to mind when I think of a healthy body. One of them has glowing skin and very white teeth, and I know she has been vegan for a number of years. My other cousin goes on park runs frequently, and she has a rosy complexion. Identity I think being (and identifying as) female has had a large influence in my experience of health and wellbeing. There is a lot of societal expectation around women having to look a certain way, and it has at times made me feel inferior as a woman. As someone with an hourglass figure, I feel extremely underrepresented and I rarely see women with bodies similar to my own in films and TV shows. On the occasions they do make an appearance, they are often characterised as strippers or prostitutes. I often struggle to find clothes that suit me, since I don’t have an hourglass role model I can look up to. I am very happy that there has been more plus size representation in film and TV, but I would also like to see more women with different body types. I have also noticed a lack of short women as main characters too. R7210 I therefore think my impression of what a healthy female body was supposed to look like was tainted for a long time. I now realise it is impossible for me to be “thin” in a healthy way, because my body structure is simply not built like that. I am now focusing on improving my core, arm and leg strength, and toning these parts of my body. Growing up and learning about health and wellbeing I am assuming I first became aware of “health” and “wellbeing” during doctor appointments I had when I was around five. For a long time, I remember telling people I had a sore throat. I saw many doctors but none of them could figure out what was wrong. Eventually, I saw an Ear, Nose and Throat specialist and he correctly guessed that the “problem” would go away on its own. I also remember learning about body image at around the same age during ballet classes when my ballet teacher told us to hold in our stomachs so she couldn’t see our breakfasts! My parents were responsible for my health and wellbeing. They were good at taking me to the necessary doctors' appointments and took any ailments I had seriously. They didn’t talk to me directly about health, but they did teach me about the nutritional values of the food and drink I consumed. When I was seven, I remember taking part in the “Food and Fitness for Families Project” in my primary school. I was only there because my mum was a volunteer helper, but I think I did pick up a few tips on healthy food and exercise. Throughout primary school, there were various lessons on eating healthy and exercising but I can’t remember much about what I learnt in them. Key Moments I started puberty relatively early, at around ten (although I was one of the oldest in my year). My breasts grew bigger, my hips grew wider and I also started to grow pubic hair. I remember feeling very insecure having to wear my first crop top, since everyone in my class had to change in the classroom for PE lessons. My friends noticed and called it a “chocolate bar,” an anagram for bra! Even when I started high school, my body was very overdeveloped compared to most of other girls; I don’t think we all caught up with each other until we were around fourteen. My mum didn’t really keep track of my bra size; I wore a 32A for most of my first year in high school, when it should have really been a 32D! I do find it interesting that my period was the last stage of puberty to happen to me; it didn’t start until I was thirteen. I remember the experience very well, since my mum was just about to leave to pick my sister up from Guides when it started. She helped me in a rush, and I remember feeling very confused. I can’t exactly remember when I first started shaving, but I only did it in order to “fit in” with the other girls in PE lessons. I still shave now, just because I like having smooth legs, but I’m more lax about it than I used to be. Growing Older I did little to maintain my mental health until I was fourteen. I felt extremely anxious, and sometimes had depressive thoughts, so my school counsellor recommended me R7210 to try meditation. It truly changed my life, and I now meditate every morning for ten minutes. It helps to ground me in the present moment, and calm my emotions. Up until the lockdown, the only physical activities I did were walking and ballet twice a week. Although I was exercising daily, it was very low-intensity, and looking back, I think my body needed more than what I did. I hated PE lessons, because we had to wear very figure-hugging PE shirts, and I felt very insecure in myself. The teachers were always yelling at us to try harder, so it wasn’t a nice environment to be in. However, when the March lockdown started, my ballet classes and daily walks to school stopped, and I knew I had to keep up my exercise somehow. I started following home workouts on YouTube and soon jumped onto the trend of doing monthly challenges set by the fitness Youtuber Chloe Ting, who went viral during the lockdown. This was the first high-intensity exercise I did on a regular basis, and I soon realised I had lost some weight. My appearance changed because of it, and I felt much more confident in myself. I kept up with the workouts even when school started again, and now that I am back to online school, I have started another one of Chloe Ting’s challenges. I rarely need information on health and wellbeing, but if I had any queries, I would use the internet, or ask my parents. If I had any concerns about my mental health, I would ask my school counsellor. I would say that I am more aware of my body now, because although I have finished puberty, I would say that I’m still developing into my “adult” body. I have noticed it change for the better, and I think I will become less conscious about it over time. I am also more concerned about any physical symptoms I experience, since it could be an indicator that I have COVID-19. In future years, I know that I will have to change how I exercise if I move into a flat or shared accommodation after I leave home. Health, wellbeing and appearance In my opinion, I don’t think you can regard yourself as being in good mental health unless you like your external appearance. This doesn’t necessarily mean changing your physical appearance, you might just have to change how you see yourself mentally. I also believe that if you look after yourself mentally, your physical appearance will automatically improve. I definitely have been influenced by popular ideals of beauty, but less so by celebrities (as I mentioned in the identity section, I haven’t found anyone I can look up to) than my peers in school. I generally try to dress like everyone else and I usually do my hair and makeup when going to (in-person) school. I admit this is very shallow, and I hope I will find my own style as I grow older. I think my mum has been influenced by popular ideals of beauty, but less so than other adults her age. She did teach me how to shave my legs, therefore passing down that beauty standard to me. A few months ago, I watched a video explaining that the idea that women had to shave their legs came from companies that wanted to make money from selling shaving products. I still continue to shave, but I always keep this idea in the back of my head. R7210 I think the only health products I use daily are soap, deodorant, and lip balm. I shower three times a week, in which I use shampoo, conditioner, shower gel and argan oil. I also use shaving cream. When I wear makeup, I use concealer, blusher, bronzer and mascara. I think my Desert Island product would have to be beeswax lip balm, closely followed by my over-the-counter iron tablets I take. They have transformed my life; I no longer feel super tired during the daytime. Getting ready to leave the house I don’t remember my parents having any specific ritual before going to work (they work from home now). If they were going out for the evening, my mum would usually have a shower, wear some fancier clothes than usual, and put on a little bit of makeup – usually just tinted moisturiser and eyeliner. Before school moved online, I had quite a strict routine before leaving the house. I would get up, get dressed straightaway, have breakfast, put on some makeup and straighten my hair. I usually did this all in a rush, and I miss that excitement in wondering whether I was going to be late for school or not. I usually take out a bit more time in getting ready to socialise, since I have to spend time choosing an outfit. I also spend more time doing my hair and makeup. Now that we are in lockdown again, I never bother with hair and makeup, and I wear whatever clothes I am comfiest in. I think this is much more sensible, and I hope I will continue with it once the lockdown ends.

Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'COVID-19 (Update)'. Mass-Observer R7210 describes themself as female; age 16; single; high school student.;The Directive 'COVID-19 (Update)' was issued on 27 April 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their experiences of the COVID-19 pandemic, in particular 'health'; 'the government'; 'news'; 'work and home life'; 'technology'; 'shopping and food'; 'entertainment and leisure'; 'personal hygiene' and 'sleep'.
Contents: Part 2: COVID-19 Update MO Number: R7210 Gender: Female Age: 16 Marital Status: Single Place of Residence: Cardiff, Wales Occupation: High School Student 23rd May 2020 As I am writing this, Wales has now been in lockdown for over two months. Since I last wrote about COVID-19 for Mass Observation, staying at home has become quite draining. I find it hard to believe that there will ever be a time where I will be able to see other people again, but I know this won’t last forever. The number of new cases each day here are gradually decreasing and I think most people are now focusing on how the “new normal” is going to be enforced when we are allowed out again. Health Thankfully, none of the people I live with have suffered any major physical or mental health issues during this lockdown period. None of us have shown any symptoms of the virus so far. A few years ago, I was suffering with mental health issues and I saw a councillor at school once a week. Over time, I reduced seeing them to once a month as my mental health started to improve. When school closed, they emailed me to say that they would check in with me once a fortnight, as they are doing with all their other pupils that they see. Emailing them has really helped me to work through any issues that I have and I am so grateful to have someone outside of the family who will listen to me. My emotions have been extremely varied over the past few weeks. I have noticed that they will drop dramatically if I feel I haven’t had a “productive” day. This usually entails schoolwork, reading in the garden, violin practise, working out and writing. I would love to get out of this mindset where I feel that spending an entire day on my phone is a bad thing, but I am finding it very difficult! I think it is because I was working very hard for my GCSEs, and so when they were suddenly cancelled, my brain found it hard to adjust to the fact that I no longer have to do any work if I don’t want to. Since it was supposed to be half term next week, I am not going to do any schoolwork during this time. I hope this will improve my mental health. The Government At the moment, Wales, Scotland and Northern Island are still being told to stay at home, but the British Government is allowing people in England to see people outside their household as long as they are socially distant from one another. They have also said that Primary Schools may open to some students on the 1st June. I understand that they want to get the economy moving again, but I am worried that this is happening too soon. Since we have the second highest number of deaths from the virus in the world, it concerns me that we are moving faster than a lot of other countries. I also think the government is underestimating how hard it will be to socially distance, especially in cities. In the coming months, permitting that the R number is still low, I think that the British Government will open schools in September and allow lots more people to go back to work. However, I don’t think any of this will be full time and I doubt that anything will go completely back to normal until a vaccine is found. I wouldn’t be surprised if there was another spike in cases, especially during July and August when people may think it is safe to socialise again. Overall, I think the government is more focused on restarting the economy rather than saving lives, and already the impact of this has been devastating. News I mostly check the BBC website for news. I prefer to do this in the afternoon so it is not the first or last thing I think about. I find that lots of it is negative and since everything is beginning to calm down I have checked it less. My mental health is definitely improving because of it. We haven’t been watching the daily government briefings, but we always know it’s happening because our wifi usually goes down at five o’clock! My mum prefers to watch the ten o’clock news as it  just gives the main details. I usually go to bed at this time or I lose sleep thinking about what I’ve watched. No one I know has experienced challenges with accessing the news and I believe it’s vital that it is accessible for everyone during these times. I have noticed the BSL interpreters at Nicola Sturgeon’s broadcasts and wondered why they weren’t used for general UK broadcasts. I think they should be introduced as soon as possible. I also think it would be good if the briefings were translated into other languages. It could help people living in the UK who don’t have English as their first language or don’t speak it at all to understand what’s going on much better. Work and home life My GCSEs were cancelled, and I therefore have no compulsory work that I need to be doing. However, my school has put up optional tasks for us to step into our A level subjects. I have decided to only focus on the subjects I am taking next year, which are English, French, History and Welsh. For French and Welsh, I learn vocabulary and grammar and I have also been watching films and TV in those languages. I have been reading the Wolf Hall trilogy for History, as we are studying the Tudors next year and I am currently on the third book, The Mirror and the Light. For English, I have been working my way through classic novels. Since lockdown began, I have read The Great Gatsby, Wuthering Heights and David Copperfield. All of the work has been really enjoyable and I feel like I am making much more progress at home. In school, I had to spend a lot of time doing work that didn’t seem to teach me anything at all, and I definitely prefer to work independently. Lockdown hasn’t had a very big impact on my home life. As I am quite introverted, I like to spend lots of time at home anyways. I don’t think any of the relationships with the people I live with has changed much. My parents can be annoying at times, but I know that they mean well, so I can cope with it. My sister and I get along well, and we do this by leaving each other alone most of the time. If I ever get really irritated by them, I’ll go up to my room for a while. I feel very privileged to have a space I can call my own and it has been invaluable during lockdown. Technology As a teenager, I am used to using technology, but for my parents, this has been a challenge. They have never had a smartphone before, but I have given them my old one so they can be on our extended family’s group chat. It took them some time to get used to it, but they rarely need to ask for my help with it anymore. My mum’s work asked her to trial Google Classrooms with the classes she teaches, and since my sister and I use it for school, we taught her how to use it. My mum made a fake class for us to join and gave us some “assignments” for us to do. In school, we have to use Google Classrooms responsibly, so I took the opportunity to spam the comments section of this fake class! I have been having online violin lessons. I use Google Duo for this, and the video calls have only cut out once or twice. I have noticed that the quality is much worse when someone else in my house is on a video call, so we have been trying to schedule them at different times. My friends sometimes video call me on FaceTime or Whatsapp. It’s nice to catch up with them and there are only ever connection problems when the wifi dips at the five o’clock briefing time. I have always struggled with communicating with my friends online and I much prefer talking face to face. Texting makes me feel anxious and I often take hours if not days to reply to them. Thankfully, my friends are very understanding about this. All of my extended family live outside Wales and through technology, we are now seeing more of them in lockdown than we did before! We have been keeping in touch with my dad’s -very large -family through our group chat on WhatsApp. Many of them live in London and some of them have had COVID-19, so this chat is a great way to check in on them. We have kept in touch with my mum’s side of the family through Zoom. We have done an online “escape room” with some of my cousins and though it took hours to solve, it was lots of fun. We are going to do a second one with them later today. I have been using social media to escape what’s going on. I use Instagram the most, as it is a good way to see what my friends have been up to. My ballet school and my orchestra group both have Facebook pages, so I have been following them for any updates or resources that they share. I have found TikTok to be the best way to completely switch off from the outside world and have enjoyed spending hours watching funny videos on there. Shopping and Food My mum is the “designated shopper” in our family and tends to do a big shop at Sainsbury’s early on Tuesday morning, and a smaller shop at our local Tesco on Saturday morning. We are vegetarian and there has been a lot less meat and fish alternatives available for us, as well as baking goods.  At the beginning of lockdown, the fruit and veg company we use stopped delivering for a few weeks, but we now have our weekly deliveries back again. My eating habits have definitely changed during lockdown. I am now drinking over 2 litres of water everyday, and it has made me feel so much better about myself. I have also been snacking less, as I am using up less of my energy. My sister and I now cook a meal for us and our parents every Friday and it has been fun learning how to cook properly. Entertainment and Leisure By far my favourite part of lockdown is how much more time I have to do my favourite thing in the world: writing! I like to write first thing in the morning, and when I was at school, that meant getting up at 5.30! Since lockdown, I have been getting up at 8.00 and writing for an hour and a half before breakfast. Doing this puts me in a positive mindset for the rest of the day. I now have time to edit my work too, and I like to do this around mid-afternoon. As a result of all this extra time, I am now extremely close to finishing my story, and considering I have been writing it for over two years, this is very exciting for me. Another thing I have loved doing since lockdown is spending time in the garden. I feel extremely grateful to have one right now and I try to go there at least once a day. I have enjoyed re-reading some of my old childhood books, including The Hunger Games and His Dark Materials trilogies and the Harry Potter series. I have also read lots of stories by two of my favourite authors, Hilary Mckay and Jane Gardam. If I don’t feel like reading, I have some scratch boards that I can draw pictures on, and it’s very therapeutic. I am currently doing a big spring clean of my room to make it a nicer place to work in. So far, I have sorted out my wardrobe, chest of drawers, shelves, desk, and storage boxes. Tomorrow, I shall attempt to dust all of these spaces, which I have been putting off for weeks! I have been doing lots of exercise at home to make up for the forty minutes it would usually take to get me to school. Every evening, I do a fifteen minute HIIT workout by myself, and then another one later with my mum. I think my core strength has greatly improved because of this. On the weekends, I like to do a barre work video that my ballet teacher sent me. I have been watching a lot more Netflix since lockdown began. Some of my favourite movies I’ve seen so far are The Breakfast Club, Crazy Beautiful You, The Perks of Being a Wallflower, Midnight Sun and Ladies in Black. I have just finished the series Outer Banks and I loved it! It was about a group of teenagers who go searching for gold and it was very fast paced and exciting. I did feel a little sad watching it though, seeing as I will probably be spending my summer being 16 stuck at home instead of having adventures. Personal Hygiene My personal hygiene hasn’t changed much since lockdown. I only have one pair of black leggings which I have worn almost all the time, but I change my t-shirts every day. Since it is getting hotter I like to wear shorts and sometimes dresses, but I certainly don’t miss jeans! I have to have a shower every other day, or my hair gets very greasy, so that routine hasn’t changed. I think I have been shaving more than I usually do, as I like to go out to the garden to tan since the weather has been hotter. I have been feeling much better about my body since lockdown began, as I finally have the time to take care of it properly. Sleep I have always been very lucky when it comes to sleep and rarely have problems with insomnia or nightmares. I am definitely getting much more sleep since lockdown. I got around seven hours sleep when I had school, but I get at least nine hours now. Sleep is what motivates me to work out, as it takes me much less time to fall asleep when I do so. I usually go through phases of having very vivid and crazy dreams for about one week every four months. This last happened in late February but since lockdown, it feels as if they have continued, although they are much less vivid. My craziest dream so far was a few weeks ago when I delivered a baby in Tesco! It was right next to the checkouts and I remember feeling very pleased with myself when I had done it. I also remember another dream I had where I went to the theatre at 11.30 PM with some of my friends from primary school and one friend from high school. We kept stopping off at different places and I was worried that we were going to be late. When we eventually arrived, it was not the play I originally thought it would be, An Inspector Calls, but a production of Grease (An Inspector Calls was the play I was supposed to be studying for my English Literature exam, which my mum and I had seen a week before lockdown. We had watched Grease as a family a few nights before this dream). The most interesting dream I had was last week. I was looking in the mirror and was watching my hair, which was spiky and sticking up everywhere, turning grey! I was very freaked out by this, but my mum who was with me in the dream said that it would turn back again and she was right. I think this was probably symbolic to all the time that has flown by in these past few months.

Occupation 2020 Free Text: Deputy Headteacher of rural comprehensive school
Current Occupation Free Text: Deputy Headteacher of rural comprehensive school
Partners Occupation Free Text: Local Authority Lead for Children's Centres
Keywords: COVID-19 pandemic (2020-);Lifestyle, health and well-being;Family life;Food;Society and social behaviour;Racism;Teaching and education;Employment and occupations;Schools;Family members;Mental health;Reproductive health;Adolescence;Emotional states;Personal hygiene;Physical health conditions;Personal appearance;
Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing'. Mass-Observer T6838 describes themself as male; married; age 64; retired teacher.;The Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing' was issued on 27 November 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their opinions on and experiences of health and wellbeing, in particular 'health, wellbeing and the healthy body'; 'identity'; 'growing up and learning about health and wellbeing'; 'growing older'; 'health, wellbeing and appearance'; 'getting ready to leave the house'.
Contents: Mass Occupation – Autumn 2020 Number: T6838; Gender: Male; Status: Married; Town/ village: Melton, Suffolk. Age: 64; Occupation: Retired teacher Part two: Everyday health and well being Health, wellbeing and the healthy body Health is concerned with illness and injury. Good health is about having little or no issues with either illness or injury. Everyday activities are not hampered. Wellbeing adds to good physical health a dimension of positive emotional health. A sense of feeling warm and positive about yourself and your life and the ability to cope with problems as they arise. An overall feeling of contentment. Healthy body in five words: Pain-free; Strong; Content; Confident; Warm A healthy person is someone who maintains a healthy body and happy mind. They achieve and keep to a sensible weight, eat well and take regular, appropriate levels of exercise. They interact with others as they wish to. There is a balance to their lives physically and emotionally as they avoid excesses that might unsettle them. They are confident and content in who they are and what they stand for and make decisions that are in their own best interests whilst being mindful of others around them. Identity Although in early childhood my parents had little money, they tried hard to ensure we ate well. I can recall visits to a fruit and vegetable market stall late on Saturday afternoons where my father would haggle for some of the remaining, often rather tired looking or over-ripe, produce, which he would turn into fresh fruit salads and coleslaw. My parents had grown up during the second world war, had coped with the demands of rationing and understood the importance of a healthy diet. My parents fed us based on what their own parents had fed them. My father chose fatty joints of meat for Sunday lunch and always insisted we ate all the fat on any meat we were fed because ‘fat is good for you’. My mum dosed us with sugary rosehip syrup and provided is with deep-fried bread to chew on. Twenty first century nutritionists would raise serious concerns about some of the things we were given to eat, although I am sure my parents’ notions about our diet were always well-intentioned. These early experiences about eating fruit and vegetables though, have stayed with me. Later in childhood, my father achieved a better salary, and, in turn, this helped with our general standard of living. We ate well and had choices that some young people were denied. Like almost all my friends from school, for example, I benefited in that ‘baby boomer’ era from the improved housing stock, readily available clean water and the vaccination programmes initiated by the NHS. A lifelong interest in sport has been a significant factor in my attitudes towards health and wellbeing. Lacking the talent of some of my peers I always trained hard to raise my standards of performance which in turn enhanced my awareness of factors that shaped fitness and health. I benefited from having friends who also had a positive approach to fitness and health. Being male and interested in sport during the 1970s and 1980s was also helpful as opportunities for women interested in sport were often more limited, especially after leaving school. Growing up, the prevailing attitudes towards ethnicity and sexual orientation were hampered by a lack of education and understanding. I was certainly aware of prejudiced actions and attitudes towards non-white people and those who, in 2020, would be regarded LGBTQ+. Some of my teammates in the school rugby team were racists. I recall one player, two years older than me, stamping on the head of one of our opponents, simply because he had skin that was a different colour to everyone on his own team. From a personal point of view I was not aware at the time of how I, doubtlessly, benefited by being white and straight. I cannot recall a situation in which any choices I wished to make were limited in any way by my gender (I was male), ethnicity (white British), social class (parents were aspiring to middle class), or sexual orientation (heterosexual). I am confident that my childhood experiences encouraged a positive approach to my health. In this context I was fortunate. Growing up and learning about health and wellbeing I first became aware of ‘health’ at home when my parents focused on ensuring I (and my two younger brothers) had the benefit of a healthy diet. Certain foods, like fruit, were good for you I was told. Although my father was a heavy smoker, he strongly discouraged me not to smoke because of the growing body of evidence beginning to emerge about its harmful effect on health. He was also a heavy drinker but again worked hard to ensure I had a more sensible approach to alcohol. ‘Wellbeing’ is something I do not recall being aware of until much more recently. As a teacher I recall an increasing awareness of mental health issues in the 1990s when teaching health education classes. However, it is only in the final few years of my career (I retired in 2017) that wellbeing became more prominent. One factor for increased awareness in schools and the media was the growing evidence and concern about suicide rates amongst young people, especially young men. A friend of my son, someone I knew well and taught for several years, committed suicide in his early 30s – those experiences make an impact on personal awareness. At primary school and my early years at high school I recall some health screening taking place at school. Some vaccinations were conducted at school, as were rudimentary dental check-ups. I also recall brief check-ups with doctors who visited schools so that all children could be seen by someone medically qualified. Despite these interventions it was very much my parents who were responsible for my health. They encouraged healthy attitudes about eating and sleeping and were also keen to ensure that their children did not smoke or drink too much. I would praise my parents on how they encouraged a healthy lifestyle in childhood although their role in my overall wellbeing and its emphasis on mental health would need additional consideration. My father was extremely strict with me and my brothers and did not like his views challenged. It led to arguments about matters as varied as how to we should be allowed to have more fashionable haircuts; listen to music he did not like or wear trendier clothes. When I left for university, my father struggled to cope with my brothers becoming more independent and especially when they disagreed with his views or became defiant. One brother has really struggled with his mental health in adulthood and I wonder to what extent this may be a result of the serious tensions that developed between him and my father throughout his adolescence and early adulthood when living at home. I think my father would have struggled with the notion of wellbeing! My parents were excellent about encouraging healthy eating and I recall my father being helpful (and frank) about my sex education. He was mindful of making me and my brothers aware of issues around puberty and sexually transmitted diseases, for example. I can still recall some of these potentially embarrassing conversations being handled with genuine aplomb by my father; I suspect his years in the merchant navy helped here no end! I do not remember much health education being taught at school apart from some basic sex education lessons but do recall conversations about sex with my peers. I still recall walking home with some of the older boys from scouts one evening and one of the older boys telling us about what he had heard about sex. Key moments I do not recall there being many moments when issues around adolescence or puberty caused me too much embarrassment. Having been in the merchant navy for several years before I was born, my father had travelled the world and become aware of the need to ensure I was aware of physical changes as I was growing up. It was my father who was responsible for talking to me about these matters and he did it well. I am certain he was ‘worldly wise’ from an early age and wanted us to avoid potential problems as we got older and moved away from home. On another occasion I remember well the time he did not allow me to join a youth football team with some of my friends because of how the manager acted towards me and a friend when we first met him. My dad explained his concerns to me when we got home, and so I found an alternative club to play for. Two years later the manager my father was so concerned about was jailed for child molestation; some of my friends had been this person’s victims. My father was excellent in this ‘protection’ role. I think the one issue that caused some embarrassment for me was that of facial hair. I matured quite early and had that fuzzy hair on my top lip that drew some attention before I started to shave. I remember doing some shopping at a local newsagent and the proprietor, who knew my parents, saying to me ‘You need to have a shave’. I was about twelve and can still remember blushing in the middle of the shop! I still remember thinking that the man’s comments were unkind; it was certainly one of those moments that I filed away and recalled in adulthood when I hope I would have behaved in a more sensitive way. I have never been someone to share those kinds of experiences described above with other people and am certain that this short but difficult exchange would not have been passed on to my parents. However, the fact that I can so readily recall the conversation over 50 years on, and how it made me feel, reminds me of the vulnerability of young people and the potential impact those kinds of interactions can have on young people as they search for the self-confidence to cope in a raft of social settings. I ought to add that I am sure that the man did not intend to hurt my feelings in any way; but he most certainly did, and I have never forgotten that encounter. I certainly made sure my own son was armed with a razor to deal with fuzzy facial hair before it became a point of potential embarrassment! Growing older My interest and involvement in sport has continued into my mid-60s. This, together with trying to be a positive role model for my own children and those I taught, has meant that I have always wanted to look and feel in good shape. I do not like to look or feel overweight and continue to exercise regularly and am mindful of ensuring I have a healthy diet. For example, I try to ensure that fruit and vegetables are prominent in my diet; even more so in recent years after I had to have colorectal surgery to remove some polyps and then a couple of years ago having a TIA (transient ischaemic attack / mini stroke) both of which I found unsettling. I think I have become more aware of my body and how I need to look after it as I have got older. The health issues I have faced in recent years have made more mindful of what I eat, the importance of not over-exercising (which has certainly been the cause of various joint problems in my 50s and 60s) and that by failing to be proactive about these things is likely to lead to earlier and more difficult problems going forward. I try to keep updated by reading the press about contemporary research and trends and I have an excellent GP who I can call upon if worried about anything. I intend to keep myself well informed. Health, wellbeing and appearance A real hero of mine was a PE teacher who taught me for several years at high school. He was a brilliant sportsman, had a great physique, always looked smart and was noticeably kind to everyone. I have aspired to be like him in these respects ever since! In doing so I have always sought to look after my appearance and continue to me mindful of my body image in my 60s. I think the only currently popular ideal of which I am conscious of is to do with body hair. I have never liked having hair where it should not grow! In the last two decades having no body hair has been the trend for men in the public eye and certainly if they are photographed in swimming trunks or similar. Every few weeks or so, after I have trimmed down my chest hair with an electric razor, I enlist the (reluctant) help of my wife to apply cream to deal with my hairy back. She always tells me that she does not mind it herself and reminds me that she is the only one to see me with a hairy back, but I still go through the ritual of ridding myself of unwanted body hair because it makes me feel good about myself. I try to tell myself that this does not make me a shallow person?! I think my father was a bit vain – I think I am too! I do not think my parents were quite as aware of trends in the way that the next generation became. The 1960s counter-culture movement and growth of social media in the last decade or so has had a huge impact on people, especially younger people, and their attitude towards image projection. The only supplement I take is vitamin D which I read helps boost the body’s immune system. I do use moisturiser products, but largely because I was told to do so on medical grounds having had to have several cryotherapy treatments on my face. I suspect moisturiser would be a choice for a stay on a desert island!  Getting ready to leave the house I cannot remember my father’s early morning routine as he left for work before I was up. I do remember that his return in the evening had only one recurring routine – a large whisky! My own morning rituals have changed over time depending on personal circumstances and the need, for example, to help get our children ready for school. However, in its most recent form, it included a previous-evening shave (to save precious time in the morning), a cup of tea and a banana with BBC Breakfast television and a shower. On arrival at work, around 6.30am, I liked to have a bowl of porridge and another cup of tea. I was usually the first one to arrive at work and by the time I had eaten my porridge and drunk my second cup of tea of the day I had checked emails and made a start on the first jobs of the day before other colleagues had arrived. I loved the solitude of this first hour of the day. Because I like structure and routine there were usually key parts of the routine at the end of the day. A shower, the donning of loose clothing and a beer with food preparation were important components. In retirement daily routines depend on whether I am volunteering at the local hospice. If not at the hospice I try to have a morning walk. Please post your response to: Freepost: RTGU-AYJE-YSSC, The Mass Observation Archive, The Keep, Woollards Way, Brighton, BN1 9BP (please note that the MOA team are currently working from home and unable to respond to directives sent by post) or by email to: moa@sussex.ac.uk. JS/KP Summer Directive/No. 120
