Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing'. Mass-Observer K7522 describes themself as female; age 67; married; legal manager.;The Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing' was issued on 27 November 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their opinions on and experiences of health and wellbeing, in particular 'health, wellbeing and the healthy body'; 'identity'; 'growing up and learning about health and wellbeing'; 'growing older'; 'health, wellbeing and appearance'; 'getting ready to leave the house'.
Contents: MO K7522 FEMALE AGE 67 MARRIED MORPETH LEGAL MANAGER PART 2: EVERYDAY HEALTH AND WELLBEING Since my retirement in 2017 I have taken a much greater interest in both my physical and mental health. I suppose that I have the time to now, as before I always seemed to have mountains of things to think about, what with work demands, supporting a busy husband and bringing up four children. We also had a period when there were frequent house moves and re-locations, something which brought their own challenges. I would define health as being the physical condition of the mind and body and wellbeing as being the state of that mind and body.  If you care for your health and mental health then you should adopt a process of care (or wellbeing) to ensure that good health is maintained. So what is a healthy body?  I have thought about this a great deal in the past three years as I was diagnosed as Type 2 diabetic around ten years ago, but it took a long time for me to both understand the condition and to take active steps to manage it.  Work and other life events intervened, and I coped with it without really dealing with it.  I was obese and totally failed to manage my diet. I just ate what I wanted when I wanted. In other words, I didn’t take my health seriously at all. However, when it gets to the point when you can’t wipe your own arse because you’re too fat it is time to take stock.  I looked and felt fat. I began to suffer from other health conditions, such as back and knee problems too.  I took hardly any exercise and was often out of breath if I had to walk a distance.  My dress size was a 22 and I just looked like a little round tub of lard.  I wasn’t proud of this, but I didn’t have the self-discipline to do anything about it. Five words relating to health: . Fitness . Contentment . Energy . Appearance . Self-worth When I was unfit my self esteem was really low and my body image was poor too.  I still feel very self-conscious when I look at myself in the mirror, often concentrating upon the bits that I don’t like rather than the parts of me that look good. I don’t like to spend time in thinking about a particular person to whom I can aspire. I just want to be me, and I want to be a healthy me.  I look at some ageing personalities and feel sad that they’ve obviously had treatment of some sort.  You can tell by the way that their face appears to be stuck K7522 with no apparent ability to move a muscle. They look a little like wooden puppets.  There is a lot to be said for growing old gracefully. I still have some way to go but I believe that I’m getting there.  Now I can go into shops and look at clothes for a size 16.  I still want to do better than that but at least I now know that I can reach my goal.  In the past year I have lost two and a half stone and I’m aiming for further weight loss in the coming year. I am no longer obese, but I am overweight.  My general health has improved as a result.  I walk at least three miles a day and usually more without any concerns.  In fact, walking is one of the great enjoyments of my life, especially if we go out to a rural location and I can enjoy the peace and quiet of the countryside. It is good for both my mind and my body and I always return home with the feeling that it has been worthwhile. When I was younger I spent a great deal of time in playing sport. I was never still and right up until the time that I had my first child, aged twenty-eight, I engaged in sport of one sort or another.  After my first baby arrived that more or less stopped totally.  There were very few activities then for women at home to participate in.  My eldest daughter has just had her second child and she participates in things such as yoga and swimming.  There was very little such as that available for me and, anyway, money was tight, and I couldn’t afford to do much. As a child my family was large (five children), and the budget was limited.  Good wholesome family food was the norm but not all of it was what we would now regard as healthy. Mum regarded food (and plenty of it) as being essential and I suspect that nowadays the sort of things which we ate would be frowned upon by some.  It is only recently that I have paid much attention to what I eat and consider whether it is all right for me. The volumes eaten were also much bigger than they needed to be.  The essence was to have full plates followed by (over) full bellies. I remember having a few sessions at school at which we discussed food and its value as well as the dangers of smoking.  My parents were both heavy smokers but none of their five children smoke at all, which is interesting. This was at about the time when the dangers of lung cancer being caused by smoking were brought into prominence. I remember waking up one night when I was around thirteen and finding that I was bleeding. I went into my mother’s room and told her, and she shot out of bed and provided a sanitary towel.  But nothing was explained as such. I knew that I was having my first period and that meant that I could now have babies but that was about it. Mum was more concerned with the practicalities of the event than the causes, so it was all about keeping yourself clean and dealing with the physical side. The big fear for all girls at our school (a small girls grammar school) was of getting pregnant. The Headmistress gave us advice about our behaviour, and we were certainly advised about how we should conclude an evening when we went out with a boy. We were to shake hands and thank them for a lovely evening.  Needless to say not many of us bothered to follow that advice. When my sister and I got our first bra ( we were twins) I remember my dad speaking with a man who delivered eggs to our house and explaining that we were walking around with our arms folded across our chest because we were so self-conscious. I was mortified, although I can laugh about it now. K7522 After I was diagnosed with breast cancer in 2013 I participated in various exercises designed to complement the treatment of chemo and radiotherapy.  These were designed to provide a mental health benefit to cope with the strains of undergoing the treatment which was often unpleasant and difficult.  I wasn’t always convinced, to be honest, of their benefit but it was interesting to experience the options. Some I liked and others felt less convincing. After a couple of years I also had CBT counselling which helped me to explore and understand the impact which the treatment had had upon my mental health. I was dealing with various significant life changes at the time and I needed to understand my loss of confidence and my resentment at the hand which life had dealt me. Understanding it and then putting those lessons into practice was far more difficult.  I was searching for peace of mind and it simply wasn’t there.  I had constant feelings of doom, even when things were good. There was, I considered, bound to be a shitstorm waiting just around the corner to descend upon me.  The interesting thing was that I recognised over a period of time that my mother had the same approach to life and that I was behaving just as she had when it came to dealing with (and living ) my life.  I am gradually getting to grips with that and seeing it for what it is but there are still times when I experience massive anxieties around forthcoming situations, and they can sometimes be in terms of the most trivial things. I know what is happening and I recognise it for what it is but stopping it occurring in the first place has never seemed possible. As I am type 2 I am in regular touch with a nurse at my GP and we are working on a plan to reduce my sugar levels and maintain my fitness through diet and exercise. I have twice-yearly checks at which my weight and bloods are checked, and we discuss possible actions to improve my health.  I should say at this point that the initial action to instigate the plan was from me. I wanted to do it and she has helped me in order to identify positive action to improve my overall health. I found out about the low-calorie approach developed by Professor Roy Taylor of Newcastle and how it lowered levels to the extent that Type 2 diabetes can be managed and maybe even overcome altogether.  I reduced my calories to around 800 a day for some two months and since then have followed a careful diet, avoiding foods with high levels of sugar. My husband has joined me in this regime and, if anything, is now even more passionate about it than I am. I now think of cake as being the occasional treat and not the norm.  I’ve got to like wholemeal bread and I’ve learnt more about recipes and potentials, experimenting more with new flavours and tastes.  I still find myself looking at cookery programmes on the tele and stating that I couldn’t possibly cook that as it is loaded with sugar. I know that when I am fed up there are dangers lurking in that I find food (or rather the wrong sort of food) to be a source of comfort.  I know full well that this is not the answer but every now and again I simply have to indulge.  I always feel horribly guilty about it afterwards though! The forthcoming Christmas period will be a big challenge but I’m hoping that I’ll be able to keep things in proportion and not go too excessive on the treats! I don’t like being placed into a category and being classified according to my age, which is what seems to be the case these days. I can see forty-year olds in the street who are far less fit than I am.  But because I’m 67 that makes me an “old” person.  I am not old, and I don’t feel old. Why is it that everybody has to be put into a box of one sort of another?  It drives me nuts. I take responsibility for my own well-being and I don’t see why others don’t as well. My husband describes those who are K7522 continually critical of health services as “the entitlement generation”.  They have always had what they wanted when they wanted it.  Their view appears to be that having paid their taxes they are now entitled to be looked after, even though much of their health issues are due to their own self-neglect. They fail to take responsibility and that is not right. I believe that I have recognised this now, (albeit a little too late perhaps), and it is right that I try to help myself. I certainly don’t expect others to feel sorry for me. I don’t think that either of my parents understood this sort of thing, but they had quite different circumstances under which to operate. For example, my mum and dad were married on Christmas Day, 1940.  There was a war on, and Dad went off to fight in Burma for a couple of years.  Mum experienced the Blitz and then V1’s and V2’s.  It was a scary time and, of course, there was rationing in place as well.  Small wonder then that, during the fifties, when things began to improve, there was little concern about obesity.  Housework was hard and physical, especially wash day and the effort that that involved.  There was a copper and  a mangle and a lot of heavy lifting! Mum considered that feeding the family was one of her key responsibilities and she’d never had any lessons in relation to balanced meals and healthy eating. As things improved you ate more, and you ate more sugary food as that had been in such short supply but was now freely available. It could be viewed as a sign of increased affluence. I can remember when my mum was pregnant in 1961 that we paid frequent visits to the Baby Clinic and the hospital. After my brother was born we made trips to the clinic for baby milk powder, in a big tin and rose hip syrup (which must have been absolutely loaded with sugar!). I can also remember as a four-year-old at school being given vitamin capsules on a daily basis.  There was also free school milk as well, of course, but I never had that because it tasted disgusting (in my opinion). I am not bothered about beauty products at all and I very rarely buy anything like that. I’ve had the occasional massage which is pleasant enough but it’s not something that I do on a regular basis.  I visit the hairdresser once a month and get a cut.  Every two months I get a colour put in as well. My hairdresser, who I have known for many years, is great and we have a lot of fun in choosing colours.  I like to be different and to have a different look although I wouldn’t say that I go too extreme.  But we have a laugh in trying different things – blues, pinks, reds, and greens have all been experimented with.  But I’m not bothered about being grey and during lockdown there has been little option but to go with it. I have three daughters who all spend time and money on make-up and beauty products. When my youngest got married recently (Covid wedding), I was astounded as to how much stuff they carted around with them.  They have subscriptions to beauty product groups and often experiment with different looks.  I’m afraid that I’m in the “Can’t be Arsed” brigade and I don’t know where they have got that passion from.  Certainly not from me. I don’t wear make-up at all if I can avoid it. Spreading dead spiders across my face does not appeal.  I keep a deodorant and I use body lotion to deal with dry skin but other than that I don’t bother. The only thing that I wouldn’t be able to live without is a daily shower and I’m not sure if that counts. It is quite some time since my mum and dad were in the situation of getting ready for work and I’m trying to remember what the routine was, as there was certainly a routine in place.  I can remember my dad shaving at the sink in the kitchen, putting soap across his face, using a shaving brush to K7522 spread it and then a Gillette razor taking off the overnight growth.  He had a small moustache which remained until the end of his life. Mum would get ready in the bathroom and bedroom.  We didn’t have a shower then and so a wash at the sink was the norm. Baths were taken later, usually at the end of the day. Hair was washed once a week, with occasional trips to the hairdresser.  She used make-up but it was restricted to face powder and lipstick. Mum and Dad rarely went out without one child or another in tow. When there was a special event, such as the annual dinner-dance with my Dad’s firm, she would go and get her hair done and additional make-up would be carefully applied. A long, formal dress was the norm and Dad would be in a dinner jacket/bow tie get-up. I used to love seeing them before they set off as they both looked really grand. They would usually return in a cheery mood, often festooned with balloons which they had collected for us to play with. Now, in relation to myself, I have recently had my youngest daughter’s wedding and it was subject to Covid restrictions, but we still did all of the usual stuff.  My make-up and hair were sorted by professionals engaged by my daughter and I made sure that I chose my outfit with care.  I didn’t wear a hat, but my face mask was colour-coordinated with my dress! I used to wear make-up for work but that changed and towards the end of my role I didn’t usually bother. I’m not sure why, other than that I always used to get to work early in order to avoid the traffic and to have a calmer start to my day.  That didn’t involve much time on make-up and hair.  I shower first thing as I get out of bed and I wouldn’t change that routine as I like to feel refreshed in order to start my day. Now that I’m retired I wear casual clothes and jumpers or tops.  When working I would wear what Marks and Spencer would describe as “business wear”.  Suits, skirts, jackets, and trousers (not all at once, of course!). I was smart but not glamorous. So that appears to sum up my health and well-being attitudes and the things which I can remember from the past.  I remain interested in learning of new approaches and philosophies in relation to a healthy lifestyle, but I think that I approach any new ideas with caution, waiting to be persuaded of their relevance to my situation before I practice anything new.

Keywords: COVID-19 pandemic (2020-);Lifestyle, health and well-being;Physical health conditions;Family life;Schools;Adolescence;Reproductive health;Personal hygiene;Personal appearance;Older people;
Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing'. Mass-Observer S3035 describes themself as 'a 74 year-old male retired banker'; 'married with two grown up daughters, and three grandchildren'.;The Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing' was issued on 27 November 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their opinions on and experiences of health and wellbeing, in particular 'health, wellbeing and the healthy body'; 'identity'; 'growing up and learning about health and wellbeing'; 'growing older'; 'health, wellbeing and appearance'; 'getting ready to leave the house'.
Contents: S3035 I am a 73 year-old male retired banker (born 1947), who ultimately worked in the business banking sector, looking after small businesses, after a career in branch banking. I took early retirement at the age of 50 and haven’t regretted it for a moment. I completed a part-time degree course in Landscape Studies at Sussex University in 2006, obtaining my BA. I live at Southwick in West Sussex, and I am married with two grown up daughters, and three grandchildren, the youngest of whom is 18. I had a heart attack in November 2012, and was fitted with a pacemaker/defibrillator in August 2013. Summer 2020 (No.120) Part 2: Everyday Health and Wellbeing Health, wellbeing and the healthy body Health is being free of illness. Wellbeing is feeling good with one’s lifestyle and overall wellness. A healthy body is one that is physically fit without any disabilities. Fit, young, athletic. Can’t think of anything else. Not a subject I ever think about. Identity I try not to succumb to illness, and am very loathe to take medicines. I am a great believer in the body healing itself with sleep being a big part of this. I generally ignore unwellness and try to work through it. Having said that, I am on medication for my heart, gout and glaucoma as prescribed by my doctor. My attitude to illness was probably influenced by my upbringing when the doctor was only visited (or called in) in extreme cases, otherwise one was expected to ‘get on with it’. Possibly, as a man, giving in to illness could also be seen as a sign of weakness. Growing up and learning about health and wellbeing S3035 I don’t ever remember health being the subject of conversation when I was growing up. It was just taken for granted that one was well, until an illness struck, when it was appropriately dealt with. My mother did make me have a spoonful of ‘Radio Malt’ every morning during the winter to ward off colds, which I called ‘Doctor’s Toffee’. We did have a ‘Newnes Family Health Encyclopaedia’ (which I still possess, but never now refer to), where ailments could be looked up and diagnosed. My health education was probably learnt from this source as I was an avid reader when I was young, although I cannot recall any specific examples. We also possessed a full set of ‘The Children’s Encyclopaedia’ which covered many subjects and which I studied at length. These may have contained medical information. Books were the main source of knowledge in those days, there was no internet to refer to. Other than being examined by the nit nurse, I don’t remember health ever being a topic that was covered at school. I did take biology as an ‘O’ level subject and learnt some anatomy and bodily functions from that, although I was already aware of the basics. Key moments When I was about 10 my body started producing large quantities of semen, which overflowed onto my pyjama trousers causing them to become stiff and sticky. I asked my father what was causing this effect, but I think he was embarrassed, and did not give any answer. My parents did give me a sex education book to read shortly afterwards though, without comment. I did not fully understand it at that time due to my age, but as far as I recall, no discussion of the subject took place. Around this time my facial hair started to grow, and so, at the age of 11, at my mother’s instigation, I started to shave, initially with an electric razor. I also grew rapidly taller, so that during my first year at senior school, I was the tallest boy in my class. My upward trajectory stopped when I was about 14, and most of my schoolmates overtook me, so that I then became one of the shorter pupils. I don’t remember my voice breaking, but it must have been around the age of 10/11 when these other changes were taking place. S3035 S3035 I don’t remember having any particular feelings at these changes. As far as I recall, they were just accepted as part of growing up, and were not treated as anything special. Growing older When I was younger I played a lot of sport, which kept me fairly fit, although I did not do any specific training. When I gave this up in my mid thirties I did try jogging for a while with some neighbours, but found the constant jarring was causing me knee problems so I gave it up. I also belonged to a square dance club for many years which gave me good aerobic exercise every week. After my heart attack, I did some gym sessions organised by the hospital to improve my heart health, but I did not persevere with this. I did take up occasional walking and still did so for about 1 hour a week with a small group, but since the Covid outbreak, I have given this up. I do read the medical pages in the newspaper and watch TV programmes on the subject without necessarily heeding the advice given. However the information received is interesting and allows me to increase my knowledge. I keep a daily track of my weight however, and if it should rise unduly, I curtail my eating to reduce it again. As I have got older, I have become more aware of my body, as various bits start to wear out, and I expect this process to continue, however I tend to accept this as part of life and don’t do anything in particular to stop the process. Health, wellbeing and appearance I am often told how well I look, (probably by people who expect me to look old and decrepit having had a heart attack and because of my age) to which I always respond that looks can be deceiving. When I was young, the over 60’s were generally regarded as old, and usually looked it (often aided by the effects of cigarette smoking), but now people don’t S3035 start to look old until they are well into their 80’s and beyond. There are many more 90+ and centenarians about now. I plough my own furrow, and so am not influenced by popular ideals of any sort, and how people look is down to their own lifestyles and choices and has no effect on my own thinking. I don’t think my parents would have been influenced either, as living from day to day was enough for them. However, having said that, I remember a conversation between them (sitting on a bus at Hove Station on return from holiday in Scotland) when my mother asked my father if he would mind if she died her hair. Surprisingly, he agreed, on condition that he was allowed to grow a beard. Both events happened and my father had a beard for the rest of his life. I don’t use any health or beauty products (other than my prescribed medication) unless you include deodorant under this heading. Never having listened to Desert Island Discs, this question regarding my Desert Island item has no meaning to me. Getting ready to leave the house I can’t say that my parents had any rituals when going out that I was aware of, other than to ensure they were clean and appropriately dressed. I don’t have any particular routine when going out, other than to ensure I am appropriately dressed for whatever activity i am doing, and that I don’t smell too bad. I am not that fussy on my appearance as long as I look reasonably neat and tidy. This has always been the case, and I don’t think my attitude has changed over time.

Living Arrangement Free Text: Widowed in 2017 after 34 years of marriage living solely with my husband (no children).
Keywords: COVID-19 pandemic (2020-);Lifestyle, health and well-being;Family life;Food;Family members;Rural environment;Leisure time and social activities;Nature and wildlife;Emotional states;Schools;Physical health conditions;Reproductive health;Personal hygiene;Adolescence;Partners (personal);Bereavement;Health services and medical care;Voluntary work;Friends;Housing, homes and gardens;Personal appearance;Society and social behaviour;
Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing'. Mass-Observer M7145 describes themself as female; age 64; widow; retired administrator.;The Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing' was issued on 27 November 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their opinions on and experiences of health and wellbeing, in particular 'health, wellbeing and the healthy body'; 'identity'; 'growing up and learning about health and wellbeing'; 'growing older'; 'health, wellbeing and appearance'; 'getting ready to leave the house'.
Contents: MO7145, Female, 64, widow, Plymouth, retired administrator Autumn Directive 2020 Part 2: Everyday Health and Wellbeing Health, wellbeing and the healthy body When I hear the word ‘Health’ I think of what the body needs and what needs to be done to keep it functioning as well as it can within its own limits. It also has the connotation to me, of how precarious good health can be. This is related to my and my family’s experiences. ‘Wellbeing’ I see as a term meaning a person’s overall ability to enjoy life in a balanced way, feeling content, being able to cope with difficulties and challenges with resilience, whatever one’s state of physical or mental health. I think of the words ‘active, strong, slim, nutrition, positive’ when thinking about a healthy body.  The image that comes to mind is a slim, fresh faced happy-looking young female adult in outdoor clothing. Identity My experience of health and wellbeing has been largely influenced by my parents and having access to good healthcare through school, the Armed Forces and work. Much of my parents’ attitude comes from their own family experience and their understanding of good nutrition, the importance of education and appreciation of life.  I was born in the fifties’ into what was by then a lower middle class (I guess), and I identify as being white, female, from a conventional binary family. Spending my formative years on RAF stations within a stable family meant I had more advantages and access to education, sports facilities and health services than many. Growing up and learning about health and wellbeing My maternal grandfather was a nurseryman with a smallholding, and he and my grandmother ran a greengrocery and florist business in the Welsh Valleys. My mother used to say that as a young woman she didn’t really appreciate all the fruit and vegetables that were available to her, even during WWII. She recalls being unimpressed by her father’s rhapsodising about a lovely fresh cauliflower! That upbringing obviously made an impression on her though, as she was an excellent home cook and my sister and I were always encouraged to eat a varied diet with a lot of fish, fruit and vegetables.  I don’t remember my grandfather clearly as he died when I was young, but his influence has been strong in our family.  Ironically, he died from pneumonia, having been a heavy smoker all his life.  His obituary mentioned his generous nature during the 1930’s Depression, when he allowed local families to run up credit in his shop, so that they could eat well. I believe he never called in those debts. From an early age therefore, I had an appreciation that home grown ingredients and cooking were important to health. There were rules too; no sweets until after lunch, no pudding until the main course was finished. Interestingly though, my rather Edwardian paternal grandmother expected my sister and I to eat whatever was put in front of us, yet not to clear our plates completely; a lady would always leave something ‘for Miss Manners’. Inoculations, dental treatments etc were a routine part of my life so I knew of their importance too. As children born in the mid-1950’s, my sister and I had a varied diet and were encouraged to be active and have enquiring minds, outside interests and hobbies. I think coming through the War, my parents understood that it was important to work hard and have purpose in life, but also to enjoy it (what I’d now call a sense of wellbeing) and to make the most of every day.  My mother’s mantra was ‘you’ll never be this young again’. I remember conversations about food, choosing ingredients in the shops, and helping to make meals and bake cakes.  I don’t recall any arguments about food -neither my sister nor I were fussy eaters. My mother was adventurous for her time and our meals were not just meat and two veg, but included things like curries, bircher muesli and yoghurt (I remember our friends back in the 60’s were suspicious of this strange dairy food my sister and I enjoyed). When I was around ten I was horrified when I learned that the boy next door would eat nothing but chips and tomato sauce.  I remember he was overweight and thinking how strange he was.  I couldn’t understand it.  I loved trying all sorts of food and I liked helping my father in the garden to grow vegetables. Although we moved quarters every two or three years in the RAF, he still grew annual flowers and crops and I often had a little patch to grow radish or sweetpeas. There was nothing better than digging up potatoes and carrots, and favourite family meals included gammon with broad beans and parsley sauce or lamb and mint sauce – it was my job to cut the herbs from the garden and make the sauces. We were exposed to different foods and cultures and also opportunities to join activities, on the stations where we lived. Learning to swim in the excellent station pools, school athletics and sports days, caravanning, walking and exploring in Austria, Germany, Switzerland and Italy were all part of my early life.  RAF stations are often located in rural areas and returning from Germany we lived in married quarters in a Cotswold village, miles from anywhere and then later on the edge of a village in Glamorgan. Roaming free as a child in local fields and woods, often on my own, climbing trees, cycling along the lanes and fishing for sticklebacks, were all pastimes I enjoyed. I felt alive and happy when sitting in a tree listening to the wind, or when hunting for primroses in the lanes around my house. That connection to nature has always been quite important to me and even more so as I get older. I also loved reading, whether Jack and Jill schoolbooks, Enid Blyton or Arthur Ransome.  Losing myself in a book still helps me relax. This all sounds as though everything was happy and carefree in my childhood, and although it was wonderful in many ways, it wasn’t always the case. I think my first awareness of wellbeing or rather the lack of it, was when I started primary school and became quite anxious.  I felt sick over breakfast. I couldn’t bear the smell of school dinners so took sandwiches but couldn’t eat them either.  I was an average pupil but worked hard and did reasonably well in tests and homework. Moving schools so often (seven primaries, two secondaries) was sometimes difficult.  The advantage was that all the children were in the same boat and although being the new girl could be hard, I was never bullied because of being the outsider. To a certain extent I became inured to change.  My parents didn’t make a fuss, just tried hard to encourage me and adapt each time and I began to understand the benefits of doing things that made me happy. My mother took most of the responsibility for my health on a day-to-day basis. I am of the generation that was fed rosehip syrup for added vitamin C, and Radio Malt (a dietary vitamin and nutrient supplement that in retrospect was probably too sugary to be much good). Morning break with a bottle of milk was part of the school routine up until I was 14 or 15.  The various schools I attended, encouraged physical fitness in different ways; some with team sports, others with more options.  I liked being outdoors and active as a child but wasn’t particularly sporty or competitive. Hockey, lacrosse, relay races, netball were all sports I did at various times, but I preferred individual activities like javelin, trampolining, swimming and ice skating. I’ve always liked music and one of my earliest memories, despite being about my first school where I couldn’t eat through anxiety, was happiness at being allowed to play the triangle. When ill in bed aged around seven, I listened to the radio and heard the song ‘How much is that doggie in the window’ (that dates me!) I recall distinctly telling my mother I felt much better after hearing that. I enjoyed the BBC radio sessions for primary schools called ‘Music and Movement’.  I loved being able to dance and mime to music, and hearing ‘Ride of the Valkyries’ for the first time and thinking how exciting it was and how good I felt, is a strong memory. I’ve always known that good health has to be appreciated as over the years there have been some family health issues. My father had surgery for a detached retina which in the 60’s meant having to keep immobile for a week or more.  My mother who was asthmatic, had some severe bouts that involved hospitalisation.  Those were difficult and worrying times, and I remember being so upset that I refused to have school dinners or sandwiches again and my poor father had to arrange to come home each day from work to give me lunch. Looking back at how my anxiety was related to my digestion as a young child, I am quite relieved that later in life this didn’t become an eating disorder. My parents’ approach to health and any illness has always been not make a big fuss, take clinical advice where necessary and just get on with treatment. We had childhood inoculations, regularly went to the dentist, seeing the ‘nit nurse’ at school was part of the routine.  Some friends seemed to me to be more cossetted and indulged than my sister and I were, when feeling off colour, but I still felt very cared for by my parents. I recall one incident though, when I had flu, and my mother persuaded me to get up and have a wash because I ‘would feel much better for it’.  When I fainted on the landing, she was so apologetic and concerned. When I was 13, I slipped on mud at school and my ankle swelled up.  Everyone assumed it was a sprain and as it was the beginning of half-term I hobbled around for several days before my doctor sent me for an x-ray ‘just to make sure’. It was a greenstick fracture, and I was in plaster for weeks. I remember being a bit aggrieved at this, but quite proud of not complaining too much. I couldn’t walk far with the cast so took the bus to Girl Guides one evening, only to be told off by the captain for being late.  Perhaps it was that generation with experience of war, that didn’t hold with giving much sympathy. My anxiety had become more tangible when I was around nine and cut my finger and felt faint.  I’d had childhood scrapes before, but this seemed different, like getting an electric shock, feeling frightened and sick and hearing buzzing in my head. I remember putting my head against the cool of the bathroom tiles to try and recover.  That surge of adrenaline and my heart jumping into my mouth, became familiar whenever I was in an anxious situation and it developed into a fear of fainting in public. In fact, I fainted at the altar when I was a bridesmaid at my sister’s wedding. The best man gracefully caught me, I was sat in the front pew and given a drink of water but some of the congregation at the back apparently didn’t even notice. The ceremony didn’t pause, I recovered and the rest of the day went without problem or with me feeling embarassed; again perhaps tribute to my parents’ acceptance, non-judgement and practical steps to deal with a situation.  Later in my twenties I developed palpitations from time to time.  My mother had these throughout her life, and I put it down to something similar and worried that I too might eventually have a stroke or heart failure, as she did towards the end of her life. The episodes are horrible, sometimes short-lived of just a few minutes, but on the odd occasion have lasted several hours and have been quite debilitating. They have eased a little as I got older, but despite some investigations it is only in the last three years that I have been diagnosed with an ectopic heartbeat. This isn’t a threat to health and doesn’t need medication but occasionally causes extra beats that are uncomfortable and worrying.  Now I know those heart blips, the palpitations, the feelings I’ve had throughout my life, are not connected with my mother’s heart failure, I feel much calmer and able to cope. If I had had that knowledge at an earlier age, it would have made a big difference to my life, particularly regarding some of my career and holiday decisions. My whole family’s understanding of the importance of a balanced diet and exercise to stay healthy expanded further when my sister was diagnosed aged eleven, with Type 1 diabetes. She showed great maturity and took responsibility for her own care from the start and my parents never had to intervene to inject her.  Other than going into hospital early to be induced as a precaution when having a baby, my sister has never been hospitalised in connection with her diabetes.  She qualified as a physiotherapist and has been engaged in diabetic research studies throughout her working life and into retirement.  She has recently been part of the Jensen Covid-19 vaccination study.  She now uses the latest technology like blood sensors and insulin pumps, but carbohydrate counting has remained important. Her interest and passion for looking after her own health and wellbeing has served her well and that has impacted on me too.  I think I have a pretty healthy diet, and if buying manufactured food, always read nutrition labels, and my choices are largely influenced by them.  Key moments When I was around nine or ten, I was in a public loo with my mother and sister and asked them what the machine on the wall was for. I recall precisely that they smiled at each other and my mother said ‘in case a girl or woman is out for the day and has an accident’. I thought this meant a car accident but was puzzled as I couldn’t see how little bandages from that machine would help!  My mother was open and not prudish and not long afterwards she told me about periods and her own experiences of puberty.  She recalled having her first period (around 1930) and being terrified, telling her mother ‘I think I’m dying’, being given a folded handkerchief and told to go to school.  When she moved to London just before the War, a friend who was using tampons, had to go to a doctor because she couldn’t remove it.  My mother never used tampons herself and thought her friend who did, was very sophisticated. Living in shared digs, my mother was afraid if she had a bath after one of the male residents, she would get pregnant.  All those experiences had made her determined to tell her own daughters the facts of life.  I decided that having periods (we all called it ‘the curse’) was a hugely inconvenient thing and was convinced that I would be a medical miracle and it wouldn’t happen to me. Another layer was added to my underlying anxiety. What if I did start my periods and it happened when I was out, or in school, or in church?  I was so relieved when I started at home and wasn’t a dramatic thing. Even my father was aware of what had happened, and it was no big deal. I benefited from being the second girl in the family and having my sister to discuss things with.  My mother had provided me with sanitary towels, but my sister gave me tampons to try, which was much more convenient, especially when I went away to school.  I went to all-girls secondary schools so you’d think there would be less worry, but even so I remember praying I would never have to undergo the embarrassment of having to go to the matron or the headmistress’s secretary to ask for an ST. That anxiety of being caught out with a period was with me until the menopause, even though thankfully I was very regular.  I remember being so embarrassed on behalf of a friend at school who had to carry out a chair from the dining room when she discovered as she got up to leave, that she had leaked. I was paranoid about something happening to me like that and always took great care having plenty of supplies and planning trips during periods, carefully.  I would double up on protection and as my last job involved working away from the office in sometimes rural areas, I would avoid setting appointments up on the heaviest days of the month. I worked out my itinerary around public loo stops. I am pleased to see more discussion in the media these days about problems that some women get such as pain, heavy periods, and also period poverty. One of the last taboos.  It’s natural, shouldn’t be a ‘curse’. I don’t remember my mother telling me about sex or intercourse but do recall her saying never to be worried about telling her if I ever got pregnant.  I think she gave me a book to read.   My father wasn’t involved.  I don’t recall specific sex lessons at school, other than an explanation of reproduction in biology classes.  Certainly relationship education was unheard of.  As a teenager, I got a lot of information from magazines like Jackie and later Cosmopolitan and I poured over the agony aunt and letters pages for advice regarding everything from the latest lipstick colours to the pill. Despite having a good grounding from my mother, I always looked for peer advice and experience and being away at school, relied on them rather than her or my sister.  I am not particularly happy about my own body shape and think that began around puberty. Prior to that I had enjoyed being a tomboy, slim and tall for my age.  I was a similar size to my sister and many of my clothes were hand me downs, including my first ‘training’ bra which I think was a Berlei lilac gingham bra which my mother introduced me to when I was around 12. By the time I moved to boarding school aged 14, it was obvious I was going to follow the maternal line and become full-breasted.  I was quite self-conscious about this and when I insisted my mother buy me Triumph ‘cross your heart’ bras as I felt secure in those.  Sharing a dormitory with six or seven other girls meant I got used to undressing in front of others, though we were all fairly discreet about how we changed.  I didn’t enjoy communal showers, although that only happened in one of my schools.  I still don’t like them in public swimming pools and usually leave my costume on. Growing older My attitude to maintaining my physical and mental health hasn’t changed greatly over the years but I am finding it harder to maintain as my weight, level of activity and flexibility change with age. I have always been a fairly healthy weight (8-9 stone) for my height (5’6”) although it started to creep up in middle age until I was nearly 10 stone.  Caring for my late husband took a toll and I dropped back to nearer 9.  After he died, the advantage to eating alone was having to think about what only I liked to eat -so having more fish, vegetables and salads.  But lately I have been baking more bread and cake which has been my downfall. I don’t have scales any more so don’t know what I weigh, but the waistbands don’t lie’. This angers me because I know it is my own fault and lack of self-control. I had to stop my three days a week active volunteering after lockdown and have not done much to compensate for that, yet know I have been baking and eating more. I am still interested in nutrition, enjoy cooking from scratch, grow some vegetables, try to keep active and positive.  I know I am not as active as I should be, but I don’t really enjoy organised sport or gym sessions, unlike my sister who belongs to a fitness club and normally does five or six days a week in the gym, swimming, pilates and badminton.  She has continued with a customised exercise regime, even while shielding. I joined a coastal walking group for a while but it clashed with my volunteering so that finished.  I was attending an Age Uk line-dancing class which I particularly enjoyed but that has ceased for the time being. In the past I enjoyed swimming and horse riding regularly but as pastimes rather than for keeping fit. I haven’t done either for many years.  I’d like to start sea bathing again. I found yoga beneficial, but these days I prefer to meditate at home. I took up formal meditation, using a self-help book and CD, when caring for my husband in the last years of his life  That really helped me and therefore him, to become resilient in coping with his illness.  After getting married, I had compromised to a certain degree with our meals as he was a bigger meat eater than me and wasn’t a fan of salads or vegetables.  After his diagnosis in 2008, I did a lot of research into lifestyle changes to help immunity and our diets became better from that point. He even accepted vegetable juices. I’ve always tried to be proactive in my life and look for ways to cope with my anxiety and improve my wellbeing.  After his death in 2017, I knew I needed some outside help. I had some counselling which I found hugely helpful and rather than going through the NHS, I decided to engage a counsellor myself as I wanted specific help on a family matter and could research local therapists with relevant experience. Joining a bereavement music group was a natural choice for me, as I wanted to retain connection with the hospice that had cared for my husband. Music has remained a consolation.  I also became a volunteer for the National Trust and in the hospice’s warehouse and these roles too, became important in my life and sense of well-being. The group and the volunteering helped me hugely to feel more connected, less alone and more positive than I had before.  I am due to start back with the Trust soon so am looking forward to that. I miss the music and friendship of the music sessions hugely since lockdown and although that might resume eventually, sadly the warehouse has been sold. I am hoping to help the hospice in another capacity eventually. I have walked regularly during lockdown and love being in my local woods or walking along the coast, although not very far. Meeting another widowed friend three times a week during lockdown for exercise has been a lifeline as I often feel a bit aimless. My friend and I have a lot in common, always have a laugh together and benefit from meeting up, even if we might initially not feel bothered about going out. Although I am conscious of trying to stay healthy and active and I do things to help my wellbeing, my tendency to over-think, be self-critical and inward looking, I know probably isn’t good. However, I am never down for too long and being aware of what I need to do, and of what is available to help me, I feel is half the battle.  I am lucky to have access to online classes, advice and even counselling workshops through my volunteering, if I want them. I get some health advice through the magazine from Benenden Health of which I am a member, and also from NHS and Gov.uk websites.  When I’ve needed specific advice, I might do a general online search but concentrate my research on valid sites such as the specialist medical charity advice forums.  I rarely read magazines unless online these days, but they have been useful in the past and I still have yellowing cuttings about anxiety, helplines, facial exercises etc. Over the years in my various jobs, I had access to health services such as occupational nurses, lifting and handling courses, opportunities that I took up whenever available. I take advantage of initiatives like the Age UK/University of Plymouth health MOTs.  I have always used pharmacists as helpful sources of information regarding medication. Going back to my active volunteering will help my wellbeing in terms of feeling useful but as I get older, I know it will be harder to stay active and engaged and maintain a healthy weight.  I have a foot joint problem that prevents me walking long distance and will eventually make maintaining my fairly large garden more difficult.  I know from personal experience of family house moves in later life, that it’s important not to leave things too late, so I anticipate moving to a smaller property in the next ten years.  Yet I value the privacy, views, garden etc that I have now and will be less likely to be active and happy if for example, I move to a retirement flat without outside space. I intend to be open minded about joining a fitness class, or a club where I can swim regularly, as my circumstances change. I am in reasonable health overall and take no medication, and I feel it is up to me to stay independent and as fit and healthy as I can, as long as I can. With experience of caring for my mother, father-in-law and husband I am quite apprehensive about the future, not having any children and not wanting to be a burden to my sister and her family.  I want to plan for the future as much as possible, thinking ahead about supported living apartments, sheltered accommodation and the like. I have seen for myself the positives of finding the right residential care, so that is something that I have thought about for myself too when it might become necessary, though the quality or otherwise, of institutional meals, is a bit of a worry. On one occasion when my husband was in hospital, two other men on the ward (one in his forties, the other in his sixties) were both being cared for by their mothers (in their sixties and eighties respectively)  The patients were both being treated for lifestyle problems and I felt quite annoyed about this. I worry almost as much for the health of the younger members of my family, as the older. Health, wellbeing and appearance I can be quite critical of my own appearance and my feeling of wellbeing is closely related to that, as I know on those days when I’m pleased with what I’m wearing, and how I look in the mirror, I feel positive and happy. However, I have often felt unhappy about my proportions.  Having an appreciative husband didn’t offset the fact that I would have loved to have been small breasted, neat and slim.  I’ve always liked the androgynous look in fashion. I look at other women who have poise, elegance, flair, good bone structure, who all seemed to be the ideal I’ve always wanted.  I’ve never wanted to be the conventional ‘feminine’ ideal – pretty, blonde, long haired, full make-up, dresses and high heels, and I can be critical of women who don’t change their look as they age.  Yet some who don’t, seem to be aging much better than me, like Joanna Lumley.  Other women I admire are artistic and talented, striking and different in terms of style yet still so cool – like Annie Lennox. I see my ageing skin and the drooping jawline and remember my mother bemoaning the same fact as she got older.  When looking around at other elderly women with grey hair and glasses she’d say ‘there’s a lot of us around’.  There still are!  She hated the fact that she had to have most of her teeth out in her fifties and always told my sister and me to look after ours.  She had worn spectacles since a child and blamed them for her ‘piggy’ eyes.  To us of course, she was lovely.  But you don’t see that, when it’s yourself that feels that way and I really understand her now. She was very stylish in her youth and photographs show her with high heels, sharp 1940’s suits, gloves and hats. Her 1960’s evening clothes were just as stylish (I wore a couple of her outfits in my twenties). In her later years, she didn’t have much confidence in her own appearance, despite having a good eye and an appreciation of quality clothes. She knew I lacked the same confidence as a teenager, but told me ‘who do you think is looking at you?’  I think she was trying to tell herself the same. I can be equally critical of others as of myself, and often make judgements about the health of others based on what I see, which is a bit unfair when I don’t know the whole story.  And I am aware that someone who looks slim and attractive (to me) might have a very unhealthy lifestyle, or an underlying health problem, that isn’t visible. I do think though, that people’s demeanour, complexion and weight generally reflect their health. When I see other people walking with difficulty, stooping, using a mobility scooter, looking pale and under-nourished or alternatively over-fed, especially the young obese, I can be critical and wonder why they don’t help themselves to be healthier.  They should be wearing better footwear to help their gait, or using a stick to balance better, and if they only ate better, they’d lose weight and not put themselves at risk of type 2 diabetes etc. And why on earth is that overweight girl wearing those tight leggings? Can she see herself? I wonder what they think of me. I think I am more aware of my physical health than I’ve ever been and that’s partly to do with getting older but also now I’m living on my own, feeling worried whenever I feel off-colour.  I feel more vulnerable to illness and am less adventurous (have had a bike for four years but haven’t gone out on it as I’m worried about having a fall during lockdown).  Although I know I feel better when the anxiety is under control and when I am happy about my appearance, I sometimes find it hard to make the effort to improve those. I have become a bit less attentive to my appearance since lockdown, even when I go out for walks or to collect groceries, although not so much that I don’t change out of the obligatory comfortable at home joggers! I’ve only put mascara on a handful of times in the last year. I decided to grow out my short pixie haircut during lockdown and try a short bob as it would last longer in between cuts, but it has been nearly five months since the last trim and my hair is collar-length and makes me feel old and ungroomed. I see other women with long hair tied in a loose, elegant knot that looks so attractive, but on me, looks messy and too young for my face. I have trimmed my fringe myself and tried hard to make it look good, but often I think ‘who cares anyway’ whatever my hair looks like. I’m still committed to spending money on a decent hairdresser every six weeks or so though (after lockdown) and am looking forward to my first haircut in months, on 17th April. My attitude to my looks has changed since my husband’s death.  He was always supportive whenever I felt unhappy about my image, but I tended to make an effort for him anyway.  After he died, I tried not to look like I was neglecting myself and it gave me something to do, to choose and buy new clothes carefully,  put on make-up etc. Now I don’t really mind if my hair flies all over the place, or my spare tyre shows through my jumper. I haven’t neglected personal hygiene though and the one thing I really do care about, is ensuring I don’t have facial hair as it’s something I associate with old ladies who don’t care for themselves.  I’m lucky in that I don’t have much facial hair and what there is, is fair, but I’ve certainly seen an increase in individual chin hairs!  I know that taking care of oneself contributes to one’s sense of wellbeing so I deliberately do things to relax and have taken to having the occasional bath with fragrant salts (I usually shower). These are the health and beauty products that I wouldn’t like to be without (in addition to a decent first aid kit). I usually buy natural, eco products with minimal chemicals and artificial perfumes. . Toothpaste & brush . Facial moisturiser . Shower gel/soap . Shampoo . Hair conditioner . Aloe vera gel . Mint and lemon balm plants (for herbal tea) . Deodorant (I don’t use anti-perspirants) . Tweezers . Magnifying mirror . Facial hair remover . Nasal sprays, one for hayfever in the summer, another a protective spray which helps to dispel nasal viruses and lessen colds. I was using the latter long before the pandemic. . Bach Rescue Remedy spray.  Although I use meditation effectively to cope with anxiety, I find the activity of placing drops on the tongue is helpful, even though I know this is probably placebo effect. . Moisturising eye drops (I have a dry eye issue sometimes) If it was a choice between any of these for a desert island, it would be the aloe vera gel as it’s a good all-rounder for skin irritations and as a
