Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing'. Mass-Observer J7420 describes themself as female; married; retired local government administrator.;The Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing' was issued on 27 November 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their opinions on and experiences of health and wellbeing, in particular 'health, wellbeing and the healthy body'; 'identity'; 'growing up and learning about health and wellbeing'; 'growing older'; 'health, wellbeing and appearance'; 'getting ready to leave the house'.
Contents: J7420: Autumn 2020, Everyday Health & WellbeingMOno:J7420Female, married, Knaresborough, retired local government administratorAutumn Directive 2020Part 2: Everyday Health and Wellbeing Health, wellbeing and the healthy bodyGood health, to me, means not having to worry, or even think about, bits of your body playing up, breaking down or affecting what you want to do with your life. Poor health means just the opposite; that your day to day life is dogged by things you either must or mustn't do with your body in order to either make things better or not make things worse.Wellbeing is more of a mental state of contentment, so it's possible to have poor health and yet be happy, mainly I think, due to having accepted your situation rather than spending your days tearing your hair out and saying, 'Why me?'Five words to sum up a healthy body: Energetic, supple, pain-free, unmedicated, robust.Person or image that comes to mind: It would probably be one of the presenters of the walking/exploring type of TV series which I enjoy- coastal walks, walks along old railway routes, etc. Julia Bradbury or Rob Bell. Someone with a backpack who's striding out on a sunny day and who isn't averse to a slice of cake or a pint of beer along the way (it wouldn't be someone who lives at the gym, pumping weights in order to have a six-pack).IdentityI'm a bit stumped as to what to write about this. It's pretty obvious that women and men share a lot of health issues but also have others which are specific to their sex. 'Women's troubles' have often been belittled in the past, even when they are having catastrophic effects on the sufferer's lives.And, only last week, black women were talking on Woman's Hour about how they are treated differently and talked down to during their maternity care. How do I know what my experience would have been if I'd been born male, black, gay or posh? I could tell a few anecdotes here, like the male doctor who suggested having a child as a cure for my excessively heavy periods (what a stupid idea, I thought), but a 'different experience' is just speculation. I think I'll leave the analysis to PhD students or medical statisticians.Growing up and learning about health and wellbeingWhen I was four, in 1960, I had to go into hospital with a bone complaint in my hip joints, and I stayed there for 2 years 9 months, in bed and lying flat on my back, strapped to a metal frame. As I have only a couple of memories of my pre-hospital life, I knew from being very young that there was1J7420: Autumn 2020, Everyday Health & Wellbeingsomething wrong with me. I also knew at that age that my parents were different from other childrens' parents as they were both totally blind.IBefore I went into hospital I was looked after by my parents (mostly my mum), and by her older sister who lived with us. This all changed when I went into hospital and my care was handed over to nurses and doctors. This was particularly hard on my mum; that strangers were now responsible for organising my meals, cleanliness, haircuts, dentistry, etc. In the 1960's, whether it was your parents or professionals giving you health information, it was generally given as a series of orders: 'You will wash your hair or you'll get nits' (not true), or ''You must clean your teeth twice a day or they'll decay and you'll have to have them out.' Or sometimes, 'Just do this because I say so.'In hospital, I wasn't told much about the progress of my hip condition, just that I'd be going home eventually but nobody knew exactly when. Actually, Mum and Dad weren't told that much, just that the softened hip joint would spontaneously harden again, this would be visible on one of my six­ monthly X-rays, and then I could go home.My parents had very different attitudes to health and to medical professionals. Mum was more pragmatic about health matters and more trusting of doctors, usually following their advice to the letter. Dad was suspicious of all medics, often believing that they had a hidden agenda - making life easier for themselves, doing experiments on their patients, etc. So when it came to my hip complaint Mum, though initially extremely upset at being told that if they didn't comply I'd develop arthritis and be unable to walk by the time I was thirty, just got on with arranging hospital visits and making my time there as good as possible. Dad was in an absolute rage with the doctors and seemed to think that they were deliberately splitting families up for their own amusement. He wanted to research my condition himself (practically impossible in the 1960's), ask a ton of questions and query their decisions. And when I did develop arthritis at twenty five, he took great satisfaction in saying I told you so - it was all for nothing. By then I was training for a medical career myself and I talked to him about how treatments change over the years and the treatment you get depends on when you're born (by then my condition wasn't treated by hospitalisation and bed rest any more) but he was still very bitter.Mum did overrule Dad on quite a few health matters, most noticeably regarding dentistry. Dad hated dentists even more than doctors, and only went when he was in pain. He had some of his teeth and a partial denture but Mum had full dentures and didn't want me to end up the same. So, against his wishes, she dragged me to the dentist every six months for some quite horrific non­ anaesthetised drilling and filling. A few years after I left primary school, I bumped into an old classmate and was horrified when she smiled and revealed a mouthful of brown stumps. 'This is what happens,' I thought, 'if you don't go to the dentist. Thank you, Mum.'Mum and Dad were also very wary of me having any vaccinations because Mum had lost her sight as a result of a smallpox vaccination when she was a baby. They'd reluctantly let me have my infant vaccinations, but refused to let me have the BCG at school when I was in my teens. I vividly remember one of the girls at school saying, 'You deserve to get TB,' when I didn't go with the others2J7420: Autumn 2020, Everyday Health & Wellbeingfor the jab (I had it later, in my twenties). Problems arose again when I had to have smallpox and typhoid vaccinations for a school trip to the Middle East in 1972. My parents nearly refused those too but gave in when told that I wouldn't be allowed off the ship at Haifa if I hadn't had them. On the day of the smallpox jab, Dad thrust a rosary on me (we weren't Catholic but hey, any port in a storm) and said they'd both be praying for me. I'd been OK up till then but the rosary and the prayers seriously spooked me. There were no ill effects.Up to the age of eight, when I returned to my original primary school, I'd been treated as an unwell, delicate child. When I left hospital I had to wear callipers and learn to walk again, and I went to a school for handicapped children for a year. So at eight, I wasn't very robust, I tired quickly, and I really wasn't prepared for the rough and tumble (and the noise!) of normal school playgrounds.Some of the kids knew where I'd been and made allowances but some just seemed to like fighting and shoving you about.At primary school I enjoyed swimming but the games in the school hall were a bit of a trial. On Fridays, the 'apparatus' was set up in the hall - an adventure playground-type arrangement of beams, ropes, ladders, hoops, etc - and I tried to do all the easy bits, well away from the most boisterous kids. The teachers were OK with me (I think they'd all been informed by the head that I was delicate), it was the other kids that were the problem.One of the male teachers used to organise occasional weekends away, youth hostelling, and I longed to go, not realising how strenuous it would be. My parents, after informing the teacher concerned, eventually relented, but it turned out to be a mistake. I'd had no idea of the walking distances involved and I quickly tired. It became a miserable trudge until the teacher gave me a piggy-back, telling me that all the others would be jealous. I suppose that I was at my walking best from fifteen to twenty five but after the youth hostelling torment, I shrank away from anything that involved being on my feet for any length of time. It was never suggested and never occurred to me that I could have done anything to strengthen my leg muscles but I probably wouldn't have been interested in that anyway.At secondary school we didn't have any sort of health education as such. There was just PE, 'balanced meals' in Domestic Science (healthy... ha! We were being served up spam fritters and jam roly poly for school dinners), and a bit of sex education slotted into Biology classes.School games... oh God. I hated hockey, netball, tennis and running, trying just to not get noticed. Other stuff I just could not do - long jump, high jump, throwing things, vaulting over things.Badminton and swimming were OK. Once again, my parents had informed the headmistress of my medical past and she was supposed to have a quiet word with the PE teachers about me, but our PE teachers changed all the time, the headmistress very likely forgot, and any explaining was left to me, 'Please miss, I was in hospital with my hips for nearly three years then I had to learn to walk again, so I'm never going to be able to vault over that horse.' Well, I didn't bother. Some of the PE teachers were OK and tailored their lessons to what each girl could do but some were hard as nails and just3yelled that you weren't trying! In the sixth form we were supposed to do one session of PE a week, so me and my friends just did comedy volleyball in the gym together and that was actually great fun.In Biology, there was a bit of 'this is what smoking does to your lungs', but I'm not sure how much use it was. The girls who thought smoking was cool and were smoking already didn't listen, and me and my friends just thought smoking was idiotic, smelly and a waste of money and had no intention of doing it.Sex education was thrust upon us in alarmingly real fashion when, in the fourth form, one of our number became pregnant at fourteen. Sex had been explained to me when I was about twelve, not by my mum (who, though quite forthright at explaining some bodily functions, stopped short at spelling out the mechanics of sex), but by my cousin who was eighteen months older than me. I also looked a few details up in the local library. But one of us actually getting pregnant at fourteen was shocking.Just after we all found out, our headmistress came to speak to us at the start of one of our Biology lessons. To call her speech excruciating was an understatement. She never actually said, 'Sis expecting a baby- the rest of you be bloody careful!' she said something like: girls and boys are very different. At your ages when boys are with girls they can get so carried away that they cannot stop themselves. It is up to you not to lead them on. Revealing clothing such as 'hot pants' will excite boys and lead you into trouble.During her speech we were all fighting laughter and as soon as the door closed after her, suppressed snorts blasted forth. Our young, pretty Biology teacher was smirking too and shouted, 'Right you lot, that's enough of that. Back to transpiration.' Saying 'hot pants' was enough to set everyone in the room off for the rest of our time at school.It must have been a year later, in the fifth form, before we had a Biology class chat about contraception. I remember discussing the Pill in some depth (one or two of the girls seemed to know an awful lot about it) and other methods being briefly mentioned but it was all a bit sketchy. I got more info from magazines. Mum wouldn't have talked to me about contraception because she assumed that I'd be a virgin until my wedding night and that was a long way away. She thought I'd be sensible enough not to do 'anything like that' before I got married.The group of friends I had didn't talk much about sex either. I don't know why we were so cagey - fear of giving away how little we knew? And talking with friends about health matters was more about looking good (which shampoo/cleanser? Was thick make-up worth it if it gave you the spots that it was supposed to be covering up?) than about health.Magazines for young girls, like Jackie, were useless for anything practical. They just told you to eat jelly cubes to strengthen your nails and to run your wrists under the cold tap in the loo if you got too hot at a party. To find out anything adult you had to buy an adult magazine which you were meant to be too young for. Then you found out that there was no need to douche your vagina because it4kept itself clean. Phew, that was a relief because I'd no idea whether a douche was something you could improvise at home or something you had to buy from Boots. I don't remember the article explaining that.Key momentsI suppose I'd be about thirteen when puberty hit - the beginnings of breasts, body hair and periods - the unholy trinity (boy, am I going to have fun writing about this horrendous time in my life). Naked showers after PE kept us all bang up to date with how we compared with everyone else in the class. You weren't meant to stare but you looked as much as you dared. So at thirteen I was aware that some girls had no breasts and some had huge ones that necessitated C-cup bras. Some had pubic hair sprouting, some had none. Some had started their periods (no shower and sometimes, no PE).I was desperate for my first bra but there's little point when you're perfectly flat. As soon as I had the slightest swelling, I was off to Littlewoods to try on a selection of 32 AA's. I soon found out that bras were bloody uncomfortable and for decades I don't think I had one that fitted properly. I've spent my life avoiding bras as much as possible. But it was nice to flash your pretty new bra in the changing rooms back then.Unwanted body hair was a worse problem than bras. The message came at you from all sides; to be feminine is to be smooth and hairless in all 'those' areas. Not the pubic area - pubes were normal in the 1970's, thank God. I'd have hated to have grown up in the age of pubic waxing. No, you just kept it tucked away inside well-elasticated knickers and swimming costumes. But underarm hair, leg hair and facial hair... only women who lived in communes or German women flaunted that sort of hair.I don't remember having top lip problems but I did use a razor (a dainty, feminine type) and shaving cream/gel (flowery smelling feminine stuff) on my legs, arms (I had quite a lot of forearm hair) and armpits. I toyed with depilatory creams but they were smelly, messy and didn't always work well, especially on the armpits. Even shaving didn't work well there and I had to shave just before wearing anything sleeveless in public to avoid that stubbly look (then the deodorant often made you scream with pain). It was easier to avoid sleeveless garments altogether. I couldn't understand how dark­ haired women in magazines or on TV achieved that flawless pit-look with no tiny dark spots of hair just under the skin. They must have had some skill that I didn't have.Periods - the worst nightmare of all. Mum had told me a lot about periods (it was a nuisance but meant that you were a woman at last) and my older cousin J actually started her periods when she was on holiday with us. She had nothing with her so Mum went to the landlady of our B&B to enlist her help. Mum thought it was terrible that J's mother hadn't prepared J enough for the great day, so not long after, we bought a sanitary arrangement for me to carry around with me just in case. It was called a Nikini and was a sort of plastic and elastic mini brief with poppers for the pads to attach to. I'd seen an advert for it, told my mum (who thought it sounded very modern) and we bought it together. This was before stick-on pads had appeared in the shops.5I 'started' at thirteen, in the Ladies of a pub where we were having lunch and whipped the Nikini out of my bag like a pro. I was thrilled to have reached this milestone and like most of the other girls at school, whispered 'I've started' to my pals so that the news would get round. But just like the first bra, the euphoria didn't last long. I had very heavy periods right from the start and if you don't compare detailed notes with other girls, you don't realise that you're much further along the scale of period incapacity than most of your schoolfriends. I just thought that they were all managing their periods far better than I was; that they had some instinctive female knowledge of how to cope and that I alone was botching it up. I had to ask my mum for money to buy so many pads and, for one whole week out of four, my life was a misery of constant loo checks, the embarrassment of pad disposal and the terrible fear of 'accidents'. I remember a boy at my church youth club regaling his mates with a story of seeing a girl getting up from a chair and leaving a bloodstain behind. He told this with suitable retching noises and I knew that if this happened to me, I'd want to die- I wouldn't be able to laugh it off or call him out by asking him why he was such a vile specimen of humanity.One lovely girl at school was such a fan of tampons that she gave sample ones away for us to try out. I longed to be able to use them on their own but they weren't reliable enough and, even using the biggest size, I had to back them up with small pads. There were even more accidents with tampons. On a school trip, I leaked while asleep in bed and the next day, sneaked the bottom sheet into the showers, scrubbed at the blood, then slept on a damp sheet that night. Telling the teacher in charge what had happened and asking for her help was out of the question. Pretending nothing had happened was the only option.The misery went on and on and if there were other girls who had similar problems, I didn't know who they were. Maybe they thought they were alone too.I was constantly anaemic and on iron tablets. There was some reprieve in my twenties when I briefly went on the pill but the monthly torture wasn't really resolved until, in my forties, I was found to have such a low blood count that I was admitted to hospital for tests, then fitted with a Mirena coil. My periods soon stopped altogether and it transformed my life. I wished I'd had a coil fitted twenty years earlier.So, to sum up, adolescence was a mess of discomfort, misery and embarrassment and I was bloody glad when it was over.Growing olderWhat have I done to actively maintain my health? Well, I've never smoked (why would you?), never taken drugs (ditto) and only drunk to excess on a few occasions when I was in my teens and very unhappy. I associate being drunk with being miserable and I don't ever want to be in that state again.Band I have never eaten very much processed food or takeaways. Even in our first bedsit when we just had a Baby Belling to cook with, we tried to make proper meals. It still amazes me that some people seem to live on microwaved meals and frozen pizza when omelettes, soup, pasta and6cauliflower cheese are so nice and so easy to make. Having said that, both of us love dairy products, so our diet is high in cheese, butter and cream. I can imagine giving up meat as we are all being urged to do (and Band I definitely eat less meat than we used to) but I can't imagine cutting back on the dairy because theirin lies all the joy and deliciousness of our meals. We also enjoy sweet things far too much. I know we should cut back on cakes, biscuits and puddings but ...Exercise is a problem because I've always had mobility issues and, since I was forty two, had replacement hip joints. B loves walking and I have tried, but it's often been a case of 'I must do this because it's good for me and I'll seize up if I don't', rather than that I'm longing to get out into the country and enjoy some beautiful scenery. I've done some nightmare walks which have turned out to have blocked or unclear paths or unclimbable stiles and I've become very upset and got home in tears, swearing that I was never going to go on any ****ing walks ever again. Now, I only do walks if they've been checked and if they're flattish with good paths. It makes sense.I've had a few mental health issues over the years: anxiety, panic attacks and 'low mood' (I hesitate to call it depression because it's never been full blown depression as I understand it).The first real problem I remember was shortly after my mum's sister died. My lovely Aunty C lived with us; she was like my grandma and she died very suddenly of a heart attack when I was fifteen. For a while afterwards, whenever Mum and Dad used to go out in the evening, I would be gripped by terror that they wouldn't make it home. I would take up position in the living room window, peeking through the curtains, staring at the spot where they'd become visible as they walked up the street. I'd do this for an hour or more sometimes, then when I saw them coming, I'd pick up a book or put a record on and get ready to act nonchalant when they came in through the door.It was another five years before Mum died, also suddenly of a heart attack, but, not being as fond of my Dad, I didn't obsess about him dying too. The 'suddenly being left alone by the one you love' syndrome transferred to my husband and I have never managed to shake off the fear of him possibly not coming home again whenever he's late back from a walk and I'm waiting and waiting. He's got a relaxed attitude to time passing and he doesn't understand why I can't say to myself, oh it's probably a train delay, and just get on with reading a book or watching TV until he appears. It's impossible to explain to a non-worrier that youcan't concentrate on the words on the page due to the many dreadful scenarios playing out in your head. To me, if I stopped thinking like this, it would mean that I'd stopped loving him - that I no longer cared whether he came home or not.After Dad died, when I was thirty four, I began having panic attacks which were related to being out of the house. Many a trip out was ruined by wanting to just go home ASAP, and going on holiday was difficult. I sought help when I had trouble getting to work on the bus one day, then couldn't function so had to come straight home again. I was prescribed relaxation exercises and they did work, though I've remained affected by anxiety to varying degrees. I got back into relaxation and mindfulness when I was having terrible problems at work. I wish I could say that I've kept up with it but I'm afraid it's something I only turn to when in difficulty. I know logically that I should do it all the time as a preventative measure... but I don't. I wait till things are bad.7J7420: Autumn 2020, Everyday Health & WellbeingI get info about health and wellbeing from the internet these days, occasionally from books, though I'm careful not to use dodgy websites or to spend time reading other people's advice. I think there's more harm than good in 'this is what happened to me' chat threads.Am I more or less aware of my body now? Well, I've always had health issues so it's not as if, after a fit and active life, now that I'm in my sixties I've been pulled up short by the ageing process. I can't say that I'm more aware of my body now, as I've always been aware of its shortcomings. I've been adapting to changes all my life and that's just continuing. If I'd been told in my twenties, that from being forty two (when I had my first hip replacements) I'd be using a walking stick, I'd have been horrified - but the stick was necessary to keep active. I've got a sporty-looking German-designed one, and it's just part of me now. Equally, if I'd been told that by the time I was sixty four, I'd have had ten eye operations and lost patches of my vision, I'd have been even more horrified. But it's all happened (and is still ongoing- more eye surgery is lined up) and I've coped up to now. The fear never goes away but I take comfort in the fact that medical knowledge and expertise is constantly evolving in order to help people like me. The thought of my dad's failed retinal surgery in the 1930's haunts me- I'm lucky compared to him but that doesn't mean that I'm not worried about my future. In the future I can't see my attitudes to health and wellbeing changing much. Even if I had some great health scare am I really the type to eat a restricted diet or do daily exercises (or both)? There's a fatalistic streak in me that's saying, what will be will be, so why try and live in a way that feels punishing? I used to be afraid of dying suddenly, like my mum, but now I'm more afraid of living for a long time in an incapacitated state in some ghastly care home, getting more and more crabby (like my dad.) To be frank, I want the laws on euthanasia to change.Health, wellbeing and appearanceYou just can't tell how healthy someone is by looking at them. Some celebrities look fine, then you find out that their lives have been dominated by an eating disorder for decades. Some look overweight but seem fitter than people who are thinner. There are very obvious disabilities and ones which aren't visible at all and which have to be constantly explained to other people (and sometimes the other people don't believe you.) No, you just can't tell.Who isn't influenced by popular ideals of beauty or physical appearance? Even my parents and their blind friends picked up information from sighted people around them as to which film and TV stars were reckoned to be beautiful/handsome and why. Although my parents assessed people using different criteria - their tone of voice, accents, choice of language, whether they smoked, and even their physical slightness or bulk- they were still interested in what people looked like. Mum, who'd never had sight, knew that Sophia Loren with her voluptuous figure and pronounced cheekbones, was deemed to be beautiful in quite a different way to the petite, elfin Audrey Hepburn. Mum also knew that I admired different women to the ones her sisters adored. My Aunty L loved the glamorous Hollywood look, all big hair and make-up that must have taken hours to perfect, while my teenage idols were 'natural' looking women: Carly Simon, Stevie Nicks and Katharine Ross.8J7420: Autumn 2020, Everyday Health & WellbeingIn your teens, you are influenced by popular ideals to a huge extent. You do your make-up and hair and wear the clothes that are in fashion, regardless of whether such styles suit you (or suit anybody, for that matter) because you just want to fit in. One of my favourite comedy lines of recent years is from Derry Girls, when the girls all decide to be 'individual' and daringly turn up at school in denim jackets. On the day, only one of them has actually had the nerve to do this and she furiously stuffs the jacket into her bag, wailing 'I'm not being individual on my own!'Just look at eyebrows. I hated plucking my eyebrows into a thin line in the 70's (the permanently startled look), but it was what you did. Not doing it was another sign that you were hairy and unfeminine. What a relief when it became OK to have proper eyebrows (even if you still had to pluck a bit to keep them tidy.) Then, how I laughed when, decades later, young women began defacing their faces with huge, triangular brows that looked as if two black slugs had landed.This slavery to conform and ignore your own body does fade - well it has with me, anyway. I don't care what the current fashion is for eyebrows but I still spend a bit of time on mine because if I didn't I'd look like Bernard Ingham, all iron grey barbed wire shooting off in every direction. And I still look at other women and think, my God, what are you doing to yourself! The difference is that I don't say (or write) anything much about the crimes against their bodies or their image (other than to my dearest friends) because women are entitled to wear too-tight tops or draw rings around their lips if they want. And l might be accused of slut-shaming or letting down the sisterhood or something.The two health/beauty products I couldn't live without are Neutrogena hand cream and Nivea lip salve, and I take both with me wherever l go. Fortunately, they're both nice and cheap. And if I had to pick one for a desert island, I'd take the hand cream and hope it worked on my lips as well as everywhere else.Getting ready to leave the houseI was a bit bemused by being asked to think about my parents getting ready to go out. They both had few clothes. Dad kept his for ever and wore a succession of items which were very similar but graded according to age and decrepitude. He only got a new coat/shirt etc, when it became an emergency. So the outfit was much the same (tailored trousers, shirt, short jacket or overcoat) whether he was going to work, a school open day or a classical concert, it was just a matter of choosing new or old.Mum did have different outfits for different occasions. She wore old skirts and blouses with a pinny or housecoat over the top for staying in, smarter versions for going to the shops or the hairdressers or out to see her friends or for a meal, and some nice dresses and fancier shoes and handbags when she had a 'do' to attend. She never wore trousers. I used to help her buy clothes and put her outfits together and check her make-up before she went out. She used to say that it was lovely to have a daughter who could advise her like this.9t	IJ7420: Autumn 2020, Everyday Health & WellbeingMy routine? I'll have showered and done my hair that morning, so I'd wash my face again, do my make-up (on autopilot), put on perfume and get changed. I'll have chosen the outfit and probably changed my mind about three times, in my head over the course of the day. My wardrobe ranges• from house-scruffy, through various stages of messy-casual and smart-casual to 'OK for a meal out ina smartish restaurant.' If I ever had to attend a posh 'do' (perish the thought), I'd have to buy something specially and that would stress me out no end. If I ever had to meet the Queen, I'd be mysteriously indisposed with something infectious that might endanger the monarch's life. That would get me out of the dress, the shoes, the hat (aargh - the hat!) and - worst of all - the curtseying. No, no, no.10

Living Arrangement Free Text: I live on a 62' Narrowboat with my husband on a permanent mooring near [REDACTED] on the Trent and Mersey canal, prior to this we had a mooring in Burscough, West Lancashire, before that at Crooke village, Wigan and initially after buying our boat in a marina in Rufford on the Leeds Liverpool canal. Up until 2012 we lived in a house in Westhoughton, Bolton
Occupation 2020 Free Text: Administrator in a haulage and road planing company
Current Occupation Free Text: Administrator in a haulage and road planing company
Partners Occupation Free Text: Low loader driver  in a haulage and road planing company (same company)
Keywords: COVID-19 pandemic (2020-);Lifestyle, health and well-being;Emotional states;Physical health conditions;Food;Sleep;Religion and spirituality;Nature and wildlife;Family life;Family members;Leisure time and social activities;Schools;Reproductive health;Adolescence;Personal appearance;
Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing'. Mass-Observer F7368 describes themself as female; age 47; administrator - haulage industry.;The Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing' was issued on 27 November 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their opinions on and experiences of health and wellbeing, in particular 'health, wellbeing and the healthy body'; 'identity'; 'growing up and learning about health and wellbeing'; 'growing older'; 'health, wellbeing and appearance'; 'getting ready to leave the house'.
Contents: F7368 M-O Number F7368 Gender Identity Female Age 47 Residing Northwich Occupation Administrator -Haulage Industry Autumn Directive 2020 Part 2: Everyday Health and Wellbeing A healthy body in five words – happy, active, fed, rested, spiritual For me a healthy body starts with the word ‘happy’. I believe that if you are unhappy, not just having a bad day, but in your normal disposition, or experience a prolonged episode of unhappiness, it can be detrimental to your overall health. I speak from experience; having had a bad relationship and a job I began to dread. My sleep was interrupted, I developed IBS, my feelings of self-worth plummeted, I was an emotional wreck in an otherwise fit and healthy body. It can be difficult to stay positive all the time but if you find what works for you (for me it is walking, being in nature, cycling and creativity), you should set aside time to do that, and see it as just as important as healthy eating or exercise. Next would be ‘active’. Regardless of your capabilities, I feel it so important to keep moving, walking, running, stretching, yoga, taking the dog out, dancing, cycling, doing the housework. Whatever you can manage within your own limits, just do it, get out there, sweat a little, push yourself even. Rather than thinking of fitness being ‘exercise’ which makes it feel like you should be doing some kind of sport or class, thinking of it as movement or mobility is a better approach. This will also help with maintaining the first word. ‘Fed’, to be well fed -as in a having good diet -is also important. I am a coeliac and cannot eat gluten. Diagnosed at an early age, I have always been aware of reading ingredients, checking what is in my food. I can’t eat a lot of junk or convenience food, so I learned to cook and prepare my own food at a young age. I was vegetarian for 15 years until I decided to introduce fish into my diet for health reasons. I grew vegetables organically in my garden allotment for many years, knowing the provenance of my food has become more important as I grow older. During the pandemic I have prepared pretty much every meal I eat myself, and although I was making most of them before anyway, this has increased the satisfaction of eating a lovingly prepared meal, made to my exact taste with fresh ingredients. Now in my middle age, I fully appreciate the benefits of being ‘Rested’. Having a good night’s sleep can be harder to achieve as you age. I have suffered from interrupted sleep on and off throughout my life. I wasn’t a good sleeper as a youngster and had bouts of insomnia at college. If I’m worried, I will have a bad night, either I can’t go to sleep or I wake up and toss and turn. Developing tinnitus at 18 caused huge problems, I listened to low level music to help me drift off for many years. I truly believe you should listen to your body, when you feel tired or run down, plan an early night. I have recently started to get up earlier in the morning to go for a walk before work (in winter I feel I don’t get enough time outside in the daylight as I work in an office) and I think this has a triple benefit, more exercise, helps with my feeling of wellbeing and makes me ‘good tired’ (as in physically tired through being active, rather than drained which is ‘bad tired’) at the end of the day which can aid sleep. When people think of the word ‘spiritual’ or ‘spirituality’ I imagine they would connect it to religion at one end of the scale and ‘hippy nonsense’ at the other. To be honest, both are fine with me and everything in between. I am not religious, but I come alive in nature. I connect. It makes my spirit soar to see a buzzard circling above me on a walk, to see the majestic colours of a sunrise. I do an hour of yoga once a week followed by a relaxation where I have regularly had an almost ‘out of body experience’. I feel calm and restored afterwards. I embrace all these opportunities to tune into F7368 myself, my spiritual side. Maybe some people wouldn’t equate this to being healthy but, to me, it completes the circle to be healthy in mind, body and spirit. Growing up my mum was always trying the latest health fad or diet. From the vibrating belt in the 1970’s to red and green days diets in the 1990’s, she spent decades (and no small fortune) on contraptions and subscriptions, none of which were successful. There was always some unused contraption gathering dust in their bedroom, that had promised to work miracles on your abs, bum or tum, but never delivered as she simply didn’t have the commitment. I don’t remember her as being particularly overweight as a child but in my teens, and her forties, she ballooned. At her heaviest she was wearing size 22 clothes. Eventually she was diagnosed with an under active thyroid and after medication had helped right her metabolism, she lost the weight steadily over four years and never regained it. Prior to this, it was the search for the quick fix. She had always been ‘big’ since childhood, in her opinion, and I think this had an effect on her mental health over the years. A constant struggle with her weight and unhappiness with her appearance made her prone to periods of depression and anxiety that culminated in a hospital admission. She simply stopped eating and wouldn’t get out of bed. My Dad was, and still is at almost eighty, a very active person. He was a television engineer by trade, and he would also do repairs at home in the loft conversion of our bungalow, carrying huge tube television sets up the extendable ladders. Eventually working for himself, he was putting in fourteen-hour days, every day. He did a bit of cycling, was involved with a local scout group and helped the work parties at their camp, building huts, chopping down trees. He never stopped, and although he has had two major heart surgeries in his fifties, then seventies, he is still out every day, chopping wood for his wood burner, building cabinets, shelves, little projects for friends and families, painting, decorating, he is an accomplished clay pigeon shooter, hefting a shotgun up, taking the kickback in his shoulder. I am in awe of him. As a family, we were never very active together. My mum taught me to swim from a very young age and I remember she took me to the swimming baths every Sunday morning up to around the age of seven nor eight. The mismatch of my parent’s interests and my Dad’s work meant we spent very little time together. I would holiday with my Mum in a family friend’s caravan while my Dad carried on working, we simply couldn’t afford him not to be working. We would walk our dog along the beach, and I would swim in the freezing brown water. Occasionally we would go for a day out, I called it the family fall out as we all irritated each other in close quarters of the car, but it would rarely involve anything physical, more a visit to somewhere, a look round the shops, a cafe stop. They once decided, on a whim, to visit a local nature reserve on the way home from a family get together and there was a warden doing guided trips. I was dressed in a bright yellow jacket, not having been prepared for the impromptu bird watching and the look of disbelief in my attire that the warden gave me has never left me. At school, health was called sport. It was called swimming (which I was ok at) and badminton, running, gymnastics, hockey, netball, rounders, and all the others you can think of (which I was not). As a girl it was never football, cricket our rugby. I decided at an early age that it was just not for me. If you didn’t excel at any of the above, you were discounted. No other alternatives offered. Picked last for everything, laughed at. When we did the occasional cross country running through the local park, I would call at home and have a brew with my mum as we lived close to the school, tag on at the back as they looped back past the house. I hated sport. We had home economics where we learned how to make a pineapple upside down cake and biology where we learned embarrassing things about our bodies. None of these were ever connected together. Wellbeing hadn’t been invented then. Puberty was an awful time. There seemed to be huge importance put on starting your periods as early as possible (I was late at 14). I never had much of a bust. I was uncomfortable in my skin, I had puppy fat and the memory of all those redundant exercise contraptions. I needed to be thinner, prettier, with big breasts, have long blonde hair, taller, sportier. I was none of these. It wasn’t until I was around 15 and met some different people, who listened to different music and F7368 wore goth style clothes and make up that I began to be happy with my appearance. I died my hair black, wore black eyeliner, boots and fishnet tights. I stopped caring what my peers at school thought. I had my own identity. I didn’t need to conform. When I left home and started work, I started swimming again. I think I had always enjoyed being in the water, but I also began to feel the buzz of pushing myself physically. I swam for an hour; I swam a mile. Later I would try running but this didn’t suit me, I kept getting little injuries. I joined a gym and started doing classes, mainly spin class but also pilates, yoga and some circuits. I never considered myself a ‘gym goer’ but until the closure of gyms last year I has been a member for over 15 years. I did enjoy the convenience of a led class, over quickly, done and dusted straight after work. I would get home and feel energized and tired in equal measures. Then, in my early thirties, I got a bike. This has to be the defining moment in realizing that exercise (sport even) is for me. I felt at one with my bike. I got a better one, a mountain bike and would go riding up in the local moorland. With my husband, who had been a keen cyclist for years (I had resisted), we went to trail centres, to the lakes, wooded cloughs and rode. We rode some of the Pennine trail in mid-winter, nearly breaking ourselves, we went to Majorca with our road bikes, we went to France and followed stages of Le Tour. I had found my perfect exercise, my happy place. Fitness and wellbeing followed but it was for the pure joy of riding that I did it. The good outcomes were a bonus. Now, in my late forties I still ride, but I do a lot more walking. We live on a narrowboat so there is always a ready-made walk straight from the door. This year I have started to walk in the morning before work for half an hour. Getting up in the dark and walking back to the sunrise helps both physically and mentally. I also walk most lunchtimes, do an hour of yoga once a week and try to get out on my bike at weekends in the winter. In the summer I ride two or three times a week. I am probably more aware of my body now but in a different way. I don’t aim for thin, I want to be strong, supple, active. Living on a boat means physical work, pushing a wheelbarrow full of shopping down the towpath, pulling on ropes, working the locks. It my aim to be able to do these for as long as possible. Like most people, I access the internet to research about health and nutrition but in all honesty, I don’t really do very much of this. I know enough about a healthy diet from past experience and I don’t overly concern myself with new trends or fads. I know what I enjoy, what I should do in moderation. I drink but try to be sensible, I no longer smoke having given up in my early thirties. I don’t eat meat, only fish. I prepare most of my own food from scratch, sharing recipe ideas with a colleague at work who shares the same interests in healthy eating. I am physically active every day. I don’t have any beauty regimes as such, I don’t wear make up. I developed exercise induced asthma (probably as a result of smoking) when I had a brief go at running and so I always have my inhaler with me (thankfully I don’t have to use it very often). I don’t do much with my hair (super curly). I think I’m pretty low maintenance. Apart from a bit of moisturizer, I do very little to prepare myself before I leave the house. My mum would always pop a bit of eyeshadow on before going out but she was never really one for getting ‘dolled up’. I’m not sure of my Dad ever looked in the mirror much! Regardless of their faults, my parents never put much importance on what you looked like. This was not where a person’s value came from. I have, from time to time, fallen victim to thinking I should look a certain way, and as I age, I see my face change, my skin crease and line, my body become less firm. But I have managed to stay happy and healthy though a mixture of exercise, diet and not worrying too much about what other people think.

Keywords: COVID-19 pandemic (2020-);Lifestyle, health and well-being;Society and social behaviour;Health services and medical care;Pregnancy and early maternity;Family life;Schools;Adolescence;Reproductive health;Personal hygiene;Mental health;Personal appearance;Family members;Leisure time and social activities;
Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing'. Mass-Observer T7345 describes themself as 'a 36-year-old female living ... with my partner, our son and my partner's brother. I am a social worker by background, and currently work for a charity that trains graduates to work as mental health social workers.';The Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing' was issued on 27 November 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their opinions on and experiences of health and wellbeing, in particular 'health, wellbeing and the healthy body'; 'identity'; 'growing up and learning about health and wellbeing'; 'growing older'; 'health, wellbeing and appearance'; 'getting ready to leave the house'.
Contents: I am a 36-year-old female living in Leeds with my partner, our son and my partner’s brother. I am a social worker by background, and currently work for a charity that trains graduates to work as mental health social workers. My job involves setting up and overseeing the trainees’ practice placements in community mental health teams. My MO number is T7345. Health, wellbeing and the healthy body What does “health” mean to you? What does “wellbeing” mean to you? How do you define these words? I find it hard to separate my definitions of these two words. They both make me think about freedom from illness (physical or mental) but also something more positive than that – my body and mind feeling generally good and being able to respond positively to challenges, whether that be a more strenuous session of exercise or a mentally or emotionally taxing period in my life. I think of health as something that can be present or absent, a positive or a negative, in good health or in poor health – whereas I see wellbeing a positive concept that everyone has more or less of at different points during their lives. What do you think about when you imagine “a healthy body”? Please share the first five words that come to your mind when you think of this term. Fit; strong; eating well; sleep; resilient. Is there a particular person or image that comes to mind? Please describe, or draw, this person. I think of times when I have been really enjoying a run, muscles fully warmed up, in a nice rhythm, feeling like I’m absolutely flying. Identity How do you think that your own experience of health and wellbeing has been influenced by your gender, ethnicity, social class, or sexual orientation? Do you think your experience of health has been influenced by these or other aspects of your identity at all? Gender: The impact of my gender on my health and well-being feels multi-faceted. I believe strongly that there are huge pressures on women in terms of their body shape and physical appearance, and have seen these pressures have a significant impact on many of my friends’ self-esteem and lifestyle choices. However, my body shape is slim and remains so without too much effort from myself, leaving me privileged in terms of the match between my appearance and how society expects women to look. I feel that this match – which I perceive as more to do with genetics than anything else, given the resemblance to my mother’s body shape -has contributed to the fact that I am pretty body-confident. A little while ago I read a book about women and sport – and more specifically, the barriers that women experience to exercising regularly. This book was a bit of a revelation for me, as lots of the structural issues that the author identifies felt very relevant to explaining why I didn’t exercise regularly and reap the health and well-being benefits of this during much of my teens and twenties. Finally, I think societal expectations around female behaviour have contributed negatively to my mental health over the years in ways in which I am only just beginning to understand and unpick. Women being socialised to support others, to disregard their own needs, emotions and preferences, not to speak out … these are patterns of behaviour that I recognise in my own life and that have not contributed to my good mental health. Ethnicity: I have thought about this a lot more recently, further to different discussions coming out of the Black Lives Matter movement after the murder of George Floyd and the disproportionate impact of Covid-19 on BAME people in the UK. I am white, and have become more aware this year than ever before that my experience of the National Health Service as largely efficient and supportive is part of my white privilege. One statistic that crystallised this for me is that black women in the UK are five times more likely to die in childbirth than white women. I became a mother in 2019, with amazing support from the midwifery and obstetrics team at the hospital where my son was born. This statistic really drove home to me the inequalities that exist in the UK today around access to effective and sometimes life-saving healthcare. Social class: My financial status and social class definitely impact on my health and well-being. I have the time and money to commit to eating healthily, exercising and resources to support my mental health (self-help books, meditation apps, therapy if required). Within my social circle, I mix with others who are in a similar position, which helps to motivate me and affirm the importance of looking after my body and mind. Sexual orientation: I’ve never thought about this one, likely because I belong to the privileged or normative group in terms of sexual orientation (heterosexual). I’m aware however of times when gay friends have felt disadvantaged or discriminated against when seeking healthcare support, and am aware that I don’t face similar barriers of discrimination or omission as has been the case in their experience – which can only have promoted my health and wellbeing. Growing up and learning about health and wellbeing When and where did you first become aware of “health” or of “wellbeing”? Health feels like a concept that I’ve always been aware of – because perhaps because one of its opposites, illness, is something that one experiences quite a lot of in childhood (colds, ear infections, viruses etc). Wellbeing feels like a much newer concept that I’ve only heard discussed in the last few years. Who had responsibility for looking after your health and wellbeing when you were younger? My parents. Do you remember your parents, or other caregivers, talking to you about health? If so, what did they talk to you about? Where did these conversations take place? Only in snatches. I remember for example my dad telling me all the different reasons why it was important to clean my teeth – to avoid toothache, so my teeth would look nice, so my breath would smell good … I think in their behaviour they showed me different ways in which they valued health and well-being, however. For example, we always went out for walks at the weekend, which I think was linked to their belief that exercise and being outside was good for all of us in lots of different ways. My mum ensured that we got our feet measured regularly, had all our childhood vaccinations and went to the dentist as often as was recommended. Did you receive any education about health in school? And/or did you learn about health and wellbeing in other ways – from friends, magazines, or the internet, for example? Again, I only remember snatches of health education at school. A scary video about the dangers of using illegal drugs – a bit of sex education (I don’t really remember the content of the lesson, more the novelty that our parents had to sign a disclaimer so we could attend.) I read magazines like Just 17 when I was a teenager which I’m pretty sure had content about health. And there were community resources – I went to a youth health organisation when I became sexually active and wanted to start taking the contraceptive pill, for example. Key moments As an adolescent, when did you first become aware of bodily changes associated with puberty? I remember my mum talking to me about periods. We must have been on our own in the house as I was having a bath without the door locked, and she came in and asked if I knew what a period was. I said that I thought it meant that you bleed when you have a wee. I know that she explained it in a bit more detail than that (!) but I can’t really remember what she said or how old I was (probably quite young, if I wasn’t locking the door when having a bath?) Are there any moments or rituals that you think are particularly important for young women or men? These might include, but are not limited to, first period, voice breaking, buying the first bra, or shaving, for example? How did you feel about these moments if/when they happened to you? I remember having my first period, and being excited about changing my sanitary towel because of the novelty of it. I remember it was difficult at school to change sanitary towels at each break/lunchtime as not-so-nice kids hung around in the toilet and would notice if you kept going in there and make sarcastic comments. I don’t remember buying my first bra – I think maybe I went with my mum to Marks & Spencers to get it fitted? – perhaps because there was a fashion when I was a teenager to wear crop tops before you really needed a bra so the transition to bra didn’t feel like such a big deal. One moment I remember as being particularly difficult was shaving my legs for the first time. I felt really embarrassed that my legs were getting hairy and that other girls might notice in PE, but also found it hard to pluck up the courage to ask my mum for support to buy razors and shaving gel and to show me how to do it. Growing older Throughout your life, what if anything, have you done to actively maintain your health both physically and mentally? Has this changed at all over the years? If so, was this due to a particular event in your life? In recent years I feel like I’ve done much more to maintain my health, both mentally and physically. One important factor is my current relationship, which began in 2015. My partner has always exercised regularly, and being with him motivated me to do the Couch to 5k programme so we could run together. Running is now a regular part of my life and my main form of exercise. He is also vegetarian and more mindful of healthy eating than I had been prior to meeting him. A few years into our relationship, when my meat-and fish-eating had dwindled substantially, I decided to become vegetarian too. I am also more thoughtful about my mental health now than was the case when I was younger. I try to meditate and write in a journal regularly and also listen to podcasts and read material about mental health, happiness and well-being. I try to use ideas from these materials to enhance my happiness – for example taking time every day to note three things I am grateful for. I can’t put my finger on what has motivated me to do so in the same way that I can identify that being with my partner has helped me to improve my physical health. I think at some point I realised that working on one’s mental health isn’t an activity confined to people with a diagnosed mental health condition – we all have mental health which can be better or worse at different points, and we can all do things to protect and promote our mental health. I also realised in my late twenties that I was finding some aspects of my life harder than I needed to, and that maybe this wasn’t inevitable and was something I could work on. The success I had at this point in understanding myself and implementing strategies to feel better and happier about my life gave me the motivation to continue this sort of reflection and ongoing quest for better mental health. Where do you get information about health and wellbeing now? NHS website; GP. Would you say you are you more or less aware of your body now? Why do you think this is? Probably less aware of my body than I have been for a while. When I was single and dating I was more conscious of my body as a object of desire to potential partners – and then more recently I was trying to conceive, then pregnant, then breastfeeding, all of which made my body very present to me. These periods of my life being over means that at the moment I think less about my body on a day-to-day basis. In future years how do you expect your approach to health and wellbeing to change? I don’t have a very detailed answer to this question. I’d like to continue with the things I do at the moment to promote my health and well-being, and in particular to make running a bigger part of my life and to do some longer-distance races. Moving into middle age, the menopause and older age, with the possibility for my body to become more infirm, feels like a long way away at the moment and not something I can imagine. Health, wellbeing and appearance In your view, how are health and wellbeing related to external appearance? I see this relationship as not at all straightforward. External appearance -and judgements that follow from this about an individual’s health and well-being -is often judged by how closely the way they look resembles a popular ideal. I feel like these judgements are often flawed – saying that because a person looks a certain way they must be healthy or unhealthy is objectively not correct. An obvious example is weight – while there are some health risks associated with being very over-or underweight, my understanding is that the relationship between whether a person looks fat or thin and their overall health is much more complex than the simple thin = healthy / fat = unhealthy assumption that permeates our culture. Have you ever been influenced by popular ideals of beauty or physical appearance? Without a doubt and probably in many more ways than I am aware, as I think these ideals are so omnipresent and pernicious in our culture for women in particular. One particular example that I am aware of is that I felt really pleased and a little proud when my body returned to its pre-pregnancy shape quite quickly after I gave birth to my son. It annoyed me that I felt this way, as this response ran so counter to my values and to my knowledge of what is entirely normal in women’s post­partum bodies. The only explanation I can think of for my emotional response is that it was informed by popular ideals about female body shape which I have absorbed. Do you think your parents were influenced by these kinds of ideals? If so, in what way? Something I’m really appreciative of is that I don’t feel my mum paid much attention to ideals of beauty or physical appearance, and it was certainly never something that she made a part of my childhood. Girlie dressing up games and Barbie dolls were not something that she encouraged and I never heard her speak negatively about her body or anyone else’s body. I think this was hugely important in fostering a sense of body confidence in me that has lasted until this day – in comparison to some friends who were very aware of their mothers’ concerns about their own body or their daughters’ bodies, concerns that had a lasting impact on how my friends viewed their own physical appearance. Are there any health or beauty products (excluding medicines) that you couldn’t live without? What would be your Desert Island item? Moisturising cream and lip balm Getting ready to leave the house Do you remember your mother or father getting ready to go out for work, or for the evening? If so, can you describe their rituals? I don’t remember much about this, but I remember my mum always wearing jewellery when going out for the evening and me playing with her jewellery as a little girl. What is your own routine when getting ready to go out for work or for socialising? Has this routine changed over time? My routine has definitely changed over time. In my twenties I would always wear make-up for work and definitely for socialising and would also often dry straighten my hair. Now I very rarely wear make-up so my routine is shower, deodorant, moisturise, hair product to make my hair curly, watch/jewellery – and that’s it. When going out for a night out with friends in my teens and twenties we would often spend a couple of hours getting ready together – having a few drinks and a natter as we did our hair and make-up. Sometimes this was the most fun bit of the whole night for me, just hanging out, catching up and pampering ourselves. It feels a long time since we have been able to do this, what with my pregnancy and then the pandemic, but I’m really looking forward to being able to spend time like this with my girlfriends again.

Mass-Observer B7287 describes themself as female; age 40; married; wine and spirits advisor.;The Directive 'COVID-19 (Update)' was issued on 27 April 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their experiences of the COVID-19 pandemic, in particular 'health'; 'the government'; 'news'; 'work and home life'; 'technology'; 'shopping and food'; 'entertainment and leisure'; 'personal hygiene' and 'sleep'.
Contents: B7287 Female Married Basingstoke Wine & Spirits Advisor Spring Directive 2020 Part 2: Covid19 Update Health I live with my wife. We are usually pretty active, and so the lockdown rules regarding exercise outside of the home were hard to swallow. That said, our physical health has not suffered too much. We have walked, plus have a skipping rope and a mini step machine at home. We have not required any medical or professional help during this period. Our emotions have been up and down. It is hard not being able to see family, especially since my father recently had CV19 (recovered, thankfully) – I just wanted to be with my mother. Most of the time, emotionally, it’s ok. It’s only when we really start to think about what a crazy situation we’re in it becomes harder to manage. Neither of us have had panic attacks, but we have found it both stressful & hysterical, on and off. Difficult to describe. The Government I am in utter despair. I don’t believe they have made one good timely decision, and I absolutely distrust everything they say. I believe that they will re-open the economy too soon – relax the lockdown rules, I mean. I think we will see further cases. News I have tried not to look at the news too much – see ‘despair’, above. I look at The Guardian online, and Twitter, to get a general gist. We have not been watching the daily 5pm briefings. Mainly because it doesn’t suit us to, and also I don’t want to because I can’t believe a word that anyone at one of those podiums says, and I find their answers to be non-answers and it makes me frustrated and cross. I don’t know anyone who struggles to access the news. I think it is a good idea to be more inclusive, and I fully support the presence of a BSL interpreter. Work & Home Life I was furloughed during April. I was brought back to work (from home) at the beginning of May. Being furloughed was tough – my wife has been too, but she will be going back to work from next Monday 18th – but I managed to create a new routine – some exercise, we did some jigsaw puzzles, reading, writing. Even gardening. We usually take our walk in the evenings, which is a nice end to the day. Working from home is ok. I have a good set-up and I am in contact with my team and other colleagues via Teams daily. There are no children in the house. I couldn’t imagine having that additional pressure. My wife and I are enjoying spending so much time together and have generally found much to laugh about. We have shared ‘socially-distanced’ drinks with our neighbours over the back fence. The sunshine during April helped a lot. Technology We had already been using Teams at work, but it has been a really useful tool for keeping in touch with my colleagues – both in my immediate team and throughout the company. I use Teams to chat with a small group of friends every fortnight or so – this has been initiated since the lockdown. Wife & I also use Teams to talk to her siblings every week or so. I was using WhatsApp anyway, but now have been using it for video calls a bit more – mainly to the same group of people that I message; it is nice to see faces. I have just started using Zoom. My mum likes it because she can use her laptop and see us on a big screen, rather than on her phone (smaller) via WhatsApp. I am only using Zoom with my family. I have not reconnected with anybody. I am in touch with the people I want to be in touch with, and I don’t feel obliged to reach out. I dislike Facebook, and my use of it has not changed. Ditto Twitter, although I use it now to escape from everything as well as to see the news. There are some funny things on Twitter. Shopping & Food I have driven to Big Sainsbury’s once every fortnight since lockdown began. At first it was very strange – dystopian – and there wasn’t much available. My third trip was yesterday, and it seems much more ‘new normal’ although there are still some items in short supply. I have not had any trouble finding what I need, however, and even if there was I could do without or find alternatives. The bigger supermarket is a weird experience. I haven’t enjoyed it much. One feels almost criminal. I have glanced at online shopping, but there are no slots. During the week we top up our shopping – milk, fresh fruit & veg – at the little Tesco Express down the road. I go early in the morning (0620hrs or so) when it is quiet. We have been planning our meals more, and also using food we have – tinned food and food from the freezer. Our habits have generally stayed the same. Entertainment & Leisure I have been blogging – I started a blog at the beginning of my furlough leave. And I have been continuing to learn French (using Duolingo), which I had already been doing since the start of the year. I have done some alternative exercising – I am used to going for runs, or taking more walks – so I now do skipping in the morning, and some steps on the step machine at lunchtime. We have been doing more gardening – wife painted the shed, and we trimmed the bushes in the front garden. Our DIY skills are limited… We both read a lot – I am reading a wine book, currently, alongside Elton John’s autobiography. Wife is reading some fiction alongside Cathy Newman’s Bloody Brilliant Women. I have been listening to Jameela Jamil’s podcast, I Weigh. Wife has got audible. We listen to books together (The Secret Barrister’s book at the moment) and she has her own books she listens to as well. When it all gets too much, we watch some silly movies. We watched all three Pitch Perfect movies recently, and Finding Dory as well. On Netflix we watched Wanderlust, Dr Foster, and currently, After Life. We have got Pose on the go, and a few other things that we dip in and out of. We have a lot of Poirot recorded off the telly. They are terrible but they do the trick, sometimes. For laughs, we watch Brooklyn 99. Personal Hygiene We both shower every morning, wash our hair when it needs washing, and get dressed in proper clothes. I still put on a little eye makeup because I think it makes me look a little less haggard. Neither of us have been wearing our bras. Why would we? As far as I can tell, our personal hygiene habits have not altered. Sleep I am a terribly sleeper anyway, so I don’t think my sleep has been any different. I don’t think my wife’s has either. We both have work-based anxiety that is different from CV19 anxiety – work stuff occasionally keeps my wife awake, but on the whole our sleep is no different. I rarely remember my dreams, sorry.

Mass-Observer W3163 describes themself as age 63; retired; married.;The Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing' was issued on 27 November 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their opinions on and experiences of health and wellbeing, in particular 'health, wellbeing and the healthy body'; 'identity'; 'growing up and learning about health and wellbeing'; 'growing older'; 'health, wellbeing and appearance'; 'getting ready to leave the house'.
Contents: M.O. No. W3163 Age: 63. Occupation: Retired. Location: St Gennys, Cornwall. Marital Status: Married Date: 11th March 2021 Subject: Everyday Health and Wellbeing Health, wellbeing and the healthy body I think of health as being free from illness, and pain injury and wellbeing more as a state of mind; as healthy, happy and comfortable. If you’re in pain, injured or ill you’re wellbeing is likely to be detrimentally affected. Five words – weight; fitness; nutrition; sufficient sleep; fresh air. Images of people who are said to be fit and healthy always depict super slim, super fit people. This can make us mere mortals feel a little uncomfortable or inferior as it’s not the norm and unachievable for a lot of people for various reasons. To my mind, the adage of ‘moderation in all things’ is an appropriate approach. Identity I can’t help but wonder what gender, ethnicity, social class or sexual orientation has to do with a person’s health – it certainly has nothing to do with mine. Wellbeing could be affected if you are unhappy or uncomfortable with any of these things but that is an entirely different case and as I don’t have any issues with any of the above mentioned they don’t affect my wellbeing. Growing up/learning about health and wellbeing Health and wellbeing are things which have never been at the forefront of my mind. It seems to me that it’s something which has become an ‘in’ thing in more recent years – possibly due to advertising of products and supplements which are supposed improve your health and appearance. W3163 As a child my parents had the responsibility of taking care of me – after all that is part of the roll of a parent. Health was never a subject of discussion at home or school and I don’t recall it being something that was talked about among friends or school pals. It’s still not something that exercises my mind. Key moments I suppose I first became aware of bodily changes around age 12 or so. I can’t think of any specific moments to talk about here. You know you are going to grow into an adult and if things didn’t change that would be something to be concerned about. Growing older I think it’s obvious by now that this is not a subject I spend any time thinking about. I’ve always been physically active and that’s because I enjoy it, not because I’m concerned with my health. Health, wellbeing and appearance I’m not sure health and wellbeing are related to external appearance generally save to say that if someone is obviously overweight it’s likely they will have other related health issues. I don’t follow any ideals of beauty, as the saying goes ‘beauty is in the eye of the beholder’. My mother was and to some extent still is very vain and always had to have what she considered stylish, fashionable clothing and makeup. Clearly I didn’t take after her! Items I couldn’t live without; nail clippers and or files. I hate long nails. Getting ready to leave the house I don’t go to work and haven’t been out socially for a year now!! But I don’t do much if I do go out – probably just comb my hair! I used to wear eye makeup but a long time ago.
