Mass-Observer M7490 describes themself as female; age 45; civil servant.;The Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing' was issued on 27 November 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their opinions on and experiences of health and wellbeing, in particular 'health, wellbeing and the healthy body'; 'identity'; 'growing up and learning about health and wellbeing'; 'growing older'; 'health, wellbeing and appearance'; 'getting ready to leave the house'.
Contents: Autumn Directive 2020 Part 2: Everyday Health and Wellbeing Health, wellbeing and the healthy body To me ‘health’ means physical and mental condition – good or bad. Wellbeing to me is a sense of how I feel mentally and physically. I’m more conscious of wellbeing this year. For example on the days I get to go in the office I have a strong sense of wellbeing to the point where I dread the following day working from home and not being able to have a natural conversation with a person or group of people while looking at them. ‘a healthy body’ in five words: disease-free, able, fit, energetic, well. The person that comes to mind for me is a Blond Ambition era Madonna. Fit, energetic, able. Identity It’s hard to say whether my experience of health and wellbeing has been influenced by things such as my gender and ethnicity as I cannot separate myself from those things. Saying that, it has been influenced by how I relate to media images of women and comparing myself to them. For example, thinking that women on TV and in films represented what I should look like when I grew up. Growing up and learning about health and wellbeing Health and wellbeing are things that I became aware of (maybe without those specific titles) relatively early on. Both my parents were mental health nurses, so in that sense, hearing their conversations about their jobs, it was impossible not to be aware of health. Also, as my mother became ill when I was a teenager, ending her career, that was a strong lesson for me in the importance of staying healthy. A what not to do type of lesson. I can’t say I was very aware of health when I was a child; I ate what I liked and did what I liked in terms of playing. I didn’t have a consciousness of doing things because they were healthy. Both my parents were overweight and I never had anyone telling me to watch what I ate. However, for the most part I didn’t overeat or become unhealthily overweight. I don’t remember any particular lessons about health in school, other than being shown a video about periods in the last year of primary school. There was no internet back then, and to be honest, I wasn’t that interested in health. The one thing I do remember about health when I was growing up was the AIDS crisis – who could forget, living through it? All those tombstone adverts. That of course worried me growing up, not that I’ve ever knowingly met anyone with AIDS but the adverts caused a lasting impression. Key moments I first became aware of bodily changes when I was about 11 – I noticed my waist curved in. Then I waited for the breasts to arrive. Still waiting. Although not much in need of it, I remember my mum taking me to get my first bras. The first time I wore one to school, a boy pulled the back of of it. I remember my first period. I was scared it would happen at a bad time. It wasn’t too bad, but not too great either. It was in the summer holidays after first year at secondary school, so I was twelve. My friend and I went down to stay with my grandparents in Clevedon. We were taken down by my dad, so it was a bit awkward, saying I needed to get sanitary products. I actually hated having my periods from the very first. They seemed messy painful and pointless to me. It always seemed unfair to me that women had to have them. I always wished they’d just stop on their own, but while I sometimes had extra weeks between them, I never missed one. After the first day it was a bit better; I was with a friend who’d already started her periods so that was helpful. The most cringey moment was when we were watching TV and the Golden Girls episode where they talk about their first periods was on. I wanted to sink through the floor. Growing older My first real issue with stress was when I was studying for my A Levels. I had been down before, but never anxious like that. The stress and anxiety hit me and I could not eat. I felt sick all the time. The weird thing was, before that I thought I had to eat to function, now I had a lesson in not eating and still functioning which is probably a very bad thing to happen to a teenager. At the time I was a little overweight, but I wasn’t worried or self conscious about it. I wouldn’t say I was fat, just a little plump, at the time, I didn’t think about it at all. I’d always ate what I liked and when I was younger I could get away with it because I was growing. I was never that bothered by food – I liked chocolate and could have as much as I wanted, but at Easter I asked to have toys instead as I couldn’t eat all the eggs I got. But then I lost weight – I didn’t eat much more than having a pint of milk for breakfast and my evening meal. I worked at the time at a cleaning job in an office. I had holiday and when I came back I had comments from some of the men who worked in the office who noticed I’d lost weight. I wasn’t exercising, just going to college, doing my cleaning job. I didn’t even think about exercise. Once I lost the weight that was when I started being more conscious of what I looked like and what size I was. I wanted to stay slimmer, but I didn’t feel in control because I hadn’t done anything deliberately to lose weight; it was a side effect of anxiety. That’s when I started to become aware of what I ate and think about it. A year before I finished my degree, a friend who I was planning to go on holiday with mentioned she used the gym. So I gave it a go, the idea being to look good for the holiday. Actually, my first session at the gym left me feeling high. I felt like I could breathe and it made me feel like I could do anything. I had had mild asthma and both my parents had it a lot worse (as well as being overweight). So while I started going to the gym to look better, I ended up continuing to go because of how it made me feel, and it the hope that it would protect me from getting ill like my parents. Inevitably I pushed to the limit and while doing my finals I felt really high from being ready for it and exercising, I crashed the day after I finished. All that time with an unhealthy view of food also caught up with me. I went to America as an au pair for a year and suffered with boredom a lot of the time, the opposite of the stress of studying for so long, which led to overeating in a country where sugar is in pretty much everything. That was the only time I was seriously overweight. I came home, got a retail job, went back to the gym and ate normal food. So in the end after swinging between anxiety and boredom I got to a level. One thing, I’ve never been on a diet. I couldn’t do it. I am clearly an emotional eater (eat when I’m bored, stop when I’m stressed), which is something I’ve had to be aware of this year. Being stuck at home is a little close to that year as an au pair, isolated in a foreign country on my own a lot of the time. Difference is I’m not living in leggings and I don’t have time to be bored. But there is no way in hell I could set up my desk in the kitchen, as some people I know have done. I have to keep to my exercise routine and wear jeans. The worst problem I had with anxiety was in my early thirties when I ended up off sick with work related stress. At the time I’d stopped exercising. I had my kit set up at home, but was spending so much time in work I didn’t have time for it. So I got mentally and physically out of shape. When I was off sick I made a point of getting back into a regular exercise routine. Since then I’ve stuck to it pretty rigidly. It helped me mentally too. I felt good after exercise but also felt a sense of achievement. I know that there is a link between physical and mental health – I’ve been there. This is what keeps me exercising. I don’t do much but half an hour of cardio and a few weights five days a week seems to work for me. I don’t pay too much attention to magazines or media stories about health because of being shaped by my own experiences. I just try to eat reasonably sensibly and exercise. I feel thankful that I was able to lose the extra weight after the au pair year, and I just want to stay the same size now, if I can. I feel good as I am. In future if I can’t keep up the cardio (rowing machine and exercise bike) I think I’ll do more walking. One thing I’ve started doing recently is cycling. I bought a bike when dad moved into the home in town. I cycle over to see him most of the time now and I actually really enjoy it. I’ve never been an outdoorsy person but cycling round the estate reminds me of when I had a bike as a child; it’s actually fun! Health, wellbeing and appearance I used to think external appearance was very much related to health. Now I know better. I’ve looked good and been extremely unhealthy (see above). I’ve come out of the gym feeling great and looking a complete mess. Saying that, I do love getting dressed up and staying fit helps me fit into those fancy clothes I like. But just cos I look good doesn’t mean I’m feeling great at the time. But I do think getting dressed up can make you feel better. I have made a point of getting properly dressed every day so I feel like I’m in the office (even if the dressing gown goes on top cos I’m cold). And every time I go into the office I dress up smart, do my hair and makeup. I even bought some new perfume recently – I hadn’t been wearing perfume this year, reasoning that whatever I chose would be the fragrance of 2020 forever. But I fancied a perfume I hadn’t had for a while and it was a treat to wear it. I have absolutely been influenced by popular ideals of beauty. When I was young I watched a lot of classic Hollywood films. At one point I thought becoming a grown-up meant waking up looking like Rita Hayworth one morning. Rita Hayworth in Cover Girl to be exact. I was destined for extreme disappointment. I also had a favourite Dolly Parton concert that we taped from TV and I watched a lot. I thought I’d have the face of Rita Hayworth and the chest of Dolly Parton. Needless to say, neither of those things happened. My parents were, sometimes embarrassingly, lacking in caring about their appearance. When they were younger they had fashion moments, but most of my life that wasn’t a thing. Therefore I felt extremely unprepared for makeup, grooming etc. In a way it was very positive in that I didn’t feel any pressure at home to look good, but a little would have been nice. I had to learn to do things myself and I still feel like a novice with beauty products; mostly just foundation and mascara for me. I’ve also always had acne, even now which seems cruel. I’ve had it since I was 13; you’d think it would be over by 45. Since lockdown I started using an expensive cleanser I had bought before but not really started using. Now I couldn’t do without it because it’s the only thing that seems to help (and I’ve been on Roaccutane). It is Environ Skin EssentiA cleansing lotion. I got talked into buying it on a cruise then started using it in earnest this year. I was worried I wouldn’t be able to get hold of it, but found a stockist in the UK. It’s expensive, but it works. Getting ready to leave the house From the above, you will gather that my parents were a bit short on ‘getting ready’ rituals. My own routine has changed, with the recent discovery of hair straighteners for when I wear my hair down, and the assistance of a work colleague who showed me (back in the days when we could go into the office) how to put a donut in my hair to make a nice fancy bun. It’s the only thing I can do with my hair and now it’s my go-to style for those rare days in the office. I also use foundation, eye liner (another relatively new development) and mascara. That with perfume and nice clothes is the effort. I think I’ve got better at choosing decent clothes so less fashion disasters than in the past. It’s just a shame that at the moment I don’t have anywhere to wear my clothes. My most recent clothes purchases are two zip-up fleeces from Lidl. And this was because a friend told me off for wearing my dressing gown during the day over my clothes! When I was younger I had no idea what I was doing with makeup and don’t remember using hairspray regularly, which for a teen of the 1980s is pretty unusual. I just had no idea. I’ve got to say that even with the signs of aging, I put myself together better now than I ever did as a youngster.

Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'COVID-19 (Update)'. Mass-Observer M7490 describes themself as female; age 45; civil servant.;The Directive 'COVID-19 (Update)' was issued on 27 April 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their experiences of the COVID-19 pandemic, in particular 'health'; 'the government'; 'news'; 'work and home life'; 'technology'; 'shopping and food'; 'entertainment and leisure'; 'personal hygiene' and 'sleep'.
Contents: Part 2 Covid 19 (update) Health Physically I am keeping fit by maintaining my normal workout routine. I have a rowing machine, stationary bike and weights at home and use them five days a week in the morning. As I am no longer driving into work, I don’t have to get up as early in the morning to fit in my exercise routine before starting work. I know I’m less active than I would be if I was going to the office each day and I do miss the long flight of stairs I walked up to my office every day. I’ve bought an exercise trampoline for between-times like when I’m waiting for the kettle to boil for a cup of tea. Mentally I’m OK – but I think I’ll feel it more as restrictions are lifted. Yesterday I had tears in my eyes when I saw that the Baker was open again. A little bit of normality back. I’m just taking it day by day and dealing with it, but it will be such a relief when we’re at least over this a bit. The Government I think there have been some very difficult decisions made and that we won’t be able to assess what the impact has been for years to come. I think it was right to bring in the lockdown and relatively easy compared to deciding on an exit strategy. This is unprecedented and mistakes will be made and undoubtably have been. I think we’ve done on balance not badly, but not particularly well in comparison to other countries. I think there will be more of the gradual easing of restrictions, there will be more confusion and more frustration that there has been until now. When the message was clear – stay at home – protect the NHS – save lives everyone understood that. It was absolute. The latest message doesn’t really mean anything, it’s just an attempt at a follow-up catchphrase. I see there is already an increase in testing and talk of tracing. There may also soon be more things opening. News At the start I watched the daily updates from the government. That was when there were big announcements like closing pubs/restaurants and schools). Now I tend to read the summaries on the BBC website (unless it’s going to be a big announcement). I feel like the government broadcasts are a good thing to have, but I don’t need to see them every day. They also run a bit long. I’ve got a bit of covid news fatigue now. Sometimes in the morning I watch CNN just for a change from UK news. I have the BBC News app on my phone which sent me alerts when Boris Johnson and Prince Charles were found to be positive. I don’t’ have any challenges getting the news – between the TV, BBC and Guardian apps and the odd newspaper, I feel like I’m overwhelmed with news about Covid. I know it’s a worldwide crisis, but I’m tired of it. Work and home life At the start of lockdown I was working on a laptop on a folding table. My elbow started to be painful. I haven’t gone to the Doctor about it because of lockdown. At work I normally have a rising desk so I can sit or stand because I have a bad knee. I don’t have that at home. Once my arm started to bother me I went into work and brought home peripherals (keyboard/mouse/docking station) and bought a stand so that I could raise my laptop up to the correct monitor height above the plugin keyboard. I also started using an ironing board as a desk so that I could stand up. I bought a bar stool after making sure it was exactly the right height for me to use at my temporary ‘standing desk’. I should be getting a breakfast bar delivered tomorrow to replace my increasingly wobbly ironing board set up. Again, I measured to ensure it is exactly the right height and depth and that it will fit in the spare bedroom. While I’d love a sit/stand desk, all of the ones I’ve seen are way too big for the space I have. I have a member of staff with back problems – one of our senior managers didn’t think we’d need to bring anything but laptops home for the duration – I told my member of staff to take their specialist chair if they needed it. I can see all sorts of enduring neck, back and leg problems coming out of the lockdown. I’m surprised that I’m relatively happy working at home. I used to feel isolated when I did so, but as the whole team (of around 20 people) is doing so, we are finding ways to communicate. I also think when we do call each other, we always chat more than we need to purely for work. That helps to make up for the social interaction we are missing from when we sat in the same office. My cat keeps me company every day (sometimes sitting on the ironing board, or on me, or on the bed next to the ironing board). That’s something I will miss going back to the office (if I ever do) and I think that the cat will miss it too. I actually feel more anxious about returning to work right now than staying where I am. The talk is of 25% maximum back in office with rules about which way to walk down a corridor, stairs which are for walking one way only (one set up the other set down) washing of desks and social distancing. That’s a lot to be thinking about when you’ve got a busy job already. I’d rather stay home. I know some people are really missing being physically in the same space, especially those who live on their own, but for me the constant worry related to being in the workplace outweighs the advantages. Also, I’m saving lots of money and wear on the car by not having a daily commute. I’m getting uplater and even if I finishlater at night,I close the laptop and I’m done. No commute. Because I’msobusy with work, the majority of my day is spent in the same way it was before lockdown, if at a different location. I talk to the same people and deal with the same tasks. I think that has helped my mental health. Most of the day I can ignore the context. My husband has been off work with (work-related) stress for the whole of the lockdown so far but is going back to work soon. But he’s been busy in the garden and now he can go back to playing golf. I make a point of having time away from him. Also, my work day means I see him for the same amount of time I normally would in the evenings. The only difference is the occasional cup of tea I get delivered. I feel very lucky to be working and not to have children. While being furloughed sounds nice (money for nothing) I know that if I was in that position I would be far more anxious than I am now and I wouldn’t be able to enjoy it. Technology We already have whatsapp groups at work and now at home we have a ‘pub’ group. Workwise we use skype constantly for phone meetings and group messaging. At work we now have an optional zoom meeting every Friday for drinks and quiz; it’s nice to be able to see each other. At home we’ve started zoom meetings for the pub group. None of us had used zoom before and it isn’t always smooth, but it is helpful. Shopping and food At the beginning of lockdown I was most upset when the restriction on buying UHT milk came in – one or two cartons a time. Before this we’d buy 12/24 cartons at the beginning of the month and then not have to think about buying milk again until the following month. That’s something that’s happened in my house growing up for as long as I can remember. At the start we then went to buying 4/6 pint containers from the local shop. I had no idea how quickly I went through milk (and it is mostly me rather than my husband). Now, even with the restriction lifted, it’s still something we go to the shop for. It’s a reason toleave the house and walk to the local shop and for me it’s a symbol of lockdown. Once I feel like things are normal enough we’ll go back to bulk-buying UHT. But until then it’s a walk to the shop ever other day or so for the fresh stuff. I don’t normally dothefoodshopping as I don’t dothe cooking, sosupermarkets are not somewhere I used to spend much time. Now I dread going in to Morrisons in case there is a queue, if not outside then for the tills. I don’t mind going to the smaller shops but it’s all a lot more effort than normal. Husband cooks the same things as before and I eat them. I have also made a conscious effort to stick with my normal work-day eating. Since getting a desk job nearly 20 years ago I have been conscious of not burning that many calories at work. It helps that I’m busy working because I tend to eat when I’m bored. Entertainment and leisure I’m still watching what I normally would to keep entertained. I’m not into sports so it hasn’t affected me too much. I do miss going to the cinema. I generally watch films/TV drama to get away from current events, but sometimes I do catch myself seeing things in films that wouldn’t happen now – crowded airports, eating out and it seems weird that it was so normal a few months ago and now it isn’t. We watched Contagion. I enjoyed the film and felt it was in some ways realistic, in some ways not (where was the panic-buying of loo-rolls?). As I’m not a Gwyneth Paltrow fan I was pleased her character was the first to die. We watched Outbreak too which was rubbish – bomb a town to deal with the disease? We’ve finally got round to watching Friday Night Dinner, which is hilarious. One show per night and we’re nearly caught up. At work we play along on our skype group message with Radio 2’s Popmaster nearly every day. I’d never heard of it before this. I have gone from reading a biography of Marie Antoinette to Penny Jordan Mills & Boon. I think I’m regressing and it’s my way of doing something utterly brainless. I haven’t read Mills & Boon for years and it really is utter trash, but I just can’t stop. But at least it’s not affecting my waistline, as eating trash food would. I wish I had the spare time to do all these things other people are doing at this time. I stand in my spare room day after day working all day, staring out the window. I have to walk past the things in my house that I want to do. I have no more time than I did before, I just have the constant awareness that other people have spare time. But then I remind myself I’m extremely lucky to have a job. In the interests of self-improvement I started watching a performance of Carmen while I do my exercise. Half and hour of opera a day while cycling/rowing is about all the extra enrichment I have time for. I like to crochet but I just don’t feel motivated at the moment. Personal Hygiene I still get up every morning, exercise and shower. I wash my hair twice a week, as per normal. What I haven’t done since lockdown started is use any heat on my hair to dry or straighten it. I also haven’t used any hairspray. Sometimes I put my hair up for zoom meetings but it doesn’t have to last or withstand the outside world so no hairspray needed. Makeup is only for zoom meetings, but I do enjoy making the effort. Normally my hairdresser dyes my hair with foils and I’ve just passed the first cancelled appointment. I will not ruin my hair with box dye (why? Who’s looking?) I will rest it until I can go to the hairdresser. I can’t remember the last time I wore my contact lenses (which I used to wear most week days). Glasses are less effort. Contacts are better for driving (especially at night) but when am I going to do that again? I’ve started putting nail hardener on my nails once a week. I feel like my nails and hair are in hibernation. I’mkeepingthem healthy until they can come out to play again. I wear jeans most days that are stretchy but not that stretchy – I bought a load of clothes for my (cancelled) holiday and want to be able to fit in them once this is over. I mostly wear sports tops (non-iron) at the moment. I feellikeI’min aholdingpattern –keeptheroutine, stay healthy, don’t let things slide. It’s almost like waiting for your wedding – look after yourself, watch what you eat, exercise, look after nails and hair then you get to show it off at the end – main difference being we don’t have a date for the Big Day yet. Sleep I have terrible insomnia anyway, so no real change there. But I am having more anxiety dreams. The night before I drove to work to get my desk kit, I had bad dreams – I think because I was worried I’d get stopped by the police. Things that were normal before have become sources of anxiety. My husband has been sticking to a routine of getting up and going to bed at normal times, as have I. I do get up later because I use my normal commute time to do my exercise and sometimes I struggle with motivation. I could get to work earlier but the nature of the work is, I’ll still end up working late. So might as well get there later. I don’t usually exercise in the morning on a Wednesday – I have a walk at lunchtime to my dad’s flat to pick up the post. He went into hospital in March, where he caught Covid-19 and his mobility deteriorated to a point where he won’t walk again, so he’s in acare home (temporary at the moment,but no way will he be able to come home). I guess I could redirect the mail, but it’s nice to have a reason to go for a walk and I don’t have to go inside the block as the post-boxes are outside. I sometimes use the Headspace app to try sleep meditation or for sleep soundscapes. I also use sleeping pills once a week to try and get at least one night’s good sleep – but this is the same as it was before the lockdown.

Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'COVID-19 and Time'. Mass-Observer M7490 describes themself as female; age 35; civil servant.;The Directive 'COVID-19 and Time' was issued on 7 August 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their experiences of the COVID-19 pandemic and lockdown in relation to the 'rhythm and routine of the day'; 'homelife'; use of 'media and technology'; their experiences of 'waiting'.
Contents: Summer Directive 2020 Part 1 Covid and Time Rhythm and routine of the day At the start of lockdown I was working from home as instructed by work. My daily routine changed because normally I have a long commute to work in the car. This was an immediate change. My drive to work got replaced by a lie in. I still got up and did my exercise routine before starting work, but I started getting up later and later. I wasn’t benefiting from no commute. My days ended later and later because there was no reason not to (no long drive home and light evenings). Because I am now having to look after my father’s business (as an advocate rather than a direct carer) I have a lot of things that need doing – from forms to fill in to things he needs to be delivered to the homes/hospitals he has been in since March. I therefore asked to work compressed hours – four long days with one day off during the week. This was a way to motivate myself to get out of bed on my work days and to make the fact that I was working later benefit me (and my dad). I use my non-work day for all the admin things I am too tired to do by the time it comes to the weekend.  Before I started working compressed hours I thought it would be a good way to also control the amount of hours I was working – I was going to work nine hours, 15 minutes a day and no more. That didn’t last a week. I’ve kept working flexi-time and recording my hours. Otherwise I would be working a lot of hours for free. I know that a lot of people in my department have been working ridiculous hours and not stopping at the weekend. I am trying to discipline myself not to do that. It is difficult. I would compare opening the laptop in the morning to being sucked into a whirlwind, and it just doesn’t stop, ever. What compressed hours does do is clear one day a week for me to deal with some of the things I have to do in terms of my father’s care and planning on selling his flat to pay for that.  Working from home also enables me to take and make the calls I need to related to my father’s care. I can put my phone on speaker while waiting for social care or DWP or the hospital to answer and continue with my work. Something I could not do in the office. I cannot always take my dad’s calls – sometimes I’m on a work call or extremely busy with work. But I hear the calls come to the phone and call back when I can. Not something I could do if I was in office where my phone would be on silent. My work day now starts earlier than it would if I was in the office and ends much later. Because it can and because we are so busy. My days and weeks fly by, and often I need to look at my desk calendar to work out what day it actually is.  My non-working day is Thursday, which is market day in Devizes. Not my choice, but the most convenient day for work. I wouldn’t by choice go into town on market day (too busy and most people are quite grumpy/bad mannered on market day). However, due to the things I’ve had to do, I have often found myself in town on a Thursday. It’s not been as bad as I expected. I was pleasantly surprised that when the news came out that mask wearing in shops was going to be compulsory, a lot of people started wearing them the week before.  Since the non-essential shops have opened, I have bought a few more things locally than I ever would. I’d normally go out of town for shopping. I had to go to Swindon town centre on a dad-related task a few weeks ago and enjoyed being back there as that’s one of the places I normally shop. However I won’t be going back anytime soon, with the covid cases there. I don’t wear a watch most days – which I always used to. But sitting at my computer all day means I can see the time on the monitor. I only need a watch if I leave the house, and only then if there is some time limitation (parking). I have recently seen articles (why do I read these media outlets?) about how civil servants need to set an example by going ‘back to work’. What a great way to use civil servants as a national political punching-bag yet again. These articles make me angry. I have been working the whole time. We were ordered out of the office and we kept up the productivity. Now they want to order us back to the office to help the economy and who cares about our health? I suppose if we die that will be better too as they won’t have to pay us. Personally, I am not one for buying coffee and sandwiches at work. Maybe at Christmas or on a special occasion, that’s it. So I won’t be helping the economy in the town I work in by going back there. I can just as easily help the economy in Devizes by staying here. If I do go into town on a Thursday I very often buy my lunch there. Also, even before the pandemic, we were told that our workplace was moving towards 70% office occupancy. There were grumblings about that, but it was reaching crisis level with the car parking not coping, so that was the plan already. So if the office can’t cope with 100% occupancy and there’s no sign of the end of the pandemic and we’re managing working from home, where is the urgency to go back?  Saying that, I have been in to the office a few times. My job can be emotionally difficult and I can tell by speaking to people in my team when they are also feeling a bit frayed by what we are having to do while sitting on our own without anyone to blow off steam with. We need the social contact for our mental health. I started going in once a fortnight for this reason and letting other members of the team know that this was an option for them too, as a way for us to meet and properly be able to socialise together (in a socially distant way). I can tell that people’s social skills are being eroded, including mine. I’ve seen emails that are blunter than they should be (and in some cases outright rude and unacceptable). This is because we are on our own and have no one to bounce things off before we hit send. We are also all dealing with different home pressures. We run the risk of all becoming isolated and acting more like internet trolls. We need that balance of other people to vent our frustrations to before composing the socially acceptable version of the ‘why the hell are you doing that?’ type of email. Without regular face to face interaction I feel like we are going a little off course. We need at least occasional interaction to keep us on the right track. There is a certain amount of what I call ‘covid blindness’ in the department. An expectation that things will get done as normal. When someone senior questions why something wasn’t done in March this year and states that we must do better, it is legitimate to wonder what planet they are living on. Homelife As I said above, I’ve been working from home the whole time. But with work colleagues we still talk in terms of ‘going to work’ and ‘going home’ sometimes. Because we haven’t yet got the language down for working from home.  I get up and start work at regular times. I’m not so good about finishing work. If my husband goes to the pub after work I just stay at work (there’s always plenty to do) until he gets home. Now that he’s going to work, I have the house to myself, just me and the cat, during the day.  I think that in future, it’s likely that I’ll be going in to the office two days a week, but it’s all up in the air at the moment. I think two days would be about right for me, and I want to keep doing compressed hours so that I have one day to do dad-admin.  My cat supervises my work. He comes and sits on the desk or me every day. This is both soothing (when I’ve got difficult things to deal with) and annoying (when he gets between me and the keyboard) but overall I’d say he’s a very positive influence on my mood. I don’t feel completely alone. I am a little worried about him and how attached he’s getting, so we’re getting kittens soon. I’m hoping they aren’t too much trouble for our old boy but I can be here to supervise the introductions and interactions for a while.  I set up my workspace in the spare bedroom. I now have a breakfast bar for a desk which I can sit at (on a bar stool) or stand at, so it’s a standing desk (sort of). We were able to have our desk technology (keyboard/monitor etc) at home, which I did to start with. Then I bought my own, in white rather than work-black. So the only work-owned thing I use is my laptop. This was an effort to reclaim my space and pretend that the desk is for my own use, not primarily a workspace.  It hasn’t worked. I used to use the spare room for my hobby room and gym. I still have my gym here, but it’s not the sanctuary it was. How can it be, with my desk in here? And it’s the last place I want to be on the weekend when I’ve spent my whole work-week here. Right now I’m at my desk, using my home laptop, but sitting here it feels like a work-day, because that’s what it is the majority of the time I’m sat here. Media and technology Before lockdown we were all issued with headsets, but we didn’t use them really, we continued to use our desk phones. Of course, all that changed when we all started working from home. Using Skype for phone in meetings and calls is so useful. I’ve been on a call to one person and invited someone else to join (very useful). And in big meetings I like that it shows who is talking (I’m terrible at names and can’t recognise voices very well). I actually prefer attending large meetings (where I may not have much of a role) this way. I can listen but also do other things. I can take actions while in the meeting – taking notes for sending out to others on the computer rather than in a note book, or if someone in the meeting asks for something, I can send it to them right away.  I was already tagging people for status changes in Skype to see when they were back at their desk, now that’s how I call them too. I also like that I can see who is calling before I answer – I always do answer but it’s a heads-up to what the call is likely to be about. We’re not having social get-togethers with work on zoom anymore. To me the lockdown reminds me of starting college. All dealing with a new location and a new context and wanting to be together all the time in the new environment. Then people settle down and get on with it.  Home-wise, we’ve continued the pub-zoom meeting on a Sunday – although there has been some controversy on the whatsapp group recently. Some of the bar workers are on the zoom and whatsapp group and one was questioning why more of us were not returning to the pub. That turned into a ‘discussion’ between two people – one saying we should go back (to help the pub) and one saying (very politely) that due to health concerns they didn’t feel comfortable yet. The person who was pushing for a return to the pub called the health concerns ‘an excuse’ which set me off. My response was:  While I understand the need to support the economy, I also know that health concerns must be top priority. And I don’t need to have gone through the worry of my dad catching covid whilst in isolation in a hospital to feel that way. That stopped the conversation but it had already upset me. I’ve had a lot to deal with this year and I don’t need this kind of rubbish. Waiting The queues outside shops have eased now that non-essential shops are open. While they were in existence, I found acceptance the easiest way to deal with it. If I was going to Boots, I knew there would be a queue so I made sure I had a book on my phone to read. No point getting annoyed, we all had to do it. One of the worst parts was waiting for my holiday (a cruise) to be cancelled. We knew it was going to happen, but the company took ages to confirm, then ages to pay our money back. We’re not booking anything now, no point while things are still uncertain. I feel like I’ve been in hibernation for ages, not wearing my nice work clothes, makeup or contact lenses or going out clothes. I am sick of my sports tops (which are non-iron) which I have been wearing all the time and are now my lockdown uniform. I did buy a new work suit and wore it to work on one of my days in the office. We don’t have a dress code but I like wearing smart clothes. Just no point at the moment. All of my going out clothes haven’t been touched. I do have a wedding coming up, so I am looking forward to dressing up for that! My dad has been waiting for somewhere permanent to live following being in hospital and catching covid there. He couldn’t go home as he’s lost the use of his legs. He was moved to one care home, then another after being pushed out of hospital. All he wanted was to be back in Devizes, but he needed a nursing home. Now he’s got a place in Devizes but he’s been hospitalised again with an infection and feels like he’s gone back to square one on this horrible game. I was so upset that we’d finally got him back home and a permanent place to live and he had to go back to the hospital where this all started in March. He’s now waiting for an MRI scan (the machine has broken down) and they won’t let him out until he’s had it. I tell him it’s not the same as last time as he now has a home to go to, but it is so disheartening. Every day he’s in hospital he’s getting less mobile.

Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing'. Mass-Observer D6836 describes themself as female; age 70; married; retired teacher.;The Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing' was issued on 27 November 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their opinions on and experiences of health and wellbeing, in particular 'health, wellbeing and the healthy body'; 'identity'; 'growing up and learning about health and wellbeing'; 'growing older'; 'health, wellbeing and appearance'; 'getting ready to leave the house'.
Contents: MO D6836 Female 70 Married Worlington Suffolk Retired teacher Part 2: Everyday Health and Wellbeing To me, ‘health’ is more to do with physical and ‘wellbeing’ more to do with mental and emotional health. ‘A healthy body’ – fit, right weight, good diet, I can only imagine a generic person to describe this, and the words above sum it up really.  Probably someone who exercises regularly, with good lung function and no health issues.  Someone who carries no excess fat, but neither are they underweight. They don’t smoke and they drink moderately if at all. They eat a healthy diet, low in meat. high in fruit and vegetables. They get enough sleep. I can’t think of any specific ways that my gender, ethnicity, social class or sexual orientation has affected my general health.  Maybe my working class 1950s upbringing had some influence – getting on with hard work, eating mostly non-processed food in those days – these early experiences have lived with me and continue, so that I do get a fair amount of exercise and I eat a pretty healthy diet. Aren’t we all somehow at least vaguely aware of ‘health’ most of our lives?  My maternal grandmother died when my mother was just 6, which had a profound effect on my mother’s life, so I was always aware of that and of how my mother hated hospitals.  My father had had a serious accident when he was 14 which resulted in him losing several toes and spending months in hospital, so again, I was aware of that.  But everyday health was not something talked about, other than the usual occasional common illnesses that occurred.  At secondary school we were given talks about not smoking, as it was bad for our health.  My first job was working in the offices of the local health department, so I was constantly aware of it then. The notion of ‘wellbeing’ is much more recent I think. When I was still teaching, my head teacher took staff wellbeing seriously and undertook several initiatives in that area – this is probably when I first became aware of it.  She made sure that our staff room was a pleasant place to be, nicely furnished and light. She provided coffee and tea free of charge.  But it became obvious to me that not everyone has the same ideas about what wellbeing is. She engaged a lady to give massages during the lunch break, each of us able to have one a month.  For most of the staff, this was very much welcomed, but I am not a fan of massages – I did try it but it had only a negative effect and because it was during the lunch hour, it wasn’t ideal to then have to go straight back to the classroom.  I somewhat jokingly suggested that my own well being would be served very well if the head would take my class for half an hour occasionally, giving me an extra half hour at lunchtime, but of course it never happened. I can’t remember when I first learned about puberty – it was a long time ago!  Probably through talking with friends, most of whom started their periods before me.  My mother never mentioned them so it was difficult when I did start to tell her.  She then just dealt with it matter of factly and gave me sanitary towels and an elastic belt to hook them on to. It was all very embarrassing. Nowadays things are discussed much more openly which can only be a good thing. As I mentioned earlier, I have always kept reasonably physically active and eat a pretty healthy diet.  I have never smoked and drink moderately.  I am increasingly aware of looking after myself as I get older – anything that will help stave off the inevitable. I take Vitamin D. As I have a thyroid problem I take tablets for that. I’ve never had problems with my mental state particularly, and maybe that’s due to keeping active – even when I’m watching TV I like to have some sewing or knitting or internet browsing to do.  I avoid watching too much news as I find it depressing. I do tend to avoid things that I know will upset me when I can. The only place I seek information about health is online, mostly the NHS website, if I or my husband has any symptoms. I suppose that external appearance to some extent is a reflection of health – I’m thinking predominantly of the large number of overweight people one sees these days.  I doubt you can detect a person’s wellbeing from their physical appearance.  Appearances can be deceptive. I’ve never been especially influenced by popular ideals of beauty etc, other than being overweight, but that has more to do with the potential health issues. I don’t buy beauty products other than shampoo and face cream, I rarely wear make-up. I do admit, however, to not liking my hair to look a mess! My mum liked her make-up, basic though it was. My dad wasn’t at all interested like most men of his generation and class I think. What couldn’t I live without? Just shampoo, conditioner and a basic face cream, as mentioned above. How funny to think of a desert island product! Well, being equally flippant, if there were coconuts I guess I could figure out how to make a face cream/body lotion, but I’d struggle to make shampoo, so I guess it would have to be that! All I can recall about my parents getting ready to go out for the evening is getting washed (latterly showered) and changed, my mum putting on her make-up and always perfume.  As for me, when I was still working I would shower each morning and wash my hair, sometimes apply a bit of basic make-up. That’s it.  It’s pretty much the same now when going out socially, though I rarely bother with the make-up, despite knowing it would probably make me look better. I’d put on some perfume probably.  My husband has no sense of smell, so it’s lost on him!

Mass-Observer D6836 describes themself as female; age 69; married; retired teacher.;The Directive 'COVID-19 (Update)' was issued on 27 April 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their experiences of the COVID-19 pandemic, in particular 'health'; 'the government'; 'news'; 'work and home life'; 'technology'; 'shopping and food'; 'entertainment and leisure'; 'personal hygiene' and 'sleep'.
Contents: MO D6836 Female 69 Married Suffolk Retired teacher Spring 2020 Part 2: Covid 19 (update) Health I’m in lockdown with my husband. Neither of us has had any health issues (9 weeks now) either physical or mental. We’ve been fine the whole time. As for emotions, I’ve felt sad that I can’t hug my daughter when she comes round with shopping for us. I’m extremely aware that we are lucky in having a large garden with lots of work to do in it which is good for our health. I have felt anxious about where it’s all going to lead and leave us – all of us. The Government I think the government has done too little too late throughout the pandemic. They made the decision not to buy PEP three times early on which is inexcusable and continue to be too easy going about it all I feel. What will they do in the coming months? Who knows. Make the wrong decisions probably, relaxing restrictions too soon, trying to blame others when things go wrong. I look at leaders such as the New Zealand prime minister and Nicola Sturgeon in Scotland and wish our leader was more like them. News My husband and I have totally different attitudes towards the news. I look at the BBC news website every morning to get the headlines and that’s enough for me. He watches every news – mid-day, 6pm, 10pm and then Newsnight (by which time I’ve gone to bed). I don’t think it helps to immerse yourself in it – it certainly wouldn’t help me, though he finds it vital. We haven’t watched the daily government briefings at all. I wonder how many people do? So much of what is in the TV news (which I watch the headlines of then go into another room while my husband watches the rest) seem to focus on what ifs and complaints against the authorities/government. I don’t see the point of that. Just deal with it and move forward. I don’t know anyone having problems with access. The Scottish parliament using BSL seems a good idea, though I know it’s possible to have subtitles on TV and I imagine people do use that. Work and home life As we are retired the lockdown has had far less impact on us than many others, and I suspect that people in our position will be the least affected. Our life has changed only in that we haven’t been shopping, but the main affect is that we would have been over at our house in France since March which of course hasn’t been possible. As we’re used to spending all our time together everything has been fine. Technology It would have been much more difficult to cope with the lockdown without the internet that’s for sure. A friend in the village set up a Zoom group early on for several of us to chat each morning at 11am with a coffee. This continues, mostly just with us and her and her husband, occasionally some of the other 4 couples join in. It’s been good having this contact, even though we all live within a few hundred yards of each other. I regularly Whats App with my daughter and have kept in touch a little more than usual via that and email with family in Cumbria. I’ve also emailed friends nearby and further afield a little more frequently than usual. I’m not a lover of the phone so rarely use that. I do use Facebook and Twitter but no more than usual – though this is several times a day. It feels good to be in touch with friends around the world, know they’re OK and share memories as well as current statuses. A friend who lives in Derbyshire invited us with another couple to a Zoom dinner party that was good fun. We chatted, had a break to eat, then came back together after each course. He had sent us a couple of quiz rounds to look at while we ate then we shared answers. It was also good to interact with new people – something that of course isn’t happening now. Shopping and food Prior to lockdown I had gradually stocked the pantry pretty well, including the things we would have been taking with us had we been able to go to France, so we were OK for some things from the start. We have been fortunate that we had just started to get Hello Fresh deliveries which provides the ingredients for three fresh meals each week that I cook. This has been fun – I don’t have to plan the meals and I’m learning new recipes. It works out at £5 per head per meal. The other good things are that because the local market has been closed, some of the market traders have been delivering, so we have had weekly deliveries of fruit and veg, milk, eggs, bread and butter; meat and fish (we alternate those). For other things my daughter has shopped for us once every 7-10 days which she brings over and we can chat in the garden at the appropriate distance of course! So we haven’t missed out on anything. Oh, and I’ve also bartered rhubarb from the garden for eggs from a friend up the road – we hang our respective bags on the gatepost for exchange when she passes. As things reopen gradually (the markets start next week) we plan to do click and collect from Sainsbury’s to avoid going into the shops. We haven’t been near any sort of shop for the past nine weeks. An interesting and unexpected bonus came via a friend in the village. Through contacts she gets a delivery each week from Waitrose of their unsold short shelf-life products (fruit and veg and sometimes bread). We pick up some of that from her driveway and help bag the rest for delivery to vulnerable people in the village. What’s left then goes to Mildenhall up the road for distribution to families there. For non-grocery items I have ordered a couple of thing s online which is not something I would normally do. I ordered seeds for the garden and a kettle when the old one broke! Oh, and I’ve just sent for some summer clothes as all mine are in France! That’s definitely a first! Entertainment and Leisure Because the weather has been mostly in our favour and we have a large garden that has been neglected for several years with us being in France most of the summer, we have spent a lot of time working outside. This has felt good on two counts – (a) to be outside and productively occupied and (b) because the garden is looking much better than it has for years. We’ve cleared several large overgrown areas and replanted them and have had the opportunity to consider plans for larger scale, longer-term projects like erecting fencing and a wooden garage. A couple of friends kindly donated plants they were clearing and we were able to get some delivered from a market garden in the village. There’s still plenty to do and we have a veg plot that’s coming on well. We have potatoes, onions, spinach, runner and French beans, carrots, leeks, tomatoes and courgettes. I had bought the seeds prior to lockdown and we got tomato plants from a stall in the village. We also have apples, pears, cherries, raspberries, strawberries and quinces coming on, though the birds always get to the cherries before we do. I enjoy genealogy and have spent some time doing that, for others as well as myself. Like many others, I’ve cleared out cupboards and drawers and got rid of things no longer needed. I put a box of books outside the gate for people to help themselves to, replenishing it as they were taken. That felt good. My husband is missing his trips to the gym so has been running three times a week, either a 3 or 5 or on two occasions an 8 mile route. We walk the dog twice a day on our friend’s field opposite the house with occasional longer walks round the village. TV watching hasn’t changed. Lunch while watching Bargain Hunt which is a nice distraction. N then watches the news. In the evening I enjoy quizzes such as Mastermind, Only Connect and Pointless, and cooking programmes like The Greta British Menu and Masterchef but most of those have finished now. I enjoy the Great British Sewing Bee. We watch Poirot (all of which we’ve seen before). There’s nothing much worth while watching really. We’ve watched a couple of DVDs. As I said earlier, N. watches a lot of news which I leave him to and he often goes to listen to music in his study while I watch my programmes. It’s not a bad thing to be able to spend some time apart in this situation. For example, I am writing this sitting in my garden beach hut while N. is writing poems in his study. We know that we are very fortunate to have this space and I am very aware that for many people lockdown must be extremely difficult because of where they live. We both read, me mostly when I go to bed. I’ve just finished Gerald Durrell’s Corfu Trilogy having enjoyed watching The Durrells on TV. I thoroughly enjoyed it. I have a book here in the beach hut – The Trials of the King of Hampshire (non-fiction historical) and there’s a biography of Mrs. Beeton on the kitchen table rather appropriately! which I sometimes dip into while eating. N. has started having the Saturday Guardian delivered which keeps him happy for most of the week. I haven’t listened to much radio, though I occasionally have it on while I’m cooking. Radio 4. I used to have Today on in the morning but it’s too much these days. I like the comedy programmes such as I’m Sorry I haven’t a clue or The Unbelievable Truth. There’s sometimes a good play or documentary. Personal hygiene We’ve certainly been doing the hand-washing that’s recommended, even though we aren’t going out. We always wash our hands when touching anything that’s come into the house – mail, deliveries etc. And I use an anti-bac wipe on the gate handle when people come through. Like just about everyone, our hair has grown! I always’ cut N’s so he’s all right but mine is usually quite short. I’ve had a go at trimming it myself a bit which seems OK, but I’ve just been styling it differently and it’s fine. Sleep There’s been no change in our sleep patterns at all. Though this is an interesting question for us as my husband has a sleep disorder which means we are used to disturbed nights. He has something called REM Sleep Behaviour Disorder which basically means that he enacts his dreams, which are usually quite active, e.g. running away from animals, fighting off assailants or wasps. This inevitably wakes me up, and we have had to make adjustments to our bedroom to accommodate it, e.g. a very low bed, foam pieces around his side of the bed, as he has thrown himself out several times in the past, causing quite severe injury. He has medication that has helped a bit. Other than that, it’s been perfectly normal!

Contents: MO number: H5724   Female Age: 65 Married Rugby   Retired/Library Assistant Autumn Directive 2020 Part 2: Everyday health and wellbeing. With the health of the nation coming under closer scrutiny during the Covid-19 pandemic I have felt more aware of my own physical health but am not overly worried to the point of putting myself on a diet or taking up strenuous exercise. However, my mental health has definitely changed, not for the better, mainly due to an almost constant diet of ‘worst case scenarios‘ pushed on us by the media! At 65, I am not doing too badly. I can manage most everyday tasks with no problem, other than age-related wear of joints and muscles. I try to eat a varied diet but there is always room for improvement. During the pandemic it has been very obvious that there has been quite a lot of ‘comfort’ eating and drinking – at the lowest points, when media outlets carried wall-to-wall pessimism about the virus, it was easy to slip into an attitude of ‘eat, drink and be merry, for tomorrow we die’ mentality! Growing up hearing about health and wellbeing Growing up in post-War Britain, we were told to eat what was in front of us, there was no time for ‘fads’, you ate what you were given or went without. However, for all we were in the low-income bracket, we never went to bed hungry. There may have been a little more stodge to fill out the meals, but we generally had a good range of vegetables and fruit (home grown out of economic necessity and a hang-over from the ‘dig for victory’ habits of the war years). Exercise came naturally – we walked every where and kids played out and about or used bicycles. That said, I never took part in extra-curricular organised sports – I was more of a bookworm. Key Moments Puberty arrived, a few talks from the District Nurse at school and a much-relieved Mother who audibly sighed when she sat me down to talk about the facts of life and realised she didn’t have to engage with things that were generally not talked about! I had an older sister, so I had someone else to talk to about practicalities. My mother was quite reserved about personal things and although we did get on well, she had a debilitating illness (MS) which was diagnosed when I was four years old, so I basically never had what some might call a close maternal relationship. She died when I was 18. I faced all the usual feminine milestones mainly with the help of magazines and playground conversations. I found this lack of maternal connection affected my own issues with having children of my own – what was normal and what to expect.  My sister lived in another part of the country and we were not really close in relationship, so I had no-one to talk to, other than friends going through a similar stage of life. Growing older Again, when the menopause appeared on the horizon, I had no familial experiences by which to judge what was expected or normal, but at least I now had access to the internet by which to educate myself. I also booked an appointment with the Community Nurse at the Doctor’s Surgery to get advice, which was helpful – but during the course of this she discovered I had high blood pressure so menopause concerns went out of the window as she dealt with that less appealing stage of age and bodily decline! More recently I have developed an auto-immune condition which has required further tablets and blood tests and an acceptance that some activities are now off limits. Age-related vision problems then reared their ugly head, so anno domini is certainly making its presence felt! However, all in all, I am not too bad and I keep soldiering on, ever mindful that I can no longer accomplish what I used to do! Health, wellbeing and appearance Since I retired I have been able to dress to suit my mood or whatever I’ve been doing, rather than having to be smart for work. In the lockdown restrictions of the Covid-19 pandemic, it has been very liberating to only have to ‘dress up’ when leaving the house! That said, I have never spent days in pyjamas, unlike many I’ve spoken to on the subject. I always get up and wash/shower and change into day clothes, even if it’s only joggers and a comfortable warm jumper – I wouldn’t be seen dead walking down the garden to the dustbin in my PJs! Again, with the restrictions imposed by lockdowns and a lack of visits to the hairdresser, I’ve never succumbed to trying to cut my own hair (or my husband’s!) Wearing a hat in the cold weather was a useful alternative, but I do think if things progress I may have to wear a hairband to keep things under the semblance of control! When I was still going out to work I would not leave the house with at least mascara and a dash of eye shadow, but since I’ve had cataract trouble (as well as a torn retina) I found I couldn’t see so well to apply make-up and as time has worn on I have got out of the habit. Perhaps I’m no longer bothered about keeping up appearances! Getting ready to leave the house In my Parents’ day, you always left the house appropriately dressed – I am no different. I remember my father, who worked the night shift in a factory, getting ready for work. He would prepare his packed ‘lunch’ (he called it his ‘bait’!) or my sister or myself would do it. Then he’d get his coat or jacket and one of us children would be sent to look out of the front room window to watch out for one of his work mates to arrive by car to give him a lift to the factory. I remember it was always about the same time as the BBC radio programme “The Archers” was on, as the theme tune was almost the soundtrack to Dad setting off for work. Even if I happen to hear it nowadays, it conjures up Dad setting off along the path to the waiting car. As a child there was always someone at home, either my mother or Grandmother, so I never had the need of a door key and never returned to an empty house. Nowadays, of course, I need to pick up car keys, handbag, hand sanitizer and masks! As long as I’m ‘presentable’ I don’t tend to bother too much – besides, in the Winter months a decent coat covers a multitude of sins!

Mass-Observer W7312 describes themself as female; age 51; married; academic notetaker.;The Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing' was issued on 27 November 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their opinions on and experiences of health and wellbeing, in particular 'health, wellbeing and the healthy body'; 'identity'; 'growing up and learning about health and wellbeing'; 'growing older'; 'health, wellbeing and appearance'; 'getting ready to leave the house'.
Contents: MO Number:  W7312 Gender:  Female Age: 51 Marital Status:  Married City:  Derby Occupation:  Academic Notetaker Part 2: Everyday Health and Wellbeing The challenges of COVID-19 mean that in recent months, there has been a lot of reflection on health and wellbeing in unprecedented circumstances. But what about health and wellbeing in everyday life? We learn about health in many different ways, and it can mean different things to different people depending on their circumstances. In this Directive, we want to find out what health and wellbeing means to you (and what it meant before COVID-19) but particularly where your ideas about health and wellbeing came from, and what has influenced your own experiences of health and wellbeing in everyday life. Health, wellbeing and the healthy body What does “health” mean to you? What does “wellbeing” mean to you? How do you define these words? What do you think about when you imagine “a healthy body”? Please share the first five words that come to your mind when you think of this term. • Resilience (to minor infections) • Stamina • Vitality • Strength • Wellness Is there a particular person or image that comes to mind? Please describe, or draw, this person. There are a handful of people who come to mind. Some are much younger than me but others are a similar age.  Those of a similar age enjoy yoga, running, walking, swimming, cooking for themselves wherever possible and eating well.  They also take (sometimes forced) time to look after their mental health. Identity How do you think that your own experience of health and wellbeing has been influenced by your gender, ethnicity, social class, or sexual orientation? Do you think your experience of health has been influenced by these or other aspects of your identity at all? Yes I do. I was lucky to have been raised by parents who believed in a healthy, balanced diet which included plenty of fresh fruit and vegetables.  They also encouraged us to walk every day, swim once a week and emphasised the importance of getting outside whenever possible and in all types of weather (as long as we were dressed appropriately.  I am pretty sure my Dad believed in the saying ‘There's no such thing as bad weather, only unsuitable clothing’). I always thought that was a Norwegian quote but I am not so sure now. I still walk every day, in all kinds of weather.  In fact, I prefer to walk when it is colder than during the very hot, humid months of Summer. I particularly love Autumn and Spring; they are my two favourite seasons. I adore the colours in late September, October and November and I also enjoy Springtime with all of the flowers coming back to life. Growing up and learning about health and wellbeing When and where did you first become aware of “health” or of “wellbeing”? I first became aware of health when I was a teenager.  The term ‘Wellbeing’ came much later. I think the increased awareness surrounding mental wellbeing has been something that was much needed and very welcomed.  I do hope that the focus on wellbeing around mental health is increased within schools and I believe it should also include information on the benefits of good quality sleep and how lack of sleep can affect immunity.  Who had responsibility for looking after your health and wellbeing when you were younger? My parents.  Do you remember your parents, or other caregivers, talking to you about health? If so, what did they talk to you about? Where did these conversations take place? I do not specifically remember my parents talking to me about health. I have two sisters and one of them was very ill with renal failure. I would have been about eight years old when she was first diagnosed.  She was six.  A lot of the conversations that we, as a family had were about my sister’s health.  Sadly, she spent a large amount of time in hospital, both in Suffolk (my childhood home) and in London, where she was able to receive more specific treatment.  She underwent a kidney transplant at the age of 14 and is now 49. Did you receive any education about health in school? And/or did you learn about health and wellbeing in other ways – from friends, magazines, or the internet, for example? To be honest, health education in school in the 1970s and 1980s was lacking somewhat.  The internet was not around so I read a lot of magazines and talked to friends. Key moments As an adolescent, when did you first become aware of bodily changes associated with puberty? Are there any moments or rituals that you think are particularly important for young women or men? These might include, but are not limited to, first period, voice breaking, buying the first bra, or shaving, for example? I think first period and buying your first bra are very important. How did you feel about these moments if/when they happened to you? In all honesty, I did not really give them too much thought.  It was very much a case of ‘Get on with it’ which I know now is not very helpful to a teenager (or anyone at any age!) but when I was growing up, it really was like that.  It was almost as if feeling slightly sorry for oneself was seen as a weakness and an indulgence.  Growing older Throughout your life, what if anything, have you done to actively maintain your health both physically and mentally? Has this changed at all over the years? If so, was this due to a particular event in your life? Where do you get information about health and wellbeing now? Would you say you are you more or less aware of your body now? Why do you think this is? In future years how do you expect your approach to health and wellbeing to change? I walk for a few miles every day.  I also practise Pilates on a daily basis.  I used to swim quite a bit as well and I do plan to take this up again.  W7312 My information regarding health and wellbeing comes mainly from professionals on social media.  I am far more aware of my body now, at the age of 51, than I was thirty years ago. In future years I intend to remain as physically active as possible.  I have had a handful of health ‘scares’ over the past ten years and was diagnosed with Osteoarthritis in both feet last year.  Unfortunately, this meant an operation within three months of diagnosis in order to try and release the joint in my left foot.  I am absolutely determined to carry on walking as much as I can as walking is so important to my overall health and wellbeing.  Health, wellbeing and appearance In your view, how are health and wellbeing related to external appearance? Have you ever been influenced by popular ideals of beauty or physical appearance? Do you think your parents were influenced by these kinds of ideals? If so, in what way? Are there any health or beauty products (excluding medicines) that you couldn’t live without? What would be your Desert Island item? I take multivitamins and have been using a Vitamin D spray for around four years.  I am not sure what level of protection the multivitamins give but I definitely could not be without the Vitamin D spray. In respect of beauty products, I would take moisturiser and lots of it!  My skin is particularly sensitive and I have experienced Psoriasis in the past and currently have episodes of Eczema.  I have to use a lot of moisturising cream every day so that would be one thing that I could not be without.  To be honest, I love beauty products!  I follow a handful of make-up artists on Instagram (Lisa Eldridge being my favourite) and I find it quite therapeutic to watch a tutorial every now and again. Getting ready to leave the house Do you remember your mother or father getting ready to go out for work, or for the evening? If so, can you describe their rituals? What is your own routine when getting ready to go out for work or for socialising? Has this routine changed over time? My parents would occasionally attend dances where they would dress up. I do not really remember them getting ready but looking back at photographs I can see that they did look rather glamorous!  My routine for work includes applying make-up and straightening my hair.  I have never followed clothing fashion and tend to buy something that I like rather than if it is ‘In Vogue’.  I tend to seek out bargains and I do enjoy a good sale.  My clothes that I have not worn for a while go straight to charity.  I also do the same with both my daughters’ clothes.  A couple of years ago I gave quite a few old coats away to a charity that had sent out a plea.  When I visited the charity, I hung the coats on a rack and it struck me how utterly sad it was that a child would have to be without a coat in the depth of Winter.

Disability Free Text: I choose to accept I have a disability on technical grounds only, as my eyesight is poor. I wear spectacles from the moment I get dressed of a morning and they stay perched on my nose until i climb back into bed of a night. without them I cannot read the words on this document, indeed I wouldn't be able to read much at all, or write for that matter. I've learned to value my spectacles above any other possessions I have.
Other Adult Occupation Free Text: I am the bar manager at my local bowls club, I'm paid for five hours per week to perform my duties there, but the reality is I probably work fifteen or more each week. Its more for love than money.

Living Arrangement Free Text: I have been living in rented accommodation since September 2020 when I separated from my husband. I am in the process of buying a new build property that will be ready at the  end of July 2021
