Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing'. Mass-Observer P7590 describes themself as female; age 72; 'Married but living apart'; retired.;The Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing' was issued on 27 November 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their opinions on and experiences of health and wellbeing, in particular 'health, wellbeing and the healthy body'; 'identity'; 'growing up and learning about health and wellbeing'; 'growing older'; 'health, wellbeing and appearance'; 'getting ready to leave the house'.
Contents: Mass Observation Autumn Directive 2020. Part 2 MO number P7590. Female. 72. Married but living apart. Kendal Cumbria. Retired. Everyday Health and Well Being. Health, wellbeing and the healthy body; Health is very important to me. Any part of it can be taken away from you at a moments notice. It needs to be nurtured and cherished and not taken for granted. It requires daily maintenance just to keep things ticking along smoothly. Wellbeing. The mind needs daily care too. A positive attitude to life whatever is thrown your way. A cheerful disposition to everyone around you helps them to see you care. A joy in waking up each day and the anticipation of what the days experiences will be you and at the end of the day cherishing those memories. A healthy body. Weight, teeth, skin, posture, fitness. No particular person comes to mind. Identity. I do think my experience of health has been influenced by gender and  social class by wanting to fit in with those around me who are the same. Ethnicity or sexual orientation has not had any influence on how I feel about my identity. Growing up and learning about health and well being. I first became aware of health at nursery school aged 4. We were given a daily spoon full of Cod Live Oil and fresh concentrated orange juice. We were told it was to keep us healthy. We were still experiencing rationing at that time. My parents and extended family encouraged me to be out in the open as much as possible and to socialise with other children and adult family members. I believe it was to give me confidence in life’s experiences and to teach me to look after myself. I am very grateful for the opportunities I was given as a child to go and explore the geography and history of the surrounding area where I lived. I was able to see first hand the massive changes to the area of Smethwick West Midlands undergoing mass slum clearance. The old courts swept away to be supplanted by high rise flats.. The decline of the canal system and the slowly changes from steam powered trains to diesel locomotives. The difference the clean air policy introduced to clear away the frequent smog’s caused by factory and coal fire emissions. At those times you could taste the sulphur when you walked in the fog. My parents and school took responsibility for looking after my health and wellbeing. At primary school we were given a chart with a list of things we should doo each day and to tick the days we achieved each one. i.e. Brushing our teeth or sleeping with the window open etc. It encouraged me to be very honest and I felt quite guilty if I had to put a cross in any of the boxes. My whole school life had at various stages talks and films on health and wellbeing  suitable for our age group at the time. My mother also talked about periods and how you got pregnant when I was quite young. Possibly because I had a brother 6 years older than me. She told us together. Key moments I was thirteen when I fist noticed my boobs getting bigger and 14 when I had my first period. P7590 It was important to me at the time that my first bra was the same as my peers and that I had the same stockings. I wept buckets if my mum bought the wrong stockings and I was teased about it. She thought buying e thick ones for the winter would keep me warmer. I was terrified when my mother suggested I should shave under my arm pits. She did it for time the first time. Growing older I have always been active in some forms of sport. At school it was the gym or cross country running I liked the most. Once I had learnt to swim I went every week if I could. I also had a bike and would cycle everyday. I walked to and from school and home every day. Going home for lunch in my final year. I continued to cycle and swim until I had a series of operations which now prevents those activities. I walk most days now for exercise. Living in the Lake district I have been fell walking for the last 25 years. I don’t really look for articles on health and wellbeing. I do follow healthy eating recipes in the cookery books written by Doctor/food advisor Dale Pinnock. He gives explanations as to what food groups are good for what parts of the body and why. His recipes are quick and easy and small portions size. I am more aware of my limitations now I am getting older. I am not able to do as much as a few years ago. My body is wearing out. I don’t expect my approach to health and well being to change. I shall continue to stretch my body to its maximum potential. Also, to continue on my current eating habits with the exception of alcohol intake which needs to be reduced a bit. Health, well being and appearance I have always felt that to make that extra effort with appearance makes a person feel better. Even washing your face and brushing teeth every day has an uplifting affect. During the lock down times I have made the effort to still wear perfume and occasionally put on a nice skirt and top instead of slumming around in jogging pants. When you’re not going anywhere it is easy to slip into doing nothing but watch tv all day and lounge on the couch. I have not done this and found something positive to do every day so I don’t get bored and feel sorry for myself. With regard to being influenced by popular ideals of beauty, I suppose I have been to a degree. Seeing clothes modelled in magazines or on a pc web page influences your choice as to whether you want to buy a particular garment. Of course, you never look quite the same as the picture but you can in your own way feel comfortable with the choice. I have continued to shave my legs, wax lip and chin and whiten my teeth even though I am haven’t been going anywhere. My mother always made the effort to look properly dressed when going out. Wearing a hat and gloves in the1950’s and 60’s. These were dropped in later years as they became less fashionable. She coloured her hair and waxed her top lip as we all do up to a certain age. My father always wore a collar and tie or cravat with leisure wear. There is one product I can’t live without and would need on a desert island. Sun cream. I spend a lot of time out of doors and have fair skin and once had red hair. I were it on my face every day under a face cream as I can get sunburnt in minutes. I remember my mother getting ready to go to a dance. She had a very curved back and would get me to roll her back with a rolling pin while she laid face down on the floor. I don’t think it ever worked much. She was very self-conscious of her back . It was prevalent in her family and I have it to a lesser degree too. My father would always shave and shower or bath before going out anywhere. If to a dance with my mother he would wear dinner suit or sometimes tails if it was a really highbrow affair. My routine is similar. Shower first and maybe wash and style my hair. Wear something smart and add perfume. I used to always wear face makeup but now I just colour my eyebrows and P7590 occasionally a bit of lipstick. Yes my routine has changed over time. I don’t go out to dinner dances anymore. In normal times I would just go out for a meal or visit friends or social gatherings at one of the many clubs I have joined. These have ceased for the time being. I have not been out for a meal since February 2020. I have however visited a few friends in their homes when that has been allowed.

Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'COVID-19 (Update)'. Mass-Observer C7357 describes themself as female; age 67; married; retired customer services assistant.;The Directive 'COVID-19 (Update)' was issued on 27 April 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their experiences of the COVID-19 pandemic, in particular 'health'; 'the government'; 'news'; 'work and home life'; 'technology'; 'shopping and food'; 'entertainment and leisure'; 'personal hygiene' and 'sleep'.
Contents: MO C7357Female, 67, Married,                         Crawley, Retired Customer Service Assistant.Spring Directive 2020 - Part 2Covid 19 (Update}Health - On the second week of lockdown I suffered an extremely painful attack of acid reflux and after calling 1111 was sent to hospital for a check up. The ambulance arrived immediately as it was very quiet with no-one calling. The A&E at the hospital was similarly empty but fully staffed and I was seen quickly and was able to go home after a couple of hours. All the time I was at hospital there were only 2 other patients in the A&E department. Because my husband was not allowed to accompany me due to the Covid restrictions I had to call my daughter to come and collect me and take me home. Seemed a bit odd! Apart from that I have not had any physical issues at all during lockdown. Neither has my husband. Mentally I have been okay although there are days when I feel low but this passes quite quickly and I walk through the local fields with our dog which is a great boost to my spirits.Emotionally I have been fine. I miss my children and grandchildren but its something we have to do - so I just get on with it.The government - I think the government has done a good job regarding the decisions made. It is very easy for the press and the other political parties to be wise after the event. No-one could have foreseen this and the government is helping people as much as practically possible.As a country we have to get back to work. I believe that over the coming weeks and months restrictions will be gradually lifted. I believe that if the cases of the virus goes up then restrictions will be imposed again.News - I listen to the news once a day; but only a short 3 minute bulletin. Listening to the BBC Radio 4 Today programme is the most depressing thing as it is so biased and so depressing.I do listen to the daily Government Broadcasts at 5pm. I call it 'misery hour.' I think the daily government minister and experts are good. The questions from the general public are good. The questions from the press are hostile and repetitive. It's like they don't listen to each other. The same question is asked by every different reporter. The women reporters are usually more hostile than the men. They don't see understand how much this type of interrogations put people off.I have not experienced any challenges when accessing the news. As said I only watch the 5pm broadcast and listen to one other bulleting. I did not know about a petition regarding BSL. I wear hearing aids myself and I put on sub-titles if I find I cannot hear a programme.2Nicola Sturgeon in Scotland is a law unto herself. No doubt she has a BSL interpreter to ensue she scores a point with the politically correct brigade.Work and home life - I am retired so working from home/furloughed does not apply. There are just the 2 of us in our home and we have been fineTechnology- I was already familiar with Syke, Facetime and Whatsapp and have used these to keep in contact with children/grandchildren. I am a member of several social groups and have enjoyed zoom meetings. Zoom was a new experience and is very good except that everyone has a tendency to talk over each other. It is nice to catch up though. I've not found it stressful or a challenge as I like to think I am quite savvy when it comes to technology.I am a member of Facebook and use it primarily to keep in touch with a cousin in Nebraska USA and my WI group but otherwise try to use it as little as possible. I find it incredible that people are taken in by the absolute rubbish and vitriol which is posted on it by people who are quite pleasant if you meet them in real life. If you dare to post a different point of view then the dislike and hate which comes your way is palatable. If you rely on Facebook for any true news then you are quite likely to be disappointed. Because of the evils of Facebook I don't touch any other social media platforms.Shopping and food - . My husband has asthma so I have done all the shopping. This was a challenge at first. I had not used my online shopping account with Sainsburys for a while and found I was locked out of my account and completely unable to contact their helpline. was able to use Iceland Home delivery service and they were great. In order to avoid going to a supermarket more than once a fortnight I found that Abel and Cole were offering a non­ organic veg box which I have delivered weekly. Apart from going to a local store for milk and bread I am able to avoid the larger shops for the most part. From my experience in shopping in person I think the smaller shops are doing much better on the social distancing than the larger ones. You may have to queue at 2 metre intervals at the checkouts and in the queue to get inside but once you are in the shop then its impossible to keep the correct distance with in-store shoppers who just walk up close to you to get to the shelves, totally ignoring the in-store customers who are trying to play by the rules. In the smaller co-ops for example, where they operate a one-out, one-in system I feel much safer.Entertainment and leisure - I promised myself this year that I would not race about too much and have more time for myself-you should be careful what you wish for! I have rediscovered my love for jigsaws and have completed 3 hard ones so far. I enjoy alternate days walking the dog and have discovered some lovely walks right on my doorstep. Usually I drive to a local park and walk but its too crowded with joggers and cyclists at the moment so I am avoiding it. My husband walks our dog on the days I don't. On my non dog-walking days I walk locally for at least 40 minutes. I enjoy listening to Scala Radio and Magic Radio3and I try not to start watching TV until at least 4pm. Sometimes in the evening we will play games such as Scrabble or Mexican Train. I read a lot. I potter in the garden. I don't do any DIY. Housework is not something I enjoy, ever, and continue to do it as I normally do - when it needs doing. I have felt no compunction to start cleaning out cupboards! I have 6 grandchildren ranging from 3 to 17. I keep in touch with the older 2 (12 and 17) via Facetime but the other ones - 3, 5, 6 and 7 I have started to write to. Short letters and cards once a week which they really seem to enjoy getting. Hats off to the Royal Mail for keeping the mail deliveries going. It's beginning to be a struggle to think of things to say in my letters but I am managing to find various puzzles and photos to send. All in all I am surprised at how quickly the time has passed although I am getting a bit bored at times.Personal hygiene - My daily habits have remained the same. I set the alarm for 7am and I shower every morning. Normally I put on make up every day but I don't bother all the time at the moment. I always wear makeup to the shops or even to post a letter.Sleep - Funnily enough I have slept better over the past few weeks than I have other the past few years! I am aware that we are fortunate in that we don't have a job to worry about or an income in jeopardy. I worry for our children but manage to keep busy enough during the day to ensure a good nights sleep. My dreams, as far as I can remember have remained untroubles.

Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing'. Mass-Observer H1776 describes themself as female; age 70; married; former counsellor / psychotherapist. Response included lyrics from the song 'Wives and Lovers'; these have been redacted by the Mass-Observation Project for copyright reasons. Please contact the Mass-Observation Project for further details.;The Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing' was issued on 27 November 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their opinions on and experiences of health and wellbeing, in particular 'health, wellbeing and the healthy body'; 'identity'; 'growing up and learning about health and wellbeing'; 'growing older'; 'health, wellbeing and appearance'; 'getting ready to leave the house'.
Contents: H1776 Female 70 years’ old Married Broadstairs Former Occupation:  Counsellor/Psychotherapist Autumn Directive 2020 Part 2: Everyday Health and Wellbeing The first five words that come to mind when I imagine a ‘healthy body” are: Happy; Proportionate; Glowing; Clean; and Inoffensive.  I suppose physically a healthy body is a body that appears to be well nourished, clean well-toned and supple. This of course is an ideal and that shape and concept changes with age and disability. I always imagine top sports men/women to have healthy bodies as they have the correct nutritional advice and exercise routines that others may not have access to. Poverty may not allow us to eat as well as we could but education can help there. Obesity to me is a dread and I find it really unattractive. Some people aspire to look different or to look like celebrities, achieving this by plastic surgery Botox and or fillers. We have all noticed when this has gone wrong, the sight of hideous over blown lips are certainly not attractive. I suppose the ideal for me would be to be well toned, with no excess weight, good teeth and a great posture., and of course healthy. This though is just the outer shell of a person not the real self.  But this is always the first thing anyone notices. Growing up in the early 60’s the emphasis was that that girls were clean and tidy and on becoming a teenager needing to impress boys. We were influenced by Peer pressure, TV adverts, TV programmes magazines and songs etc., As I have grown older I look back on some of the songs that I used to listen to and love and hear the lyrics with a different mindset and am frankly horrified how some of them help shape the identity and behaviour of women. One example being ‘Sons and Lovers’ A verse went: This is an example of a clear message to women to look the part for men. I guess there are many more songs like that that give messages on how we should look or behave. Some of H1776 the songs from Grease show very clearly the way each that gender views the other. Just listen to the lyrics of Summer Nights! In the 50’s and 60’s there really wasn’t much taught around health and certainly not well­being. We had the usual visits from the ‘nit nurse’ in primary school. One good thing though was that we all had a bottle of milk a day and all had school dinners. No packed lunches. In our school we would sit 8 to a table and be served by older pupils, the teachers all sat in the dining hall too. It was a good way to eat and socialise. I still put all our meals into serving bowls when the family come and the grandchildren love this way of eating. We had very cursory sex education delivered in such a way that was excruciating for everyone. I went to an all-girls school so didn’t get to mix with the opposite sex much. I can remember being hugely embarrassed at having to shower with others at PE. I was in the fourth year at secondary school when we were taken to the new sports field that had showers. Oh, the agony of this. I was a skinny underdeveloped teenager and felt so inadequate next to some of the girls. They constantly gave the excuse of having a period so couldn’t shower. I didn’t have that excuse until I was 16! I still have the scar on my leg from my first attempt at shaving them. I pinched my brothers razor and made a real mess of it. I have never really been overweight until about 45 years old, and then I piled on the pounds. This has never really been resolved. This initially was down to an underactive thyroid and I put on 3 stone in about as many months. I lost some of it after medical intervention but I have never got truly back to my ideal weight. Even at the age of 70 I am conscious of weight and wear a towel right to the edge of the sea before going in, there are so many beautiful people around that I feel I stand out like a sore thumb. This is where the physical imperfections show and seem to matter. I have had two hip replacements and a shoulder replacement due to arthritis. I have scars that cannot be hidden and I am aware of them. I wish I didn’t have them. I have wrinkles and my hair has changed colour. Actually, I like the colour as it is much lighter with shades of silver. A new hairdresser also complimented me on the colour and said that many younger women were having their hair dyed this colour. It was apparently on “On trend’. She then spoilt it by describing it as ‘beige’ a colour that in my view magazines like to describe the invisible elderly. I try to exercise daily especially in ‘lockdown (Covid)” my husband is also 70, we play pool daily in the summer and since the weather has got colder we have dug out The Wii and play tennis or bowling. We also try to walk each day once the day trippers have disappeared from the beach. I make an effort each morning and shower and wash my hair. I put light make up on This is for my benefit as I believe that stopping caring for yourself is a downward slippery slope. I have a dread of being seen as dirty or smelly!! I visit the dentist and hygienist regularly. I have an absolute fear of losing my teeth. When I worked as a counsellor I worked with a man who had lost his front teeth. My own teeth always hurt after he had left the session, to point of me taking paracetamol on occasions! I have only lost one tooth and that was down H1776 to an overzealous dentist who probably couldn’t be bothered. It doesn’t show though as it is at the back of my jaw. Health and well-being are extremely important and I am pleased that this is taught much more openly ion schools now. Today this emphasis is not just on physical health but emotional well-being also. A great advancement since my schooldays. I just wish they would bring back social dinner breaks instead of the canteen style. I doubt thought that the young people would agree.

Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'COVID-19 (Update)'. Mass-Observer H1776 describes themself as female; age 69; married; former counsellor / psychotherapist. Response includes diary entries from 3 March 2020 to 1 June 2020.;The Directive 'COVID-19 (Update)' was issued on 27 April 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their experiences of the COVID-19 pandemic, in particular 'health'; 'the government'; 'news'; 'work and home life'; 'technology'; 'shopping and food'; 'entertainment and leisure'; 'personal hygiene' and 'sleep'.
Contents: H1776 Female 69 years’ old Married Broadstairs Former Occupation: Counsellor/Psychotherapist Spring 2020 Directive Part 2: Covid19 I suppose that we started to worry about coronavirus about February time when we started to hear the reports from China. I remember at the time being horrified at the way the Chinese citizens were being treated if they refused to adhere to the stringent lockdown rules. People and streets being sprayed with disinfectant and some residents being dragged into ambulances. It seemed so barbaric but in retrospect perhaps some more harshness wouldn’t have gone amiss in the UK.! We had a holiday booked for April 12th. We were to fly to New York stay for a few nights and then embark on a Transatlantic cruise back to Southampton. My daughter and friends also had a holiday to Tenerife booked for around the same time. There was much discussion about whether it would be safe to go. We all thought at that time that it would. Little did we know. I have now written some of the experiences from the past three months. If they are dated they were written at the time others are thoughts and memories in retrospect. 3rd March 2020... We have decided that we do not want to go on our holiday regardless of whether we are reimbursed or not. It is just too risky, so today we cancelled the day tour we have booked for our tour in New York and got an immediate refund thank goodness. I have also cancelled our day trip to Honfleur as part of our cruise. We are trying to get as much money back on sundries as possible as at the moment the cruise company isn’t cancelling. If they don’t cancel we are unlikely to get our money back. There are several cases of Coronavirus on Princess cruise ships. 16th March 2020 At indoor bowls this morning I felt slightly nervous about mixing with other players due to the spread of Coronavirus. The numbers seem fairly small at the moment but there is some scary talk around. Italy in particular sounds a terrible place to be the rapid spread is very frightening. A bowler came in and immediately started coughing and saying that he feels under the weather and then stating he has just flown in from Tenerife. Why oh why has he come. I stay the other side of the room all morning. We decided afterwards to give bowls a miss for a while. 12th March 2020. We went to Sainsbury’s to do a shop in case we are forced to stay in. It was like Christmas it was so busy but we managed to get most of what we needed. I wore gloves the whole time, the only drawback was the touch screen when going to pay only accepts skin contact so that worried me. I sanitised my hands immediately. 15th March 2020 things seem to be getting serious now with the spread of the virus. We are being told to socially distance ourselves particularly the vulnerable and 70’s and over. We are just coming up to that age and I have had lung problems for many years so feel even more vulnerable. I have a few friends all roughly the same age who will soon have to restrict their movements so I have set up a support group for us. The over 70’s isolation group. We had our first meeting this morning down at our beach hut. Four couples all sitting 2 metres apart from each other. We had a laugh and a chat but there was definitely an air of uncertainty. 19th March 2020. I have a really bad lung pain all week, I think that I got a chill on the beach whilst meeting our friends. Eventually I phoned the GP and he wanted me to go for an X-Ray because of my previously problems. I was really nervous about this. I had had a bad chest infection in early January so was unsure of what to do. I had a feeling that the hospitals might be a hot bed of virus infection. We eventually did go up to the X-Ray department and were actually in and out within 15 misn. We didn’t even have to pay the car park fee it was that efficient. I was prescribed anti biotics but didn’t really get to see the GP as lockdown had suddenly come into force. All I know from the doctor’s receptionist is that I have to have another one in three months’ time. Not sure why but because of the crisis I didn’t want to bother the GP. We will decide that in the future I think! We now know that officially we have to stay indoors so our group has retreated to an online one via WhatsApp. Keeping each other supplied with info about online slots at supermarkets etc. also sending jokes and videos. It has been a scary few weeks with far more to come. On the 25th of March the Government asked for 250,000 volunteers to help with shopping delivering medicines etc., 405,000 volunteers signed up in 24 hours. People the size of the population of Coventry, it makes you proud. Easter Sunday. 2020 The Pope gave his Easter Sunday address from the closed St Peters Basilica, an absolutely magnificent surround. The Archbishop of Canterbury gave his Easter Sunday address from his kitchen in Lambeth Palace what a contrast.! Not a good one either, I found it a little embarrassing. Sometimes we need a little Pomp and Circumstance. The builders on the site next to us are carrying on as normal. Sitting together in vans or on our wall having a cigarette there is no distancing what so ever. There has been such a tremendous surge in people wanting to rent an allotment that we have now closed the waiting list. We now have a waiting list to go on the waiting list. I guess the plots will sadly stay vacant for a while as we are not allowed to show people around. What a waste of time and growing potential. Still rules are rules and are there for a reason. The beaches are deserted but someone has written a “Stay Safe” poignant note with out of the chalk rocks. ../Pictures/Photos%20Library.photoslibrary/resources/media/version/1d/00/fullsizeoutput_1d24.jpegThe local Face Book page erupted yesterday when three people were spotted surfing. Suddenly there are online vigilantes talking about distancing etc. I am not sure how I felt. They were young and of course thought themselves to be invincible, the annoyance would be if they got into difficulties and had to call the rescue services out, who would then have no choice about social distancing. A young couple over the road have constant visitors from their family, all crowding around the gate on a daily basis. It is getting a little tiresome. They are not adhering to any of the guild lines about family visiting or social distancing. barely staying safe. 1st April 2020 My brother who lives in the Ilse-of Man has been rushed into hospital this has been frightening for my niece. And very worrying for us. She said that the paramedics were gowned and masked which seemed to make it more serious and frightening for her. He has had the Covid 19 test but this will be a few days for the results as they have to be flown to Liverpool for testing. He is 72 and has COPD and apparently has been told that if he has Covid he will NOT be put on a ventilator. This is dreadful. April 3rd 2020 Good news is that he hasn’t got COVID but does have pneumonia. He was discharged on the 5th April as it is deemed unsafe to be in the hospital. The daily death toll is looking to overtake Italy. I assumed Italy was bad because of all kissing hello obviously not, 15th April 2020 at last our holiday has been officially cancelled. No doubt we shall have to wait some while for a refund. We have been offered 100% cash back or 125% future cruise credit. Who knows what the future holds so have opted for a refund. We are doing Online grocery shopping at Sainsburys, and because I already have an account can do a click and collect. It is getting addictive. And quite good fun. At the moment though some of the basics are in very short supply flour rice eggs yeast etc. Meal planning and eating now seem to be in the forefront of my mind from waking till bedtime? Sourcing our usual wine is proving difficult. I have resorted to sending away for 6/12 bottles at a time from online wine merchants as Sainsburys have run out of our usual tipple. We shall all be heavy drinkers by the end of this. Most of friends say the same. With no one eating out and, on the beach, we wonder what the seagulls are eating Thursday night there was a hand clap for NHS I actually felt this to be slightly weird...seems the public either love it or hate it What news that Boris Johnson the Prime Minister has the virus and even more shocking when he was taken into hospital and then intensive care. This is getting really frightening. Famous people are dying some of natural causes, the papers are so full of Covid 19 they are not getting the usual grand obituaries. I wonder what Prince Harry thinks so far from home. I bet that he is regretting his decision to leave the country with Megan and the baby. He must be really worried about his family and friends especially as prince Charles had also had the virus. The Queens address to the nation with the theme of we’ll meet again was watched by millions I watched it and it was poignant, it made me a little emotional. It feels like we are fighting a real war. Thinking of TV, some of the programmes filmed at home just don’t work. Have I got news for you being the worst? There is a plethora of celebs doing little sound bites from their own homes to keep fit etc. Have to say not interested they have all become Irrelevant somehow. I am happy to watch repeats of drams and comedies. We have been watching the Covid 19 update from Number 10 everyday but it seems to be getting a little tedious. I just wonder what is going on in the rest of the world apart from this virus. We are trying to keep fit., by playing pool and working on the allotment. I am doing jigsaws, and going to bed earlier than usual. I wonder if people are no less likely to visit A&E and the GP surgeries I am thinking more about the hypochondriacs and time wasters, will habits change for good I wonder. I hope so. what happens in the future I think that I will be always wary of walking close to others. Today the Post lady tried to deliver parcels to house opposite today. They were out and she was clearly frustrated. I offered to help and take them in but she said she was not allowed she had to go back to the van do paper work and retake the parcels. She was grumbling* that it was worse than Christmas but with only half of the staff. She said she couldn’t understand people ordering paddling pools and fake grass. I can, actually if you are stuck indoors you need something to do. Just a strain on services I guess. Life goes on, Great Tits are nesting in the box and Robin is out singing. Feels today on April 22nd that people are relaxing their fears there seems to be more people passing the window. I went for one of my twice weekly walks but stayed on the cliff top as there were so many dog walkers on the beach. We can’t use our beach hut which is a pain, especially as it costs over £1000 a year to rent. Never mind better safe than sorry. Lovely weather this week we have been working on the allotment and rejoicing in the asparagus spears that are emerging. The birds are singing and the general feeling of well­being this brings makes this emerging crisis seems invisible. How hard it must be to be living in the city or a small flat with family. All on top of each other. I bet domestic violence and abuse of all kinds have increased. Boots have stated they can be a safe point for sufferers of abuse...not sure whether this is fake news as I can’t see how they manage that unless they allow them to use the phone? May 12 2020. Hurrah all our money has been refunded for our cancelled holiday. Monday June 1st 2020 A very sad today as a neighbour four doors down is being buried today. She worked in a London hospital and contracted the virus about 6 weeks ago and has been in a ventilator for some time. She leaves behind a husband and two teenage children. The numbers at the funeral are restricted and the family cannot travel to the cemetery in the funeral cars. All of the street came out and stood in respect as the hearse left. A colleague of hers gave everyone a pink rose and we walked to the harbour and threw the roses into the sea and sent her on her way so to speak. It was very sad and very sobering to know someone that has died of this dreadful and unforgiving virus. The next day the daughter wrote a heartfelt plea on social media for people to take notice of the restrictions and not meet up in crowds. She said that she was heartbroken at the sight if so many people taking no notice of lockdown. Part 2: Spring Covid 19 Update Health (some comments may be repeated from above) repeated sections are in italics My daughter who lives several hundred miles away was very unwell at the beginning of the spread of the virus. She is a single mother and had no one to get shopping or medicines etc., her ex wasn’t being that helpful although he did take the children. I was sending her a thermometer pain killers and throat sweets etc, by post. She was unable to speak to 111 as her throat was so bad but managed to email them. they just said stay indoors. This lasted over 3 weeks and she messaged to say that she had a bag packed in the hall in case she had to contact an ambulance she felt so ill. She was very alone and we felt very helpless. It would be good to have a test available for anyone that has been severely ill to see whether you have had the virus. 19th March 2020. I have a really bad lung pain all week, I think that I got a chill on the beach whilst meeting our friends. Eventually I phoned the GP and he wanted me to go for an X-Ray because of my previously problems. I was really nervous about this. I had had a bad chest infection in early January so was unsure of what to do. I had a feeling that the hospitals might be a hot bed of virus infection. We eventually did go up to the X-Ray department and were actually in and out within 15 minutes. We didn’t even have to pay the car park fee it was that efficient. I was prescribed anti biotics but didn’t really get to see the GP as lockdown had suddenly come into force. All I know from the doctor’s receptionist is that I have to have another one in three months’ time. Not sure why but because of the crisis I didn’t want to bother the GP. We will decide that in the future I think Our GP surgery will only do telephone triage, you are not allowed into the surgery unless by invitation of a GP. 1st April 2020 My brother who lives in the Ilse-of Man has been rushed into hospital this has been frightening for my niece. She said that the paramedics were gowned and masked which seemed to make it more serious and frightening for her. He has had the Covid 19 test but this will be a few days for the results as they have to be flown to Liverpool for testing. He is 72and has COPD and apparently has been told that if he has Covid he will NOT be put on a ventilator. This is dreadful. April 3rd 2020 Good news is that he hasn’t got COVID but does have pneumonia. He was discharged on the 5th April as it is deemed unsafe to be in the hospital. Monday June 1st 2020 A very sad today as a neighbour four doors down is being buried today. She worked in a London hospital and contracted the virus about 6 weeks ago and has been in a ventilator for some time. She leaves behind a husband and two teenage children. The numbers at the funeral are restricted and the family cannot travel to the cemetery in the funeral cars. All of the street came out and stood in respect as the hearse left. A colleague of hers gave everyone a pink rose and we walked to the harbour and threw the roses into the sea and sent her on her way so to speak. It was very sad and very sobering to know someone that has died of this dreadful and unforgiving virus. The next day the daughter wrote a heartfelt plea on social media for people to take notice of the restrictions and not meet up in crowds. She said that she was heartbroken at the sight if so many people taking no notice of lockdown. My husband had a hospital appointment with his consultant re a pelvic fracture. This was eventually rearranged and the consultant rang him at home and rebooked a face to face appointment for 6 months’ time. Emotionally I think that we have fared reasonably well. I am quite a fan of peace and quiet and do not needs crowds of people around me. I am missing the family of course but we can use the computer to see and talk to each other. I am enjoying the freedom from the rigidity of attending some meetings and clubs etc., all guilt free. If I haven’t read the book of the month for our book club it doesn’t matter we will not be discussing it. News Initially we watched all of the broadcasts re Covid avidly but this has really lessened off now. There was too much endless hour after hour. The Number 10 Government broadcasts were always a must, but less so now. It used to irritate me that the BBC never quite managed to start the broadcast on time always seemingly taken unaware that the PM or ministers had started. The charts were a bit boring, it was mainly the infection and daily death rate that we really wanted to know. I just wondered what we have missed that has gone on around the world that has gone unreported. A good time to break bad news so to speak as it probably wouldn’t have got a mention. The big news for us was Dominic Cummings breach of lockdown rules. Definitely one rule for him and one for others. We couldn’t believe that he still remains in office why? We wonder what does he know that we don’t. Work and Home Life We are retired so our daily routine has been unaffected. My daughter has been able to work from home but has had to manage two teenage boys and try to get them to do school work at the same time. They are at state school and have a certain amount of work set. But there is reluctance to do it. My sons’ children are at private school and the difference has been marked. The children have had to register on line each morning and they have a full lesson plan every day. Money makes a difference. The challenges for all of them have been huge. My son is self-employed so has had no income and doesn’t qualify for any help from the government. A big worry. Technology We have using Messenger to video talk to family, WhatsApp between friends and occasionally the good old-fashioned phone. We haven’t ventured onto Zoom yet but that may come. Shopping and food As I said before we have embraced on line shopping. We order food and my husband collects. This is extremely efficient and mostly we find a slot to suit us. The longest between shops have been 10 days, but that was only once. I have just started going out to the local fishmonger as they open very early so I can go out when it is quiet. Only one person is allowed in the shop at one time. I pay by contactless card so all pretty safe. I do not want to gout otherwise. The tourists that have been flocking to our seaside town has been horrendous. No social distances at all. We blame Dominic Cummins for this, people have seen his “getting away with it” as permission to flout the rules. There are no toilets open no car parks and no cafes. The streets are teeming and there is a stink of urine in the air. We are staying in. Entertainment and Leisure We have a very large allotment so that has kept us busy. It is about 20 meters from our house so perfectly safe to go to. We spend two hours a day there. We also play pool in the evening and sometimes board games. With the weather improving we can sit outside. There are plenty of jobs to do around the house but apart from clearing out a few drawers none of the jobs on the to do list have been done. We have probably done less in fact. Somehow it feels like permission has been given to let slip a bit. Personal Hygiene. This has stayed the same, daily showers and hair wash. The only bad thing has been our hair. We have just plucked up courage and given each other a hair cut after watching some tips on YouTube. The results have been ok. My next-door neighbour has grown a beard and now looks 5 years older. Sleep This has stayed much the same, sometimes worry about family has kept us awake. But we don’t need to rush up in the morning so it doesn’t really matter. Two of grandsons have been very worried, one refusing to go to the corner shop, and the other younger one afraid of going to sleep in case he dies. Very sad. Finally: The amount of death and infection to come as a result of this virus is truly dreadful. Hindsight is a wonderful thing but it does seem as if this country and government have been complacent and at times too slow to act. The PM being in hospital has slowed things but may have made a difference in other ways. He may be more empathic. Wearing of masks etc., why put a date in the future to start wearing them, travel restrictions should have been put into place much sooner and lockdown extended in terms of visiting beauty spots beaches etc., Let’s hope it all improves soon. Sent from my iPad

Religion Free Text: I would not describe myself as 'religious', as I associate this with behaviours rather than faith/belief system. I do identify as having a spiritual aspect to my life: meditation, contemplative music (based on Taize/Christian chants etc), belief in 'something bigger than us as a human race' that we can experience with nature (Gaia?)
Keywords: COVID-19 pandemic (2020-);Lifestyle, health and well-being;Employment and occupations;Tertiary education and students;Society and social behaviour;Emotional states;Physical health conditions;Family life;Family members;Reproductive health;Schools;Adolescence;Personal hygiene;COVID-19--restrictions--lockdown;Older people;Personal appearance;Pets;Leisure time and social activities;
Physical Description: Some details redacted by the Mass-Observation Project.;
Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing'. Mass-Observer W7332 describes themself as female; age 61; married; manager of university counselling service.;The Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing' was issued on 27 November 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their opinions on and experiences of health and wellbeing, in particular 'health, wellbeing and the healthy body'; 'identity'; 'growing up and learning about health and wellbeing'; 'growing older'; 'health, wellbeing and appearance'; 'getting ready to leave the house'.
Contents: Mass Observation: Autumn 2020 Directive MO no.: W7332 Female Age: 61 Married Living in , Matlock Manager of University Counselling Service Autumn Directive 2020 Part 2:  Everyday Health and Wellbeing Health, wellbeing and the healthy body What does “health” mean to you? What does “wellbeing” mean to you? How do you define these words? What do you think about when you imagine “a healthy body”? Please share the first five words that come to your mind when you think of this term. Is there a particular person or image that comes to mind? Please describe, or draw, this person. ‘Health’ means more than an absence of illness. In other words, it is so much more than having your options for life being impeded by specific behaviours, fears, uncertainties, discomfort, pain determined by the state of your body or your mind. I define ‘health’ in terms of feeling and living well in body, mind (and spirit?), able to make positive choices for self without restraints of dis-ease. ‘Wellbeing’ is for me a work-related word, as I have a professional role which aims to support and help develop the wellbeing of University students. It’s a holistic concept, which relates to the wellness of the physical body, the emotional life of a person, their psychological health (mental health) and their social health. If these human needs which relate to these areas are held in a healthy balance, then this results in wellbeing. Good wellbeing also impacts on our ability to learn well. ‘A healthy body’ for me, conjures the following 5 words: 1. Wellbeing 2. Mindset 3. Balance 4. Regenerating 5. Sleep An image? Maybe someone with an imperfect body – maybe older -walking on the beach/countryside, looking content and at ease with themselves. Identity How do you think that your own experience of health and wellbeing has been influenced by your gender, ethnicity, social class, or sexual orientation? Do you think your experience of health has been influenced by these or other aspects of your identity at all? As a young woman growing up in the 1970s, just as many young women and men growing up now, I became very body conscious and wanted my body to be not just acceptable to the opposite sex as I started dating, but desirable, special – even ‘perfect’, which I knew it could never be. I was always highly sensitive, and tuned in to comments from a very young age, that influenced how I regarded myself and whether I was ‘OK’ or ‘not OK’. At university, for a period of my life, I went on extreme diets, never at all needing to lose weight, but because my weight was the one thing I could easily control, and I was good at self-denial with regard to eating. We think of younger people now being influenced by social media about how they ‘should look’, and we can easily believe anxiety and roots of insecurity about identity and self as being relatively recent. However, this anxiety is not new, though the means for individuals to experience it and the culture to feed it, are different. Then, it was fed by a magazine culture such as ‘Jackie’, and advertising targeted to nurture our self-image as being inadequate. As young women we were also learning that we should not be objectified, but it was still a common experience to be wolf-whistled – and then to feel undesirable if we weren’t. Social media and advertising continue to shape the robustness or fragility of people’s sense of inner security, and their wellbeing. Wolf whistles have been replaced simply by ‘Likes’ and emoticons. As a 61 year old woman, I would have thought when younger, that I would no longer be bothered by how I look. But I know, regrettably, that it still matters. I’m aware of how quickly on meeting someone new, we sum up what we think of them – at both a conscious but also sub-conscious level. So for example, I don’t want to be seen as having an easy life, because that’s not how I see myself, but yet ‘privilege’ is culturally specific, and in many cultures then of course I am privileged and can easily be seen in this way, not least by the appearance of my ‘wellness’. I have a chronic health condition (Type 1 diabetes) which will never go away, and in many parts of the world this would be a huge problem for me. But I have access to great health care, and so I am able to enjoy my health to the full. I am also aware that in the Western world, Type 2 diabetes is a growing health concern and cost, affecting ever greater numbers of people. Because Type 2 diabetes, (as opposed to Type 1 diabetes), is a lifestyle-related disease – linked to excessive consumption of carbohydrate I find myself hugely irritated by commentators who lump both Type 1 and Type 2 together – as if I also have to take some responsibility for my condition. Growing up and learning about health and wellbeing When and where did you first become aware of “health” or of “wellbeing”? Who had responsibility for looking after your health and wellbeing when you were younger? Do you remember your parents, or other caregivers, talking to you about health? If so, what did they talk to you about? Where did these conversations take place? Did you receive any education about health in school? And/or did you learn about health and wellbeing in other ways – from friends, magazines, or the internet, for example? ‘Health’ for me was managed mostly by my mother, as the one who monitored both my brother’s and my wellness. She was the one who took me to the doctor when needed. However, she wasn’t too good with blood, so I assume my dad must have taken over at the point when blood was flowing much – though I don’t really recall that, so maybe we never really hurt ourselves too much. Health wasn’t a topic we discussed too much unless we really needed to, though I recall the little medicine cabinet being stuffed with the same things year on year: Vick, Germolene, Disprins, ‘Febs’ – for colds, plasters, TCP. As I became older, and more aware of my mum’s anxieties, I recognised her as having an element of fear about pain, blood, deterioration. She did talk to me at an older age, about the difficult birth she had had with my brother, how he nearly died, and the damage it caused her own reproductive system resulting in a hysterectomy when in her 50s. She also had an op when she was much younger to do with this, but she didn’t like to discuss it, or maybe thought it inappropriate? I don’t recall discussing ‘health’ at school too much, though I do remember a lesson at primary school when I was about 10, in which the teacher was explaining about arteries and veins, and the memorable element to this was not so much about the content of the lesson, more about the fact that one of my classmates fainted. I recognise that there was a lot I would have benefited from knowing more about, as a young child and a sensitive child. For example, I had a very occasional Stye on my eyelid, and because my parents never really gave me any information about what they were and what to expect, I believed them to be a sign of something very wrong, and to be feared as they were painful. I learned health-related things as I grew up, and from those I knew who experienced health issues. My dad broke his ankle, so I learned from him things like how long it took bones to heal. Never about pain levels, as he never mentioned that. My best friend had her appendix removed so I saw it in a jar(!) and learned a lot about the pain of that. Key moments As an adolescent, when did you first become aware of bodily changes associated with puberty? Are there any moments or rituals that you think are particularly important for young women or men? These might include, but are not limited to, first period, voice breaking, buying the first bra, or shaving, for example? How did you feel about these moments if/when they happened to you? My first experience that I remember of my own bodily changes came when I (eventually at around 13) had a bra. My mum had taken me to a rather traditional outfitters that also supplied my school uniform, and although I didn’t need a bra at that age, I was more than happy to be fitted with my first teenage bra. I recall learning about menstruation mostly from my school mates, most of whom started their periods a long time before I started mine. My mum told me nothing – well, very little. In fact, when I was 9, I came across some sanitary towels she had bought and not yet taken to her bedroom. I asked what they were and she rushed away saying she had to go and talk to dad. After hanging around for what seemed like ages, she came back and I had a hissy fit, saying I didn’t want to know anyway. I had learned that this was too embarrassing a topic and too difficult to talk to me about. When I did start my periods, I mumbled something very vague, and although she was then very practical about it all, I still didn’t really know what to expect, or more importantly, how to handle it. The handling of all information about puberty, by parents/care-givers and the experience of learning about how your body will inevitably be changing, is so precious and determines so much about how people develop into the adults they become. Growing older Throughout your life, what if anything, have you done to actively maintain your health both physically and mentally? Has this changed at all over the years? If so, was this due to a particular event in your life? Where do you get information about health and wellbeing now? Would you say you are you more or less aware of your body now? Why do you think this is? In future years how do you expect your approach to health and wellbeing to change? Since having Type 1 diabetes, I have consciously considered the importance of a good diet and exercise. Generally, I haven’t struggled with these areas of life. Up until COVID 19 took hold and we went into Lockdown, I had been going to the gym at 6.30am before work every morning apart from weekends, when I would be out walking with husband/family/friends. Since Lockdown, I have developed the practise of running in the mornings – although when the ground is too muddy or slippy, I walk. My husband and I have also been walking together every day. I have been doing yoga for many, many years and don’t struggle at all with the concept or practice of relaxation. My yoga practice continues and I attend between 3-6 online classes a week. I love it. I honestly believe this contributes to sound mental health as well as good strength and reasonable flexibility and balance for my age. Certain things have shifted for me though: 3 years ago I fell while ice-skating and broke my wrist. I had a bone density scan which indicated that I have some osteopenia – in other words, my bone density had declined more than would be expected for someone my age. My son is a physio, and he has advised me of the importance of doing weight-bearing exercise. I’d like to say I do this everyday, but apart from yoga, I can go a little while without. Must try harder….. I am much more aware of my body now, certainly have been within the last 5-10 years. Last summer I did a very short online course on MSK health, and after learning about the steep decline in body strength to be expected, along with overall deterioration in physical wellbeing, I vouched to do all I can to protect, strengthen and look after my body. So even just getting up out of my chair and moving around frequently when working all day at the computer, hopping on one leg then the other to make my husband laugh. All this helps. I do expect my health to deteriorate as I age, and in all honesty, I am very fearful of this. Both my parents experienced horrible decline: mum developing Alzheimers which she was able to conceal until the point when dad had a severe stroke and she had no idea what to do, leaving him on the floor, covered by a blanket overnight. Her dementia led to aggressive behaviour – she was terrified. My dad had to depend on carers to come in and manage his needs as well as oversee his wellbeing from a safeguarding perspective. My brother and I, both living a good distance away, felt helpless, it wasn’t possible to have them living with either of us for various reasons and all we could do was hunt out suitable residential care for them. My mother-in-law has been doing a national campaign to raise positive awareness of the elderly, emphasizing that you can be old and happy. However, she has recently had a stroke and is now having weekly falls. She had been a senior physio, but now struggles to get up from the floor when she falls. She has had a brilliant brain but is now trying to come to terms with the fact that she can’t still lecture or do public talks, or TV interviews – or even just teach bridge. She lives 5 hours away, and we are in another COVID Lockdown. Once again, I am left feeling somewhat helpless and very concerned. Old age seems to have little to recommend it. My expectations are not hopeful. Health, wellbeing and appearance In your view, how are health and wellbeing related to external appearance? Have you ever been influenced by popular ideals of beauty or physical appearance? Do you think your parents were influenced by these kinds of ideals? If so, in what way? Are there any health or beauty products (excluding medicines) that you couldn’t live without? What would be your Desert Island item? Health and wellbeing can certainly be linked to external appearance – very sadly. We live in a culture which celebrates youth and beauty. It is very easy to become anxious about not being ‘young enough’ or ‘beautiful’ or maybe just ‘too shy’, and therefore seen as a ‘wallflower’, someone who doesn’t stand out enough, is apparently ‘boring’. I now notice that older people in adverts tend to illustrate people with conditions such as erectile dysfunction or urinary incontinence. They may also feature as smiling grandparents – but even then they may be considering how to pay for a sensible funeral plan. Ok, I can cope with this, but I often dislike this artifice of the ‘perfect world’. For those younger, not seeing themselves as having that perfect skin or shape, or the celebrity status that can only come with being so ‘desirable’, anxiety is fuelled with discontent. We are led to believe that we should all be able to achieve happiness, and therefore with this perfect life – its what we can expect to have. But I don’t think this is a default state for the human race. Contentment and appreciation of who we are and what we have, never mind happiness, is not compatible with a consumerist society. I have been influenced by ideals of beauty in many respects – (see my earlier reflections on Identity). I learned from a young age that I wasn’t really pretty, and that I was too shy and awkward to be very popular once I’d progressed from Infants School. Now, I am comfortable with who I am, but it took me a while to get here, and a journey that progressed through a number of years of disordered eating. However, it probably did take me into a career of professional Psychotherapy, which I may not have otherwise considered, so for that, I am thankful as its been a great career. Were my parents influenced by these ideals? Yes, to some extent, but I believe just my mum was, and only to a limited extent – and even now, I’m struggling to come up with an example, so maybe its not true. My dad didn’t really care how people looked, as long as they were honest people. I guess for my mum, she could be a little of a ‘social snob’, certain people mattering more in her social landscape than others, because of who they were, what their status was. My dad cared nothing about that. Neither of my parents put great pressure on me or my brother to be someone we couldn’t be or didn’t want to be, and they gave unconditional love. That is a huge gift I have had from birth. What could I not live without? Difficult to answer as there is a difference between what I regularly use every day, and what I couldn’t live without. I would struggle to be without my toothbrush and toothpaste. I also like to use moisturiser every day and my skin would now feel dry without it, likewise handcream – but I could always improvise. Hair wax I use on an almost daily basis – without it, my hair can be flat. I have no need really for make-up, wearing very little of it. I am happy to wash my hair with just water, happy to go without soap or deodorant, but forever? Probably not. Getting ready to leave the house Do you remember your mother or father getting ready to go out for work, or for the evening? If so, can you describe their rituals? What is your own routine when getting ready to go out for work or for socialising? Has this routine changed over time? My mother always got up earlier than my father in order to prepare his breakfast. He would get up – as late as possible – wash and shave, get dressed and eat his breakfast (bacon, fried bread and fried tomatoes). I remember nothing more ritualised than that, but I believe for a period of time, they had a ‘TeasMade’ contraption beside their bed which acted as their alarm clock while steaming into gear to produce a pot of tea. I have memories of our dog as a puppy, running off with one of dad’s socks while he was trying to get dressed, and then him feeding the dog with his bacon rind, which the dog sat and waited for, somewhat impatiently. When they went out in the evenings, I recall my mum sitting at her 1950s dressing table (which I still have), putting on a little make-up, but nothing much more than powder and lipstick. She didn’t take much time over it, but she didn’t need to, as in her younger days she was attractive. She seemed to brush her hair a lot more than I ever do. When I was very little, I remember her going to bed with curlers in her hair and a hairnet over it all. It must have been very uncomfortable. The clothes she wore were important to her, and she had prepared them in advance, getting them out well in advance. My pre-socialising preparation ‘ritual’ is very slapdash I think, and hard to call it ritual, or routine. Depending on the event, I will wash/shower. I very often have no idea what I will wear, and can frequently change my mind a number of times, using up precious tens of minutes that I haven’t allocated for the task. If my hair appears flat or in the wrong shape, I use wax to poke it into shape – I like it messy, the ‘dragged out of a hedge backwards’ look. Maybe a little hairspray to retain the messiness. Then finally a little eye makeup, depending on event – not much more than eye liner and mascara. And that’s it. If I’m going in to work (Pre COVID-19 days), all of the above would be done in the gym changing room after a workout, with the only difference being that I would have prepared my outfit the night before. That said, I still might have 1 or 2 alternatives – just in case.

Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing'. Mass-Observer N6622 describes themself as married; male; age 73; 'Self-employed Consultant - Financial Services'.;The Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing' was issued on 27 November 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their opinions on and experiences of health and wellbeing, in particular 'health, wellbeing and the healthy body'; 'identity'; 'growing up and learning about health and wellbeing'; 'growing older'; 'health, wellbeing and appearance'; 'getting ready to leave the house'.
Contents: MO Number:  N6622  Marital Status:  Married  Sex:  Male  Location:  Wickford, Essex  Age:  73  Occupation:  Self-employed Consultant – Financial Services  Part 2: Everyday Health and Wellbeing The challenges of COVID-19 mean that in recent months, there has been a lot of reflection on health and wellbeing in unprecedented circumstances. But what about health and wellbeing in everyday life? We learn about health in many different ways, and it can mean different things to different people depending on their circumstances. In this Directive, we want to find out what health and wellbeing means to you (and what it meant before COVID-19) but particularly where your ideas about health and wellbeing came from, and what has influenced your own experiences of health and wellbeing in everyday life. Health, wellbeing and the healthy body Whatdoes “health” meantoyou?Whatdoes “wellbeing” meanto you?Howdoyou define these words? For me, health relates to my physical state. Despite having Osteoarthritis and Raynaud's Phenomenon, I think I am still healthy because I have nothing that might stop me from being active, no breathing or organ issues. Wellbeing, on the other hand, is my overall state, be that physical, mental or self-caring. What do you think about when you imagine “a healthy body”? Please share the first five words that come to your mind when you think of this term . Posture, condition, strength, supple, lithe Is there a particular person or image that comes to mind? Please describe, or draw, this person. Some people like Ashley Banjo. Phillip Schofield, Nigel Havers Sex: Male Location: Wickford, Essex Age: 73 Occupation: Self-employed Consultant – Financial Services Identity How do you think that your own experience of health and wellbeing has been influenced by your gender, ethnicity, social class, or sexual orientation? Do you think your experience of health has been influenced by these or other aspects of your identity at all? I was certainly influenced by my social class in the in my formative years, the 1960s. I come from a working class background, parents from the East End of London, so food was looked at as fuel and was seasonal, less processed and basic (no pasta!), unlike now when various food types and health benefit go hand-in-hand and there are some who want good looking food, no wonky carrots! All were entirely acceptable when I was younger. All of my friends, both male and female seemed to be naturally slim and there was less evidence of obesity. I recently met up with an old friend who I had not seemed for close on 50 years and it was interesting from old photos we shared, to see that both of us have retained a similar build and weight that we had as teenagers. I do not think that gender and sexual orientation has had any influence. Ethnicity has not influenced me at it has always seemed to me that your ethnic background might determine how you look, for example a lot of Asians tend to be shorter than their North European counterparts. I think that all my friends were slim, naturally meant that you would consider that the healthiest thing for you and it has been something I have tried to continue as I have grown older. Although I have Raynauds and Osteoarthritis, I am still at a similar weight (10 stone) as when younger and until a recent hernia operation had rather luckily never stayed in hospital or had an operation under general anaesthetic. Sex: Male Location: Wickford, Essex Age: 73 Occupation: Self-employed Consultant – Financial Services Growing up and learning about health and wellbeing When and where did you first become aware of “health” or of “wellbeing”? Unless you were part of the scientific community, I do not think that there was much talk about ‘being healthy’ until at least thirty years ago. Before that people were defined and healthy or ‘suffering from poor healthy’ or perhaps ‘having mental problems’. Then in the early seventies, John Yudkin wrote a book entitled ‘Pure, White and Deadly’ highlighting the damage caused by too much sugar in our diets. From then on there appeared a mass of information produced by scientists, magazines and newspapers. Certainly, at that time there was then more interest being paid not only to sugar levels but fat and even eggs (hat tip to Edwina Currie), Wellbeing has appeared more recently at the start of the New Age way of life where there was more of a holistic approach to health that meant that body, mind and soul were as one. Although I was never an out and out New Ager, I certainly bought into the incense, crystals and food that was part of it. Who had responsibility for looking after your health and wellbeing when you were younger? Although my father would try to ‘build me up’ physically with Ribena and concoctionssuchasraweggsinmilk,itwasalwaysmymotherastheprimary ‘carer’. She was the person who supplied the Haliborange vitamin C tablets, instructions on how to care for hair and teeth and at one point why a smallpox injection was necessary. Do you remember your parents, or other caregivers, talking to you about health? If so, what did they talk to you about? Sex: Male Location: Wickford, Essex Age: 73 Occupation: Self-employed Consultant – Financial Services Where did these conversations take place? I do not remember much advice being given by my parents; it appeared to be a source of embarrassment to do this. My father perhaps mentioned STDs (not a term used at the time) and this would have been along the lines that the Royal Navy imparted where he served. My mother’s only advice was ‘do not bring any trouble home’ whenever I went out with friends. On reflection, I think this covered both breaking the law and getting girls pregnant! Did you receive any education about health in school? And/or did you learn about health and wellbeing in other ways – from friends, magazines, or the internet, for example? No health or sex education at school, not even a biology class. Any knowledge that was required came from friends or others in school that had somehow had learned about them. There were of course, ’dirty magazines’ but I am not sure now that their role was to inform! The internet was not available when I was thirteen years old. Key moments As an adolescent, when did you first become aware of bodily changes associated with puberty? I suppose the first sign would have been about 13 years old when the majority of my class in an all-boys’ school started having moustaches. The growth of pubic hair was also a sign of recognition. . My voice breaking was another pointer. In my case, it meant the end of my days in the school choir. I liked the deep voice but not the fact that I cannot sing in tune. Then, of course, the desire to masturbate and the dire warnings about the practice that seemed to be attached Sex: Male Location: Wickford, Essex Age: 73 Occupation: Self-employed Consultant – Financial Services Are there any moments or rituals that you think are particularly important for young women or men? These might include, but are not limited to, first period, voice breaking, buying the first bra, or shaving, for example? I think that shaving was the important ritual for especially when the moustache that had appeared or as it was referred ‘bum fluff’ was removed, inmycase by myfather who instructed me in the art. I watched him shave many times as a child and then a couple of times when older to get instruction. The first attempt was as expected a tad bloody as razorswere open ‘cut-throat’ or ‘safety’ razors, no five-blade Gillette’s at that time. How did you feel about these moments if/when they happened to you? The feeling that most of those I when having that first shave was that you overnight, grown-up or a man. You had attained maturity and you could show some swagger. All a bit premature as you soon found out when you started to work and earn a living and treated as the ‘boy’. Growing older Throughout your life, what if anything, have you done to actively maintain your health both physically and mentally? Has this changed at all over the years? If so, was this due to a particular event in your life? Staying healthy has always been a priority and has been so since I discovered girls and wanting to be attractive and smart. As have grown older, it has become even more important to me as the crux of being alive for many years. I have no great fear of being aged, but to be healthy, mobile and having all my faculties is extremely important. I think this became pivotal when I reached fifty years old and one realises that your youth is slowly departing. There was a period in middle age where I started jogging regularly as my work schedule had changed and there was time. However, this only lasted for about three Sex: Male Location: Wickford, Essex Age: 73 Occupation: Self-employed Consultant – Financial Services years and work demands did not allow sufficient time to carry. A regular swim on a Saturday morning for over twenty-five years has been the mainstay of my exercise and has not only kept me well but made new friends as well. Covid-19 has halted this and I now rely on walks either outside or when the weather is poor, on a treadmill that I purchase some years ago. Where do you get information about health and wellbeing now? A lot of my information comes from various serious websites such as the NHS MIND for example. I do not buy magazines such as Men’s Health as they are aimed at a specific market and do not apply. I use a local health shop for various items mainly seeds such as sunflower, pumpkin and flax but find that you can get swept away by the amount of so-called good stuff so one has to be selective. I am lucky enough to have an excellent GP and Pharmacist and both have been extremely helpful when it has been necessary to consult them. Would you say you are you more or less aware of your body now? Why do you think this is? In future years how do you expect your approach to health and wellbeing to change? Growing older has meant that I have become more of my body especially because of my Osteoarthritis, the need to be a good weight, have rest and movement. As previously mentioned, I am determined to stay well and live a good few many years yet, thus being conscious of one’s health is an important aspect. This is certainly going to continue throughout the rest of my life. Health, wellbeing and appearance Sex: Male Location: Wickford, Essex Age: 73 Occupation: Self-employed Consultant – Financial Services In your view, how are health and wellbeing related to external appearance? Have you ever been influenced by popular ideals of beauty or physical appearance? I think there is some correlation between health and wellbeing and external appearance in that if you feel well and look well, this is a tremendous boost to your confidence and attitude. I suspect many of us who have had a heavy cold and simply stayed at home, not shaved and worn an old comfy and warm tracksuit. You feel rubbish and end up looking rubbish!! However, I have never been influenced by the popular ideals of physical appearance. We are all individuals and I can never be the same as say George Clooney for example so why try? We have to find our path and accept what we have. I would never go for cosmetic surgery because I was not happy with some aspect of my physical appearance except when this is required for medical reasons such as burns. Do you think your parents were influenced by these kinds of ideals? If so, in what way? My parents were never influenced by these kinds of ideals, they were too busy working and bringing up me and my sister. My mother used make-up and my father used a hair cream such as Brylcream, but certainly not envious of the film stars of their day. I think they might have been a tad envious of the money they had though. Are there any health or beauty products (excluding medicines) that you couldn’t live without? What would be your Desert Island item? My shaving kit and moisturiser cream would rank high and perhaps some factor fifty sun-screens if the desert island was hot. I shave every day to keep up to standard Sex: Male Location: Wickford, Essex Age: 73 Occupation: Self-employed Consultant – Financial Services and have used a moisturiser for years to keep my skin dry and soft – nothing worse than rough skin! Importantly it makes me feel more whole as a person and have the integrity not to let myself go. Getting ready to leave the house Do you remember your mother or father getting ready to go out for work, or for the evening? If so, can you describe their rituals? I remember my father was the one with a ritual once he was ready to go out. He would pat himself down and recite “wallet, keys, handkerchief, and comb”. Only would he go out when he touched each item in its respective pocket. What is your own routine when getting ready to go out for work or for socialising? Has this routine changed over time? When going out to work I would prepare clothing and bag/briefcase the night before. When driving to travel, I would prepare lunch or snacks the night before to save time. The morning would be the usual shower, shave, moisturise, breakfast, clean teeth, dress, check everything in place and go. For a social night out with friends, it would start by selecting the clothes I would be wearing followed by a wash and shave, moisturise, clean teeth and then dress. I have adopted my father’s ritual of the pat-down and call-over in all cases of going outbut have added ‘phone’ as he didnot have a mobile phone untilmuchlaterafter I had moved out of my parent’s home.
