Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'COVID-19 (Update)'. Mass-Observer J7229 describes themself as female; age 67; married; journalist.;The Directive 'COVID-19 (Update)' was issued on 27 April 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their experiences of the COVID-19 pandemic, in particular 'health'; 'the government'; 'news'; 'work and home life'; 'technology'; 'shopping and food'; 'entertainment and leisure'; 'personal hygiene' and 'sleep'.
Contents: J7229 MOA Spring 2020 Directive – from J7229, female, 67, married, Sheffield, journalist PART 2: Covid-19 update I’ve actually just sent in my coronavirus diaries from March-June of last year, which have answered many of the questions posed here. I’ll just add a few extra notes: Health: Thankfully, everyone I know has kept pretty well during the past year, apart from a brother whose anxiety & depression has worsened. However, he has sought help for that, including Cognitive Behavioural Therapy – and is now back at work. He’s been very open with friends and colleagues about his ill-health, which has resulted in others telling him about their own mental health issues. Physically, though, none of my nearest and dearest have had Covid, though I do know through friends of others who have, ranging in age from mid-30s to 80+. One or two of those have been left with long Covid. The Government:  There have been times when they have handled this ineptly and badly. I eagerly await Dominic Cummings’ thoughts on the matter when he goes before a Parliamentary Select Committee in the next week or so. There is still (May 2021) a lot of uncertainty over what people can and can’t do, where they can and can’t go. However, the big success story is the vaccination programme. None of us can thank the NHS enough for that. News: I’ve very much rationed my news intake over the past year. There were months when Radio 4 in particular was like the scene in the Hitchcock film Blackmail, where a woman keeps hearing the word ‘knife…knife…knife’ in her head. That’s how I felt every time I turned on R4, hence my addiction to Radio 3. We’ve never watched much TV news, which has also been a boon. Our next-door neighbour’s 70-something mother has become more and more anxiety-ridden over this past year, because she’s been devouring the television news 24/7. Her daughter has tried again and again to get her to stop, but she can’t – she’s obsessed with the news, which has had a marked effect on her mental health. Maybe now she’d had the vaccines, she’ll calm down a bit. J7229 As for the Govt Press briefings – I’m afraid most members of the current Government bring me out in hives when I see or hear them, Boris Johnson in particular. So no, I have saved my temper and my sanity by never watching them. Work and home life: I’ve pretty much covered this in my coronavirus diaries. All I can add really is to say that, thankfully, my husband and I have always got on very well, and we make each other laugh a lot. Nonetheless, there have been times when I think he’s mentally slowed down – he’s become terrible at remembering names, for example, and gets facts wrong when retelling stories. That’s made me very impatient at times, as we’ve been together pretty much all day, every day. But he still makes me laugh – sometimes in the middle of my impatience – so the irritation has been nothing compared to what many others must have suffered over this past year. I’ve often wondered how working couples ­whose daily lives used to involve seeing each other only first thing in the morning and then in the evenings – have fared this past year. Two sets of neighbours are in that situation, both with two young children to home-school at times as well. But they all seem to have survived. Technology: Again, I covered this pretty extensively in my coronavirus diaries. Shopping & cooking: Ditto. I reckon we’ve eaten much better than usual, as I’ve been at home to make soups for lunch, and evening meals from scratch. But it also means we’ve eaten too much – and definitely drunk more than we did pre-pandemic. Entertainment & leisure: All I can add here is that I’ve started (but not finished) an online Introduction to Classical Music course. I want to take that up again, as it was interesting and useful. At one point, thanks to a book I’d bought – Year of Wonder, by Clemency Burton-Hill – I was listening to a particular recommended piece of music each day, but that’s gone by the board. I need to start that up again now, too. We’ve had almost daily walks as exercise, together with my regular Zoom sessions of yoga and Mindfulness (the latter including mindful movement). What else have I read? Various Moomin stories from the wonderful Tove Jansson – I only discovered them a couple of years ago, and they’ve been a great boon during the pandemic, with their messages of resilience, kindness, compassion and humour. Also Tove Jansson’s letters, and now her biography. Also The Time Traveller’s Guide to Regency Britain, by Ian Mortimer. I’ve read all his previous TT guides, too, and find them wonderful in the way they take you back in time, and bring previous eras alive. Again, there’s a lot to be said for being able to put the pandemic into a historical perspective, and learn about the hardships our ancestors would have encountered, and how they dealt with them (or not). J7229 Personal hygiene: This hasn’t changed. I’ve made a determined effort not to let standards slip. OK, I’m no longer standing in front of a lecture-or seminar-room full of students, but that’s no reason not to put on an Indian salwar kameez-inspired outfit, or a Gudrun Sjoden Swedish-influenced dress with bright leggings. Plus matching/mismatching earrings, necklace, ankle socks, scarves, whatever. I may not photograph myself in my ‘outfit of the day’ and post it on Facebook/WhatsApp like my sister-in-law does, but I still like to make the effort… Sleep: There have been nights of disrupted sleep, particularly early on in the pandemic. And yes, very vivid dreams, though I’m hard put to remember any of those now. But they were quite hallucinogenic in their colours, over-population of people, swirls of conflicting and overlapping events. My husband’s had them, too, as have other people I know – and have read about in the newspapers. I get them during my afternoon naps, too – where I’ve also discovered, much to my horror, that I sleep with my mouth open, so it feels revolting when I wake up, disorientated. As for what I do when I can’t sleep – usually, I’ll get up, make myself a cup of tea and a slice of bread and butter, read a bit of Agatha Christie, then go back to bed. Or I’ll stick my iPod on and listen to the hypnotic voice of my Mindfulness teacher reciting the 25-minute breathing meditation, and that almost inevitably puts me to sleep. That’s why I call it Beditation. ENDS

Keywords: COVID-19 pandemic (2020-);Lifestyle, health and well-being;Vaccines, vaccination and immunisation;Food;Health services and medical care;Family members;Personal appearance;Leisure time and social activities;
Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing'. Mass-Observer B6659 describes themself as female; age 65; widow; retired university lecturer.;The Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing' was issued on 27 November 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their opinions on and experiences of health and wellbeing, in particular 'health, wellbeing and the healthy body'; 'identity'; 'growing up and learning about health and wellbeing'; 'growing older'; 'health, wellbeing and appearance'; 'getting ready to leave the house'.
Contents: B 6659 female, 65, widow, East Yorkshire, retired university lecturer Health I will not give an academic definition of health or wellbeing. I am not coming to this topic for the first time and my previous academic background will influence any definition I give. Five words 1. Active 2. Alert 3. Supple 4. Pain free 5. Blooming No person comes to mind. People are infinitely variable and the visible is not the full story. I think it is a mistake to pick certain body shapes or grooming as an ideal for health. I think the year one was born is important. I was born after the introduction of the NHS and penicillin. There were vaccinations for smallpox, TB and later polio. But one had a range of childhood diseases such as measles, mumps and German measles which modern children are vaccinated against. There were epidemics of polio when I was very young. One heard of occasional outbreaks of smallpox and typhoid. It was important to avoid these. It was important to select food carefully at good shops and store food carefully. For example my mother would never purchase potted meat or cream cheese. Food was plain, seasonal and home made. It was important to take care about water quality in rural areas. My parents, the GP, the baby clinic in an old Victorian school, the school nurse and the local pharmicist were responsible for my health. I think wellbeing is a useful, but more modern concept. No. We learnt about food values in Biology, and this was a very useful topic. It was more useful than cookery, which can be learnt from a book. Home had a nineteenth century attitude that food was important in maintaining good health. I have read the nineteenth century volumes of the Lancet with interest as apart from some surgery and case experience it is food and nutrition which underpinned anything positive. I have paid attention to what I eat, not in terms of organic and non-organic but in terms of consulting my old MAFF ‘Handbook of Nutrition’ to ensure I have a balanced diet and keeping a food diary so I can search out seasonal fruit and vegetables. As I age I ensure I have enough daily protein. I like most vegetables but I avoid a certain group. I do not purchase prepared meals or sauces and I very rarely eat out. So I have control of my meals in terms of food values, fat, sugar and salt. I enjoy seasonal fruit and vegetables. I also check my BMI from time to time and avoid putting on weight. It is all a bit self righteous. I cannot avoid ageing, or unseen problems which might need medical tests to detect, but I do what I can to help myself. B 6659 I think it is important for me to have variety in activities each day, including absorbing hobbies, some exercise and seeking out new interests. My parents were not really influenced by transient ideals. They regarded make-up as necessary for actors. Neatness and appropriateness was the ideal. Character and personality were seen as important. I find it amusing to look at old photographs and to date them by the style of glasses and colour of lipstick. For a sojourn on a desert island I would probably chose a bath with hot water and soap as my luxury, to remove all the salt water. I would also chose a comprehensive book about plants, so I could find which were edible and the food values, and could study which plants would be useful to make a big hat, salves and lotions.

Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'COVID-19 (Update)'. Mass-Observer B6659 describes themself as female; age 65; widow; retired university lecturer. Includes daily record of televison watched and radio listened to between 20 March and 6 May 2020.;The Directive 'COVID-19 (Update)' was issued on 27 April 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their experiences of the COVID-19 pandemic, in particular 'health'; 'the government'; 'news'; 'work and home life'; 'technology'; 'shopping and food'; 'entertainment and leisure'; 'personal hygiene' and 'sleep'.
Contents: B 6659 female, 65, widow, East Yorkshire, retired university lecturer . UPDATE SECTION: Health Nothing, apart from catching the coronavirus, and experiencing tiredness for a couple of weeks. I had a mild bout and live to describe it. I did not require medical assistance. I embarked on walking up the stairs to equal Everest. At first I was very tired but later I could easily fit in 600 feet or 1,000 feet while tea brewed. To date, I have passed Kilimajaro and am now ticking off peaks in the Himalayas.  I am in a fortunate position. I have hobbies, a garden, e-mails and the weather has been good. I have found it different but in a curious way it has not been unenjoyable. Knowing that everyone else is in the same position has made a difference. But my family and friends have been well upto now and that has been important. The Government What are your thoughts on the political decisions that have been made? It was an impossible position. Without knowledge of the disease, whether people could be infected but not show symptoms, whether it could be passed on by those not showing symptoms, how it was transmitted, what proportion of cases would be mild, or serious, or fatal, it was fightingin the dark. The government did its best. There will have to be serious discussion of the policies and timing – but not yet. It is no use comparing the UK with other countries as different countries collect data in different ways. Only the excess deaths with illuminate the overall picture. It will be important to learn lessons as this may not be the last pandemic. It is always possible that this will be a rehearsal for future pandemics. What steps do you think the British government will make in the coming months? It is difficult to predict as their ideal will probably not coincide with practical necessity. The R number may rise if the lock-down is relaxed.  Also the population may be very cautious, whatever they are formally allowed to do. But there will be a need to get people back to work in some way. The daily updates Yes, I have been watching this daily. I do not watch the rolling news. I have the 6pm new on, but tend to be busy doing other things.  I like experts being present to comment and answer questions. I am glad the pool of questioners has been widened. I do not know anyone who has had difficulty accessing the news. I have seen the Scottish use of a BSL interpreter. It is a good idea. It made me want to go and find out more, but the library is shut. Work and home life. I am retired so have been in a fortunate position. One child is working from his home, one is on a hospital front-line and one is working as usual. The son who is working from home, and his wife, who is working from home, are also home schooling. I wish I could go and run the home schooling, but that is impossible. Technology I have probably been exchanging e-mails with friends more frequently. But I haven’t seen them. I do not use Zoom, Facebook and all these other modern methods. Neither do I shop on-line. People occasionally recommend You Tube items on random subjects. I do not use such methods to access news. Shopping I continue to shop in the village, once weekly for milk and once for everything else. It is slightly limiting but it is adequate. Flour has not come back onto the shelves. I would have purchased some rice if I had foreseen the lock-down. But there are plenty of potatoes. My eating habits have not changed. I am pleased that seasonal vegetables and fruit are available. I have tried a few new things. In honour of the VE Day commemoration I have read through my file of wartime recipes and have been doing a tried and tested recipe each day. Yesterday I included homemade fish cakes. Tomorrow I will include Woolton Pie. I will have to use a wartime pastry recipe, including potato, as I am using flour sparingly. Entertainment and Leisure I find I have time to think about my embroidery projects as I am not distracted by other tasks. As I both design and execute these I am making better progress than in normal times. I have done spring cleaning, which is not usually top of the daily agenda. I am making a wholecloth quilt. This is a new project which I would not have attempted without the lock down. I planned to try making dipped candles but I have not yet had time. I have made some cards to try tablet braiding. But I need to do more spring cleaning to find two colours of wool. What have I been watching or listening to? I am a creature of habit. I have kept a diary of the best each day so I can tell you, to date. I regret that broadcasts has mainly consisted of repeats. I have watched the Coronavirus Update daily, but have not always noted this. I have half watched some programmes, while doing another task at the same time. Update, 2 Greatest Generation, 25 VE Day films, 81 Rumpole of the Bailey Personal Hygiene I would describe my regime as the same as usual. But my hair is now much shorter, as I was due to go to the hairdresser when lock-down started and have used a hair clipper on longest setting. Fortunately my hair is not dyed or permed. Sleep I have experienced no problems sleeping. I am active during the day, get up at a set time, go to bed at a set time and read in bed for a set time ( unless I am at the end of an excellent book ). The village has been very quiet, which has been excellent. There has been a curfew, as an accidental consequence of the lock-down. Dreams I am afraid I have yet to remember any dreams, ever.

Keywords: COVID-19 pandemic (2020-);Lifestyle, health and well-being;Reproductive health;Schools;Adolescence;Society and social behaviour;Gender inequality;Health services and medical care;Physical health conditions;Family life;Family members;Mental health;Employment and occupations;Libraries;Personal appearance;Personal hygiene;Leisure time and social activities;
Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing'. Mass-Observer F4813 describes themself as female; age 49; living with partner; 'librarian (public libraries)'.;The Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing' was issued on 27 November 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their opinions on and experiences of health and wellbeing, in particular 'health, wellbeing and the healthy body'; 'identity'; 'growing up and learning about health and wellbeing'; 'growing older'; 'health, wellbeing and appearance'; 'getting ready to leave the house'.
Contents: MO number  F4813  Sex  Female  Age  49  Marital Status  Live with partner  Town where reside  Bedale  Occupation  Librarian (Public Libraries)  Directive  Everyday Health and Wellbeing  Health, wellbeing and the healthy body To me 'health' describes physical and mental fitness -whether or not you have any identifiable medical conditions and to what degree these affect you, how your body and mind respond to physical activity and mental challenges (cerebral and emotional) and how what you eat and drink affects your physical and mental state. 'Wellbeing' to me describes a state of being -how comfortable you are in your own mind and body, your local environment and the wider world. The two are inexorably intertwined. The first words I think of when I imagine 'a healthy body' are: . Lean . Muscular . Strong . Glowing . Primed The first image which comes to mind when I think of 'a healthy body' is Leonardo Da Vinci's drawing known as 'The Vitruvian Man', which shows the proportions of a human form drawn in 2 superimposed positions inside a square and a circle.  The figure is naked, male, muscular, strong, with a thick head of hair. Oddly, however, I do not think of my own body as unhealthy even though I would not apply any of the words above to its form. Identity I believe identity can have a strong influence on an individual's experience of health and wellbeing and can think of several examples based on my own identity. As a woman my health and wellbeing has been influenced by biology and in particular hormones. I started my periods at around the age of 12 and for 7 years experienced severe monthly period pains which were not soothed by painkillers but could be relieved slightly through use of a hot water bottle and going through various bodily contortions to find a more comfortable way of sitting or lying down.  The pain did not prevent me from going to school but did affect my concentration and sleep and the bleeding made me wary of taking part in sporting activities (particularly swimming) in case of leaking. I went to a girls' school and can remember on regular occasions more than half the class sitting out a swimming lesson having given the reason that they were on their period, but remember the PE teacher being quite rightly sceptical about the likelihood of this. At the same time I developed acne on my face and back which affected my confidence (which was already low), was uncomfortable and again made me more reluctant to take part in activities such as swimming where I would have to show my back. Only when I started taking a F4813 Autumn 2020 -Everyday Health and Wellbeing Page 1 of 9 contraceptive pill when I was nearly 19 did the acne improve and period pain substantially reduce; the accompanying regulation of periods also making life easier to manage. I have also throughout my life experienced a high number of urinary infections (again design of the female body makes these more prevalent in women) and now in menopause I am experiencing hot flushes and bladder discomfort and in place of the pill am now managing my errant hormones with a vaginal pessary. I am delighted, however, to be post-period. Although some medical conditions have a genetic/hereditary link affecting people from particular ethnic backgrounds (e.g. sickle cell disease is much more common in the Black population), social factors (including education, income, local environment, racism and other discrimination) can have a much stronger impact on an individual's health and wellbeing and studies on health inequalities in the UK bear this out. Being White, middle-class, financially secure, heterosexual, educated to postgraduate level, in full employment for 25+ years, living in a long-term stable relationship and a relatively clean rural environment I tick a lot of boxes for positive social factors which strongly enhance my chances of experiencing good physical and mental health. I believe, however, that one social factor did have a long-term impact on my health and that is gender bias. Between the ages of 19 and 29 I experienced a physical health issue with almost daily symptoms of nausea, vomiting and diarrhoea which had a significant impact on my life.  Aside from the unpleasantness of the physical symptoms themselves, the condition affected my sleep (I was often awake many hours each night with vomiting and diarrhoea), my eating habits (I often didn't eat on the basis that the less I had in my stomach the less could come out) and my confidence, in particular in being out and about and not close to a toilet.  Anxiety and depression were also factors as I felt as if I would never feel 'normal' or well again.  I visited many doctors during that time, trying to explain the physical symptoms but also the impact on my life, but felt largely ignored or dismissed as a neurotic woman with irritable bowel syndrome which could only be treated for the symptoms -I never went anywhere without a packet of Imodium and took them almost daily. The majority of the doctors I saw were male and didn't seem to have any inclination to get to the root of the problem; eventually I insisted on a referral for further investigations, although even then my male doctor said he would make the referral against his better judgement. Numerous inconclusive tests later, it was only when I mentioned that in trying multiple different diets I had found that I felt better on a low-starch diet that I was tested for and diagnosed with the Coeliac disease which was responsible for the symptoms. The physical symptoms are now largely under control through a gluten-free diet but I am still dealing 20 years later with the affects of long-term anxiety, including a fear of using public transport and travelling abroad. Growing up and learning about health and wellbeing I think I first became aware of health at around the age of 4, as it's from that age I can remember visits to the dentist and doctor.  I was certainly aware that at times one had to suffer for the sake of improving one's health -I dreaded the annual fluoride session at the dentist where I had to sit clamping my teeth together wearing gum shields loaded with a foul tasting gel presented as an appealing 'orange' or 'strawberry'  flavour; I was on the verge of retching throughout the whole procedure which I think lasted around 5 minutes. I also remember at about the same age visiting a great uncle in hospital -he could only croak and whisper and I was told he was in hospital because he had lost his voice. This wasn't a particularly good explanation as he died not long after and I worried about losing my own voice and what this could mean; only many years later did I find out he died of throat cancer. My parents were largely responsible for my health and wellbeing, ensuring I had standard childhood injections (although I recently had a measles vaccination as this seemed to be missing from my early records), check-ups and twice-yearly visits to the dentist. They were also responsible to a large degree for my nutrition (although I resisted all vegetables except potatoes and carrots until I was in my 20s!) and activity levels.  As they both worked full-time, however, I also had other caregivers particularly in my early life -e.g. neighbours, an au-pair and nursery school teachers. These individuals certainly had a strong role to play in making sure I was fed and watered, socially engaging me and taking me out and about (e.g. to parks). Although I recall statements from adults, along the lines of 'eating carrots is good for you' or 'it does you good to stretch your legs' or 'you need to clean your teeth', I don't remember many two-way conversations about health during my childhood. Even at school education seemed to be targeted at very specific issues -namely periods and sexual health and even then delivered in a somewhat obscure manner. The internet did not exist when I was growing up so other sources of information were TV, books and magazines but I can remember very little which was health-related beyond picture books based on topics such as going to the dentist. Key moments I first became aware of bodily changes associated with puberty between the ages of 11 and 12 when my breasts started to develop and thin downy hair started to appear in the pubic area; not long after that my periods started.  I was largely accepting of the developing breasts and pubic hair but less keen on my periods starting.  Although I knew about periods from school (formal education and classmates starting their periods earlier than me), from my mum talking to me and from Judy Blume (who was writing teenage fiction before it was a 'thing') it was still a bit of a shock when I got my first one.  When it started I was waiting to be picked up by a friend and her parents to go to a horse show at Hickstead; I don't know why but I was too embarrassed to tell anyone so thought I could manage with layers of toilet paper in my knickers, which turned out not to be the case. I had a thoroughly unpleasant day making regular visits to the toilets and yet still ending up staining my knickers and light pink jogging bottoms which I managed to cover up until I got home, then disposing of the knickers and washing the trousers. For over a year on a monthly basis I filched tampons from my mum's supply and/or bought my own with my pocket money until I eventually made a wordless declaration that my periods had started by putting some tampons in a shopping trolley whilst out doing the weekly grocery shop with my mum.  For months before that she had asked as we passed the aisle of sanitary products whether I needed anything and I had shaken my head -I don't think I was fooling anybody and to this day I don't know why I couldn't just speak up. I've also never been to a horse show since! Although there were 3 women in the household (me, my sister and my mum) the topic of periods was always somewhat taboo in my father's presence -I remember vividly when we were going away on holiday when my sister and I were in our early teens that my dad had a small space left in his suitcase which my mum duly filled with a large box of tampons for 3; all I need say is that he wouldn't close his suitcase up until the offending items had been removed. My first bra, probably again at around the age of 12, was a size 28AA, which hardly seems worth bothering with. However, other girls at school, many more buxom than I, were sporting bras when getting changed for PE and I think I felt childish still wearing my vest.  Nowadays I'd much rather a vest than a bra, although I do tend to wear a bra when going outside the house, only for it to be removed asap on returning home -bras just feel so restrictive. I have never been particularly hairy and am quite fair, but again reacting to peer pressure I started shaving my legs at around the age of 13. Again not wanting to discuss the matter with my parents I risked if not life then at least limb by using the sharpest object in the house to which I had easy access.  My parents were chiropodists and had a surgery in the house, well-equipped with medical instruments including scalpels. I think the E11 blade was my tool of choice and when nobody was around I would stand in the surgery with one foot resting on the patient's chair and carefully scrape off the hairs, with only a few minor bloody incidents. Around a year later I plucked up the courage to ask for an electric shaver (Ladyshave) for Christmas, although I have to say it missed more hairs than the scalpel. As already mentioned above the only other bodily change I experienced in relation to puberty was acne, although in my case it has returned (although in a much milder form) since I stopped taking the contraceptive pill in my mid 40s and is therefore something I seem to be stuck with for life. Growing older My attempts to actively maintain both physical and mental health over the years have been sporadic. In school, aside from mandatory PE lessons I didn't take much part in physical activities in my school years, with the exception of gymnastics between the ages of 6 and 14 (at school and at a gym club); outside school I was pretty active until my mid teens, spending a lot of time playing outside with my sister and friends -riding bikes, racing each other in the garden, playing 'rounders' with a tennis racket and ball and (a particular favourite of mine) climbing trees. At university I rowed for a year in a half-hearted manner and did a lot of walking in the course of getting to tutorials and visiting college bars; during my 20s I played some badminton and took up swimming, gradually building up to half hour 40-50 length sessions on a fairly regular basis.  The swimming I have continued in a regular but sporadic way -when I'm in the swim, so to speak, I do around 3 half hour sessions a week for several months at a time but these periods are interspersed with hiatuses when I'm not seen at the pool for months. I stopped going in March 2020 when the first Covid lockdown occurred and am looking forward to going back, but not until I have been vaccinated. I am also an occasional cyclist -the tandem my transport of choice as I think my partner does about two-thirds of the work and just pre-lockdown had started attending yoga classes which I was very much enjoying and am hoping will resume some time this year. F4813 Autumn 2020 -Everyday Health and Wellbeing Page 4 of 9 As I write it is the 3rd January and, as is the case with many of us at New Year, am appraising my physical condition -the appraisal is not good; I currently weigh 10st 10lb which according to a BMI calculation based on my height puts me into the overweight category.  I have dug out my 5:2 diet book and will commence fasting (i.e. limiting intake to 500 calories) 2 days a week as of tomorrow when I go back to work.  I have used this diet before and found it good for weight loss, but the older I get the longer it seems to take. My aim is to reduce my weight to 10 stone (ideally 9, but I'm being realistic!) by the end of March.  I also want to be fitter as well as squeezing back into some of the clothes I have temporarily abandoned and am contemplating taking up running using the Couch to 5k download to instruct and guide me, but will have to battle the temptation to stay in bed on dark cold mornings. I am hoping to have had an anti-Covid vaccine by early Summer so I can also return to the pool. With regard to mental health I have in the past tended to get to crisis point before taking active steps to address the issues, be that CBT treatment which I have found reasonably helpful and/or taking anti-depressants to manage anxiety levels. I think I was in my late 30s before I accepted that I needed professional help and asked for it, with some false starts along the way before finding out what helped most.  I have also been much more aware since my 30s of the close link between physical and mental health and the need to take care of both. The internet has made it much easier to source information on health and wellbeing and this is my primary source when I am looking for information, guidance and advice.  One of my roles in the Library Service for which I work is to lead on the Health and Wellbeing aspect of the 'Universal Offers' devised by Libraries Connected which help inform the direction and delivery of public library services.  I have therefore attended training on topics such as health literacy and social prescribing, am signed up to numerous health-related partnership organisations so regularly receive email updates on matters such as mental health/dementia/public health campaigns and work on promoting health and wellbeing to the public through promotion of health books, other health resources, drop-in sessions with partners etc...  This has been an aspect of my work for over 5 years and I'd say has had a strong influence on increasing my awareness on matters of health and wellbeing, including my own. Alongside this there has been a noticeable change in the prioritising of staff health and wellbeing at corporate level within my work organisation, accentuated even further by Covid; the yoga classes I had started attending prior to lockdown were organised corporately to be available during the working day lunchtime period at a reasonable price and a strong emphasis is placed on supporting staff with physical and mental health issues. In some ways I would say I'm less aware of my body now -for example, the significant improvement in my digestive and overall health since a diagnosis of Coeliac disease at 29 means I am not constantly focused on my gut and my bowels.  In other ways I am more aware of my body -for a start there is more of it, having gradually put on around 2 stone in the 20 years since my Coeliac diagnosis.  My weight has crept up and down during the years and my markers for action (i.e. diet and exercise targeted at reducing it) have gradually moved from 9 stone to 9.5 to 10 and now 10.5 (or more accurately 10st 10lb currently!). When I am overweight I become more aware of my body because my clothes become tight and uncomfortable, I notice the sagging stomach in the bathroom mirror and the folds on my back and don't like what I see.  Eventually the discomfort and mild revulsion at what I see provides me with the incentive to act, but as I've said the older I get the harder it is to remedy the situation. Awareness of ageing (I will be 50 this year) is also influencing my awareness of health and wellbeing -I feel I need to act now to get into a routine of healthy eating and exercise both for the present and the years ahead.  My pension age keeps moving further away and I want to ensure that I am fit enough and healthy enough to enjoy the leisure time afforded by retirement when it comes. Time is no longer on my side. Health, wellbeing and appearance I believe that the relation of health and wellbeing to external appearance is limited.  I have learned by experience not to assume that the apparently overweight individual who has just got into the swimming pool will be a worse or slower swimmer than me; I know that just because someone has unsightly acne it doesn't mean that they are an unhealthy human being.  There are however exceptions to the rule -for example, visibly poor dental health is often a sign of broader poor health issues. As a teenager I was influenced to some degree by popular ideals of beauty and physical appearance -the posters on my bedroom walls were of men in the public eye that I, amongst thousands of others, held up as desirable physical specimens, be they of the day or timeless classics (for example the deceased actor James Dean, who for some reason was hot stuff in the 1980s along with Marilyn Monroe).  The poster shop Athena was an essential stop-off point if meeting up with friends in the shopping precinct at the weekend where we would flick through stacks of images deciding who we might add to our walls and who might get relegated to make space. With age this pure focus on physical appearance has dimmed and I am just as likely to find someone in the public eye attractive (that attraction being far more abstract than the attraction I felt in my hormonal teenage years) for their wit or intelligence, which isn't to say that there aren't individuals I don't admire only for their physical appearance, sometimes being fully aware that this is all I do admire about them. I think I have been less influenced, however, by ideals of beauty relating to women; I've often found catwalk models, for example, an odd representation of the female form, particularly those who by any medical standard would be classed as underweight, their bony joints and gaunt faces the very opposite of what I would consider to be beautiful. My parents were obsessed with appearance, but rather in the context of social status and presenting a picture of a well-ordered 'nice' family than health and wellbeing or physical ideals. As a family we always had to be 'well-turned out', in particular if we were going anywhere with my father -we couldn't go shopping with him as young children unless we were wearing nice dresses and shoes and my parents spent a lot of money on buying us clothes such as fake fur coats with matching boots. No matter my 'Rupert Bear' checked trousers were insanely itchy -my parents thought they looked smart and that's what counted. Photos and cine film of my childhood show my parents posing in lingering shots for the camera in what they consider to be chic and stylish outfits for the time -in the 1970s for my dad tight-waisted flared trousers, a tight shirt and a silk scarf around his neck held in place with a scarf ring; for my mum a well-fitted tweed jacket, long A-line suede skirt and knee-high heeled sued boots. They have always dressed smartly even when just lounging around at home, to the extent of wearing shoes in the house (high heels in the case of my mother); the only exception to this rule has been wearing of old casual clothing for gardening or decorating. The jogging bottoms I wear when working from home would be anathema to them. I am pretty low maintenance with regard to health and beauty products and aim to use a minimal number and where possible environmentally friendly options (e.g. solid shampoo which is wrapped in recyclable paper, rather than liquid in plastic bottle). My daily routine depends on toothpaste, pine tar body soap, solid shampoo and conditioner, aloe vera gel to moisturize, lip balm and a mineral anti-perspirant. My Desert Island item would probably be the pine tar soap as it can be used for body and hair washing and has antibacterial and insect-repelling properties -practicality outweighs luxury in this choice. Getting ready to leave the house My parents getting ready for work rituals were limited due to early starts in their self-employed role as chiropodists.  Both would have their main wash in the evening -showers for dad and baths for mum -so less needed to be done in the morning.  For dad it would be brushing teeth, washing face, combing hair and on occasions a quick shave (his facial hair growth was limited) -he did not use antiperspirant or deodorant because I believe he saw it as unmanly and believed there was no body odour to mask, which was not the case; he would be up at 6.00am and on the way to his surgery in Tooting by 6.30am in a suit, shirt, bow-tie and polished leather shoes in cooler months (covered by a white coat at work) and a dental-style tunic and trousers outfit in the warmer months.  Mum's morning routine would involve brushing teeth, washing face, using a hot brush to tidy her hair, a dab of antiperspirant and perfume and a quick make-up with foundation and bright lipstick; again she was smartly dressed, usually in a dress and tights covered by a white coat, with white clog-style surgical shoes to match when working from the home surgery and smart shoes (often high heels with straps and buckles) when she was working from the Tooting surgery, at NHS clinics or carrying out domiciliary visits. The white coats and dental-style outfits were changed daily and were always immaculate and well-pressed, the smell of starch from the ironing strong in the home. One thing that neither of them made time for was breakfast, although dad may have drunk half a cup of tea before leaving and mum an orange juice and a black coffee before starting work. In the 1970s when my sister and I were young, my parents went out fairly regularly in the evening for gatherings at friends' houses, meals out on their own or with others, special events such as Ladies' Nights at the Masonic Lodge and occasionally opera and theatre. Their preparations were often quite hurried as they both worked full-time and due to working hours and traffic dad would rarely be home before 7.00pm, although he would try and block out later sessions in the appointment book to be earlier if going out.  My sister and I could be quite clingy with my mum when small so would often sit in my parents' bedroom watching them get ready. Dad would have a quick wash and brush-up and don a smart suit, shirt and bow-tie or black-tie garb if appropriate, combing his hair and giving his shoes a quick rub if not highly polished; as he always wore a 'proper' rather than a ready-tied bow-tie he might spend several minutes in a front of a mirror trying to get it just right. He has always been a worrier, particularly with regard to time-keeping, arriving everywhere with excessive amounts of time to spare; he would always be ready first and pacing up and down the hallway in a restive manner whilst waiting for mum to be ready. Mum's 1970s routine for going out would involve a quick bath if time and if not a wash and brush up at the sink, application of make-up (foundation, powder, eye shadow, mascara and lipstick) and a spray of perfume and dressing glamorously, quite often in long dresses set off with necklace, earrings and a bracelet.  The last thing she would do is paint her nails (hands resting on old newspaper), frustrated that she was in a rush and dad was pacing the hallway so she rarely had time to do more than one coat or to let the varnish dry hard before going out, sometimes having to prise from her flowing skirt the clenched hands of a crying child as she made her way out of the door. My routine for getting ready for work has been pretty constant over time and starts with a shower or wash at the sink (on alternating days) and breakfast -the order depending on whether my partner C or I are using the single household bathroom first or second.  I then brush my teeth, moisturise my face and lips, get dressed and put in some earrings and strap on my watch, put my packed lunch together (either C or I will make sandwiches for the two of us) and tidy round the house if time (e.g. make the bed, take washing out the airing cupboard) before leaving for the office. I virtually never dry my hair with a hairdryer so either tie it back in a scrunched 'bun' or plait whilst wet or use the blowers in the car to partially dry it on the way to work, tidying it up with a brush when I get there.  I also very rarely wear make-up, although on occasions may use a tinted moisturiser to cover blemishes/uneven tones/broken veins on my skin (particularly as I get older).  I have always been happy for people to see me and take me as I am and don't like the feel of make-up on my skin, the stains it can transfer to clothes and the time it takes to apply; aside from that I am an inexpert beautician and generally look like a child who's been at her mother's dressing-table if I spend any length of time on trying to alter (enhance?) my appearance. Work clothes are somewhere between casual and formal -I rarely wear a trouser suit unless interviewing job applicants or attending a conference but instead in winter tend to wear black trousers, a shirt or long-sleeved cotton t-shirt and a jumper or cardigan and black ankle boots.  Summer clothes are usually lighter-coloured trousers and tops or long dresses or skirts and tops with cardigans and sandals.  I find tights uncomfortable and restrictive and only on rare occasions do I wear these with shorter dresses or skirt suits with court shoes or boots. For socialising informally (e.g. meeting friends for tea/lunch/a walk) my routine is much as my getting ready for work routine but with the clothes worn generally more casual in winter (jeans, cords, casual shirts and jumpers, suede lace-up shoes) although similar in summer. For more formal socialising (e.g. weddings and other celebratory events) I spend more time on getting ready and may bath instead of shower and shave my legs; I also dry and style my hair using a hairdryer, apply a little make-up (foundation, eye shadow, eye liner and mascara) and carefully select an outfit which I think suitable for the occasion but which also complements my figure, laying out all the parts -the 'good' underwear, the dreaded tights, the dress, the cardigan, the jewellery (to earrings I will add a necklace, bracelet and smart watch) and where applicable the coat, scarf and gloves. I guess I feel that I'm a little more 'on show', am aware I may be photographed and that I may be compared to other women at the occasion and don't want to be found entirely wanting; to some extent the pressure is on and I become far more aware of my whole demeanour ­how I stand, sit, get up, walk and move around the room -than in day-to-day circumstances. Again there has been no change over time in my routine, but in general as I've got older I've felt a lot less self-conscious about what people might think of what I'm wearing or how I look (in contrast to my teenage years and even early 20s when there was always a lurking fear of being singled out by my peers for ridicule or identified as 'uncool' or an outsider). In mid to late middle age I feel comfortably camouflaged as I go about my business, largely off the radar of potential detractors and impervious (almost) to outside judgement on my appearance. This is female liberation.

Disability Free Text: Multiple Sclerosis- progressive Type 2.Affects my ability to walk, plus difficulty in speech & dexterity.
Keywords: COVID-19 pandemic (2020-);Lifestyle, health and well-being;Family life;Health services and medical care;Adolescence;Emotional states;Reproductive health;Physical health conditions;Mental health;Personal appearance;
Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing'. Mass-Observer O3436 describes themself as female; age 66; married; retired civil servant. N.B. Mass-Observer uses incorrect MO code of 03436 rather than O3436.;The Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing' was issued on 27 November 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their opinions on and experiences of health and wellbeing, in particular 'health, wellbeing and the healthy body'; 'identity'; 'growing up and learning about health and wellbeing'; 'growing older'; 'health, wellbeing and appearance'; 'getting ready to leave the house'.
Contents: MO no. 03436. Female. Age 66. Married. Weymouth. Retired Civil Servant. Autumn Directive 2020 Part 2. Health means that if it is good you can engage in any activity without any physical problem. Wellbeing means that your mental health is stable & that you are enjoying life in general. Pain free. Relaxed. Unmedicated. Energetic. Healthy. The manageress of a charity shop in which I volunteer. She is very tall, exceedingly slender & athletic. Her whole being exudes health. Her legs are strong & without any fat. Her muscles can virtually be seen through her skin. She glows. I don’t think that my own health has ever been very greatly influenced other than by my upbringing. My parents never had any problems with their health until old age arrived & I think my childhood was influenced by that. I cannot recall them going to see the G.P. for any relatively trivial ailment. In fact I don’t remember Dad ever going until after retirement. So that must have rubbed off on me. I used to avoid the doctors if I possibly could so I think my childhood made me more resilient. My first recollection of health was asking my mum about the no spitting notice on the bus. She explained it was to prevent the spread of TB. I also remember being fascinated by the VD clinic notices which I saw on the back of public toilet doors. I think I must have wanted to know about those too but I cannot remember ever enquiring! Awareness of wellbeing must have started somewhere & in memory it is how I felt when I sat on mum’s lap & listened to Sunday evening radio with her. I am certain that I was never given any health education anywhere & my parents never divulged to me the ‘facts of life’. I was given an approximation of the facts by a neighbourhood friend who was a year older than me. I think I was age @10. The entire adolescent period of my life was one of total embarrassment, fear & shame. When I got my first period my mum seemed to be very cross with me. I wanted a bra because my friend’s were wearing them but I couldn’t bring myself to ask for one. I was given a second hand one by one of my mum’s friends. When I was 17, at work but living at home I fell pregnant & I had an abortion. My parents must surely have known but nothing was ever said. I was so unhappy for so many years but I know my parents loved me. I really don’t understand why my parents were so reticent. I had an older brother but we never ever discussed anything of this nature as a family or as siblings. My parents were heavily involved in voluntary social work for the probation service & also for the National Marriage Guidance Council. As a young teenager I was used as a model for a photo used in a big poster erected in the cathedral in my childhood city advertising the services like sex education available with the MGC. My dad posed as the model for the counsellor. How ironic! I was diagnosed with Multiple Sclerosis in 2011. My great love for many, many years had been walking. We had moved to North Wales 12 years earlier to be closer to Snowdonia. So M.S. eventually put paid to that activity. I used to go to exercise classes for M.S. patients in Wales & then from 2013 in Weymouth when we moved here. I gave that up a couple of years ago. It was a long way to go on my mobility scooter & very expensive by taxi. We have no car & I cannot get on buses unaided. Then I used to do a small number of exercises at home every day. This has now been whittled down to three days a week whilst my boiled egg lunch is cooking! I look on the NHS website if I think I need information. I don’t read any of the M.S. literature, my head is firmly stuck in the sand! As I have stage 2 degenerative M.S. I know that the chances of my getting worse are almost certain. I try not to think about it at all. It is difficult for me to separate appearance from health & wellbeing. I know this is wrong both morally & in reality. For example the homeless often have gorgeous suntanned skin & can look the absolute picture of health. I couldn’t imagine being without my daily antidepressant tablet. A lifetime supply would have to be my Desert Island luxury. If that was refused then I would request a cyanide suicide capsule. My parents were always well groomed. Dad in particular was very fond of his clothes & very much the dandy. Cravats etc. Unduly influenced by Noel Coward. Mum tried but had less confidence & style. I used to get fully made up when I went out & always wore mascara every day. I don’t even own a single item of cosmetics now. I simply rely wholly on my natural beauty. Oh & I studiously ignore mirrors & reflective surfaces.

Disability Free Text: Multiple Sclerosis- progressive Type 2.Affects my ability to walk, plus difficulty in speech & dexterity.
Keywords: COVID-19 pandemic (2020-);COVID-19--restrictions--lockdown;Emotional states;COVID-19--UK government and policy;News and current affairs;COVID-19--public information;Communication;Shopping and retail;Leisure time and social activities;Personal appearance;Personal hygiene;Sleep;
Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'COVID-19 (Update)'. Mass-Observer O3436 describes themself as female; age 66; married; retired civil servant. N.B. Mass-Observer gives MO code as 3436.;The Directive 'COVID-19 (Update)' was issued on 27 April 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their experiences of the COVID-19 pandemic, in particular 'health'; 'the government'; 'news'; 'work and home life'; 'technology'; 'shopping and food'; 'entertainment and leisure'; 'personal hygiene' and 'sleep'.
Contents: MO no. 3436. Female. Age 66. Married. Weymouth. Retired Civil Servant. Spring Directive 2020 Part 2. COVID 19 (update). My household of two, this being me & my husband, have not suffered from any health issues of any kind during lockdown, thankfully. I have felt happier than usual although I do worry about the pandemic & also about the terrible racial tension in the U.S.A. I have been content to stay at home, the only thing that I miss is the library. I feel so sorry for the Government. I am sure that they have all been trying desperately to make the wisest decisions but what a maelstrom of advice they have had to wade through. I have never at any time doubted that they all have everyone’s best interests in mind but they cannot help or please everyone all the time. In coming months I expect the restrictions will become more relaxed, more use of face masks to be advised plus a lot more financial responsibility & restrictions to be handed to local government. If social distancing is to be adhered to perhaps they will restrict travel to stop the recent crowding at beaches & beauty spots. I wish they would bring in a mileage limit so people stay in their own areas either by local council boundaries or geographical counties. For the first time in years I have watched some T.V. news, although very little. I always look at teletext news for the U.K. but have also been looking at the world news. I have only seen bits of the daily 5pm updates. I did watch Boris deliver the last of his lockdown changes. I thought he was clear & quite impressive. I don’t think anyone else could have done much better. Oh I definitely think there should be BSL interpreter plus available subtitles on every news broadcast. Absolutely no reason why not. My home life has improved because I have M.S. & I haven’t had to force myself to go anywhere because I think I should. I usually volunteer at a charity shop two mornings a week & very often I only went out of a sense of duty no matter how I was feeling. I am more than happy at home with my solitary pastimes of reading & puzzles. Also my husband is usually out three days a week plus away from home once a month for a 2 or 3 night break. He cannot do this & so I never have to worry about his absences. I usually only keep in touch with two people by ‘phone, I have never wanted to have Skype or FaceTime. All the rest of my friends I correspond with by email or in 2 instances by post. I don’t use any social media. I have been keeping in touch with 3 of my friends from the charity shop by phone but I wouldn’t mind if that stopped really. I stammer badly so the phone can be an ordeal. I have not had any real food problems. I have had fortnightly supermarket deliveries as I had before lockdown. Some things have been hard to get but I have muddled along well. So nothing has changed radically. Every day I spend@ an hour on my cryptic crosswords a little longer on jigsaws. I was buying & selling jigsaws on EBay, usually I buy them from my charity shop. A few weeks ago my shop manager delivered a big bag of jigsaws from the shop for me. They are going to keep me going for months! My reading matter, once I had finished my library books, has been lent to me by my sister in law who has a vast number of books. So no shortage on that score either. Maybe the jigsaws & books haven’t all been what I would have picked out but I am sure the variety is beneficial! I watch many films & some drama series, during lockdown my favourite shows have been The Great British Sewing Bee, Grayson Perry’s Art Club & Keith Lemon’s Craft Factory. I listen to Radio 2 & some Radio 4. The only thing that has changed in my personal hygiene is that my short hair is in dire need of a cut! I am sorely tempted to cut my fringe myself! Luckily I had a very, very brutally short haircut at the beginning of March so it hasn’t been too horrendous for too long plus no-one sees me anyway apart from my husband & he stopped looking at me many years ago! I am a brilliant sleeper! For example yesterday I had 50 minutes after lunch, 20 minutes after dinner, bed at 10.30 where I slept soundly until 7.30! The only thing that has changed a little bit is I have had a couple of nightmares about the pandemic & have once or twice thought that I was ill with it in the night. A sort of half awake dream but all was normal in the morning. Well normal for me! I haven’t been told of any severe cases of insomnia by my friends.
