Keywords: COVID-19 pandemic (2020-);Lifestyle, health and well-being;Family life;Adolescence;Mental health;Emotional states;Personal appearance;
Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing' by Mass-Observer G6158.;The Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing' was issued on 27 November 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their opinions on and experiences of health and wellbeing, in particular 'health, wellbeing and the healthy body'; 'identity'; 'growing up and learning about health and wellbeing'; 'growing older'; 'health, wellbeing and appearance'; 'getting ready to leave the house'.
Contents: Part 2 – Everyday health and wellbeing Health, wellbeing and the healthy body Health and wellbeing is diverse, it means maintaining your body, your eating, your mental health, your passions and interests and finding meaning in your life and what you are doing. A healthy body is balanced, fit, able, okay, content. No particular person comes to mind Identity My own experience has been influenced, being male but more feminine has made me feel inadequate, I am overweight, cannot afford particularly healthy food. All of these do influence my health, especially class with my lack of access to healthy things, be it exercise, food, therapy, wellbeing measures, space, fresh air and more. Growing up and learning about health and wellbeing When I was young, but didn’t learn of mental health and wellbeing until a lot older. My parents looked after my health and wellbeing, they talked to me a little bit about it. Talking about sunscreen mouth ulcers, drinking, smoking etc. Did also get education in school, but I learnt from many other sources, probably most from the internet and my own research. Key moments Can’t remember a particular puberty moment, again shaving and voice breaking, these rituals are physical but the heralding of them is all a construct which is rather arbitrary. Acne was a bit of an anxiety aspect Growing older I focus a lot more on mental health, mindfulness, writing poetry, photography, fresh air, walks (less due to Covid). Overall it’s gotten worse, I smoke, I don’t drink as much as I did at Uni, I get less sleep due to work. I eat better, but also at times worse, but overall better. A lot worse since starting full time work. Still get a lot of health and wellbeing info from the internet and my own research. I’m more aware of my body, but less able to explain aspects, I hope I get into a better financial situation and I can take better care of my health. I’m suffering greatly in this situation. Health, wellbeing and appearance They are somewhat related, but aren’t totally aligned, for example mental health is isn’t related to external appearance, but yes, there are many things that are physical that can indicate better or poor health. It’s complicated. I have been influence, I think everyone has been influenced, I feel a bit shy about my hair loss, only at 25, about my weight and lack of visible muscles and hair thinning, so, typical anxieties for a guy/non-binary, but although anxiety his me sometimes worse than others, most of the time not so much, because of being demiromantic demisexual if people focus on the physical then I am usually not interested. I’ve only found one person not focussing only on physical attributes rather than on a person being an actual person. Of course my parents were influenced, probably not in the same way, the influence is greater now due to pervasive images on social media and not only movie stars and models, but influencers, YouTubers and many people that this generation feel as ‘friends’ rather than models to be looked up to. Truthfully I don’t have a beauty project that would be a desert item, only cleaning products or stuff for hygiene. Getting ready to leave the house I cannot remember so much their going out rituals. The ritual for mine is to have a shower, deodorant and mostly that’s it. Tying my hair up and letting it dry there before untying it. I used to use more hair gel, but now my hair is longer and I have lost some of it is thinning which has given me more recent anxiety.

Keywords: COVID-19 pandemic (2020-);Lifestyle, health and well-being;Family life;Food;Adolescence;Reproductive health;LGBTQI+;Mental health;Personal appearance;Personal hygiene;Employment and occupations;
Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing'. Mass-Observer S5767 describes themself as female; age 35; married; academic researcher.;The Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing' was issued on 27 November 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their opinions on and experiences of health and wellbeing, in particular 'health, wellbeing and the healthy body'; 'identity'; 'growing up and learning about health and wellbeing'; 'growing older'; 'health, wellbeing and appearance'; 'getting ready to leave the house'.
Contents: S5767, female, 35, married, Gravesend, academic researcher Part 2: Everyday Health and Wellbeing Composing my thoughts for this entry, I realised that my perceptions of ‘health’ vs. ‘healthy’ are slightly difference things. Health is something we are each imbued with-or not-as the antithesis of illness. To be healthy, however, is contextual to each of our physical states, with maximal levels set by the pre-existence of a disability, or by a person’s age. Being healthy is indeed also related to the cultural context in which each one of us frames our health. As I age, I would say that my perception of what it means to be healthy has altered from being truly functional at 100% capacity (not cognisant of my physical self, because it is functioning so well), to recognising that living with some minor aches and pains is a normal part of the day-to-day. The concept of being healthy is also linked very strongly to my actions-what I eat, how much fresh air I get, the exercise that I take. My healthiness is a much more active choice than my health. ‘Wellbeing’, by comparison, is a broader and more inclusive term than includes physical and mental health, almost verging into something outside oneself-a broader sense of peace and contentment. A healthy body is well nourished, of reasonable weight (neither skinny nor overweight), smiling, gently tanned, reasonably muscular but not ridiculously so, and well rested. My view is incredibly ableist and a bit fatphobic, to be frank! Without a shadow of a doubt, my view on health and wellbeing has been shaped by my experiences of who I am. Being genetically slim has fed into my fatphobia. More generally, maintaining the ‘right’ weight (curvaceous, but not skinny) is pretty much a walk in the park for me. I get a lot out of exercising (and am conscious how much it improves my mental health, which can be decidedly troublesome) and like my physique more when I do. I grew up a white girl in a country filled with other white girls. I have never really been conscious of judging what my body shape looks like versus that of others in a negative way for myself. Quite simply, I do not see the relevance of body shapes in the media and magazines for my perception of my own. I feel as though I have a good sense as to what being healthy and happy is for myself, even if I do not achieve the mental health axis of this very consistently! I have no idea when the concepts of health and wellbeing first entered my mind-likely the former before the latter. I suppose one thing I do remember was my mother hiding the weighing scales from the bathroom early in my teenage years as she was worried that I would be inclined towards anorexic (thankfully, this never happened. I love my food.) My parents were responsible for my health, but to be honest I do not remember them saying much about it. What lodges in my brain more is our school nurse asking us how much we ate crisps and chips! To be honest, the 1980s were a very different era for what was deemed healthy food than now. I certainly do not remember learning about health and wellbeing from friends or magazines and the internet was not something I had access to until my middling to late teens. Even then, it was dial-up and it simply did not cross my mind to seek out anything on health, bodies, celebrities or fashion that might have altered my perceptions. I had my first period at 13, when my Mum was in hospital being treated for cancer. I cannot recall if this was before or after my mother took one look at me one day and decided I needed to start wearing crop tops (I quickly talked her into bras instead). I suppose this was my first conscious knowledge of my own adolescence, but even then they did not lodge, as it were. I had no real sense of my adolescent changes being a ‘thing’ that was particularly exciting or annoying. It simply happened. I suppose such moments mattered to other people and am particularly cognisant of how dreadful they must be for transgender or non-binary folk, if during your teenage years they force you even further now a route for which you want no part. This feels like an even more live issue after the Supreme Court’s ruling on puberty S5767, female, 35, married, Gravesend, academic researcher blockers before Christmas. In my 20s, I started cycling in order to commute because it was quicker and cheaper than the other options and meant I actually got some exercise. Later on, partly as a result of doing in my back, I added pilates into the mix. The pandemic has dramatically changed all this-I knew no commute meant a high risk of me not exercising at all, so I switched to running every weekday morning instead of cycling and later added in some use of the rowing machine to try to maintain the tone of my butt (cycling being very good for it). This exercise definitely does me good in terms of both mental and physical health-I have a distinct horror of being a physically unable old lady and want to do all that I can to maintain my physical health whilst it is still easier. Pandemic times have also meant that I have taken up counselling to help with my mental health, after a truly horrible patch in June after years of on and off depression and anxiety. I am probably more aware of my physical self than I used to be, partly because I do a lot more to maintain it, as well as the need to work at my mental health. I hope that all of these positive things can be maintained, even when I go back to the office. My information on health and wellbeing comes from an odd mix of scientific papers, the NHS/CDC/ECDC/WHO websites, and various people’s ponderings on positive things for mental health on Twitter! It helps to know quite a few people who are neurodivergent in terms of the latter, you get wonderful and well-curated content. My own sense of my health and wellbeing are in no way related to external markers by which other people could perceive my status, but I recognise that, when it came to describing a healthy body above, I went straight to such markers! Pot, kettle, black. Oh dear. I do not set a huge store by conventional ideals of beauty and trying to impose them on myself (being content to be middle of the road, as it feels like a waste of time that could be better spent doing something else to put in the effort to be otherwise). I also likely strongly judge especially women who seem to put in ‘too much effort’. This probably reflects the views of my parents quite strongly. I do, however, recognise that a lot of this is because I ‘pass’ easily in society as a thin, vaguely blonde, white girl. No effort is required to scrape by. On the counterargument, I like my curves (various people have complemented me on them) and work to maintain them. Saying this, if abandoned on a Desert Island, I would like to take some Heads and Shoulders with me, as I have been using it for about two decades and have a paranoia that I will get a lot of dandruff without it! As the child of two unemployed parents, going out for work or of an evening was not really a thing for them. My morning routine has changed substantially this year, but currently consists of-climbing out of bed, followed by breakfast and putting on sports gear, morning run, shower, brush hair, stretch out my back, stow dirty washing, make hot water bottles to keep me warm in the office, start my working day. Before the pandemic, getting up varied depending upon whether I was working from home for the day (as previous, but no running), commuting to Scotland (no running, no hot water bottles, breakfast only once at the second train station), or working in Scotland (breakfast once at the office, no running, no hot water bottles, cycling to and from work).

Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing'. Mass-Observer H7289 describes themself as female; age 59; married; writer.;The Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing' was issued on 27 November 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their opinions on and experiences of health and wellbeing, in particular 'health, wellbeing and the healthy body'; 'identity'; 'growing up and learning about health and wellbeing'; 'growing older'; 'health, wellbeing and appearance'; 'getting ready to leave the house'.
Contents: Autumn Directive 2020 MO number: H7289 Gender Identity: Female Age: 59 Marital Status: Married Home: Cambridge Occupation: Writer Part 2: Everyday Health and Wellbeing Health, wellbeing and the healthy body What does “health” mean to you? What does “wellbeing” mean to you? How do you define these words? To me ‘health’ means keeping my body and mind in good condition and providing them with the things they need to thrive. ‘Well-being’ is a more over-arching concept that includes this and other aspects including the emotional and the environmental. What do you think about when you imagine “a healthy body”? Please share the first five words that come to your mind when you think of this term. A healthy body is one that receives the correct fuel to perform all the necessary functions to live. It is in balance. Is there a particular person or image that comes to mind? Please describe, or draw, this person. I don’t think there’s a particular person. It’s more a feeling of someone being well-balanced and happy in their own skin. Identity How do you think that your own experience of health and wellbeing has been influenced by your gender, ethnicity, social class, or sexual orientation? Do you think your experience of health has been influenced by these or other aspects of your identity at all? Unfortunately, as a woman I think that over my lifetime health has mostly been presented in terms of how much you weigh and your bodily appearance. As a naturally pear-shaped child from a working class background I experienced constant negativity about my size and appearance. As a teenager in the 1970s I was not thin, and therefore I was considered unhealthy and told to diet. (Not by my parents I hasten to add). Adults, who should have known better, seemed to think nothing of making hurtful remarks. For me dieting meant eating next to nothing and feeling ill. I played sport ­hockey, tennis, netball -and was very active outside of school, but as I was never going to be the H7289 ‘ideal’ shape I still suffered from the name calling however hard I tried. During all this time I was, in fact, quite healthy and very rarely sick. The effect of this on my ‘wellbeing’ has been life long. Even now, after all I have achieved, I still suffer from crippling self-doubt, hate putting myself forward and have to fight hard to overcome depression and anxiety. Growing up and learning about health and wellbeing When and where did you first become aware of “health” or of “wellbeing”? Both my parents were great believers in children having fresh food and lots of exercise. They didn’t use the above terms when I was young, that would have been later when I was in my teens, and things like healthy eating and a good diet were discussed more. Who had responsibility for looking after your health and wellbeing when you were younger? My parents. Do you remember your parents, or other caregivers, talking to you about health? If so, what did they talk to you about? Where did these conversations take place? It was generally my mother, and we would be at home. We always ate as a family and both my parents encouraged us to eat fruit and vegetables. We knew these were good for us, as was milk and cheese. My father and uncle both grew vegetables and fruit. Did you receive any education about health in school? And/or did you learn about health and wellbeing in other ways – from friends, magazines, or the internet, for example? At school health advice tended to be part of other classes such as Home Economics and Sex Education. This was between 1972-79. I read a lot of magazines and spoke with friends. Key moments As an adolescent, when did you first become aware of bodily changes associated with puberty? I was probably between 12 and 13. Are there any moments or rituals that you think are particularly important for young women or men? These might include, but are not limited to, first period, voice breaking, buying the first bra, or shaving, for example? When I was a teenager it was definitely first period and shaving. I also remember a lot of talk going on in the girl’s changing rooms about pubic hair, which seemed to be of great significance at the time. How did you feel about these moments if/when they happened to you? I hated getting my first period. It was the end of the world and I’m sure my mum got quite fed up with me complaining. Growing older H7289 Throughout your life, what if anything, have you done to actively maintain your health both physically and mentally? Has this changed at all over the years? If so, was this due to a particular event in your life? I’ve been active for most of my life and enjoyed lots of sports. Unfortunately I had to give up tennis due to a wrist injury in my teens, but I still swim whenever I can and enjoy walking. I’ve always found gardening and being out in nature very good for my mental health, and enjoy reading. As my main work is writing and researching this keeps my brain active, and also helps me to relax and escape from daily pressures. Where do you get information about health and wellbeing now? Books, science journals and practitioners. Would you say you are you more or less aware of your body now? Why do you think this is? Having had a few minor health issues, and cared for my mother during the three years before her death, I’m much more aware of my body now. In future years how do you expect your approach to health and wellbeing to change? I don’t expect it to change much now, unless I receive medical advice. I think I’ve reached the point where I now do what I need to do in terms of exercise and diet. Health, wellbeing and appearance In your view, how are health and wellbeing related to external appearance? They are integrally connected. Eating the right things and exercising gives the body what it needs to create healthy skin and hair, and strong bones and teeth. Without the right fuel the body would be undernourished and this would be reflected in a person’s appearance. Lacking certain vitamins etc can, in turn, affect a person’s mental health and overall wellbeing which may lead to other difficulties. Have you ever been influenced by popular ideals of beauty or physical appearance? Honestly yes, although it was never successful. I’m not built that way. Do you think your parents were influenced by these kinds of ideals? If so, in what way? I don’t think they were. They came from a generation that didn’t have the money to be influenced by things. They could only dream. Are there any health or beauty products (excluding medicines) that you couldn’t live without? What would be your Desert Island item? Factor 50 sun lotion. I burn very easily. H7289 Getting ready to leave the house Do you remember your mother or father getting ready to go out for work, or for the evening? If so, can you describe their rituals? I remember sitting at the top of the stairs and watching my father shave. He was very slow and careful about it. I remember the smell of this aftershave and how he dressed immaculately in suit, shirt and tie. My mother always went to the hairdresser before a night out. Her hair had become every fine after her third pregnancy and she hated it to look ‘flat’. Depending on the age of her perm it might be for the full works or a wash and set. My parents were always well-presented. It didn’t matter that we didn’t have much money. What is your own routine when getting ready to go out for work or for socialising? Has this routine changed over time? At the moment, of course, my routine is minimal. Washing and dressing. Sometimes, when I go out to get the shopping I might put on some foundation. When I went out to work I got up and showered every morning. Dried my hair and put on makeup ­I always went for a minimal, natural look which took very little time. I had a strict routine and knew what I was going to wear the night before. When I started working from home this routine differed slightly in that I didn’t worry about the makeup unless I was attending meetings, and my dress style became more casual. When I’m volunteering I wear old clothes as I get involved in cleaning and this can involve working at height or on the floor.

Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing'. Mass-Observer R7156 describes themself as female; age 56; married; project coordinator.;The Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing' was issued on 27 November 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their opinions on and experiences of health and wellbeing, in particular 'health, wellbeing and the healthy body'; 'identity'; 'growing up and learning about health and wellbeing'; 'growing older'; 'health, wellbeing and appearance'; 'getting ready to leave the house'.
Contents: R7156 Female 56 years old Married Swansea Project Coordinator Part 2: Everyday health and wellbeing Health, wellbeing and the healthy body “Health” to me refers more to an absence of illness, whereas “wellbeing” feels more holistic, so includes feelings of contentment. Health body 5-words: Energetic, active, balanced, well-fed, fit There is no particular person that comes to mind, but my idea of a healthy body is one that allows you to be active, and to go about your daily business comfortably. It is about what it allows you to do, not what it looks like. Identity My experience of health and wellbeing has probably been influenced by my gender and sexual orientation in that I grew up with women’s magazines and so have absorbed (and in some cases rebelled against) what these promote a straight woman should look like. I have also had the benefit of growing up being well fed with a balanced diet, and my family has not had to worry about where our next meal will be coming from. This I feel will have had a positive impact on my health. Growing up and learning about health and wellbeing I can’t pinpoint when I became aware of health or wellbeing. My maternal grandfather had Parkinson’s disease and rheumatoid arthritis, so I became aware of illness possibly before health, and was aware of the exercises he would do to cope with this and to try to keep himself mobile and active. My parents (and more specifically my mother) was responsible for looking after my health and wellbeing when I was young. Their approach was one of balance and moderation rather than abstaining. I can’t remember specific conversations and certainly not around losing weight. Although both my parents smoked my sister and I were very much discouraged from doing this (and both parents tried to stop smoking). We did receive education about nutrition in school as part of home economics classes. I do not remember any reference to sexual health. Most answers to questions would have come from magazines, friends and family (particularly mother and grandmother). Key moments I remember my first period starting, and was aware that it would happen and what it meant, but it was still a shock. I also remember buying my first bra. This was probably prompted by me after noticing more girls in my class were starting to do this. Neither of these things were treated as rituals or momentous events, rather they were just natural changes that happen. Growing older As I have grown older I have tried to remain a healthy weight and retain flexibility. (A healthy weight to me has always been one where I have felt comfortable rather than a particular size or weight). I have done yoga on and off all my life (my mother did Tai Chi) and enjoy walking. R7156 I try to maintain a healthy diet (limiting sugar, red meat and saturated fats) but also try not to be too ‘faddy’. My approach, especially as I grow older is to try to incorporate exercise into my daily routine so that it becomes a habit. As my father dies recently in his early 80s after quite a few yars of slow decline whch seemed to be mentally rather than physically driven (he lost motivation and became depressed) I have put more effort into trying to ensure I remain connected to the worls and to try to take steps to sensure my mental health and apacity stays healthy and positive. Health, wellbeing and appearance There is a limited relationship between health and wellbeing and external appearance, although I do not think that this equates to thinness. I think it is almost impossible not to be influenced by popular ideals of beauty or physical appearance. I am glad to have grown up in a time (1970s and 80s) when popular ideals of beauty seemed more obtainable and more related to people’s (womens’s) actual appearance. I don’t have any health or beauty products that I couldn’t live without, but my Desert Island item(s) would be sun screen and mascara. Getting ready to leave the house My father worked in engineering, so like many people that didn’t wear  a shirt and tie for work he would always be well-dressed when ‘going out’. My mother would also wear full make-up and be well-dressed whenever leaving the house, including just for things like picking us up from school. I have absorbed that ritual and would also always wear make-up (at least foundation, mascara, blusher, lipstick) when leaving the house. This has changed this year during the corona virus restrictions, and I initially stopped wearing make-up entirely. At first I thought that this make-up free approach would continue in the future. I am now beginning to re-assess this and am looking forward to wearing make-up again to go out as I have realised it is something I enjoy and not something I feel I have to do.

Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'COVID-19 (Update)'. Mass-Observer R7156 describes themself as female; age 56; married; project coordinator.;The Directive 'COVID-19 (Update)' was issued on 27 April 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their experiences of the COVID-19 pandemic, in particular 'health'; 'the government'; 'news'; 'work and home life'; 'technology'; 'shopping and food'; 'entertainment and leisure'; 'personal hygiene' and 'sleep'.
Contents: R7156 Female 56 years old Married Swansea Project Coordinator Spring Directive 2020 Part 2: Covid19 update Health I have not experienced any physical health issues during lockdown, apart from a general ‘stiffening up’ of my muscles and some lower back pain, which I think is due to reduction in the amount of exercise I am doing. My favourite form of exercise is walking (which I did most days pre-lockdown). Since lockdown began I generally only go for a walk once a week (and this is usually in conjunction with food shopping). This reduction is mainly because I feel somewhat anxious or ill at ease when out, which detracts from the pleasure I usually take from walking. So rather than potentially permanently associate anxiety with walking, I have cut back on this exercise. My husband falls within one of the higher risk categories as he takes an immune suppressant drug as part of his Crohns disease treatment, and luckily he has not experienced a flare up of his condition over lockdown, so has not required any medical help over the period. We neither have had any mental health issues, beyond a general anxiety about catching or passing on the virus, and the low level boredom of lockdown. My widowed father, who is in his early eighties, does however seem to have become frailer over the period. He lives independently, but does seem to be finding it more difficult to look after himself. This seems to be a mental health rather than physical issue, as he has become more isolated. I do speak to him every day on the telephone and visit once a week to drop off groceries, but I am worried about the effect the continued isolation will have long term (and whether there will be support in place to help him in the future). The government On the whole I am not impressed by the way in which the government has handled the situation, and think that other countries have been more successful in doing so. I am also not impressed however by the quality of political scrutiny from the media in this country, which seems to be based more around point scoring rather than proper scrutiny. Despite the rhetoric from all sides about ‘all being in this together’ as a country we seem to be becoming more and more polarised, which I think is potentially very dangerous. It is hard to predict, but I would imagine that the UK government will take steps to get people back to work. I am not fundamentally against this, as I think without this so many small businesses will disappear. What I do not have confidence in is that the government will do this in a planned manner. News I listen mainly to the BBC Breakfast news, and read the Guardian online and have started to buy a hard copy version of the Sunday Times. I also look online at the Robert Koch Institute and the WHO websites for reports on Covid19. I have not watched the 5pm government broadcasts, although I did watch the Boris Johnston broadcast from the 10th May on catch-up the following day. I am not aware of anyone who has had access challenges, but do support the use of a BSL interpreter. I have noticed that a number of other countries (including Scotland and Wales) do this, and think it is indicative of a lack of inclusiveness that the UK government broadcasts do not do this. Work and home life My experience of work during lockdown is perhaps different to many, in that I have gone from working part-time (2 days per week) to full-time work. This is because a new project has started during the lockdown period. I was not intending to work full-time but was concerned that the original project might be put on hold, and I was not sure, under the terms of the project contract if I could be furloughed. As it happens, the project has continued throughout and I have been working on it from home. This has positives and negatives. I am glad to have the additional income, but it has reduced my flexibility which actually feels more important now as I have some caring responsibilities for my elderly father. Although these are not onerous they are more difficult to carry out in the current situation. I also had made a conscious choice not to work full-time, so this is taking some adjustment. I do realise I am luckier than many, in that I do not have to carry out working from home alongside home schooling. My husband and I are used to spending our days together as we shared the same workspace in the past too, so there have not been too many additional challenges on this front. The inability to go out has raised some challenges, but we are lucky to have a large enough house so that we are not ‘on top of each other’ all day. There are times when we do get irritable with each other, but this is to be expected and we both try not to take things to heart. Technology I have had an increased use of technology, both for work and socially. For work this has been in the use of Zoom and Microsoft Teams to carry out meetings. I have also used Zoom as a way of ‘meeting up’ with groups of friends. This social use has helped greatly in dealing with lockdown. My husband has been using Skype to keep in contact with family in France and across the UK, and we both use WhatsApp and text to communicate daily with friends and family, sharing jokes, snippets of news and reactions to the lockdown and the government’s handling of the crisis. We have not taken part in ‘sing-along’s’ or online quizzes. Shopping and food We have been carrying out a large shop, driving to a large supermarket, about every 3 weeks, with a weekly visit to a more local shop for items such as bread and milk. The large shop has not been too stressful; although it is not enjoyable (I did previously enjoy browsing and taking my time). We have had to queue each time, for about 20 minutes, but the queue has been well managed, and people have been respecting social distancing. I have not worn a face mask, but do wear plastic gloves to handle the trolley. We have not used online deliveries. Initially this was so that those more in need (key workers, those shielding) would have a better chance of getting a delivery slot. As time has gone on, we have decided that a visit once every 3 weeks, respecting social distancing and sanitary precautions should not unduly compromise our health or others. Our cooking habits have changed slightly. We now cook more elaborate meals mid week, and my husband has taken the opportunity to try out more recipes. Our meals have stayed about the same health-wise, and we have tried to stay away from unhealthy snacking during the day. We probably do eat more snacks in the evening (e.g. some crisps or cheese and crackers) than we would normally do. Entertainment and leisure I have not done anything new that I would not normally have done, but (prior to working full-time) I had more time in which to do it. I have taken part in online sewing webinars, and am in the middle of doing a MoMa fashion course via Coursera. The time spent on this has been made available as I would probably have been out walking or ‘wasting time’ browsing in shops. I have been watching DVDs of Miami Vice, and films on MUBI. We have also watched Schitt’s Creek, Ozarks, Bosch on Netflix, and Seinfeld on All4. I have also watched ‘classic’ films on BBC iPlayer. I read every day. Currently, I have been tending to read ‘golden age’ crime stories. I had started re-reading Orwell’s 1984 as lockdown started, but had to abandon this as I was finding it too depressing in the current circumstances. Personal hygiene My habits have remained the same on the whole. I am not changing my clothes as often as they are not getting as dirty as they are not being worn outside. I have stopped wearing make-up. I would normally do this every time I went out but have now stopped. I think that I will probably wear it on far fewer occasions in the future, as I realise it had just become a habit rather than something I wanted or needed to do. Sleep Initially I was sleeping much better than normal, as I think I had a focus for my anxiety (COVID19) that could be managed (by taking the suggested precautions). As lockdown has gone on the anxiety about COVID19 has become ‘normalised’ and I have been sleeping less well on some nights as old anxieties have come to the fore. I know that my sister who is a more anxious person than I am generally was also sleeping much better at the start of the crisis. I have not had any COVID19 related dreams that I remember, but one of my friends has and continues to have, where the virus is something that is following her around.
