Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Special Directive 'Coronavirus'. Mass-Observer W7130 describes themself as female; age 58; married; former teacher. Response is titled 'Special Directive Covid 19, written between 19 April and 8 May 2020'.;The Special Directive 'Coronavirus' was issued on 17 March 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their experiences during the early stages of the COVID-19 pandemic, including personal experiences of the virus; protecting themselves and others from the virus; changes in shopping habits; the government's response to the pandemic; news and memes.
Contents: W7130 Female 58 yo Married London Former Teacher Special Directive Covid 19, written between19 April and 8 May 2020 Have you, or others you know, been affected by the virus? Have you been ill? Neither I nor my immediate friends and family have been ill from the virus, although like many others across the country some are wondering if they’ve had it, particularly as the symptoms we’re told to look out for seem to change frequently. I suppose there are many reasons for this. Although having had the virus doesn’t mean that future infection won’t happen it is a way of making oneself less fearful of catching the virus. As an asthmatic in a family of asthmatics, levels of anxiety were initially high about becoming ill, especially as my parents who are both elderly, and with underlying conditions, are in a high-risk group. I feel a sense of responsibility to keep them safe by ensuring they have provisions although this is complicated as they live 60 miles away. They along with my in laws seem to have been affected more greatly psychologically than those of us who are younger. This doesn’t appear to be through fear that they will become victims to the virus, but there’s an irrational and unfounded sense that others are continuing to go out and getting the social contact that they are craving. Conversely my son continues to work as a key worker on a zero hours contract through an agency and is distressed at the amount of social contact that he has to endure on a daily basis. As someone in his twenties, he misses going to the pub with his friends but they are inventive enough to use the technology they’ve grown up with to socialise online and draw into the group their friends working overseas. He also misses sitting on the beach. Living in a flat about 50 metres from the beach and being denied the right to sit in your “back garden” is hard. We count ourselves lucky. Whilst some things are out of bounds at the moment – using the bus, going to the theatre, a June trip to Europe in the camper van – we are comfortable in our own home, with a garden and so far have managed to order food online and have it delivered. I have a friend on the government’s vulnerable person’s list, and he has now acclimatised to shielding and being in quarantine, and again counts himself lucky to have a garden. He lives with his wife who struggled initially with the idea that she had to self isolate for his sake. She found it hard -she is in her early 70’s she is fit and active. They have developed a routine, and are perhaps drinking more than usual but are happy, laughing and joking when we’re in touch. More concerning is a friend who lives on her own. She has no family, and being in her 70’s, her friends also have to quarantine or self isolate, so she has become socially isolated. Her anxiety levels are rising, and as an ex government scientist her anxiety is fuelled by her knowledge and therefore enhanced ability to see through the messages the public are fed from government through the mainstream media. Everyone is affected by the virus in some way, and it was particularly frustrating early on to see people trying to outdo eachother in terms of “it’s really hard for me because….”. Also there were instances of politicians going to their second homes/visiting family despite this being in contravention of the guidelines. There was an element of the encouragement of the intergenerational conflict that we’ve witnessed growing over the last few years. Are you doing anything to protect yourself or others from the coronavirus? Have you self-isolated? Have you changed your behaviour? Initial behaviour change was about scrupulous hand washing and the use of hand gel when out and about. This continues, but now it’s also about wiping surfaces and ensuring that anything that enters the house is wiped with antiseptic. We leave letters on the floor in the hall for a couple of days, although recently it’s been said that the virus can’t exist on paper despite previously being told it could survive for 24 hours and then 9 days. It’s an example of where you have to “listen to the science” and then behave in a way that seems proportionate, as there can’t be a definitive answer. The main change on a day to day basis is self isolation and supporting others to self isolate. We go out for the permitted daily exercise strictly observing social distancing. Unless we have food to deliver to a friend (which has been delivered to us) we stay in the house and garden. Our behaviour has undoubtedly changed because going out is no longer going somewhere but taking an ever changing route to avoid other people on our daily walk. Ordinarily we walk a lot anyway but this this might also involve initially taking a bus/the tube/Overground. It feels odd sometimes that tomorrow will be home based but it doesn’t worry me at the moment. The only real concern is not being able to visit our elderly parents. I’ve managed to avoid going into a shop since March 29, and that was just for a few items in a shop operating a “one in one out” policy. My partner and I are both supporting our elderly parents to self isolate by arranging food deliveries so they don’t have to shop even in the special “elderly and vulnerable hours”. Although it’s slightly warping their view of the difficulties others are having it will hopefully give them a chance of keeping safe. A couple of hours at least each day are spent trying to book slots for supermarket deliveries, finding out what people want, ordering, making phone calls to establish what people want, phoning to make sure everyone is alright -and so it goes on. Have your shopping habits changed? Shopping, specifically for food is a hugely significant activity, as I’m ordering regularly for 4 households and help supplement shopping for a further three. I’ve used supermarket online delivery services for about 20 years and also fruit and veg box delivery before the days of online delivery, but stopped the latter when my son was in his teens and the boxes just didn’t have enough fruit. How I’ve used these services has changed over the years as family circumstances have changed. When working and having to feed a family I had weekly deliveries, but in recent years this has become less of a necessity. A delivery has become the exception rather than the norm – maybe to stock up on dry goods, to avoid supermarkets at the end of November and the run up to Christmas etc. Like many we have in the main switched to shopping more frequently I store with a basket of typically £5 to £10 worth of goods. Not only is this more doable with the variety of supermarkets and international shops locally, but also makes sense when no longer having a working household with a teenager (and friends) to feed. Such shopping habits now seem positively scary so the overriding motivation in our shopping behaviour is to avoid entering a shop. The last time I stepped into a shop was in the last week of March. We have had a couple of supermarket deliveries and have started to use a weekly box delivery of fruit and veg. Due to the closure of restaurants and cafés there is a surplus of fresh produce and some companies are now operating from Nine Elms delivering directly to residential premises instead. I share my supermarket delivery slots with several friends, one who is shielding and another who is over 70 who wants to avoid the shops. The favour is then reciprocated, and in fact I’ve just been texted by a friend who has a delivery at the end of nest week and she will add a few items for us. This keeps dairy topped up for us. As she and her husband are self isolating, making the arrangements and collecting the food also becomes a form of “justifiable” social contact and the opportunity for a brief, socially distanced chat on the doorstep. In addition to this are the arrangements for deliveries to be made to parents and in laws, and to my son who is a key worker. The last thing he wants to do after a day at work is to queue in a supermarket exposing himself to more risk. This all takes quite a bit of time but at least it feels useful and that my friends and family are being helped. My instinct when I open my laptop is to check for slots, add items to a basket etc, which although not a great habit is not as psychologically disturbing as constantly checking the update death toll which some people say they spend much of their day doing. I’m very conscious that I’m in a privileged position. I have a credit card, a certain financial safety net, organisational skills, and I’m not in paid employment so have time. I’m very conscious that there are elderly and vulnerable people who have to go into shops or they would have no food or general provisions. I even find myself justifying my actions by saying that any delivery we receive is shared with others which keeps us out of the shops which is better for those who are in the shops. An element of truth but shows a feeling of guilt. Have you noticed any changes in the availability of food or other goods in the shops? Apart from seeing shelves striped bare in a large supermarket in March I can’t really comment on what’s happening in shops. We made one trip after that to the nearest supermarket (in March) for fruit and veg only and there were no supply issues. However even at the start of March shops were running low or were out of stock of soap and hand gel, toilet paper, tinned goods (tomatoes, tinned fruit, evaporated milk!!!) Pasta and rice were also out of stock but readily available in the international shops. At one point there was an announcement that taking ibuprofen to control fever should be avoided so there was a shortage of paracetamol. There have been on-going shortages of eggs and flour, and yeast is still not available. I have a bread maker so always have sufficient yeast but I did start to run out of flour. My main concern about this was that all the time I could bake it was again another way of avoiding going to the shops. I have over the years bought flour direct from a mill and I was able to replenish with an order from them. What this did highlight is that because companies offering delivery were being overwhelmed they were prioritising existing customers. This has been a particular problem for the elderly who are unable to get deliveries, as they have not been users of online shopping. Many can’t understand that they can’t ring someone. This has also discriminated against those on low incomes, many living in housing with limited space for storage. Eggs were non-existent for several weeks causing much consternation, and supply is still irregular. What were people doing with the eggs? Were they trying to store them? Is the issue one of supply or demand? Are chickens laying fewer eggs? And so on. It seems some of the issues are down to packaging differences for the retail and commercial sectors. There are stories that flour exists but it is in 16kg bags for businesses. A friend got 30 eggs destined for a restaurant for £6 when it was impossible to find boxes of six in any type of shop, so packaging seems to be playing a part. I also wonder whether all this flour is going to be used. It seems unlikely that the population has suddenly become bakers, especially as there is no yeast!! For several weeks there were articles on sourdough bread making but these are disappearing. What do you think about the UK government’s response to the pandemic? The government’s response was too slow. People were already adapting their behaviour and realising the seriousness of the virus whilst the government continued to say it was not necessary to give advice. The behaviour of ministers was almost cavalier with Boris Johnson proudly saying he was continuing to shake hands with people. This was on the same new bulletins where we were seeing complete lockdown in China and distressing footage of people on ventilators in Italy. This Conservative government has over the year’s delivered its policies in slogan form to the electorate. Prior to the pandemic the focus was on “getting Brexit done”, and the same approach has been continued. “Help save the NHS”, “guided by the science”, use of the term lockdown when clearly we are not in lockdown in comparison to Spain, China, France, Italy etc. The arbitrary target set by Matt Hancock to test 100,00 people a day reminded me of Blair’s similarly arbitrary target that 50% of 18 year olds should go to university. Testing has been a debacle with health workers unable to access tests or being told to drive to an IKEA car park to queue several hours for a test. Care workers and care home residents have been neglected – no PPE and no testing of residents or staff. Elderly people being discharged from hospital with Covid symptoms back to residential care causing many deaths in care homes. The impact on the workers has been devastating to watch on the news and some workers have even moved in to the care homes where they work in an attempt to protect residents and also to avoid exposing their own families to the virus that they themselves might have been exposed to at work. Some health and care workers are living apart from their family for fear of the risk. The government failed to stockpile PPE in the way that for instance Taiwan did and found itself unprepared for what has been said was a predictable pandemic. It found itself competing globally for supplies that they’ve failed to obtain. Some regard this is as a community spirit, but I’m horrified that school children are making protective facemasks in CDT departments using 3D printers, whilst elsewhere people are sewing facemasks for hospital workers where supplies have run out. This is just plain wrong, yet the feel good media coverage of these activities is used as a distraction. In the same vein Johnson contracting the virus and becoming seriously ill is used as “we’re all in this together”. No. The poorest and those from BAME backgrounds are disproportionately affected in the community, in the health sector and in the provision of other front line services such as public transport. We welcome thoughts about any other countries response to Covid-19. I’m hesitant to comment on what is happening in other countries knowing how the media is being used in the UK to manage policy, so to then assume that the reports from other countries are a reflection of what is happening there might be naïve. In particular I am wary as to how coverage reflects the experiences of the population as opposed to providing a story that their government wants publicised, or alternatively providing a counterpoint for the policy of the UK government. For instance, the term “lockdown” is used indiscriminately – in France it requires the need to carry papers and to move no further than 1 km from home in Paris, in Italy and Spain children were not allowed outside until last week whilst adults could shop and go for medical appointments, yet in the UK the term is used even though there a merely guidelines and recommendations. Are the rules being enforced in Spain? The media coverage suggests yes but then is that being shown to make us feel “grateful” that we live in a “freer” society. Given that the UK government’s mantra is that they will follow the science it is interesting to see the different approaches taken around the world. There is no one science and that comes through in the range of responses, as ultimately the response is always politically motivated. Trump’s USP will be lost when the US economy plunges into a depression, hence the desire to “get the economy going again” in a critical period for Trump if he is to secure a second term In the Whitehouse. And of course even Trump knows the US’s economy will not be booming in time for the election so now he has to blame China. He can’t afford to lose those voters who supported him in 2016 because if they don’t vote for him they simply won’t vote thereby giving the advantage to the Democrats. The Chinese response through the use of technology, by downloading a smartphone App, to permit greater freedom of movement sits comfortably with a more authoritarian regime, although this also seems to be the way the UK government is moving. Where do you get your news about the virus? In the early days of “lockdown” I was getting news from anywhere I could and in particular found myself looking at the Guardian updates far too frequently throughout the day. Now I listen to Radio 4’s today programme from 6 – 8am. There tends to be no breaking news but it does cover any new stories from the States that have broken. My other main source is Channel 4 news. I avoid all radio phone -ins. I don’t use Facebook and just lurk on twitter. If a news item has broken I’ll then tend to look at people’s twitter accounts that I consider might have something useful to say. At the start everyone seemed to be watching the daily briefings which I never really committed to regularly as they seem so choreographed, so again once I know what the message of the day is I might then watch or listen later to original clips. I don’t feel a need to keep up with rolling news as I’m not sure it’s particularly good for anyone’s mental health, and the amount of filtering that is required with imperfect information at my disposal is draining. I feel C4 news does provide some analysis, as does Evan Davis on Radio 4 on the pm show, which is starting at 4.30pm. I don’t listen to the latter every day but might dip in on catch up. Essentially there is little news that is new news as there is only one story and it’s pretty easy to predict what will be said as there is a pattern to the day. There also tends to be a daily angle – do we need to be scared? Do we need to think we’re better than other countries? If there’s bad news make sure there’s a distraction etc. Have you noticed any jokes, memes or sources poking fun at the virus? I’m not aware of any that have entered the main stream, but as I’m not on Facebook I might be missing something. There is a tendency for those on the left to point out to people that the difficulties faced by the NHS and therefore ultimately patients are because people voted Tory and therefore voted for cuts and endorsed the privatisation of the NHS that has taken place. I suppose it’s just all too dark. Maybe one thing that people are joking about is “lockdown hair” as there are no hairdressers or barbers open. People are perhaps confronting their own vanity. Also it becomes noticeable if someone appears to have had a haircut. It’s something that people laugh about – people of all ages. Afterthought written on 9 May 2020 I had decided not to add anything to this entry as we’re now in week 7 of the so called lockdown and tomorrow on 10 May the prime minister is due to make an announcement regarding any relaxation or tightening of government advice, so I’d thought that this in itself might change how I feel. A couple of days ago the media started to pre-empt the announcement with the Sun talking about Super Monday (ie 11 May) when there would be a relaxation of guidelines. This was worrisome given that there was to be an exceptional bank holiday on Fri day 8 May to commemorate VE and the weather forecast was for a sunny warm weekend. Very quickly ministers were attempting to counter the optimism suggesting any relaxation would be minimal eg 2 daily sessions of exercise instead of one, whilst they were simultaneously explaining that the people needed to go back to work. I’ll find out tomorrow what will actually be announced but I wanted to note this because of the impact on the VE Day commemoration and what happened in the road that runs at right angles to our house along the garden boundary of our corner end of terrace house. Flags and bunting were being put up from Thursday and yesterday there was what can only be described as a street party. People started off in their front gardens, moved onto the pavements, spread out on to the road and as the day wore on neighbours were in eachother’s front gardens. A sound system was set up so that the whole road could hear the music and people were dancing. Adults who were drinking lost their inhibitions so any notion of social distancing went out the window, and children couldn’t believe their luck as they were allowed to play freely together in the street. Eventually after 11 hours of partying, and barbecues, the last stragglers went inside at 10 minutes before midnight. I’m aware that this account makes me sound like a killjoy, but I was deeply disturbed by the whole event. It has also divided people into two camps. The mainstream media, the BBC, was apparently reporting similar street parties with no comment about social distancing whilst Twitter was buzzing with tweets from people who like me could not believe what they had seen. This incredulity turned to rage especially when medics at the end of hard shifts started to see what had been going on whilst they were working to treat critically ill patients. This is also juxtaposed against the weekly clap for the NHS where people apparently show their appreciation of the hard work of frontline workers by standing at their front door on Thursday at 8pm and clap. I worry that what happened yesterday will haunt us, not only in a second spike in cases particularly in London, but will enable politicians to put the blame on the population, or a group they want to scapegoat, as showing a “lack of self control” which in reality was encouraged by the Tory popular press. And meanwhile there is still the deadline of Dec 31st for the completion of trade deals with the EU. 9 May 2020

Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'COVID-19 (Update)'. Mass-Observer P7201 describes themself as female; age 47; married; trainer / running coach.;The Directive 'COVID-19 (Update)' was issued on 27 April 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their experiences of the COVID-19 pandemic, in particular 'health'; 'the government'; 'news'; 'work and home life'; 'technology'; 'shopping and food'; 'entertainment and leisure'; 'personal hygiene' and 'sleep'.
Contents: MO number: P7201 Gender: Female Age: 47 Marital status: Married City: London Occupation: Trainer/running coach Part 2: Covid19 (update) Health I and my family have generally been in good health during lockdown. There have been a couple of times where we have worried that we might have symptoms of Covid19, such as my husband having a cough and one day where my son went back to bed with a temperature. My emotions have been very up and down throughout the lockdown period. At times I have felt a kind of contentment, a feeling of enjoying the lack of pressure to do things and be somewhere, a feeling of being safe and happy with my small unit. At other times I have found myself in tears over something seemingly trivial and overcome with frustration at the never-ending nature of this situation. The ‘homeschooling’ situation has been a big challenge for us all, with poor support and a lack of direction from the school, a child trying to make sense of it all and me desperately trying to make sure he doesn’t fall behind in his learning. There have been days where we have shouted at each other and both been in tears, with others where things have gone more smoothly and we feel satisfied with some small progress. Government I have felt angry and disappointed in our leaders. There has been indecision throughout, a lack of clarity over what is expected of us (especially as time has gone one), a withholding of supplies for care workers and a culture of blame as cases and deaths have increased. As we move on, it seems clear that industry is being prioritised over health and we are pretty much being told to take responsibility for ourselves. Boris Johnson really does seem though, to be self-congratulatory over how the pandemic has been handled. I worry that lockdown restrictions have been eased too quickly at a few points, with a strange priority being given to activities such as horse racing and professional football, where really, people would simply like to be able to see their friends and family. It looks as if lots of power will be handed over to local authorities, with they and individuals being expected to take responsibility for them/ourselves. News I have been accessing news mostly online, looking at the Guardian and BBC websites. I listen also to Radio 4 and watch the news on TV sometimes. I was watching the briefing every day at first and checking the news regularly, as things were moving quickly. I started to feel frustrated with the format of these briefings, with too much waffle and not enough clarity. I chose, instead, to summarise the facts for myself through the media listed above, focussing on what is important to me and trying to filter out other information to keep myself sane. Work and home life I have been working from home, kind of. My work couldn’t physically happen at first, so my employer (I work freelance, on a contract), cut my hours to two a week, with my wages being adjusted accordingly. This has changed slightly as time has gone on, with my hours increasing a little and my pay coming back up – the work is being carried out from home, in an admin capacity. My husband has been working from home since before lockdown, using our spare room, where he is constantly on video calls, working intensely and only appearing for meals. His hours were cut to three days a week for a while, but he is now back to five days. I mentioned above about homeschooling, which has been my responsibility. There has been tension at times, with frustrations building up and the lack of having ‘something to look forward to’. Technology I really dislike video calls. I find them stressful and uncomfortable. I have, of course, had to get over this and we have been having a weekly ‘family call’ with my husband’s family. This is nice at times, but I don’t always want to do it, finding it tiring and repetitive. We sometimes do a quiz with them, which lasts for hours and I can see is now wearing a bit thin. We would never normally see these people this much, so it can feel a bit forced at times. One positive thing is that my husband and I spent a few hours getting my mum signed up to WhatsApp so that she can do video calls with us. It was a real challenge, but we got there in the end and she was delighted to see us. On our son’s birthday, she and my dad did a video ‘party’, where they had made cakes, wore party hats and sang happy birthday. We also organised a surprise video party for our son and his friends. I do use Twitter and Facebook to keep up-to-date and to stay in touch with friends. Shopping and food As I have asthma, my husband offered to do the shopping. We had a few small deliveries at first, but it was so difficult to book these that he has been cycling to the supermarket once a week. He has worn a mask and taken a cloth to wipe down the trolley throughout. At times this has been very busy and stressful, but things seem a little less so now. I have recently been to local shops, to buy bread and it is nice to see other people and have a chat. We always cook from scratch anyway, so this isn’t a big change for us. For me, it is odd having my husband and son at home for lunch, so I tend to eat more than I would when I am on my own during the day (this has resulted in weight gain…). My husband has been making sourdough bread – he had done this previously, but is doing so more now. Entertainment and leisure I don’t think our entertainment and leisure have changed that much really, maybe we watch a little more TV in the evening. I usually read a lot, but have found it very difficult to focus on reading much. We sometimes rent a film to watch, as if we were going to the cinema and we have tuned in to the National Theatre Live events. In terms of fitness, we are normally an active family, so this has been challenging in many ways. I normally swim a lot, so have struggled with not being able to do this. We have walked most days as a family and I now get up early to walk by myself when it’s quieter (I find it stressful when the park/paths are busy). My son and I have joined in the PE with Joe Wickes sessions, completing every day until he reduced the sessions. We have a turbo trainer and my husband and I have put our bikes on here and used this (though we both find it really boring). Personal hygiene My hygiene habits haven’t changed. To have a sense of routine and normality, I was very strict with my son about getting dressed every day for ‘homeschool’. I think it is important and has helped our well-being to take care of our appearance. We have all had the huge hair growth, with my son cutting my husband’s hair a couple of times (we have both decided to go with the longer hair ourselves). I have actually enjoyed this, embracing the new look, which I think I will keep. Sleep My sleep has been very up and down. I have had bouts of sleeplessness and had one night where I had what was probably a panic attack – I had to get out of bed and was sobbing uncontrollably, I felt overwhelmed and took a while to calm down. I have had lots of weird dreams. Sometimes these are quite day-to-day, sometimes frightening (having a bird stuck in my hair, which died, climbing a very tall ladder that feel away from under me, swimming the English Channel…). My husband has also had sleep changes and odd dreams and our son sleep-walked the other night, which he has never done before.

Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing'. Mass-Observer V3767 describes themself as male; age 82; married; 'largely retired from managing my own company'.;The Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing' was issued on 27 November 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their opinions on and experiences of health and wellbeing, in particular 'health, wellbeing and the healthy body'; 'identity'; 'growing up and learning about health and wellbeing'; 'growing older'; 'health, wellbeing and appearance'; 'getting ready to leave the house'.
Contents: V3767 Mass Observation –Autumn 2020  -V3767 Male,  Age 82,  Married,  Cambridge,  largely retired from managing my own company. Part 2:  Everyday Health and Wellbeing H, Wb and the healthy body HEALTH means the absence of discomfort and pain, over a few days.  Transiently a stubbed toe or bruise may be uncomfortable or painful but that is compatible with Health.  A truly healthy person will probably be aware of lifestyle factors which might reduce Health, and will probably minimise them. WELLBEING is a neologism which I have recently met mainly used as a synonym for Health, with especial reference to freedom from STRESS.  Stress is now a dirty word not fit to be used in public; this is absurd.  There is an International Stress Management Association with an active operation in Britain but even its members prefer to avoid using STRESS now, favouring Wellbeing as more POSITIVE!! Not all neologisms are good. Five words on Healthy Body:-Fit;     Strong (meaning disease-resistant);  young;   undiseased;  free; and one more I have not yet thought of . . . . . Maybe . . . Surrounding a Healthy Mind. ! There are probably people who will say Young;  I think that is wrong and that I am an example to prove my point ! There is no person that comes to mind, save an advertising figure in the 1950s whose splendid physique promoted -something or other.  I can't remember what. (?Virol?)  I wasn't interested in physique. %%%%%%%%%%A quick WWW search (NOT via Google, which I hate) yeilds:-Virol was a by-product of the brewing industry packed full of nutrients, malt, sugar and vitamins such as riboflavin. Due to its concentrated nutritious content, Virol has been heavily marketed... %%%%%%%%%% and that supports my recollection. Identity  and Key moments I do not believe my experience of H&Wb has been influenced at all by the factors you mention.  I am a product of those factors and others that you mention, of course. The only one that may have been pertinent is my British birth and upbringing, mainly after the creation of the National Health Service when I was ten years old.  I have been blessed with outstanding service from the NHS, especially as a consequence of my needs after two head injuries from different accidents 17 years apart.  My file at  Hospital is large! Growing up and learning about H & Wb  is what I have been writing about just above. When I was a child my parents were as careful about looking after the health of us all (including my younger sister) as any normal middle-class family.  Perhaps a little more careful, as I believe my father belonged to something called The Saturday Club which ensured attention if we walked to the Surgery in the village we then lived in.  I got  four stitches in my left index finger when I was about nine, because I had been clumsy using an axe to prepare firewood for the open coal fires which were our >only< source of heating. In adolescence I could not ignore the changes in hair associated with the age.  I took them for granted.  I guess my father taught me to shave, with a 'safety razor' as it was called to distinguish it from the long straight blade, often still used then.  I cannot pretend I noticed my voice breaking; had I been a singer I probably would have.  That was life. Maintenance of health was for a very long time spontaneous and not deliberate.  As a boy I used my bicycle automatically to get around all the time, whether to explore nearby woods and river.  We walked V3767 as a family, and did so on holidays in England and Europe, including French and Swiss Alps. We did not have a car until I was 15.  So bicycle when alone and feet as a family; that was life. Growing older I think I have made clear above that an adequately healthy life just happened to me.  In about the last ten years I have been using the trampoline in our garden as a form of exercise.  My wife bought it, ostensibly as a 70th Birthday Present for me.  When new it radically altered the behaviour of visiting grandchildren.  Before, they announced their arrival with loud cries at the back door.  After, the parents would enter and announce their arrival more quietly.  But I digress. As long as its surface is dry I go out and do the simplest possible action; Bounce up, and Land on my bum, and repeat.  I have been increasing the repeats, and now usually do 100, breaking after 20 to get my breath back. The limit, as when I run, is breathlessness and not muscle pain.  My wife observes that muscle definition in my thighs is clearer that it was.  Since we are on the subject, I weigh very slightly more than when I left school.  I just dug out my Service Record for my two years of National Service in the Royal Marines; it shows my height, waist and chest measurements, but not my weight.  I know it was close to 64kg when I left school and it is no more than 2kg above that now.  My waist has thickened. Reverting to changes with age, I have never actively worked to maintain my physical health except in the modest way I describe above.  Neither have I ever done anything to maintain my mental health.  But I did get some training in Transcendental Meditation in 1971.  It was very popular, wholly voluntary and free of pressure.  So for two years or so I meditated for ten minutes morning and evening.  I think it may have reduced my tendency occasionally to shout at my sons when they were 5 and 7 and toooo active. I ended doing TM after travelling on business overseas and omitting it and seeing no change in myself.  So I stopped altogether.  I think my ability now to get back to sleep easily after waking in the night probably has its roots in that training. So changes in my life associated with my health have been small and easy to make.Remaining points in the Growing older section:-I don't get information about H&Wb now, except in the specific case of Covid-19 which therefore is outside the scope of this response.  The same applies to future changes, unless I contract Covid-19.  I am aware of how fortunate I am to be healthy.  I do sometimes wonder if an influence might have been joining a Snow Warfare course in the Cairngorm Mountains for 3 weeks when in the Marines.  We lived in holes in the snow, literally, with 'Running Cold Water'.  I logged my food intake and concluded I was taking in 6 kcal (6 kjoules now?) a day and found I was putting on no weight at all. So we arrived back in London and I recall feeling so fit I could brush a pillarbox aside rather than walk round it. 'No Pillarboxes were harmed in making that decision'. H, Wb and appearance People more acute than I are good at noticing the apperance of someone in distress.  I am not, unless they are weeping. That is an extreme example. I am almost completely indifferent to popular ideals of beauty or physical apperance.  If I am to appear in public, at a meeting or a restaurant for example, I am happy to pay some attention; I have once or twice even worn a flower in a buttonhole.  I can't think of other examples.  So guess I care, but not very much.  V3767 Getting ready to leave the house  et cetera  -above

Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'COVID-19 (Update)'. Mass-Observer G6843 describes themself as male; age 63; single, but co-habiting; self-employed management consultant.;The Directive 'COVID-19 (Update)' was issued on 27 April 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their experiences of the COVID-19 pandemic, in particular 'health'; 'the government'; 'news'; 'work and home life'; 'technology'; 'shopping and food'; 'entertainment and leisure'; 'personal hygiene' and 'sleep'.
Contents: G6843 Male age 63 Single, but co-habiting Blackheath, London SE3 Self-employed management consultant Completed 13 May 2020 Part 2: Covid19 (Update) Please share your experiences and reflections on the challenging times we are currently experiencing. Below are some questions we would like you to think about. Health My health is good, as is that of my partner. Although, as someone who is taking immunosuppressants for a health condition, he is not allowed out or to meet people for at least 12 weeks, and I am supposed to keep a distance from him too. But we are in good physical and mental health. We are not naturally pessimistic people, and make sure that we get as many facts as possible before coming to any conclusions, so we keep up to date with the news, and don’t get too down with it. In fact, my own interest in modelling means I am very interested in the rate of infection, the death rate, and so on, so that I can see ahead. I know it’s a gloomy prediction, but I am still happier being able to look at the facts myself. I have not had any paid work for over 6 months now, and my partner’s work has also dried up, so we are a little nervous about when and if we will get work again. With last year’s tax to pay off, a mortgage which still has a few years to run, and gloomy business and economy prospects, I am a little on edge about our finances. I am managing to cope by taking payment holidays, but it’s a problem. It’s also compounded by the fact that my self-employed situation means I don’t get any support from the government, and my partner’s self-employment situation means he is assessed for support on the year before last, during which he earned almost nothing, so gets 80% of almost nothing = nothing at all. Worrying. But we are keeping positive, and also supporting some friends who are more affected emotionally by it all. The Government I am frankly appalled by the decisions and strategy that the UK government has taken. (sorry, I didn’t mean to leave the text in bold, but actually it is how I feel!) We keep up with the news from around the world, and in particular Ireland, as we have family and a house there, so can easily compare what different countries are doing. The response, planning and strategy in other countries has been far, far better than in the UK. I cringe every time I hear Boris Johnson say that we are doing really well, are successful, and it’s all under control. Plus, the daily briefings are lamentable – a host of ministers who haven’t got a clue mumbling on instead of giving us facts that mean something. I worry about the current strategy – saying that people should return to work if they can, but without giving firms the right equipment, support and guidance. I really fear another spike in infections and deaths. The news last night was that the actual death rate is more like 50,000 instead of the 31,000 reported as deaths where a person was tested for the virus. With the current back-to-work strategy and noticing people’s response and behaviour in the past couple of weeks, I fear that we will end up with more than 100,000 deaths by this time next year, a crippled economy from having to continually start-stop, and millions of hours of wasted time while the luckier people get sick and slowly recover. Plus massive unemployment due to firms having to lay people off. In terms of what steps I think the Government will take, I haven’t a clue. I hope that they listen to other countries, scientists and public health experts, but they don’t seem to be doing so. News I start the morning with reading all the headlines on BBC news on my phone, and then dip into it several times a day – perhaps 10 or so. I might listen to a news-on-the-hour on BBC Radio 4 if I already have the radio on while cooking, and also the RTE (Irish) news at 8pm on digital radio. Most evenings I watch the BBC 10 o’clock news on TV before going to bed, and 2-3 times a week some of Newsnight. We tend to stop for tea around 4:30 or 5pm, and I used to tune into the radio broadcast of the press conference, but I have grown tired of the platitudes and meaningless statements, so instead head for the ONS or other government website for an update on the numbers. The 5pm briefing is getting more and more ridiculous, and the 7pm broadcasts from Boris last weekend highly farcical. However, I enjoy watching the Facebook memes that apply different voices to the video, or satirical takes on the words being used in the briefings. I am not aware of anyone who has access difficulties, but every time I see Nicola Sturgeon check behind her to ensure that her sign interpreter is ready to commence, I feel proud of the way that the Scottish First Minister understands the value of truth, plain speaking and honesty, as well as the fact that she is part of a team, not a hero. Work and home life My partner and I are self-employed, so work at home anyway. Neither of us has had any proper work for around 6 months or more, but we are both trying to get work. I have teamed up with another small network of people to address the virtual meetings/conferences market,basedonwhatweusedtodotogetherbefore. It’s beginningtogetsometraction,butsadlynothing for me yet in terms of income. There are one or two projects that have been postponed from physical meetings, and we are trying to reconfigure them for virtual sessions, and when (and if) they happen, I may then begin to relax a bit in the knowledge that business will pick up again. But it’s worrying times. Neither of us can be furloughed as we are self-employed. Neither of us is getting any state support for our work, although I did sign on for Universal Income, which has made a small difference. It’s less than 1/10th of my previous income, and doesn’t cover the mortgage, the balance on the car loan and my credit card debt as we entered the lockdown, but with payment holidays we have a little bit of breathing space. Home life hasn’t been affected – we don’t have kids, so no home-schooling, although people who I work with have commitments that means that some projects are slow to mobilise because they have divided responsibilities. Working from home and (sadly) not having pressing work deadlines means that we can spend some time in the garden, which has been good while the weather was good. Our relationship is not affected apart from both being a little depressed by the lack of income and bleak prospects for now. However, we used to go out a lot, both the theatre/cinema/galleries and to eat out, so we are missing all that. Instead we are Zooming and What’sapping friends and family, and continuing to eat really well (my partner is a really good cook and baker.) Technology We work from home, so are used to staring at a screen to get things done. I have bene using video-conference technology in a limited way for a few years, but it has developed massively in that time. Because of the business I’m in (facilitating strategy and development with groups of people) I have developed my use of Zoom, Teams, and whiteboard apps massively, and have developed some products/services for companies to help them run effective meetings and conferences. While this is just beginningtotakeoff,it’s earlydays,butpeopleseemkeenonwhat we are developing. It will either explode or people will realise that they can do it themselves, without the need for specialists. I thank good sense and foresight for the quality of our broadband – we upgraded a while ago and we really need the extra speed! We use all the apps – FaceTime, Zoom (a LOT), WhatsApp and Houseparty to connect with friends and family. If anything, we are reaching out to people a little more now – we used to rely on going to things like the theatre together, but now we hook up with cocktails and snacks in hand. One observation, though: it’s great to see people, but the chat is banter, not really as deep as a one-to-one on the phone, where you really get to hear how someone is feeling and thinking. Video doesn’t really do emotional reactions. I use Facebook to keep up with friends, but strangely I refer to it less often than I used to. Not sure why – couldbethevolumeofmessagesandthewallofsocialnoise. Maybeit’sbecausepeoplearen’tdoingreally very interesting and novel things, so it’s all a bit same-y. Hmmm… not sure I don’t use twitter much, and Insta not at all, but my partner is a very big user (and is followed a lot) on Instagram, so I get second-hand posts when they are of interest. Shopping and food Online ordering has been a major struggle but is getting better. We have used Ocado for years, and that used to be the main shop each week. However, we found firstly it was almost impossible getting a slot, and then lots of things that were missing like flour and sugar. I am sheltering my partner (he’s on the vulnerable list) so I have been trying to go to the shops as little as possible in order to minimise the risk of bringing an infection back to the house, but it is inevitable that I have to do some shopping locally. That hasn’t been much of a problem, but queuing to get into M&S Food is a novelty. So is wearing gloves and now a face mask when shopping. Not a problem, apart from having to deal with lots of other people who don’t seem to be distancing or protecting others from the risk of infection – there are some gross idiots about who don’t or can’t understand the health risks and real community infection threat. Wefinallygotmypartnerontothecritical list,soTesco’snowoffershimapriority slot, and Ocado now gives me a priority slot each week, so we are managing to get orders. We have also found local wholesalers who have switched to domestic ordering and delivery, which is good. We are foodies, and love to cook – my partner especially –so we tend to shop and eat very well indeed. We bake all our own bread (have done so for a very long time) but getting bread flour has been a real struggle. Our grocery bill used to be around £350 a month and eating out £600-800. Now the grocery bill is £700­odd! We are also drinking a lot more wine, but that probably balances out with the reduction in bar bills when out before. We area also making cocktails for Zoom chats whereas we would have met in a bar somewhere. The lack of exercise, good food and wine has meant that we are now not very fit, but happy! Entertainment and Leisure We haven’t taken up any new hobbies – being self-employed means that I have to focus on trying to get work until it’s time to stop and cook or eat. However, we are at last managing to get to the back of the garden at weekends, a place that was abandoned a few years ago during a home extension project, and we are clearing, weeding, sorting and rebuilding – especially since the weather in April has been exceptionally good. It feels good to be sorting out things, and beingpositive. Lotstodo,buthopefullywewillgetthetimetogetitallsorted. I’malsomanagingtoaddress some DIY jobs that haven’t been done over the past few months, which is good. Also, having to lay off our cleaner means that we are spending several hours every fortnight cleaning, which is hard work but we are combining that with spring cleaning the areas that the cleaner never had time or inclination to do, so some top shelves in the kitchen and space under the bed are getting a proper clean, which feels good. You really appreciate how hard and tiring the work is, and the reliance on professionals! Our watching and listening habits haven’t changed much, but we have been watching series like Money Heist, a Spanish thriller, and Killing Eve. We are watching a few things that we would have gone to see, like 5x15, a monthly series of interesting talks, and a couple of music recitals that we would have gone to see. Not an enormous change, although I do feel that the world is awash with events that are now virtual, and it makes it difficult to choose which ones to watch. Wearen’twatching,listeningorreadinganythingparticularlyrelevanttotheCovidperiod,butwe didwatch Chernobyl at the start of the lockdown, which was really good. Personal hygiene There has been practically no change to personal hygiene for either of us. Just 2 differences: - I now spend more time trying to tame my hair: it used to be cut quite short every 4 weeks, and now  it’s wavy/curly, unruly and 6 weeks overdue a cut  - My consumption of aftershave has dropped to nil, as we don’t go out  Sleep My sleep has only been affected in one way: because we are eating very well, and I am not getting any exercise (I used to just walk hard and fast everywhere – no other exercise) when I go to bed I end up with indigestion and discomfort most nights. But I am sleeping well despite this and no difficulty at all in getting off to sleep or waking with anxiety. If anything, the lack of work means that some mornings I sleep 8 hours, which is a lot for me, so I am managing to half-wake and see my dreams (no, I can’t recall any now). I still go to bed around 11:30 every night, and get up between 6 and 7:30 am. No nightmares, but I sometimes wake thinking about work pressures or potential client situations.

Contents: T5718 Male 61 married Finmere Oxon retired psychiatric nurse Written 24t November 2020 Part 2: Everyday Health and Wellbeing Health, wellbeing and the healthy body 5 words: Outdoors walking breathing stamina clear-sighted A tall tanned young person Identity I feel that my middleclass Scottish identity has given me ideas around being outdoors and enjoying long walks Male identity seems often be about sports but not for me Growing up Discussed in school and at home again being outdoors and walking a big part of it Both parents and teachers involved Health sex education and fitness all discussed at school but sexual identity not covered as in the 1970s… Key Moments Sexual development not greatly discussed I felt it was too complicated (!) Growing older I have tried to keep fit all my life but much more important now as health is less good More aware of health now and much more disciplined in doing exercises and eating right Health, wellbeing and appearance They are related to appearance but not in the way that fashion says Try not to be influenced Parents definitely not influenced Not products perhaps hairbrush! Getting ready to leave the house Father used to go to his study after breakfast pack his briefcase and say (invariably) “better be heading out then, do we need anything from the shop?

Contents: T5718 Male 60 married Finmere Oxon retired psychiatric nurse Written 7th May 2020 Spring 20202 Covid 19 (update) Health Normal health issues for me (I have COPD) some need for extra salbutamol I am being shielded but no illness from existing condition or COVID A bit stressed at times No need for medical support as have extra meds anyway Keeping fit by having a daily routine of home gym and cycling twice a day (cycle on stand so can use inside) The Government UK government have been slow to act and have undermined the seriousness of the pandemic until mid-march Happily the planners in NHS have been effective and timely Very helpful and plentiful information on shielding by post txt and phone I hope that the UK government will not relax the lockdown too soon Scottish Government has been far better more informative serious and respectful News I have read the guardian on my phone and listed to Radio 4 and watched BBC and C4 news BBC has been a bit fawning and 5pm UK government press conferences have been appalling C4 very good and Radio 4 better than TV Guardian v good V bad that UK govt did not have BSL interpreter Generally most useful was guardian Work and Home Life I am retired so work not an issue Wanted to re-join NHS but can’t due to chest Son A out of work but found other jobs and Daughter C teacher and so working from home on internet and occasional at school Son M in Estonia also working from home strict lockdown despite v low death rate Son T prison officer so far OK visits (at distance) as lives close by Technology Learnt how to face time via what’s app and Zoom Spoke more to an old friend more than before Using Facebook what’s App and messenger Shopping and Food Very difficult to ensure continued service from OCADO but did manage to Also shopping for parents in law Entertainment and Leisure More painting and sketching than normal Doing diary of past trips with sketches and maps Reading and got trial subscription to Economist Watching old TV shows like Killing Eve and Missing Also lots of news but sometimes turning this of and watching nature programs instead Personal Hygiene I have kept up personal hygiene routine but perhaps wearing shorts more Actual wearing trainers at home so keeping active (rather than flip flops) Sleep Some nightmare mainly about people getting lost Sometimes waking up with feeling of dread Waking earlier than usual

Contents: H5845 Female 41yrs Married Nottingham Community midwife Part 2: Everyday health and wellbeing The term “health” means having a body which functions well with no serious ailments today and keeping it that way to protect it for the future.  Thus having a healthy diet, not smoking, not being overweight, doing exercise seem to be the key ideas to sustain this. “Wellbeing” could be defined as more of a mental health sense of completeness, satisfaction, happiness and positive mindset as opposed to a physical state of being. When I imagine a healthy body, the five words which immediately spring to mind are healthy BMI, muscle definition, happy. People which spring to mind are some of the YouTube and Instagram fitness guru’s like Joe Wicks, Heather Robertson, jodieloufitness. I see them doing exercise a lot, eating wholesome healthy food and they look not too fat, not too thin weight wise, have a bit of muscle definition, they look happy and confident in themselves. I feel that gender and social class has played the biggest role in my own health and wellbeing.  Being middle class has given me the finances to be able to have the ability to choose a variety of foods, buy organic foods, buy foods based on health qualities not just on cost.  My education has meant that I research and understand food labelling and actively try and equip myself with the best knowledge about health based on research.  My degree has meant that I am able to critically analyse research and decipher out the most important findings. It means I can afford a TV, the internet and a Smartphone and laptop where I find out the most about these things.  The fact that I am a British citizen in a developed world makes me grateful that I have access to a free NHS, plentiful food, clean drinking water, good shelter and a stable environment-all factors which can be paramount to a person’s health and wellbeing.  My gender has impacted on my health.  My hypothyroidism developed in the postnatal period and I became aware I had acute anxiety issues as a result of having a baby. Pregnancy and childbirth also left its legacy on me through piles, ligament weakness and mild incontinence.  The upshot of pregnancy however is that it brought yoga, hypnotherapy and an understanding of my mental health issues into my life which I developed into an interest for mindfulness and created an awareness and need to prioritise self care especially in terms of mental health to match the desire I already held about keeping good physical health. Having children, breastfeeding them, being the one that they always turn to first has had a negative impact on my health and wellbeing in one respect thatit is time consuming and doesn’t allow “me” time or time to exercise or plan healthy meals.  In the same sentiment though, the love you feel for your children and the socialisation with other mothers that you have is good for your mental health.  I think women in general are a lot more able to talk and share their experiences with physical and mental health to get more help and support. Is that provoked though by the very fact that society places more expectations on women’s body image and how we should or shouldn’t behave as a woman and that we are still breaking free of the historical barriers which as a sex we have been subjected to thus this is the reason our mental health is worse in the first place? My skin has never been very clear, I have a degree of acne and when you describe a healthy person you may automatically think of clear skin. I know I am a healthy person with a healthy lifestyle so I’ve had to debunk that myth myself.  While I don’t particularly like having spots, I don’t feel it has decreased my self esteem and feel fortunate that as a female I can wear make up more easily than men could to hide the spots.  Maybe my mental health and self confidence would have suffered more as a man with acne. I would say that I have only become aware of wellbeing as an adult over the last 10 years.  The importance of mental health was never really matched to the importance of physical health in society.  It was classed as something to be ashamed of or brushed under the carpet when it was discussed.  Self care was never a thing until the past few years, especially in motherhood.  Women were expected just to cope, you’ve made your bed, you have to lie in it mentality.  On a privately funded study day about hypo birthing 10 years ago I learnt about the power of the mind and how it could influence the physical body which sparked my interest in learning more about wellbeing in terms of holistic therapies and mindfulness. Health was taught to a degree at school.  I remember in my GCSE home economics I had to work out fat/fibre/sugar content etc... per gram from food labels and we learnt about each food group and what benefit or harm it had on our bodies.  We had projects to cook meals with certain requirements such as low fat which did make you more aware of health in cooking. As a child I remember my mum hampering on at home about my sister and I needing more protein as we had chosen to be vegetarian and it always seemed like she was on a diet, counting calories and being mindful of eating low fat foods. We rarely went out to restaurants so all the discussions would be done at home. At primary school age however I feel I was unaware of health.  Sadly I don’t think we were ever taught about wellbeing in school or at home, that is something I have come across myself and researched as an adult. As a primary school governor I know that health and wellbeing is part of the national curriculum now which I think is fantastic and greatly overdue.  Schools are an integral part of a child’s life and share that responsibility with parents and the government to teach our children about health and wellbeing.  The fit for life campaign by the government will only work if other parties like parents can embed itinto the child’s life As an adolescent I think I first became aware of body changes associated with puberty around age 8yrs due to having a sister 3 years older.  I heard conversations about periods and bra’s and saw sanitary wear from my mum and sister left out.  I learnt the vast majority of things from Sugar magazine and sometimes friends but my mum did attempt to give me the period talk and chipped in a bit about deodorant but it was very minimal.  I just had to embrace changes as they happened and knew they were normal basing it from looking around to see if they were happening to my peers too! I feel puberty needs to be discussed as an earlier age to prepare children for it happening.  There are such great books on the market now that discuss both physical and emotional changes and I feel the more open you have the discussion the better placed the child is to come back with any questions.  I don’t necessarily think rituals like buying your first bra should be important as I feel they shouldn’t be made a big deal out of, but what I do feel is that we mustn’t make it a negative experience for the child.  Including them in decisions, asking what they want to happen and acknowledging their emotions would be sufficient if they are already feeling self conscious about body changes. I found it all embarrassing and just wanted to get the logistics over with quite frankly.  It was uncomfortable discussing things with my mum and I think a stranger in school who didn’t know me would have felt less embarrassing.  I have always been keen on doing exercise, both in school and as an adult.  I was part of the netball, hockey and tennis teams at school and loved to go cycling in the countryside around our village.  Since then I go to the gym, have played in an adult netball team, do exercise classes, go running and cycling. I feel it is integral to my life as I have always done it and enjoyed it.  Since covid 19 hit and gyms were closed I have done more exercise classes online in my home which I have equally loved as they are just as hard, more convenient, cost free and you don’t even have to go outside in the cold! It is making me contemplate whether I will continue my gym membership in the future. Since my mother’s cancer diagnosis myself and my husband have actively tried to eat healthier and eat more vegan, raw and less sugary foods.  We were fairly healthy before but the emotional pain that the diagnosis has created spurs me on to keep healthy so Iwill live along time so my own children don’t have to prematurely go through this heartache.  Similarly, it has made me focus more on my own wellbeing, learning how to manage and cope with stress better, listen more to mindfulness, meditate etc..This will in turn help my mental health. Through the research I have done for cancer healing I found the importance of micronutrients, reducing harboured stress, alternative therapies and diet quite powerful.  I recently also did a health DNA sequencing analysis which highlighted any predispositions to certain health conditions and gave sport, skin, nutrigenics, pharmacogenomics reports which did guide my choices of diet to a degree, though I thought it would have had more of an impact on them. Nowadays I get health and wellbeing information from articles on social media and companies’ emails as there is so much out there.  I am definitely more aware of my body now and what it can and can’t do and how exercise, diet, stress can have an impact on it.  Pregnancy and labour had taught me how it can change and create and sustain life of another human which is mind blowing.  It forced me to be patient being thatI couldn’t do the same type and intensity of exercise as before and taught me the first lesson on sacrificing your own wellbeing for the benefit of another. In the future I expect health and wellbeing to be more readily accessible and convenient in your own home more and affordable to more people.  I think the government will play a more active role in health promotion through reducing carbon emissions, thus promoting veganism and continuing to influence the media and companies in things like increasing sugar, alcohol/tobacco tax and setting stricter rules on food composition and health standards.  I feel that in the future I will most certainly turn vegan, be able to do more exercise once my youngest child is at school and I will have the time to prioritise my own wellbeing. I can’t see my situation changing in old age unless I am hit with a serious disease as it is so ingrained into my life now.  Health and wellbeing are related to external appearance to a certain degree as your body’s condition is affected by them.  Being obese or negatively thinking will be a catalyst for the manifestation of other disease like heart disease which will have the physical appearance of a red face or breathlessness.  Saying that however people can still have good wellbeing and be unhealthy and visa versa. I used to be more into going on sun beds and fake tanning than I am now which was a popular idea of beauty in the 90s and 00s.  I would much prefer to have wrinkle free skin now than get a snubbed tan. I have followed fashions a bit like getting permed hair in the 90s and plucked my eyebrows but as fashions these change so much.  I loathe how social media, fashion magazines and porn portray to people, especially younger generations, how they should be looking and what is deemed normal and attractive.  Idon’t think it has enough cross section of bodies and diversity of anything. I know my mum was influenced by TV and magazines of the 80s in her quest to be slimmer which in today’s climate was just the start of the influence social media has on people’schoices and body confidence and choices. I’m currently trying a lustre blue light therapy unit to help with my acne as I really don want to use any drugs to try and clear it up, time will tell if it proves successful.  I love the Calm app to help with my wellbeing and listen to it daily.  Any other product I use is usually organic and with an Eco slant from brands like Liz Earle, Neil’s Yard and Weleda. It used to be quite exciting seeing my mother get dressed up for parents evening or for a rare meal out. This is probably the only times she wore perfume so the strong scent of Youth Dew was associated with mum looking all fancy and applying lipstick and grandma babysitting us! She would use a hot brush to style her hair and sit at her bedroom dressing table to apply make up choosing a variety from selection tins of lipstick and nail varnish. There certainly wasn’t as much make up application as people do nowadays! She always wore a skirt or dress in the 80s, I can never remember her wearing trousers then. Downstairs she would look in the lounge mirror to see if she looked fat in her outfit and have a side ways pose breathing in and stroking her tummy flatter!! I am amazed that I don’t have an eating disorder now after seeing this so frequently as a child! My routine has changed through time as prior to kids I could spend longer getting ready and drink alcohol while doing it. It could be a whole afternoon showering, curling hair, fake tanning, trying on different outfits and doing make up.  Now I haven’t got that much time to get ready for going out so my hair styles and make up are less adventurous.  I’ll always apply perfume, foundation, concealer, eyebrow pencil, eye shadow, mascara and lipstick or gloss but it may not have the finer detail to it like lip liner or eye liner, contouring the eye shadow shades or putting highlighter on. With my hair, it may go up or straightners used as I haven’t got time to curl it. I won’t try outfits on anymore and just think this’ll do!If I can’t be bothered to shave my legs then I’ll just wear tights or trousers instead.  Getting ready in covid 19 times has been even simpler! I don’t even straighten my hair anymore, just whip it back into a frizzy mess of a pony tail.  I don’t put on make up nearly as much anymore now as mask covers most of my face and I seem to live in comfy clothes like jumpers and leggings.  Standards have definitely slipped substantially in covid 19 times mainly because I am hardly seeing anyone or going out so think why bother!

Religion Free Text: I am a member of the Church of England.
Living Arrangement Free Text: Married in 1971; living as a family (3 children) 1974 - 1998 approx. On our own now, except when family visit - eight grandchildren, making sixteen of us if we manage to get everyone together.
Relationship Status Free Text: Celebrated our Golden Wedding earlier this year.
Occupation 2020 Free Text: Retired Company Secretary of Construction firm, responsible for accounts, administration and Quality System.
Current Occupation Free Text: Retired Company Secretary of Construction firm, responsible for accounts, administration and Quality System.
Partners Occupation Free Text: Retired Chairman and Managing Director of Construction firm. Overall responsibility for contracts, personnel, health and safety.

Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing'. Mass-Observer I6609 describes themself as female; age 72; married; 'retired former company secretary, formerly teacher'.;The Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing' was issued on 27 November 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their opinions on and experiences of health and wellbeing, in particular 'health, wellbeing and the healthy body'; 'identity'; 'growing up and learning about health and wellbeing'; 'growing older'; 'health, wellbeing and appearance'; 'getting ready to leave the house'.
Contents: 16609 Female aged 72, married, Burton Bradstock, retired former Company Secretary, formerly teacher. Autumn Directive 2020: Part 2: Health and Wellbeing Health, wellbeing and the healthy body “Health” is a priceless asset that we probably only value sufficiently, when we have lost some of it. Now that I am 72, I know that how the rest of my life plays out will depend to a great extent on how my health holds up. Two years ago, I was diagnosed with breast cancer. I had a lumpectomy followed by chemotherapy and radiotherapy. I have been well since then, but I have learned that good health is not guaranteed. Imagine a healthy body: fit; agile; not obese; energetic; functioning. I am thinking of myself, but in the past – by now, I have developed a droop in my posture, so I resemble the old people on the traffic sign. I used to be upright and healthy. Identity I can’t be sure, but I think my paternal grandmother had a stoop, like me. But she was only in her early sixties when she died (so my memories of her are distant) and I wasn’t much affected by that age. I worked in an office for almost twenty years and that certainly didn’t help my posture. I used a computer frequently (I still do!). I think I have kept my health in other respects, partly because of my social class and education – I have never seriously smoked, and I only drink in moderation. Also I know about the importance of exercise. (I am fortunate there, because my husband is a keen walker and so I go walking more, probably, than I would otherwise do). I think my experience of health has been overwhelmingly influenced by my gender! Most of my experience of health care has been in relation to gynaecological events or conditions. Breast cancer is mostly a woman’s disease.  Growing up and learning about health and wellbeing I remember my mother’s pregnancies when I was five and nine. When I was nine, the baby suffered brain damage from lack of oxygen – home birth, an undiagnosed breech. The baby also had a severe cleft palate. He died at three weeks. I learned a lot at that time. Later, there was a polio epidemic and my younger sister’s best friend had it and was hospitalised, and suffered some lasting effects. We learned a lot. We were examined at intervals by the School Nurse, accompanied by a doctor, I think. We were also examined and sometimes treated by the School dentist. We went to our own doctor for routine injections; he called at home if we were poorly and in bed. Our parents were responsible for looking after our health and wellbeing. I remember my parents talking to me about why the baby died, also about polio, and other health problems that people had. When I was eleven, my younger sister was diagnosed with epilepsy. I learned about that. Mostly I learned because my mother used to talk things through with me. I was interested, but it was also because she needed to talk about these things.  I expect we had some elementary health education in primary school, but I don’t particularly remember it. I do remember it in secondary school; it was “sex education” there. The class would be divided and the girls got the talk and filmstrip from the visiting nurse, about menstruation. We were all given a booklet from Kotex, a leading manufacturer of sanitary towels. Subsequently  the whole class received “sex education” about reproduction, to everyone’s embarrassment. Filmstrips again. Questions at the end, when people thought up the weirdest things to ask about. I don’t think there was ever anything that came up in the sex education lesson, that I didn’t know already. Fortunately. In the first year of secondary school, a friend of a friend whispered to me (and the friend) in the playground, “Do you know what fuck means?” No, we didn’t. “It’s what a boy and a girl do when they make a baby”. Oh. I was impressed, particularly because the girl that told us, was, I knew, adopted, having been born illegitimate. (She herself had told us this). My mother was a teacher and before her marriage, she had been on a course in teaching sex education. The course textbook was removed from the bookcase by me and I used to read it in bed, pushing it to the bottom of the bed under the bedclothes between sessions. I was twelve at the time and I remember reading with solemn interest the recommended ages for introducing various topics to schoolchildren – generally somewhat older than I was! The book was helpful and informative. In my teens, I read girls’ magazines, though I don’t think there was much there that I didn’t already know. The advice on health and beauty was sound. Thank goodness, we didn’t have the internet or anything like that. I’m talking about the fifties and sixties. Key moments I was the eldest of three girls, with no brothers. I don’t think much fuss was made about reaching puberty; I didn’t have any physical problems with it. My mother was sympathetic and made sure I was OK. She bought me lipstick, nylons and shoes with kitten heels when I was thirteen. We lived in the country and there was no opportunity to go shopping on one’s own – nor would I have had any money! I always went to mixed schools, so didn’t get “silly” about boys in the way that girls in a single sex school often do. Growing older In retirement, my husband and I have had more time to spend on keeping fit. We joined our local Leisure Centre and used to go to classes two or three times a week, before the pandemic, as well as walking regularly. Fortunately we are able to continue with the walking. There are many sources of information on health and wellbeing available to us, from the government and NHS advice, through radio and television programmes and articles in the newspaper or in magazines. You can also look up these same sources online. I don’t think anything has changed in my awareness of my body. I don’t expect my approach to health and wellbeing to change in future, although I know that my body will change and I may develop health problems. Health, wellbeing and appearance I think external appearance is affected by vitality more than by health or wellbeing, although of course they affect it too.  Yes, I think I have been influenced by the fashions of the times! Perhaps most, with hairstyles. I like a sleek bob now, but there was a time when I had an Afro perm – and oh, it was so easy to look after! Yes, I think my mother was influenced by fashion, my father much less so. My mother, to the end of her life, used to powder her nose and check her hair before leaving the house or receiving someone. (I can’t say the same!) I couldn’t live without toothpaste, and either soap or cleansing cream. For washing my hair, I need either shampoo, or conditioner which does the same job. I do possess two lipsticks (both the same colour!) but I haven’t used lipstick since the pandemic began – I put some on the other day, before a Zoom, but it seemed so strange that I had to wipe it off. I possess some face powder too, but I’ve not been using that either. My secret pleasure is my perfume – Hugo Boss “Orange” – I enjoy a squirt of that most days. I’d like to find that on my Desert Island. Getting ready to leave the house I’ve described my mother’s powder and lipstick routine, but she also used to put her hair up – what a performance. She had set up multiple mirrors in her bedroom. She used various aids, such as combs or hairgrips, and a firm hold hairspray was needed when she’d finished. I didn’t pay much attention to my father’s routine, but he always smelled nice when he’d finished (though not of aftershave; I think it was just soap!) My own routine depends on the time available, and I am often to be found in the passenger seat of the car, applying lipstick when the road is straight and  fumbling around to get my earrings in. I usually take shoes with heels with me and change on arrival. Eye makeup makes me look terrible, I haven’t worn it for years. When I was teaching I used to take a bit more trouble; when I worked in the office, probably less! (it was definitely a back office). The routine for “leaving the house” nowadays involves, more importantly! checking on vital items such as reading glasses, mobile phone, purse or credit card, etc and just at the moment, MASK.
