Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing'. Mass-Observer P1796 describes themself as female; age 74; married; retired.;The Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing' was issued on 27 November 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their opinions on and experiences of health and wellbeing, in particular 'health, wellbeing and the healthy body'; 'identity'; 'growing up and learning about health and wellbeing'; 'growing older'; 'health, wellbeing and appearance'; 'getting ready to leave the house'.
Contents: MO NO: P1796; Female; Age 74: Married; Bridport; Dorset Retired Part 2 -Everyday Health & Wellbeing Health to me means keeping well and active, keeping relatively free from sickness and hopefully staying mobile. Wellbeing means more to do with your mind and how you are feeling mentally. A healthy body in 5 words -fit; glowing; looking good; happy I do not think I could name one person to describe a healthy body although I think the Duchess of Cambridge probably fits the bill. I believe that women are probably more aware of health and wellbeing than men are, they are the ones who normally take on the role of caring for the family so it is very important that they stay healthy. It was probably not until my mid 20’s that I thought about staying healthy. At that time many prominent stars were coming out with keep fit videos and also I was getting back into being more active. Wellbeing on the other hand I don’t really think became recognised until more recently and yet it is almost as important as that of your health. When I was growing up my father had very little to do with our health, this was handled by my mother as I imagine it was with most of my generation. It was still considered that men would go out to work and women would look after the family and we were no different. My mother was definitely a person who would carry on regardless of how she was feeling and that was instilled in my mind, although having said that the same could not be said of her treatment of my father or indeed my brothers. She cosseted them all, which needless to say I resented. I don’t recall her ever talking to us about our health, she always ensure we were well looked after, well fed(probably too well fed) which resulted in me being rather overweight. However I do remember her joining the League of Health and Beauty and I went along as well, probably I was around 10/11. I know we wore white satin blouses and black satin shorts. From what I can recall and also seeing old footage, I think it was a combination of exercise and dance and was choreographed. My mother loved dancing so probably this is what spurred her on to join. Once I was married I was able to control what I ate and so lost the weight although its always been a battle. I am afraid my school days are so long ago I cannot remember whether we had any health education, if we did it certainly wasn’t considered that important. Sports was considered part of our education and was compulsory and I certainly joined in. We also had to have cod liver oil which is truly foul presumably because it was considered good for our health. Trying to recall changes associated with puberty is taxing me a little. My mother obviously explained to me about periods probably when I was around 11, and I do remember getting my first period, but around that time my youngest brother was born after a gap of over 9 years between him and my other brother. I went to a girls school and I know we had biology lessons and obviously I was aware of changes to my body but here again it is so long ago the actual memory is hard to recall. I suppose I was excited to get my first bra although I was never particularly well endowed. I wonder how my granddaughters would feel if they were asked the same questions. They do seem very much more open in all aspects of their lives than we were. Looking back I think my mother was quite embarrassed to talk about anything to do with our bodies, this of course could have been due to the way that she was brought up. I suppose it was in my late 20’s when things started to change for me, this would have been in the early 70’s. It probably was when famous film stars started producing their keep fit video’s that I became more interested in keeping fit and plus we moved to Dubai and I started playing netball again and as they say one thing led to another. Since that time I have tried to keep fit, mainly in an effort to keep my weight down, not due to a health aspect but rather I wanted to stay trim. I know that I went through a stage when my kids 2 MO NO: P1796; Female; Age 74: Married; Bridport; Dorset Retired had to go to boarding school in the UK and I started to struggle with not seeing them. My husband was a way a lot and I seemed to be torn between missing them but actually loving living in Dubai. However I was lucky that I was able to work which helped. Since then I have always tried to do exercise and in fact I now probably do more than ever and I am inmy 70’s. We are all encouraged to do more to keep fit and I am glad to say I have found a lot of friends around the same age who feel the same way. It has been apparent with the Covid 19 that it can make a big difference to how you cope with the virus depending on how well you have kept fit. I regularly read up about keeping healthy and fit in both papers, internet, social media and of course TV. Although obviously with age one has to take care of oneself but as long as I can do the workouts, the running, cycling that I love I will continue to do so. In fact when we went into the first lockdown I could no longer go to the gym so I took up running again, not my favourite form of exercise, but I need some variation. I had given up years ago due to my knees giving me problems but I decided to give it a go and in fact I am amazed that I now regularly run 5kms even in the winter and my knees seem stronger. How long this will go on for I do not know. I believe in having as many interests outside of the home is very important for one’s wellbeing and I also like a challenge to try something new every year, although I am running out of ideas. However I have really enjoyed having time to spend on our garden this year, something I normally had to fit in. Although we cannot do anything about ageing I do think that if you keep active, have lots of interests it is reflected in your outlook and you just look better. I look at some older people who basically have the view that once they get to a certain age then they just decide that their live is over and just sit around. They don’t want to try anything new and they seem to close their minds. I must admit having grandkids around encourages you to keep up to date. My mum certainly paid close attention to how she looked and she was still swimming regularly until her late 80’s, but my Dad found life very different once he retired as he had no other interests in life. As my skin is not very good, mainly due to having spent too many years in the sun, I do need to have a number of different products to keep my skin in relatively good condition so I would hate to be without them. I would also hate to be without my make up as I always put my make up on every day regardless but I suppose I could live without them. Hard to pick a Desert Island item but I suppose mascara followed by close second of eye shadow. I really cannot remember my parents getting ready for going out, my mother didn’t work, and my father I presume would have a wash and shave and after having breakfast leave for work. My mother always used to have her hair done if she was going out for a special evening and she certainly made an effort with her clothes and being very particular about everything matching, something I hate to admit that I also like. I have always had, and still do have a shower every morning, washed my hair and blow dried it, put on my makeup before starting my day regardless of whether or not I was going out. I continued with this routine all during lockdown as it is just part of me. If I am going out I will probably spend more time on my makeup. This routine really hasn’t changed over the years although I probably don’t spend as much time getting ready to go out as I used to. 3

Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'COVID-19 and Time'. Mass-Observer P1796 describes themself as female; age 73; married; retired.;The Directive 'COVID-19 and Time' was issued on 7 August 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their experiences of the COVID-19 pandemic and lockdown in relation to the 'rhythm and routine of the day'; 'homelife'; use of 'media and technology'; their experiences of 'waiting'.
Contents: PART 1 - COVID-19 AND TIME  Rhythm and routine of the day. Indeed my daily life and routine have definitely changed beginning with the lockdown when I only went out of the house each day for exercise and to pick up the paper, that was the extent.  Compare this to pre lockdown, when I was out and about all the time, rushing from one place to another and always trying to find some spare time.  So how would I cope with all this spare time, well amazingly well which really surprised me.  Ofcourse the weather was glorious in the lockdown which was a huge benefit, as for the first time I was able to spend time in the garden and the allotment, something I really enjoyed and needless to say the garden and allotment benefitted.  I could no longer go to the gym or swim but I needed exercise, although I previously did cycle a couple of times a week.  However I had to get into a new routine, so ended up cycling 4 times a week and jogging 3 times a week, I love cycling but not keen on jogging.  I went out first thing in the morning around 6.30 and it was lovely, very few people around and they ended up becoming regulars. I would then pop into our local Spar en route home and pick up the paper wearing gloves but no mask.  Big change here as I needed to pop the outer pages of the paper in the microwave to disinfect it, not sure whether this was correct but seemed like a good idea.  At 10 am we would stop whatever we were doing and have a coffee and read the paper; here again so different from before, when I was lucky if I had time to read the paper when having a coffee.  At 11am my husband would go for a walk as he needed some exercise and it gave me the opportunity to get onto the computer and keep up with any admin I needed to do.  At 12 we would have lunch and then around 2 would head to the allotment for an hour, back home for cup of tea, make supper, and then watch TV.    We did see our neighbours from a distance and would chat to them and then we started Facetiming our family and then Zoom became part of our lives.  At the time of lockdown I was President of our local Inner Wheel Club and I decided that if we couldn’t see each other face to face, we needed to see each other virtually.  I had never used or in fact heard of Zoom but I soon learnt how to use it and got a regular weekly session going.  It was lovely to see ladies, who up until then had not really used their computers/tablets/phones for anything like this, really get into it and enjoy it.  As well as doing a weekly Zoom meeting, I also started a weekly newsletter to all the ladies telling them what I was doing, what was going on and asking them to reply stating what they were doing to pass the time.   I feel I got to know some of them a lot better during this time and was actually quite sad when with the end of my year as President in mid July I no longer did this.  As my husband and I are both retired we obviously were not involved in the furlough scheme, however 2 of our grandchildren were, and 1 still is I am sorry to say, but hoping that this will end in September, he needs to be back at work.   We live by the sea, in a very popular area for visitors, and the road outside our house can get very noisy during the summer season.  We both loved the fact that there were no cars on the road, the quiet was heavenly, we could hear the birds singing.  So then lockdown was eased and everything changed.  People started arriving, roads got busy and the harbour was packed and our lives started changing again.  However certainly not back to normal and in some ways this is harder, as people seem to want to push the boundaries of what you can/cant do and yet the virus is still here.  It has been lovely of course to see our family who we have missed, and we have had some friends over but certainly nothing like before and we are both reluctant to go any further.   I have now gone back to the gym twice a week but here again very early, and with the restrictions operating for gyms, currently there are usually only 6-7 people, so feel comfortable with that. We have to pre book our sessions which last 75 minutes, but having to clean all the equipment each time you use it, means that the 75 minutes go by quickly.  In addition our gym is now in 3 seperate areas which adds to the time. In addition we have started netball training, all within a 2 metre square which is kind of weird but better than nothing. Lovely to be able to go to the hairdressers and beautician, and for my husband to be able to play golf and get some more exercise.  We still haven’t been out to a restaurant.  We have taken day trips out to a number of National Trust properties and have enjoyed a change of scenery, but when you live in such a beautiful area it is not so important.  Here again you have to pre book your entry time to the NT grounds, but we haven’t found this too much of a problem.  Homelife There are just the two of us in the household, and I think I have already described how we have spent our time during and coming out of lockdown.  I definitely enjoy having more time to myself and wonder how I am going to cope, if and when they get a vaccine, and we can get back to more normality. I miss being able to go out for lunch with friends and also my husband, being able to do things on the spur of the moment, everything now has to be planned in advance.  Media & technology Certainly for me technology has been great, I did use it a lot prior to Covid so was well versed in its uses, but the extra time I had meant that I was prepared to try and learn more of what I could do.  As I said Zoom probably was the biggest change for me and something that I think will continue to feature in our lives.  I think that the way that we used our medical services will definitely benefit by more use of technology.  I am more than happy to have an initial consult either by phone or virtually, and in fact had one during June which so impressed me because I got to speak to a consultant within 2 weeks, whereas normally I would have to wait anywhere between 2-3 months if I was lucky! Obviously this would not always be the case, but if the initial consult could be done like this, then it would allow Drs hopefully more time with patients.   I have used online shopping for many years, mainly as I am not keen on grocery shopping at the best of times, and also we only have 1 big supermarket close by which I am not keen on.  Due to the initial problems with getting a delivery slot, I started using another company which is more expensive but had the slots.  Once things settled down a bit, my regular supermarket then had slots and so I now alternate between the 2.  I have been considering going back to my regular deliveries every 2 weeks, but who knows if we will have another lockdown and I don’t want to be prevented from getting my slot. We did invest in a Smart TV in January this year, so this has proved a real bonus as we were then able to sign up to Amazon Prime and Netflix, so we have had many programmes to choose from.  Waiting Yes to a certain extent I do feel my life has been put on hold, and I felt I have missed out on our great granddaughter growing up. She is 21 months now and has changed so much during this spell, and I feel she also has missed out on so much as well.  Fortunately we Facetime our granddaughter so were able to see the little one running around, and in fact our great granddaughter Facetimed me the other day by herself!!!  Obviously as we are getting older, we wanted to do some more travelling particularly as we no longer have a dog.   What has amazed us both is just how the time goes by and it seems it is the weekend again.  At this point I will add that we have not changed our drinking habits during Lockdown, we only drink Friday, Saturday & Sunday in the evenings.  However we do treat ourselves to some bubbly once a fortnight, but apart from that no change.  Even now I rarely go into town, so haven’t had to queue that much.  I think the worst experience I had was early on, when our pharmacy was inundated and people were waiting 5-6 hours just to get their prescription.  I did go down at 6.45 in the morning to queue for my husband’s prescription, he took my place at 8.30, the pharmacy did not open till 9, and got his prescription at 9.30.  At that point we decided to change from this pharmacy and we went online to get ours delivered to the house.  Once this was set up it has been great and we certainly will not be going back to having to pick up a perscription. I am fine with waiting to go into a shop as the weather is nice, but wonder how we will all cope in the winter.  One of the other reasons for not going into town, is that I am not keen on having to wear a mask purely because I wear glasses, and although I have tried a number of different options, my glasses seem to mist up. I prefer to do things online.   Fortunately neither of us have had major problems with health, couple of times we have used the online system and it has worked well for us, but I know that this is not the case for everyone.  In our area we have have very low rates of Covid so we have been lucky.  Other things that have changed  There are a number of things that have changed that I wanted to flag up, although I couldn’t really find a section to put them in but felt they were important to note. Firstly in those weeks of lockdown, we didn’t use our cars, we only went to the allotment so needless to say we still had petrol/diesel in our cars when lockdown was over and of course during lockdown the price of oil slumped!! Cash virtually became extinct, my husband to this day, still has £30 in his wallet that he had on March 23rd nearly 5 months ago because we have gone contactless.  We had been gradually using less cash for quite a while, but now it became the normal way to go. They did up the limit from £30 to £45 which helped.  Mind you it does seem strange to use an app to pay £0.40 for an hour’s car parking!  Previously we would buy a year’s car parking permit but no point as I probably only use the car parks twice a week and sometimes my husband doesn’t use them at all. One of the major downsides of this virus has been our church closed and is still not open.  The church is one of 6 in the team, and due to ours being located in the centre of a busy tourist area, it was felt it would be difficult to open once permission had been given. The need to keep numbers coming in for private prayer down, and the fact that you would need at least 2 people in attendance was going to be hard.  In addition the church had said that anyone over 70 could not do this job and as our congregation are 95% over 70 this was impractical.  So our church was designated as the funeral church, meaning that all funerals over the 6 churches in the team would be held here, and the funeral directors had agreed to clean the areas used after the service.  Fortunately to date we have only had 2 funerals. However we have had an online service each week, and although the team now has a service at one of the churches, as only 35 people can attend, the online service continues.  Its not the same but at least it helps. Prior to the virus, we had all been working hard to cut down on the use of plastics in all forms but particularly plastic bags and we were getting very good at it, of course helped by the fact that you now had to pay for them in shops.  Most people had long life bags which they took with them to the supermarkets etc.  However with online deliveries once again we have gone back to plastic bags which I hate, but apparently this is the only way that supermarkets can safely deliver your shopping.  I am every hopeful that an alternative can be found.   People during this time seemed to have become more caring of others, willing to do more for others whoever they are.  I think the weekly clapping for the NHS was amazing, this was one way that anyone could show that they cared. I trust that we do not loose this. As many people started working from home, and in fact continue to do so, it was reported that a lot of them would stay all day in their pyjamas, or else dress in tee shirts and joggers, occasionally putting on a shirt or blouse if they were having an office Zoom meeting.  I can honestly say that I did not change what I wore any different from what I would normally do and I would put my make up on every day regardless of not going out. I have missed wearing a lot of my clothes as I haven’t gone anywhere to wear them, I wonder how many other women did the same.

Religion Free Text: Ex/lapsed Catholic - no longer support the Church due to several abuse scandals. I still have a belief in some sort of god or divinity, so for now, I use the general term 'theist'.
Living Arrangement Free Text: Partner's daughter (my stepdaughter) stays with us three weekends out of four, and during school holidays.
Relationship Status Free Text: Co-habiting with male partner for approx 5 years
Occupation 2020 Free Text: Information Services Assistant (library assistant) for a law firm
Current Occupation Free Text: Information Services Assistant (library assistant) for a law firm
Partners Occupation Free Text: Technical Assurance Specialist for NHS Digital

Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'COVID-19 (Update)' by Mass-Observer M6884.;The Directive 'COVID-19 (Update)' was issued on 27 April 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their experiences of the COVID-19 pandemic, in particular 'health'; 'the government'; 'news'; 'work and home life'; 'technology'; 'shopping and food'; 'entertainment and leisure'; 'personal hygiene' and 'sleep'.
Contents: Part 2: Covid-19 (Update) Health I suffer from anxiety and depression, and during the lockdown, these have become much worse. I feel increasingly isolated, which makes me feel extremely sad, and I often break down in tears. I have also been placed on furlough leave from my job – originally until June, then July, and now until October – which has taken away my regular routine. This, in turn, increases my anxiety, and I struggle to fill the time each day. Sometimes, I don't even see the point in getting out of bed. I am also filled with dread at the possibility of losing my job completely, especially in a struggling economy. The Government Despite my personal troubles, I do believe the Government were right to implement a lockdown. It helps prevent the virus' spread. However, it annoys me when working-class people are giving hefty fines for going to shops, visiting family, etc. (not that I condone their actions) but a government advisor can drive all the way to Barnard Castle and get off scot free. I also found myself being angry at the Black Lives Matter protests: not because I don't support their message and their fight for equality, but because they broke lockdown rules to gather publicly. I am so fearful of a second spike of the virus and an extended lockdown, I would have much preferred that they kept their protests virtual rather than risking everybody's health. Now that the Government are opening businesses back up, I can only hope they continue to track the cases and R numbers, and that they will close down again if they have to. True, I hate lockdown, and I know a stable and strong economy is important too, but can we really put a price on people's lives? Mass Observation Archive –Spring 2020 Directive - M6884 News I read the news online,usuallythroughTwitter and the BBC News website.As we don't have aTV licence(legally, since we don't watch liveTV), we don't watch the broadcasts: I tendto read thesummaries andkeypoints on theBBCwebsite afterwards.That being said, I tryto limit myexposure tonews, as it makes me nervous and deepens my depression. I do agree that BSLinterpreters should have been onthe UK broadcast from the start, or otherwise, live transcribed subtitles. During a worldcrisis,it is irresponsible to exclude anyone from the latest news andadvice. Work andhome life I have beenfurloughed from myjob, which, as I have mentioned, has been toughon me mentalityas it takes awaymyroutine. This, inturn,has been tough on mypartner, who has the stress ofbothworkingfor the NHS from home whilst dealing with me at mylowest points. Wetryto give each other spaceand supporteach other as best as we can. However, our stepdaughter nowstays with us 50% ofthe time and notjust onweekends, so I help with homeschooling.As a hobbyist writer, I especiallyenjoying assisting with her English assignments!Wealso playeducational videogames andwatch documentaries to encouraging learning in a fun wayawayfrom textbooks. TechnologyMyself, myboss andcolleagues haveweeklychats onZoom, just tokeep in touch and help support each other. I also takeYoga classes through Zoom onceaweek to stay active, andregularlyuse ittochat with friends. I also playvideogames with friends over the internet whilst talking with them through aheadset. I am something of a gadget girl, soI havetakento all of this eagerly. Technologyhas been the saviour ofmysocial life, andhas helped keep me sane. I have mainlybeen using social media to look at funnyposts or to follow pages about my hobbies –to have a fundistraction from thesadness fuelled bythe pandemic. I doread the news in brief, but trytolimit myexposure to itto avoid anxietyattacks. I also use itto sharemywritingor photos of things I havecrafted (seeEntertainment and Leisure below). Shopping andfood Whenlockdown was firstdeclared, mypartner andI didn't exactlypanic buy, but we did pick up a fewextra frozenfoods and some tinned goods,just in case. Rice,pasta and bread turnedout to be averywise investment -especiallythe latter, as Ibought an extra loaf to freeze -and soupensured we hadalways had somethingin for lunch. Luckily, we have amilkman,so our milk supplywas ongoing. The onlyshop in our village is aM&S Food storeat the petrol station. To startwith, it was hardto getcertainthings, liketea bags and vegetables, but over time,supplies have returned tonormal. It is more expensivethan the supermarkets, butyou payfor convenience andhigher quality. Nowthat supermarkets have re-opened, we drive tothe Aldi in the next village about once aweek to doa bigger shopto tryand save money. Mypartner and I have beeneating takeaways more often: usuallyas aform ofcomfort Mass ObservationArchive–Spring2020Directive-M6884 eating, and togive us something to look forward to. Doing the weeklybig shops has helped us cut that down, as it ensures we alreadyhave food in the house touseup. Entertainment andLeisure Duringlockdown, I have learned how to loom knit, and enjoymakinghats. Iwillgive some to relatives, anddonate others to charity. Each hat takes a fewhours to knit, so it is a fun activityI can do topass long evenings -usuallywhilst listeningto music andrelaxing in a comfychair. I also write as a hobby, and have entered a fewstories into competitions run byother users of the writingwebsites... winning a few prizes along theway. Writing in itself is another fun activity – allowingme to leave this troubled worldbehind to brieflyescape into a fun fictional one – andthe prizes haveprovidedaconfidenceboost, helping to alleviate mydepression. In addition, Ihave cleared outseveral bags ofoldclothes from cupboards andwardrobes, whichI intend to give to charityshops once lockdownis lifted. Ialso cleared out some old CDs and DVDS, whilst mystepdaughter cleared outallofher old toddler toys. Thesewere placedin cardboard boxes marked “FREE”, which we put out on thepavementoutside of our housefor those in the neighbourhood totake. This was much appreciated,and other houses have since followedsuit. The fewitems thatremain will also be donatedto charity. We,like severalof our neighbours,also took part in theThursdaynight clap for carers, whichwas verymoving – although, in manyways, I also think peopleclapped for themselves: proud of coming together as a nation, proudofkeeping up the strength to cope with everything thathas happened, andis continuing to happen. I certainlyfelt that wayattimes. Mymusic taste is quiteeclectic:I listenfrom everything torock andopera, tomusicals and bubblegum pop. OnTV, comedies like Taskmaster,Blackadder and Bottomhave been fun and sometimes sillydistractions from the pandemic, bringingme some much-needed laughter. I also like watching historical documentaries to learn more aboutvarious famous figures and events, as well as quizzes to keep mybrain busy: mypartner and Ihave fun guessing theanswers together. PersonalHygieneI continueto bathe nightlyduringlockdown:bothto stayclean, and becauseI find bubble baths relaxing. I am washing clothes less oftenas I tendto wear the same clothes for a coupleof days atatime. Theyare notgetting dirtyas I haven't beenleaving the house. Myhair is getting rather longnowas Icannot go for myusual haircut, and I wear it ina low ponytail. Iwash itonce a week, as I have always done, to give myhair achance to produce its natural oils and maintain its strength before cleansingit. I'm not too upset about not being able to visit ahairdresser,as I'm taking this as a opportunitytogrowmy hair longenoughto donate itto the Little Princess Trust,so itcan be madeinto awig for a childgoingthroughchemotherapy. SleepI have had increased nightmares during lockdown –usuallyastring ofrandom illogical events -which Iinterpret as manifestations of myworries relating to myjob, familyand the Mass ObservationArchive–Spring2020Directive-M6884 pandemic atlarge. Other times, I feelso boredand depressed, I'll go to sleepjust to pass a fewhours. Mass ObservationArchive–Spring2020Directive-M6884

Religion Free Text: I describe myself as spiritual but not religious.
Disability Free Text: Lower back pain for over 40 years which severely affects my mobility.  Sitting is very difficult for me but I remain active within my abilities!

Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing'. Mass-Observer H1745 describes themself as female; age 69; widow / living with partner; retired.;The Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing' was issued on 27 November 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their opinions on and experiences of health and wellbeing, in particular 'health, wellbeing and the healthy body'; 'identity'; 'growing up and learning about health and wellbeing'; 'growing older'; 'health, wellbeing and appearance'; 'getting ready to leave the house'.
Contents: Mass Observation Autumn Directive 2020 Female H1745 Age 69 Widow/Living with partner London Retired Part 2: Everyday health and wellbeing Health, wellbeing and the healthy body To me, 'health' and 'wellbeing' are almost inextricable, but I might tend to see 'health' as relating to the body and being a more objective measure/concept and 'wellbeing' relating to the mind, emotions and psyche and being more subjective. If I knew someone had no pain, no illness, no disability and no injury, I would probably venture to say that they were 'healthy' but I would never presume to assess their sense of 'wellbeing'. I'm just writing as I think, and now realise that to be 'healthy' one's mind needs to be free of illness or affliction. Someone could easily be physically healthy but if they had psychosis (which could, of course, have a physical basis) you'd never say they were completely healthy! In a broad sense, I'd say that 'health' relates to freedom from illness, injury, pain or disability, while 'wellbeing' refers to a person's sense of satisfaction with their lives and could be affected by all sorts of things other than the condition of that person's body and mind, including financial security, emotional fulfilment, job satisfaction, relationship satisfaction, levels of experienced stress, freedom of expression… Five words Five words that come to mind when I think of the term 'healthy body' are: . Strength . Vitality . Muscle . Glowing . Balance One particular person does come to mind when I think of this term, although it's someone I've never met. She is a spiritual teacher who holds online classes my partner attends. I've only ever seen her top half as she's always sitting down, but she almost literally glows, with her long fair hair exuding a radiance and vitality which I'm sure all comes from spiritual fulfilment and strength. Identity I find it quite hard to identify whether my own experiences of 'health' and 'wellbeing' have been influenced by my gender (female), ethnicity (white British), social class (middle-class) or sexual orientation (heterosexual). I've been lucky to have been brought up in what I would identify as a middle-class family. We didn't have a lot of money, but we always had enough, with plenty of good food and medical care when necessary. I've never earnt a lot of money, but I've always had as much as I needed. Growing up and learning about health and wellbeing Becoming aware about health and wellbeing I really can't remember when I first became aware of 'health' or 'wellbeing'. I remember being given cod liver oil and orange juice when I was a young child (probably up to the age of about five) issued by the NHS and no doubt my mother explained that these were good for my health! I remember as a child of about three sitting on the draining board in the kitchen of our North London home and being given my first junior aspirin to stop a headache or other pain, and I remember having iodine put on grazed knees while at junior school. As far as 'wellbeing' is concerned, I don't think I thought of this as a concept until much later in life. Responsibility for my health and wellbeing My mother was primarily responsible for my health and wellbeing when I was a child, as my father died when I was very young. Talking about health I don't remember having any discussions about health in abstract terms with my mother. We'd certainly have talked about illness, because I had a lot of the childhood illnesses that were common in the 1950s – chickenpox, measles, rubella… and the odd mishap such as a cut forehead (requiring stitches). I think we'd only have talked about health in its absence – when things went wrong. But I do remember taking vitamin tablets (something called 'Haliborange' which combined Vitamin C and halibut liver oil – they tasted wonderfully orangey) so obviously my Mum did take steps to prevent illness and keep us healthy. I don't remember having any health education at primary or secondary school. All I remember is that every so often a visiting doctor would come to the primary school and we all had to line up holding our medical cards (pink for the girls and yellow for the boys, as far as I remember) and be weighed and measured and searched for nits (and probably not much more beyond sticking out our tongues!) There was also a visiting dentist who came to the primary school. Presumably, both of these were provided in an attempt to identify problems in children whose parents didn't look after their health! I certainly didn't learn anything about health from the Internet – it didn't exist when I was at school! – and I don't remember learning anything useful from friends, books, magazines or newspapers. Key moments I vividly remember the day my periods started. Mum had told me about it at least a year before it happened and had bought me a sanitary belt and some pads. In those days, you couldn't buy the small, discreet adhesive pads you get today and pads were much thicker, bulkier and contained at least some fabric and had fabric loops you'd attach to a belt. It was all part of growing up. I've been told about what would happen, and that I wasn't to be alarmed when it did. I was 13 when I 'started'. My paternal grandmother was staying with us as she'd had a fall and broken her hip and been discharged (with very little warning for us) to my mother's care. She was working full time, so I've no idea how she managed with Grandma sleeping in the front room! I went to the toilet, realised I was bleeding and thought 'Oh, Wow! It's happened!' I remember feeling quite excited and running into the front room, where Mum was talking to Grandma and hissing loudly in Mum's ear 'I've started!' The novelty quickly wore off. The embarrassment of doing gym with the fear of the bulky pads showing or of not being able to control the bleeding and the cramps that occasionally sent me to lie on the couch in the domestic science room, clutching a hot water bottle to my abdomen made the monthlies more of a misery than something to be proud of. I don't have any particular memories of my breasts developing or being bought my first bra. I do remember an occasion when I was probably about 15 when my cousin visited us. I'd lost a bit of weight as I'd been feeling unhappy with my shape and his comment that I was looking slimmer and that he'd 'thought you were going to be as big as your mother,' had a very negative effect on me and, I think, pushed me further into anorexia which was just beginning (my mother could never have been described as 'big'!) Growing older Current activity I'd done as much as I can over the years to maintain my physical and mental health. For more than 40 years I've suffered constant back pain which is always there but varies from quite painful to extremely painful. For the same length of time, I've had sleeping problems – waking multiple times every night and often having difficulty getting back to sleep. The back pain has made my life very difficult. I can't sit for longer than 10 minutes a few times a day (enough to eat quick meals and sit for very brief periods at my computer) and I spend most of my time lying down (reading, writing, doing proofreading, talking on the phone, dictating onto my computer, attending online meetings, etc). Maintaining my physical activity has always been important to me. Up until the Covid lockdowns, I was doing two Pilates classes a week at the local leisure centre, rebounding for 15 minutes daily, going to the gym 3-4 times a week and walking for at least 30 minutes a day. I used to swim twice a week but had problems with dry skin and sensitive eyes and haven't been for a few years now. Since lockdown began, I walk for about an hour a day (quite briskly), rebound for 15 minutes and do 20 minutes of Pilates exercises (twice a week I join an online Pilates class instead of doing my own exercises). Getting information on health and wellbeing Most of my information comes from the Internet. I've recently been researching the link between Oxaliplatin (a chemotherapy drug with which I was treated for advanced colon cancer in 2008) and hepatic portal tension/bleeding oesophageal varices (which I have but which don't seem to be caused by cirrhosis of the liver – the most usual cause). I no longer have full access to medical journals (as I once did while working) but you can get a lot free online! I get information on Covid-19 (e.g. latest statistics, information on vaccines), from the Internet, newspapers and radio. Body awareness I would say that in some ways, I'm more aware of my body now than I was, say, in my 20s, but in some ways less aware. As a young woman, I was always rather self-conscious and felt awkward in my body but I wasn't in pain and didn't experience my body as a source of discomfort. Having had severe back pain for over 40 years, I've got used to being in pain all the time and to me it is 'normal'. I don't feel as awkward and unattractive as I did when I was young, but I am very aware of my body all the time because the pain is always there and restricts my activity to a large extent. How will my approach to health and wellbeing change in future years? I can't imagine my approach to health and wellbeing changing in the future. Eating a healthy diet, getting plenty of exercise, trying to avoid unnecessary stress, meditating, and keeping away from pollution – all these things will continue to be of great importance to me. Health, wellbeing and appearance How are health and wellbeing related to external appearance? It is possible to tell quite a lot about a person's state of health (both physical and mental) from how they look, how they dress, how they walk etc. Psychological tension shows in the face and posture, tiredness, etc can also be quite visible. Wellbeing is, I suppose, more difficult to assess (more subjective) but depression, agitation, anger, frustration etc (all of which would contribute to how a person 'is' in the world) can often be detected from a person's external appearance. Appearances can be deceptive, of course. A man we know who committed suicide recently gave an outward appearance of being healthy, happy with his life and generally at ease. Being influenced by popular ideals of beauty or physical appearance I think we must all be influenced by popular ideals of beauty or physical appearance! These ideals are embedded in so much that we read, see on television and at the cinema, on the radio, look at on social media… It can be very subtle and unstated but the ideals are there and usually they're extremely difficult to meet. The fashion, cosmetic, fitness and beauty industries rely heavily on persuading us of how we should look and suggest that unless we conform, we won't be accepted by our fellows. I do try not to be influenced by these ideals and I'm pleased to say I've never been a slave to fashion and hardly ever wear make up. I do have a morbid fear of being fat but (fortunately, for a recovered anorexic!) I'm also aware of the dangers of being too thin and try to maintain a 'healthy' weight. Were my parents influenced by these ideals? I don't think they were. My father died when I was very young so I can't speak for him, but my mother has never been very fashion-conscious (she has good taste but certainly isn't a slave to fashion) and as far as I can remember has never dieted or embarked on any particular exercise regime. Health and beauty products I couldn't do without . Dental floss and interdental brushes (I have gum disease and quite large gaps between my teeth) . Moisturising lotion (different ones for face and body): my skin is very dry and I couldn't cope without at least moisturiser on my face . Back massager (it helps to relieve my pain) . Mini-trampoline: I rebound for 15 minutes every day and would really miss it if I couldn't do it. Useful low-impact exercise that protects my back but gets me moving! My desert island item would be moisturiser for my face (preferably with sun protection). Getting ready to leave the house Parents I can't give any information on my father (see above). My mother always used to use curlers in her hair (at one time heated ones) – either overnight or in the morning – and put on some make up (foundation, powder, lipstick and I'm not sure what else) before leaving for work or socialising. She still (at 95) uses a bit of make up but is now using curling tongs or something for her hair. Not that she's going out much at the moment, with the Covid restrictions getting stricter by the minute! My own 'routine' I wouldn't say I have – or ever had – much of a 'routine' when getting ready to go out to work or socialising. I've been retired for some years now but there's no difference between how I prepare to go out now and how I used to prepare when I was younger. I used to use a bit of make up for some social events (dating, going to a party) but never very much and never when going to work. The most I really do is to brush my hair – I can't go out with my hair looking a mess!

Living Arrangement Free Text: Living with retired parents in a care situation.

Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing'. Mass-Observer F5186 describes themself as male; age 41; single; mature student.;The Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing' was issued on 27 November 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their opinions on and experiences of health and wellbeing, in particular 'health, wellbeing and the healthy body'; 'identity'; 'growing up and learning about health and wellbeing'; 'growing older'; 'health, wellbeing and appearance'; 'getting ready to leave the house'.
Contents: F5186, MALE, 41, SINGLE, THIRSK, MATURE STUDENT Everyday health and wellbeing Healthy body first five words… . Slim . A glow . Functional . Mindful . Exercise Think of a person who is healthy – I suppose that would be Joe Wicks. My God, that man is irritating. There are a lot of men who like to post gym selfies on social media showing their “gains”. I don’t see them as healthy. If your need for validation is great enough to need to post gym selfies, your mental health requires attention. The picture of health has been made toxic by neoliberalist ideals. Competition is not the answer – public health collaboration is. Identity In public health terms, health and wellbeing is massively influenced by your socioeconomic means and the populations you belong to, depending on your intersectionality. In my case, I live in a rural middle-class area and I’m keen on the gym. I have easy access to healthcare, and I think this counts for a lot. I am keenly aware of health as that is my professional background. I’m more aware of my health now I’m in my 40s – I’ve started to creak a little and make “the Dad noise” when I get out of chairs. I’m also no longer flexible enough to bite my own toenails. This is both a good and bad thing. However, when I was growing up, men in their 40s looked a lot older than they do now. This is in part down to better living conditions for those who can afford it, and better nutrition (for those who don’t need food banks). With the collapse of population growth in the UK, the widening gap between rich and poor, the increase in food and fuel poverty and the approach of Brexit (God help us), I suspect the standard of living has peaked and will soon decline. Thank you very much, Tory voters. Mental health and physical health are closely entwined, but I know there is still a lot of prejudice out there about poor mental health. I have worked in pubs and have heard myself the phrase, “they should just man up” used for people with depression and the like. I myself have a mental health disorder – obsessive compulsive disorder. It has only relatively recently been diagnosed, but an off shoot of it when younger was an eating disorder, which severely damaged both physical and mental health. Now, post therapy which taught me to manage OCD, I am the most mentally healthy I’ve ever been. If it wasn’t for lockdown closing all the gyms, I’d still be the most physically healthy I’ve ever been too. I fully intend to age as healthily as I can. Growing up… Mum was the main person keeping us healthy growing up. She got us used to eating vegetables from a very young age and I can’t remember ever disliking them. It was always focused more on diet and playing outside than targeted exercise and neither me nor my sibling have ever been overweight (before lockdown for me). There were sweets around growing up, but I can’t remember ever desperately wanting them. They were a treat to be had occasionally. Key Moments… As stated above, I had an eating disorder in my teen years. However, this was to do with undiagnosed OCD at a time when mental health wasn’t as understood as it is now. I was greatly aware of the pressure to look good and of the other teenagers in class who were developing much faster than I was. The only men in the media were buff and muscled and I thought everyone had to look like that. At the time (before a very quick growth spurt), I was small and weedy with puppy fat. I learned what grown ups looked like naked through the VHS tapes of porn that were handed pupil to pupil round the school (showing my age there!). That alerted me to where pubic hair grew and that there were different body shapes. I worry for the young now because I think that “body ideal” has taken over and they can access anything online. That body ideal was just coming in when I was a teenager and I mentally latched onto that instead. It was around the time Marky Mark did his training video and footballers started doing naked shoots. Actually, it was seeing a topless photo of Ryan Giggs in The Sunday Times that made me realise I was gay. Shaving wasanordeal.I used to slice my face apartoncheaprazors.I can’t remember anyone ever showing me how to do it. I think I locked myself away and experimented until I got it right. Nowadays, I have a big bushy beard. Much easier. There was some information about puberty around in the early 1990s, but not a great deal. It certainly wasn’t as sophisticated, and as evidence based as it is now. Remember, there was no internet, either. Before my growth spurt, I was small and weedy compared with my peers. During my growth spurt, I had excruciating growing pains in my knees and legs. My knees are still bad. Afterwards, I was self-consciously tall and gangly and awkward. You just had to figure it all out for yourself amid a climate of piss-taking, peer pressure and misinformation. My abiding memory of this is the stench of Lynx Africa deodorant. It was the brand boys wore and that was that. The gay ideal… Being gay brings all kinds of pressures. There is very much the body beautiful ideal at work, coupled with a very ageist notion that you’re on the scrapheap once you’re past 30 years old. It’s rubbish, of course, but for a long time, I believed it. The gay press and social media is full of mostly white young men with big pectorals and six pack stomachs. They are not real people. People who look like this are often very boring to talk to and are lazy in bed. Going to a gym is not a personality. It’s the same with the unrealistic notion of penis size. Porn tells gay men that they need a big penis, and if theirs isn’t the size of a small tree, they are somehow deficient. Again,it’s utter balderdash. It promotes an unhealthy arena of hyper-masculinity. Quite often, those people who believe it is everything areveryboring indeed becausethey’ve never had to try to be interesting and to cultivate a personality. The effect this so-called ideal on the gay psyche is devastating. The average joe is made to feel inadequate and somehow lacking, hence a high prevalence of eating disorders, depression and anxiety. It creates a hierarchy of masculinity and feminisation in a deeply misogynistic order. It is also very ageist, rendering anyone over 30 or so invisible. Give me an older man who can make me laugh and hold a good conversation any day of the week. That’s much healthier in my opinion. Growing Older As stated above, I am very aware of healthy ageing. In fact, I study that very subject at a high level. Personally, lockdowns permitting, I go to the gym regularly and do plenty of cardiovascular work, play memory games, and keep my brain very active. My careeris leading me more towards a sedentary life, so I’mtrying to counterbalance this with exercise. During lockdowns, I’ve taken to walking through the fields instead. Anything to keep going. Despite the sciatica and arthritis in my toes, and my bad knees and propensity to put weight on more easily, I’mactually thefittest mentally andphysically I everhave been. Speaking as someone who used to smoke like a chimney and drink like a fish through his twenties, I’m not so much in bad shape. Indeed, I know people my age who are a lot worse than I am. I am also well aware of the health benefits of socialising. For years, I was lonely. It is hard for older single gay men to meet anyone. Ironically, the pandemic has improved my social life because everyone has been forced to socialise differently via Zoom calls. Now I have the best regular social life I’ve had since my twenties. More to the point, I now have a best friend and we talk every single day. I am no longer lonely. I do worry about a time when my family are no longer around – when my parents have gone and the rest of them are still abroad. I just hope my family of choice (Weston, 1997) will still be there because I’m going to need them. I think my parent’s generation had very different ideas about health, namely not too many cigars and not drinking too much before driving. I have a vague memory of a man saying no to his eighth pint before driving in a television drama… and he got home OK. Nowadays, that would be a set-up for an accident. Their ideal of health (in the 70s and 80s) what a lot less precise than it was now. Certainly, jogging and gyms were a niche thing. I remember my Mum had a Jane Fonda yoga LP that was never played. Getting ready to leave the house… My Dad always used to wear a suit and my Mum and Aunties always used to wear tonnes of make up in the 1980s when going out. The most casual men ever got was wearing a sports jumper over their shirt. Women had handbags, men had wallets. If it was a very fancy do, the women would wear fur coats. When I leave the house, it’s very different. I have OCD and before therapy, I would load everything into a rucksack, unpack it, check it, pack it again, unpack… repeat ad nauseum. I always looked like I was going on a hike. I love my ratty old rucksack. I suppose things are more casual now. Now I’ve had therapy, I forget all sorts. I like wearing my grey trackie bottoms in the house because they’re comfy, but I never wear them outside because I don’t want to look like a total chav. Instead, I wear jeans, t shirt and hoodie. Smart casual. At a push, I’ll wear a shirt if I have to. Since the advent of the Coronavirus, of course, one is never without a mask. Being me, I have several stuffed into pockets along with hand sanitiser and tissues. I always have my wallet, mobile phone, keys, and mask. Almost always loose change too just in case and a water bottle. You’d think I’m trekking across the Andes, but I’m really only going to Tesco.

Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing'. Mass-Observer W1677 describes themself as female; age 84; retired administrator; married.;The Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing' was issued on 27 November 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their opinions on and experiences of health and wellbeing, in particular 'health, wellbeing and the healthy body'; 'identity'; 'growing up and learning about health and wellbeing'; 'growing older'; 'health, wellbeing and appearance'; 'getting ready to leave the house'.
Contents: Everyday Health and Well-being MOW1677 female aged 84 Retired Administrator Married Harrogate As I have had a fairly healthy life, health and well-being has been something I have not given much thought to. I obviously try to eat sensibly and have done a small amount of exercise over the years. Since my 40’s I have attended an assortment of keep fit classes. Aerobics, dancing to movement, ballet, tap dancing, I have tried yoga but didn’t enjoy it and have not been to a Pilates class. I must admit I haven’t been to a class for the last 10 years. I have never been obsessed with these classes and have never joined a gym. I went to these classes mainly as a social activity, with the side line that it may be doing me good. My parents were not concerned with health. One just got on with living and if one got measles ( which I think was the only childhood illness I had ) then you just stayed at home until one got better. I remember my sister having a bad case of whooping cough, but certainly although unpleasant, not a big deal. Wellbeing was certainly a word never mentioned in my childhood and one that I would rarely say even now. It is a word that I would find difficult to define. I find the idea that someone had the responsibility for looking after my health and well being quite farcical. My parents were responsible for bringing me up and making sure I was well fed and cared for . Thats what parents did . There was never a thermometer in the house, and I also have never had a thermometer in my house. I don’t remember any particular conversations about health. When I was a teenager and had started my periods, my mother took me to the cinema to see a film about having a baby. I suppose there was some discussion about it. I went to a girls only school and I believe we had some biology lesson about reproduction, but periods and when one had “started” was discussed between my friends. I was aware fairly early in my teens that I had bigger breasts than most of my contemporaries, which made me feel a bit self conscious. They have stayed bigger than most and I would prefer them to have been slightly W1677 smaller. Obviously my experience of health during my life has been influenced by my gender. I am a woman so I have had periods,pregnancy, children, then the menopause. All these activities has had side effects on ones body, and health, and although at times inconvenient and unpleasant, it has obviously made you aware of your body from time to time. Am I more aware of my body now. Yes I am getting old and am permanently told by society, that I am an old, vulnerable person. I do not have the stamina that I used to. Fortunately I am still healthy. Sleep well, well actually too much,. Enjoy food and still have a healthy appetite. Have the odd niggle but nothing to get concerned about. Unfortunately one is almost expecting something to happen because of my age.I rarely visit the doctor. I don’t take vitamin tablets, don’t follow a strict regime of activity or anything. Covid has made me less active which is a bind, but it hasn’t Affected me mentally. I find I am able to relax and as they say these days “chill out” mind you I am lucky that I have a husband who is also healthy, so can chivvy each other at times. What beauty product would I take to a desert island, a pair of tweezers because facial hair seems to be more of a problem now I get older, and a lipstick. I could live without this but would be nice. When my parents when out of the house they were always dressed well. Collar and tie for my father, often a real rose or flower in his lapel. My mother would always wear high heeled shoes, matching handbag, probably a hat. My routine is not that different. Until the past 10 years I would also have worn heels, now they are flatter as I am beginning to worry about slipping on wet leaves or shiny tiled shopping malls, I always wear make up, and try to look smartish. I think my parents casual approach to health or lack of worrying about it has had a large effect on me. Hopefully that approach which I also carried out with my children has had the same effect on them. I think it has, as health and doctors are not subjects that feature largely in their life. Mind you we have been lucky and have all been fairly healthy.

Keywords: COVID-19 pandemic (2020-);Lifestyle, health and well-being;Family life;Schools;Adolescence;Emotional states;Family members;Partners (personal);Food;Personal appearance;Personal hygiene;
Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing'. Mass-Observer P3209 describes themself as male; age 81; married; artist.;The Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing' was issued on 27 November 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their opinions on and experiences of health and wellbeing, in particular 'health, wellbeing and the healthy body'; 'identity'; 'growing up and learning about health and wellbeing'; 'growing older'; 'health, wellbeing and appearance'; 'getting ready to leave the house'.
Contents: P3209 MALE MARRIED WELTON, EAST YORKSHIRE ARTIST EVERYDAY HEALTH AND WELLBEING “A healthy body” -The first 5 words that come to mind are: AWARENESS/FITNESS/ENERGY/PAINLESS/ DIET. The healthy body that I have in mind is the athlete who trains and controls his/her body to the maximum degree. This is unattainable for the average person yet is an example of what can be achieved by willpower. GROWING UP AND LEARNING ABOUT HEALTH AND WELLBEING As a child I was brought up by my grandparents (born 1889 and 1893) – in particular by my grandmother who knew little or nothing about the structure and workings of the human body. I was first made aware of “health/wellbeing” when I was quite young. Towards the end of the war children like me were given added vitamins. A local “food office” attended by the WVS distributed orange juice and cod liver oil to parents to add to their children’s diet and I remember being told why this was necessary and why I also had to take additional “iron” medicine due to my having anaemia; it was horrible stuff! At my village school just after the war we were given an exciting project which, for a time became a craze. It was explained to us that there was a national shortage of vitamin C and this was to be found in rose-hip syrup. We were asked to collect rose-hips and bring them into school. To encourage this we received “promotions” depending on the weight of rose-hips collected. A small quantity would merit a “Private” badge; the bigger the bagful the higher the promotion, rising from “Corporal” and “Sergeant” to “Lieutenant” and up to “General”.  All other playground games paused as we searched the district for rose-hips and promotion. Eventually the school had to stop the scheme as the place was overwhelmed with sacks full of rose-hips. Also at our village school we did P.T. (physical training) twice a week in the playground (or in school if the weather was bad). We also had BBC Schools programmes which sometimes explained the importance of good health. We had regular visits from the “nit-nurse” who lined us up and examined our hands and heads. It was shaming for those whom she picked out of the line to stand apart for they were now “nitties”. At grammar school we had regular PT every week as well as games sessions. Our PT master explained the importance of keeping fit. Each term we were checked for weight and height and this was recorded on our reports. A dentist came to the school once a year. That was the only time I visited a dentist – which meant that up to the age of 11 I had never seen a dentist at all. KEY MOMENTS I recall vividly the time when I was 13 and became aware of changes in my body. I was utterly terrified and added to this I was acutely self-conscious due to being overweight. I had always played with girls as well as boys but now I found that I liked one or two girls in a different way which I found hard to explain to myself; I experienced “crushes” for numerous girls. Being a fat boy I kept such feelings to myself, fearing ridicule and humiliation yet my body was doing things I could not control. Hair was growing where it had never been and I had uncontrollable genital urges for which I was ashamed and scared. I was getting a hairy face and sometimes was leg pulled about using a razor – which I dreaded. I had never had the facts of life explained to me other than in the playground which made the whole thing even more frightening. I had no one to advise me or calm my worries. My grandmother was a kind and loving person to whom I went for assurance and advice in most things but I felt unable to ask her help with my current problem. I was aware of her dislike of anything to do with relations between the sexes. Even on-screen kissing in the cinema made her squirm. I wonder today just how she ever became a mother herself. The idea of applying to my grandfather for his advice was out of the question. I felt that a major breakthrough came when I was 17. I had lost a lot of weight and was fitter and more self confident. I was popular with my friends and I had my first girl friend. The first time I kissed her was a breakthrough which somehow freed me from past anxieties. It was a very short-lived relationship but a turning point for me. Having sex outside marriage was unthinkable at that time but I do remember an overwhelming urge to do so. GROWING OLDER From an early age I knew that health and wellbeing were important. Between the ages 9-16 I had been overweight and was well aware of it. I had played active sport and by 17 the weight dropped and I felt much better for that. I played cricket in the summer but nothing in the winter until I began playing rugby. I didn’t like the game much but as I was no good at my favourite sport football I chose rugby just to keep fit. Since those days I’ve always had fitness in mind without going about it like others – going to gyms, jogging etc. Now I’m in my 80’s I feel fitter than I have done for years – the Coronavirus lockdown has helped in that I (and my wife) have walked more than at any time in years. We have always enjoyed walks but now see the need to exercise more and more as we get older. The turning point in my health awareness was when I saw my doctor on a minor matter when I was 23. After I was married I began to put on weight again. At that time I was over 17 stone. The doctor put me on a diet which I stuck to for months and the weight fell off me. I lost about 4 stones in 3 months and never regained it as my life-style changed. I became constantly aware of my health,diet and weight and felt much better. Diet is very important to me. I’ve never liked junk food and don’t eat red meat because I just don’t like it rather than for vegetarian reasons. We eat a lot of fruit and vegetables and many meals are meat free because we like it that way. I cut down on my alcohol intake over a year ago. I don’t know what my alcohol units were but I decided that they needed reducing to weekend drinking only. Out went the daily gin and tonic.  I smoked from around 16 years until I stopped at 25 and never did so again. I keep aware of health matters in the press and on radio. There are many fads and theories which need careful sifting but generally I look for health reports and advice where there are words like “will” and “do” rather than “might” and “probably”. I don’t have many more years to go so health and wellbeing are essentials for me and my wife. We make sure we exercise regularly and take care in things we do – avoid risks like climbing ladders or doing strenuous things that we once found easy. We know all too well that although we are very fit now, life can change in an instant due to an unexpected accident. Without being ultra cautious we are aware of dangers but enjoy life none the less. It’s best not to contemplate the future too much but try not to become another problem for family and the NHS. HEALTH, WELLBEING AND APPEARANCE I’ve never been influenced by ideals of beauty or appearance and I’m certain that my grandparents’ never were either. Both my grandmother and mother followed fashion trends as most women always did but they didn’t necessarily follow slavishly what some icon wore – at the time it was the Duchess of Kent and the models in Vogue magazine. For men things were very different and I seem to have followed on from that. So I don’t have “grooming” items in my bathroom cupboard, just a toothbrush, deodorant and a razor. I always assumed that only horses and dogs were “groomed”. The idea of scent for men is laughable. If a man smells bad, bathe more and use a deodorant. Men seem to be going back to the days of the cavaliers and macaronis. I suppose it’s meant to signify that he’s on heat. If I was on my Desert Island I would need my toothbrush. GETTING READY TO LEAVE THE HOUSE I don’t ever remember seeing my grandparents going out together. When they did go out there was little ceremony about it. Grandfather just put on his hat and coat and went. Grandmother took a little more time about it. She was clothes conscious and had a couple of local dressmakers to whom she went for up-to-date styles. I remember the fuss she made with my aunt when something called the “New Look” happened in about 1947. Hats were important too, some of which looked like cakes. She also wore a fur thing draped across her shoulders which looked like a dead skunk. This thing fascinated me as it was some unknown fox-like animal with the head still on with a clip under its chin. I saw similar things worn by her friends which today would be greeted with horror, but that was around 1949 and very much “in” for ladies of a certain age. I’m now retired and do not attend any large social events other than occasional friends’ gatherings which are for the most part informal. I last wore a dinner jacket over 20 years ago and remember how much I loathed being a stuffed penguin for an evening.  When I was a magistrate I was expected to dress in a suitable way – a jacket and tie, which was perfectly acceptable. Since I retired from the bench I have hardly worn a tie since. A jacket, comfortable trousers, a shirt and a sweater will do. November 2020
