Keywords: COVID-19 Pandemic (2020-);COVID-19--restrictions--lockdown;Emotional states;COVID-19--UK government and policy;News and current affairs;COVID-19--key workers;Employment and occupations;Partners (personal);Communication;Shopping and retail;Food;Leisure time and social activities;Personal hygiene;Mental health;Personal appearance;Sleep;
Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'COVID-19 (Update)'. Mass-Observer C5716 describes themself as female; age 43; married; finance director (chartered accountant).;The Directive 'COVID-19 (Update)' was issued on 27 April 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their experiences of the COVID-19 pandemic, in particular 'health'; 'the government'; 'news'; 'work and home life'; 'technology'; 'shopping and food'; 'entertainment and leisure'; 'personal hygiene' and 'sleep'.
Contents: C5716, Female, 43, Married, Castleford, Finance Director (Chartered Accountant) Spring 2020 Directive - Part 2 Covid19 (Update) Health During the pandemic my husband and I have been very lucky. We have managed to stay fit and healthy (both physically and mentally) throughout the entire lockdown period. Emotionally we have been as usual, really. We have had occasional frustrations which have sparked small flares of tempers and bouts of grumbling but other than that we are getting on with our new lives and are remaining happy as we do so. I realise that this probably puts us in a very small minority, and we realise how lucky we are that we can carry on without any mental or physical impact. The Government I think that given that we are living in unprecedented times the Government is doing the best they can with the information that they are given - which is an ever changing outlook! Obviously they have made mistakes and can be guilty of not being as clear as they could be, but sometimes I think that the media and certainly the public can be just as obtuse when interpreting what has been said, meaning that much confusion reigns when it isn’t absolutely necessary. One thing I would have liked the Government to report on daily is the recovery rate in the UK, as this would be a positive light in the current darkness. Every other country is managing to do this, so why can’t we? Having listened to Boris speak yesterday (10th May) and whilst waiting for the 50 page document which will (hopefully) clarify what is coming over the next few months, I believe that they will try to stick to the “roadmap” as best as they can allowing for changes in the 5 criteria. Hopefully, they will be watching what is happening in Europe as they come out of their own lockdowns a few weeks ahead of us, and will use their data to help move us forward. News To be frank, I am not listening to most of the news that is out there as unfortunately there are so many conflicting reports it is hard to know what to believe. I look up the points that are relevant to me and what I need to know at the time (the infection rate and death rate for instance) and what will help me keep my business moving forward. As I am a key worker I have continued to go to the office to work so I am travelling home when the 5pm briefing is on TV. So I cannot really comment on whether they are useful or not! Work and Home Life As previously mentioned, I am still working. My work pattern has not changed, however the size of my team in the office has diminished as we have a number of office staff who can work from home during this lockdown. I am a Director for a Medical Devices company (we manufacture and supply laryngectomy and tracheostomy tubes and accessories) and our products are in great demand from the NHS at the moment so we are working flat out to maintain a good supply to them. This is good for our company, it means that it will continue to be strong during the pandemic, allowing us to keep all of our staff fully employed with no threat of the company failing or job losses. Prior to the pandemic my husband and I spent most of our time together at home quite happily. We don’t frequent pubs, clubs, restaurants or other such places. So we are carrying on pretty much in the same vein as before, with the notable exceptions that we are missing our families and our rugby league! Again, I am fully aware that by not having children, by continuing to work and by not having had to make massive changes to our home lives we are very lucky and in a minority of people who are not finding many challenges during this time. Technology I have always been a techy person so using technology to keep in touch isn’t something new to me. But I have found that I have been teaching a lot of people how to access and use technology so that they can benefit during lockdown. This has been both at home and work. At work we have taken to having Zoom meetings instead of face to face and the Teams app has been invaluable in keeping teams talking to each other. We have also been doing more WhatsApp video chatting too. They are all very useful tools, but nothing replaces face to face conversation. At home WhatsApp and Facebook Messenger have been the most used apps for us. However, I did do a WhatsApp video call with my Mum to teach her how to download books on Kindle - that was a fun 30 minutes! :) Shopping and Food The main thing that we will take away from this lockdown is that we now love to shop at Aldi. Until this happened we rarely went in Aldi, but at the start of the lockdown they were the best stocked and most civilised place to shop in. We will not stop using them after all this is over. We have not gone without anything that we need as far as food and drink is concerned. We eat simply and have found that the things we buy on a weekly basis have been in good supply at all times. The biggest change to the shopping experience is having to queue outside the shop/supermarket so that they can have a minimal amount of customers in at any one time. I do not have an issue with this and wouldn’t mind if it carried on for some time. There is something to be said about being only one of 8 people in the supermarket and being able to get to the shelves to buy what you want without having to move a gaggle of chatting people out of the way first. Queue inside, queue outside - where’s the difference, it takes no longer and it is much safer this way. Okay, it might not be so much fun when the weather isn’t so nice, but even still… Entertainment and Leisure During lockdown we have continued to entertain ourselves the same way as we did prior. We spend our evenings chilling playing games on our tablets, reading, watching classic comedies on the TV and listening to music whilst just enjoying being in each other’s company. On a weekend, now that we have no other commitments we take long walks. We are lucky that we have some great nature walks close to us so it is easy to take a good 5-6 mile round walk without leaving our postcode. The only new entertainment is that we are trying to grow our own veg, this is a new project for us and so far so good. The carrots and lettuce look like they are ready to be planted outside any time soon! Personal Hygiene We have not changed any personal hygiene habits in the past 8 weeks or so. My husband has OCD and we have always observed good hand-washing routines and wiping supermarket foods down before putting them away, so the current government directives about hygiene change nothing for us. The only difference this lockdown has made to us is that I have had to cut my own hair (it’s pixie short and if allowed to grow will get thick and curly) - I’m actually getting quite good at it too. Sleep I have to be honest, because our routines have changed very little and because we are getting a good amount of exercise and fresh air out sleeping patterns have remained pretty much the same. We have suffered with neither insomnia or nightmares.

Keywords: COVID-19 pandemic (2020-);Lifestyle, health and well-being;Reproductive health;Physical health conditions;Society and social behaviour;Family life;Schools;Adolescence;Shopping and retail;Personal appearance;Family members;Personal hygiene;
Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing'. Mass-Observer K7595 describes themself as female; age 73; married; retired teacher.;The Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing' was issued on 27 November 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their opinions on and experiences of health and wellbeing, in particular 'health, wellbeing and the healthy body'; 'identity'; 'growing up and learning about health and wellbeing'; 'growing older'; 'health, wellbeing and appearance'; 'getting ready to leave the house'.
Contents: MO Number K7595 Female Aged 73 Married Shoreham by Sea Retired Teacher AUTUMN DIRECTIVE 2020 PART 2: Everyday Health and Wellbeing Health, wellbeing and the healthy body Health to me means having a body which allows me to enjoy doing what I want to do, without inhibiting maladies and extreme aches and pains. Wellbeing for me is a state of mind and body, which is the best it can be, and is a pervasive feeling that all is well with my inner world. A healthy body is one which in general lets you get on with living your life, without having to worry overmuch about how it’s coping, or whether you’re going to be in pain. Words which come to mind are: functioning organs and physical parts of the body; weight-control; medicine-free; being pain-free. No one person embodies this for me, though I suppose a person who walks, cycles or exercises regularly is the usual norm for many people. Identity My health and wellbeing have been greatly influenced by my gender in particular, because of several operations and other gynaecological health interventions, from the age of 20 onwards. I’m not sure if it was connected, but around the age of 60, I had uterine cancer. I’ve also experienced other difficulties like cataracts in both eyes, a severe back problem, now fine after a very tricky operation, a new hip and arthritis. However, I think these have all contributed to making me a more positive and optimistic person. Each ‘cure’ or improvement shows me how lucky I’ve been to have overcome these difficulties, particularly the cancer diagnosis. Twelve years ago, this felt like a death knell. Many people who’ve had this experience, feel that each new day is a blessing. I certainly do myself. So hopefully these experiences have also made me a stronger person. K7595 Growing up and learning about health and wellbeing My earliest memory about health, as a small child, is of being warned strongly, not to play anywhere near drains, in case I got polio. This was long before vaccination came on the general scene, When I was growing up in the fifties, it was common practice (for our social working -class group anyway) to put your child to play with other infected children, so I had measles, mumps and chicken pox, and anything else going-no vaccines then. This is the ‘herd immunity’ idea I believe. We didn’t question it. In fact, I actually quite relished being ill, to a certain extent, as I got my mother’s attention, I could spend the day in bed reading her childhood books and a neighbour gave me a lot of copies of ‘Sunny Stories’ booklets. My auntie even gave me a small model of the Queen’s Coronation coach to trundle along the bedclothes. It was 1953 and I was nearly 6 years old. However, in 1957-8 the country was gripped by Asian Flu, a pandemic, which impinged on my life personally, in that I was too ill to take the 11+ exam. Fortunately for me, there were so many children with Asian Flu up and down the country, the authorities had to hold a second wave of exams later in the year. I say fortunately-if fewer ten-year olds had succumbed to ‘flu, I might not have had the opportunity to pass my 11+ and my life would have taken a totally different direction. Secondary Modern schoolchildren were often sadly not given the opportunities we received at Grammar School. I’ve got no recollection of particularly learning about health at school. We took Biology as an academic subject, but health and wellbeing were not really taken into consideration then. We just had to get on with it! Key Moments My mother tried to tell me the Facts of Life when I was around 9 years old, but I didn’t believe her for a minute. She came into the bathroom while I was in the bath. I remember being interested in the new hair growing on my pubis. I was also in denial about the growth of my breasts and refused to consider the notion of wearing a bra, even though I knew some of my classmates revelled in the thought of approaching womanhood. Even on the day my first period started in August 1959, I told my mother it must have been a scratch-I remember being in a state of confusion. Wisely, she didn’t argue, just initiated me into a new world, by giving me massive sanitary towels, to be held up by a belt contraption that looked like a torture pulley. Growing Older I think I muddled through life health-wise until I was 24 when I had a serious emergency operation, which developed into septicaemia, now called sepsis – I was very ill and nearly K7595 died. So I really had to take stock. I also married shortly after, which meant I had two bodies to care for. Growing Older… This was when I began to appreciate the importance of what you put in, and on, your body. We became vegetarian, and I visited the Body Shop, run by Anita Roddick , a business newly opened in Brighton. Thus began my life-long ‘obsession’ of eating and using organic products where I could afford it. Brighton’s Infinity Foods was the only beacon of all things organic but I’m glad to say health and wellbeing have become more the norm, with all supermarkets providing healthy food at a competitive price. I think we must have been in the vanguard, in the 1970s, even though we were regarded as hippy and alternative. I’ve never abandoned those beliefs. Although now in my seventies, I’m very much still aware of my bodily and mental health. In fact, increasingly so, as it becomes more important with age. I try to eat healthily (but with added chocolate), I now never drink or smoke, (though I did in my youth), and I take supplements. Health, wellbeing and appearance It seems logical that appearance should be linked to health and wellbeing. A healthy weight for our frame, we’re told, is important, and so is a healthy skin wrapped round a skeleton, joints and organs which are in good working order through as much exercise as possible. This isn’t easy, with age-related challenges like arthritis, for example, or mental decline, but perhaps people have to take responsibility for themselves if they possibly can. Maybe do the exercise, give up excessive drinking and smoking and eat less! Perhaps our generations have it easier than my parents’, who lived through the privations of war. Money was tight for my mother when we were children, too, so she only wore a dab of face powder, and a slick of lipstick. Occasionally, even after all these years, I have to shake off the feeling that some of my beauty items are superfluous, and probably indulgent. (Her ‘treat’ wasn’t a new lipstick or tin of Nivea cream. When she could afford it, her choice was a quarter of sherbet lemons!) In my memory store, there was never time, money or inclination to care much about the connection of wellbeing with appearance. Desert Island Item? My go-to health supplement is B12 as I believe it helps my memory to function well, but maybe on a desert island, this would matter less! Therefore, my must-have beauty product would definitely be an unlimited supply of face and body moisturiser. Organic of course! Getting Ready to Leave the House K7595 Neither of my parents spent a huge amount of time getting ready to go out. They had to get us children sorted out, but in any case, they didn’t have much choice in what to wear. A wash and change after lunch WAS important for my mother, though, staying in or going out. This washed away the debris from morning’s housework tasks. To my amusement, I do the same very often, when I stay in. When I go out, I always wear makeup, mascara being the most important, then lipstick. Older faces often look wan, so maybe a hint of blusher may be added. The ritual of shower, dressing, hair and often makeup has never changed from when I got up at 6.00 for work, or for socialising, or now, retirement in the Covid 19 world. Looking as well as I can on the outside, helps me feel good on the inside.

Religion Free Text: I was brought up C of E, and to some extent still believe.
Relationship Status Free Text: I lost my husband of 33 years to cancer in November 2020

Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing'. Mass-Observer R4100 describes themself as female; age 56;  married; librarian.;The Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing' was issued on 27 November 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their opinions on and experiences of health and wellbeing, in particular 'health, wellbeing and the healthy body'; 'identity'; 'growing up and learning about health and wellbeing'; 'growing older'; 'health, wellbeing and appearance'; 'getting ready to leave the house'.
Contents: R4100 FEMALE AGE 56 MARRIED FROM LEEDS LIBRARIAN Part 2: Everyday Health and Wellbeing Health, wellbeing and the healthy body Health means not being ill too often and not seriously at least. Well­being I think is more about peace of mind and your mental health. A healthy body? Well-fed Toned Muscles Shiny Happy The kind of person who comes to mind is slim, toned, good skin and hair. Not necessarily that young, but certainly in good health for their age. Identity I don’t know that my experience of well being and health is influenced by anything except. My parents seemed reasonably healthy, but both smoked and never exercised. Both worked full time and we ate pretty well with not much fried food and hardly any processed food. I think there is more emphasis on good health now, especially mental health and well-being. I grew up in a family where we were “healthy” unless we were ill. We didn’t discuss symptoms or feelings. You were either poorly or well. There was no in between! I don’t think this was a gender specific way of looking at things, but perhaps it was class based? Before social security and sick pay, if you were ill, you didn’t earn. I broke my radius and ulna late morning on holiday aged 12 and knew enough to not make a fuss until it really wasn’t feeling any better. I was brought up to not make a fuss, so reluctantly I told my mum it still was hurting. This sounds barbaric now, but kids were seen and not heard to some extent and I was a well behaved kid! Growing up and learning about health and wellbeing I became aware of health and well-being when I was told (sort of) that my mum had suffered a breakdown of a sort in the late 1970s. She was supporting all 5 of us on a tiny wage as my dad had been made redundant. I don’t remember thinking anything dreadful about it at the time -that stoical childhood again -but now I’m horrified. My parents were responsible for looking after my health and wellbeing when I were younger, although schools were also involved. We had the “nit nurse” who checked our hair, feet and eyesight. A dentist in primary school and milk until the Tories took it away. I don’t remember anyone talking to me about health? As I say, you were either well or not, and most people seemed to be in good health. We also didn’t receive any health education at school (other than sex education) but that didn’t cover STDs etc. Key moments I was a late starter and didn’t start my periods until I was 14. My nana told me she had started menstruating at 11, so I felt like a freak and avoided all conversations about it. I was very flat chested too, so felt very girlish. I always say my boobs arrived the day after I left school!! I remember my husband telling me that he’d started to shave at a really young age. Probably 14 or so. Your first period or bra, is so important for girls. Or at least was when I was a girl. Shaving my legs and underarms came much later, but I remember buying roll on deodorant for myself etc. In later life, my Mum and I could discuss anything, but she didn’t talk to me about puberty at all when I was heading that way. I was so glad to become “a woman” and still didn’t discuss it with contemporaries, but felt ready to, if the moment arrived! Growing older I started smoking at 19. My husband didn’t smoke and although I smoked when we met, he hated it and I agreed to stop once I reached 40, which I did. Ironically, I didn’t feel that different as I think I must have an addictive personality as I stopped smoking and started eating! The money I saved also didn’t really make that much of a difference. Following the death of my husband, I decided to start looking at my lifestyle. I was chubby. I remember thinking I was fat when I was younger, but looking back at photos, I realse I was fine. Stopping smoking made me eat. My niece is a dietitian and has helped me loose a substantial amount of weight and that has made me feel better. Physically and mentally. As the only girl with two brothers, I grew up in a sporty family, and played out. That stopped once I left high school. My niece helps me and imparts information about health and wellbeing and I am certainly more aware of my body now? I know what to eat and what to do to maintain a healthy body. I hope that in future years, my health and wellbeing will improve if anything. Health, wellbeing and appearance I hated looking at photographs of myself, So I know that health and wellbeing are directly related to external appearance. I don’t mind looking at myself again in photos. I’m not as pretty as I once was, but I’m slimmer. I’m not influenced by fashion or popular ideals of beauty or physical appearance as it changes all the time. I hope that the attitudes to what women are meant to look like has changed. We are not models. We have flaws and we are real, not airbrushed dolls. My parents grew up when the idea of the kinds of ideals was a tan, coiffured hair and good smart clothes. I don’t think I could live without shampoo and conditioner. I hate having grubby hair, but Desert Island item would probably be either foundation or eye makeup. Getting ready to leave the house My mum always wore heels for work and smart dresses or skirts and blouses. My dad wore trousers and a shirt and tie. When they went out, they wore the same! Their dressed down gear, was older, tattier versions of the same. I don’t remember them taking ages to get ready to go out like I do now! When I go out now, I take less time than I used to. I used to think that I needed 2 hours, but now it’s half that. I’m probably quicker at applying makeup, but I also think I’m less bothered as I get older. Getting ready for work takes about the same as ever, but I’m less rushed in my approach, so it actually probably takes less time.

Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'COVID-19 (Update)'. Mass-Observer R4100 describes themself as female; age 56; married; librarian.;The Directive 'COVID-19 (Update)' was issued on 27 April 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their experiences of the COVID-19 pandemic, in particular 'health'; 'the government'; 'news'; 'work and home life'; 'technology'; 'shopping and food'; 'entertainment and leisure'; 'personal hygiene' and 'sleep'.
Contents: R4100 FEMALE AGE 56 MARRIED FROM LEEDS LIBRARIAN Spring Directive 2020 Part 2: Covid19 (Update) Health I have felt fine mentally and physically during lockdown and haven’t needed to seek any professional or medical health. I don’t go out a lot other than for work, and I can be quite antisocial in some ways. My husband has been furloughed since the end of March and has enjoyed his time off -especially as he disliked his job and was looking to reduce his hours anyway. I think if one or other of us were more sociable, it would have been difficult as we were very isolated with no family nearby. I am still working through lockdown from home with one trip a week into the library, and I find that keeps me focused and content. The Government I think the furlough scheme has been a godsend to many companies -including where I work. Of our staff all but 4 are furloughed. I think some of the instructions about what constitutes an essential journey, going out and mask wearing for example have been somewhat confusing and for those people without access to the internet or a television, must have found it difficult to know what to do for the best. The government must be concerned about the amount of money it is laying out for furlough and the consequences of companies going out of business and the unemployment levels rising. I think they will have to start trying to ease the lockdown rules and try and convince the public that it is safe to go back out if you follow the strict guidelines. News Throughout lockdown, I have listened to the news bulletins and ministerial briefings at 5pm as I find that easier than reading the information in a newspaper. The briefings are the most useful part in my opinion, as the media ask the questions that I want to know the answers to. Also, in most cases it is mainly used to transmit information and not as political rabble rousing or point scoring exercise. I think there should be BSL interpreters. It seems a no brainier especially when we need everyone to know what they need to do to keep safe and protect themselves from the epidemic. I have to say that Nicola Sturgeon’s briefings in Scotland are much better than the English ones. There’s no waffle. She is sympathetic but not condescending and answers questions well and without hesitation. I think the main facts should be given as bullet points and then elaborated on and then the bullet points reiterated at the end, because sometimes you get caught up in an issue and then miss the next point which may be relevant to you. Work and home life I have been working during lockdown, which I haven’t found onerous. A lot of my usual work cannot be done out of the library, but as the only member of my team who is working, Iockdown has meant that I have had overall responsibility for all the library services jobs and so have found it easy to keep busy. My employer is paying furloughed staff the 20% top up on their salaries which does seem to be causing resentment amongst the 4 of us who are continuing to work. I think it depends on how long we are in lockdown, but I would be happy to be furloughed, if my employer decided to swap the staff around. I have worked every day since the library closed on 21 March and would have liked a day or two off on holiday when the weather was nice. I know from speaking to my friends and family that a lot of firms are paying the 80% only, or furloughing staff for 3 weeks and then swapping around the teams. As a manager, I do have a sense of responsibility and a decent work ethic, but I do think “where’s the incentive?” when my colleagues are getting paid to sit at home. As I have mentioned before, my husband and I are self-sufficient and don’t socialise a great deal, so we have found lowdown easy. We are childless too, so we haven’t had to worry about home schooling. Early on in lockdown, we agreed we may start to get on each other’s nerves, so we have a code word which we can say to take the heat out of the situation. It does work as well because we picked a funny word -SAUSAGES -which takes away the seriousness, and thus the temper. The only issues I have had is my husband’s reluctance to do jobs around the home! When we both were working, we shared the housework and did jobs around the house and garden at the weekend and on an evening. Like all homes, there are a few DIY tasks that needed more time and effort, which I had hoped he would do now he was at home all day. Also, within a week or so of lockdown, he received a letter sent to all employees telling them that the company was struggling financially, and there may have to be redundancies. As my husband was looking to reduce his hours, he opted to take voluntary redundancy. I realised that he would probably have a few weeks of relaxing at home, and then start looking to do some of the outstanding jobs, but he didn’t! Weeks went by and he didn’t do anything! In addition, we used to share the housework, which suddenly with a few exceptions seemed to be all my responsibility. I never wanted to be a nagging wife, but I did make my feelings known -especially as I was working, albeit from home. After a few rows, we have reached a compromise, but I still feel I am doing the lion’s share. Technology Before lockdown, we did FaceTime on occasion with our family and I have used it at work occasionally. We joined an online quiz in March with my niece and her husband who live in southern England. Since then, we have been taking it in turns to produce a quiz on a Thursday night. It’s more of a social event -the quiz is the excuse, but it has been great fun! I feel closer to them than before. We have used FaceTime for that and occasionally Zoom if there is interference. My boss was keen that the staff stayed in touch via Zoom and WhatsApp. Unfortunately, one of my colleagues didn’t have an Android phone so couldn’t access WhatsApp and her internet was still on dial up, so she would freeze or disappear altogether mid conversation. To be honest, I found the work Zoom socials a bit awkward at times, as some on my colleagues just sat there and didn’t speak much or went to the other extreme and talked over everyone!! I think we have enjoyed seeing each other but find them a bit awkward or strained sometimes. I have used Facebook and Instagram about the same amount as usual but started a WhatsApp group with 3 others who used to be volunteers at the library. One of them is my best friend so it has been a way of keeping in touch with her as we haven’t been able to meet up. Shopping and food We have continued to visit the supermarket each week as we are lucky enough to have a car. We have been combining it with a weekly visit to check on the library and collect books to post out. We do have to queue to go in, but this is only for at the most, half an hour and the weather has been kind. We have noticed that most people are not wearing masks, and some are not obeying the direction of travel signage. Some items have limits on how many you can buy, and we have noticed empty shelves in some of the supermarkets with things like eggs, flour, pasta, rice unavailable. We haven’t shopped online for groceries, but my friends tell me that it is almost impossible to get a slot. We are eating well, as we have more time to prepare meals and we have both put weight on as we are much more sedentary. We are also drinking more alcohol. We used to have a drink 3-4 nights a week, but now it’s every night, although not to excess. Entertainment and Leisure At the beginning of lockdown, we decided to start going for walks. This lasted a few weeks, but gradually we have stopped (we use all sorts of excuses for not going out!). We watch lots of daytime television, which of course, we would never have done when we went out to work. Most of it is rubbish, but we sometimes have the BBC news channel on in the background. I have been knitting as I promised 2 young relatives a knitted sloth. Now I am making myself a wrap and have also promised to make a blanket for my niece. My husband has been making up some model planes, cars and suchlike. He had loads of kits and has three part done but doesn’t look to be finishing them any time soon. He has also done lots of reading and I have when the weather has been good enough at the weekend to sit out. As mentioned earlier, we have been taking part in Zoom quizzes. A Wednesday night one with my husband’s pub quiz companions and the other withfamily. Personal hygiene It would have been easy to slob about during lockdown, but we decided that we would shower every day and not fall in to too many bad habits! I would usually colour my hair as soon as my grey roots showed through, but I have only done it once since lockdown started. I will carry on as normal once I’m back at work I suppose. As I have long hair, I have been able to get away with not having it cut, but my husband looks like a yeti, as his hair was supposed to have been cut one week after lockdown! It has been nice not to have to put makeup on every day as I did when I worked outside. The one thing that we have embraced though, is wearing comfortable clothes around the house. I don’t like to sit about in pyjamas, but I’m more than happy to get my joggers on! Another change is that we are wearing clothes for a few days at a time, and not chucking them in the wash after one wear. Better for the environment and less housework too. Sleep I have been going to bed later than when I went out to work and had to be up at 5.45am. Now I get up between 7.30am and 8.30am if I’m working, and a bit later if I’m not. I usually sleep well and haven’t been troubled by nightmares or anxiety, but sometimes I wake up early and things I have to do for work go round in my head, and I can’t fall back asleep, but that’s not unusual for me.

Religion Free Text: I'm a bit odd here, the only way I can describe how I feel is this: I don't believe in religion, but I strongly believe in God. I pray and say thanks/count my blessings every day. I hate to pray in groups and I think all religions are leading to the one God, it depends on how you live your life. I don't enjoy communal prayer, it means nothing to me.

Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing'. Mass-Observer D1602 describes themself as male; age 78; single; retired executive.;The Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing' was issued on 27 November 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their opinions on and experiences of health and wellbeing, in particular 'health, wellbeing and the healthy body'; 'identity'; 'growing up and learning about health and wellbeing'; 'growing older'; 'health, wellbeing and appearance'; 'getting ready to leave the house'.
Contents: D1602 Male, 78, single, S W London,  retired executive D1602 Autumn 2020 Directive – part 2:  Everyday Health and Wellbeing There is hardly a day that goes by these days when I don’t think to myself how lucky I am to be 78 years old and still in good health.  I wonder how long it can last and do as much as I can, without having to try too hard, to keep on top of the game. Currently, in the midst of the Covid-19 pandemic that is still sweeping the country, I try to keep shopping trips down to one major supermarket visit a week and I wear plastic gloves throughout and of course a face mask.  This also applies to brief visits to other shops, always kept to a minimum and at times of the day when I think they will be less crowded.  I take daily exercise -this afternoon, for instance, I walked for 50 minutes and covered about two miles, always trying to keep my distance from other people to the extent of crossing the road where necessary tp avoid  confrontation. As far as diet is concerned, I eat a variety of foods starting with a good daily breakfast of cereals, extra bran and prunes to try to keep “regular”.  Lunch is usually a sandwich with cheese, meat or smoked salmon, plus lettuce and tomato , followed by a banana or other fruit.  Supper can be one of many choices, usually home cooked but occasionally a ready meal, followed by a fruity dessert.  I drink very little alcohol and have never smoked, despite having grown up in a tobacconist’s shop. When I was a young man, I realised I was gay and took advantage of being a good-looking chap living in the heart of London.  Yes, I took chances but managed to survive unscathed and was lucky enough to share my life with the same loving partner from 1968 until he died in 2012.  He was a nurse and taught me a lot about wellbeing in both body and mind, introducing me for instance to the Mediterranean diet (he was Spanish) and the importance of varied menus. My parents did their best to bring up my brother and I on a limited income.  We always had three meals a day (many of my classmates at junior school in a poor part of London were less fortunate) but this included a fried breakfast every day for years, desserts like suet pudding and other fattening items, and D1602 the throwing away of the water vegetables had been cooked in rather than reusing it or having it as cold drink as I often do these days. I don’t recall puberty being a problem apart from the small nocturnal emissions that started to occur when I was about 15.  In those days such things weren’t talked about (although my parents were broadminded and would have undoubtedly answered my questions if I had asked them).  My brother and I knew that we “came from Mummy’s tummy” but I don’t recall asking for more details and was genuinely shocked at the age of 12 to hear a loud-mouthed boy at school describing the gory details.  “I’m sure the Queen wouldn’t do a thing like that” I recall saying very primly and disapprovingly, despite the fact that this was in 1954 and she was already the mother of two children! Both my father, his brother and my mother’s brother were slim throughout their lives and I take after them in build, being about 5ft 9ins tall, weighing a little over 60kg (note the mixture of metric and non-metric measurements) and my trouser sizes are 36in waist and 29 leg,  I always worked in offices and when I was in my late 40s my waist grew to a matching 40, a fact which horrified me so much that I’ve made a determined effort ever since to keep an eye on everything.  Since my partner died, I’ve become a member of two walking groups and although we can’t walk in groups temporarily, I still walk daily (weather permitting) as mentioned above. For mental exercise, which I think is of great importance, I regularly do cryptic and quick crosswords (and even devised some professionally at one stage in my life), Sudoku and similar puzzles, and latterly online jigsaws To my surprise, I have become coy in recent years about telling people my age as I don’t want them to realise how old I am in case they think I’m “getting past it”. When talking recently to a lady friend about vaccinations and when we were likely to get them, she gently probed to find out if I was 70 yet.  When I told her my true age, I was gratified to see that her jaw fell open in amazement.  On the other hand, when a woman in the supermarket queue a few weeks ago asked me whether I had had my vaccination yet, I said I wasn’t old enough ( at that stage they were doing the over-80s) and she seemed surprised . . . so you win some, you lose some! When it comes to appearance, I have mixed ideals.  On the one hand, I like to be reasonably colour co-ordinated in what I wear, on the other and since I started growing a beard during the first lockdown, I usually shave only once in D1602 about every six to seven days.  I feel strongly that men of my age shouldn’t wear jeans or earrings.  Comfort is of importance  and since the first lockdown and the combination of my age, a small bladder and the lack of public toilets, have started to wear what used to be called incontinence pants, although nowhere on the packs that I buy does this unattractive phrase appear. You can buy them now in a fashionable blue colour and they are very snug fit. What a pleasure it is to walk along the street or talking to someone while peeing, without them having any idea of what is happening beneath the surface,  Now this is something that really does contribute to good and happy health and wellbeing! January 21st 2021

Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing'. Mass-Observer R1025 describes themself as '77 year old housewife, formerly book-keeper, living ... with husband, retired engineer'.;The Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing' was issued on 27 November 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their opinions on and experiences of health and wellbeing, in particular 'health, wellbeing and the healthy body'; 'identity'; 'growing up and learning about health and wellbeing'; 'growing older'; 'health, wellbeing and appearance'; 'getting ready to leave the house'.
Contents: R.1025 77 year old housewife, formerly book-keeper, living in Milton Keynes, with husband, retired engineer. AUTUMN 2020 PART TWO EVERYDAY HEALTH AND WELLBEING Health, wellbeing and the healthy body I suppose to me the word health suggests free of disease, free of pain. I guess you could still have a sense of wellbeing if you did have pain or disease, it would depend how well you dealt with it. Some people will feel fantastically well with conditions that others would be devastated by. I think it’s more a mental state of mind. A healthybody is surely one that is free of disease. Fit, energetic. Can’t thinkof any more. No particular person comes to mind. Identity I can’t say that my own experience of health and wellbeing has been influenced in any way by my gender, ethnicity, social class or sexual orientation, I can’t really see what any of those things have to do with it. Growing up and learning about health and wellbeing I have no idea when I would have first become aware of health or wellbeing, they are just terms that you know, absorbed from the ether. My mother would have been responsible for my health when I was young. I don’t ever remember anyone talking about my health. I was often ill as a young child but I didn’t need anyone to talk about it, I knew I was. My parents lived before the NHS and medical care was expensive. Therefore they didn’t seek it out. When people were ill they used home-made remedies and common sense and basically just got on with life. My mother suffered frequent black-outs as a child. She would be sent home from school after one of these incidents only to be sent straight back by her mother. Any spare money that could be used for medical emergencies was reserved to treat one of her brothers who had epilepsy. She would have learned not to complain about being ill. I don’t remember any education at school about health. Back then (in the 50s) people weren’t so self absorbed as they are now and there were far more important things to think about. Do people ever really learn about health in the way you suggest, don’t most of us just muddle through life and take whatever is thrown at us? Key moments I was a late developer and so I think I was about 13 when I started to become aware, when communal showers started to be an embarrassing problem, and there was much discussion of bras and “monthlies” in the 1 R.1025 changing room. There are no rituals I can think of, not in my life anyway. The first period always seemed like a momentous occasion. I lived in dread of it happening for a year or so and got quite paranoid about it. I hated it from day one and was never more glad of anything when 36 years later it stopped. Growing older In my adult life I’ve always been reasonably healthy. I’ve never been sporty but I always cycled and walked. I was brought up that way as my parents were always very active in that way.I’ve never been a drinker, smoked a few cigarettes in my teens but quickly stopped again, I’ve certainly never done drugs of any sort, scarcely take painkillers unless strictly necessary. I keep a watch on my weight, weighing myself each week and keeping a chart so that I can quickly react if I see my weight climbing. As far as mental health is concerned I think a lot of that is down to character, I just don’t have the sort of mind that dwells on things to the extent of causing me to be ill, I’m very much an optimist. I don’t think I’ve changed over the years. I would say that overall I’m pretty healthy, but if I were to list all the things wrong with me – from osteoporosis to IBS it would sound as if it was a miracle that I still considered myself healthy. As I use several health supplements these days, for my joints and my digestion, I receive a monthly magazine from the company that I use. I do glean odd bits of information from that, but I never actively seek out information on health issues. As my body has deteriorated over time I would say that I am more aware of it now. It doesn’t move in the way I still want it to move, I’m much slower at doing things than I want to be and it’s frustrating. I’m also aware of the way that, although my weight hasn’t changed much, the shape of my body has changed and is definitely less appealing. I hope my approach to health doesn’t change, but I could foresee a time when I just didn’t care anymore, if I should live that long. Health, wellbeing and appearance We talk of people being a picture of health don’t we? People who are healthy do tend to look well, and happy usually. I really don’t think I have been influenced by popular ideals of beauty and physical appearance. I never read the type of magazines that promote that type of shallow awareness. Of course my parents would not have been influenced in any way. Life was about surviving, not trivialities like beauty and fame. They weren’t exposed to the media in those days as people are now. I guess the cinema gave them a little glimpse into the lives of glamorous people but they had no desire, nor means to be like that themselves, they would have known that was impossible. I would be very unhappy if I had to live without moisturiser, so I guess that would be my desert island item. Hand cream too is a must. Getting ready to leave the house I don’t recall either of my parents having any rituals to get ready for work (but you are testing my memory, that’s a very long time ago). They certainly never went out in the evening so that doesn’t apply. My own routine when going out is very minimal, slap a little bit of make up on, brush my hair and that’s it –done. I don’t suppose I’ve changed in at least 50 years, but I don’t think I did any more than that when I was young and at work. 2

Mass-Observer H1705 describes themself as widowed; female; age 69; [living in] Jersey; amateur artist.;The Directive 'COVID-19 (Update)' was issued on 27 April 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their experiences of the COVID-19 pandemic, in particular 'health'; 'the government'; 'news'; 'work and home life'; 'technology'; 'shopping and food'; 'entertainment and leisure'; 'personal hygiene' and 'sleep'.
Contents: Part 2: Covid 19 (Update)HealthFortunately I  haven't (as far as I know) caught the virus. Apart from problems with my back my health has been the same as it usually is. I'm used to having a  massage once a  month so my back and shoulders ache.  Within a few days of our lockdown I bent over to picksomething up and my lower back seized up momentarily.  It was painful and stiff for a fewdays but I walked everyday which helped. Also I emailed my pilates teacher who suggested an exercise to help it That was rather an alarming time. Later one of my teeth felt as if it was loose and throbbed slightly. Again luckily it stopped after a couple of days. I have beengoing fora walk most days and also being doing pilates exercises. The classes have been available online. Emotionally I was most depressed about not seeing my partner who lives in England. Luckily the borders have now opened and he is able to get over. However the prospect of another spike in the autumn and winter is worrying. Initially, because I didn't realise how serious it could get, I		was annoyed that all my activities were cancelled. Especially as the over 65s were labelled as vulnerable so encouraged to isolate much earlier than the rest of the population. I'm quite an introvert so I can cope with my own company, especially as I live on my own and have learnt to deal with feelings of loneliness. I think I	was able to cope ok because the weather was good and I was able to watch the spring unfold on my daily walks. I quite liked the feeling of not having to get up and do things and I received more phone calls than I do normally. Luckily we never had a high amount of cases over here so I	wasn't that worried about myself or friends catching it which I am grateful for. I	did find after not going anywhere fora	few weeks that I was more nervous about driving and doing things I		haven't done for a	long time. The first time I went out in the car seemed very strange. The roads were much quieter and I almost felt as if I was doing something illegal as the lockdown was still on. It has been very unreal living through a situation that has never happened before. Mypartner was very frustrated at not being able to travel anywhere. I enjoyed not having sport on the media and no Jehovah's Witnesses calling.NewsI	read the Telegraph for my news. I watched the first emergency broadcast which was one evening but haven't really bothered with the daytime ones as it doesn't apply to us so much. Here on the Island we went into lockdown a couple of weeks before England so we have always been ahead. After being a bit slow starting up the leader of our local government and our health minister were having weekly media questionnaire broadcasts but these have stopped being so regular. I found that after a while I didn't really want too much news as it was just depressing and alarming and made me worry about things beyond my control. Chatting to a friend at the height of it all I remarked that we had never experienced hearing about such huge numbers of deaths. The largest I could remember was the 9/11 disasterwhich was 3,000 but thinking about the covid figures is so overwhelming you can't really take it in.TechnologyI only have a Nokia phone so was unable to use platforms available to Smartphones. I had Skype fixed up to communicate with my cousin in Canada but there were a lot of problems with it and I  found it very stressful so have given up on it. I'm not on any social mediaplatforms. While I probably missed out on things I suspect it also spared me a lot of the scare stories.Shopping and foodI have a  corner shop nearby so did a lot of my shopping there. Otherwise I  went to a farm shop which was also fairly close. Between the two of them I managed to get most of what I needed without too much queuing. I had stocked up fairly well beforehand. Also I  lost a  bitof weight not going to M & S for a couple of months and mainly cooking my own meals. I put off going to the main supermarkets for as long as possible.Entertainment and LeisureI	didn't take up any new hobbies or anything like that. Initially I rather idled about because my back was bad and got into the habit of watching Escape to the Country and did crosswords. I looked at websites especially one of a webcam of puffins in Alderney. After a while I	pulled myself together and did a bit more cleaning and tidying up of my house and cleared out few things and gardened. I typed up some wartime letters which my grandmother sent to my mother which was interesting. Looking back it seems like I didn't really achieve anything much and I've hardly done any painting however the days seemed to go byespecially if I went for a long walk and there was housework to do. One day I spent about 3 hours on the phone.Personal hygiene and sleepI		don't remember my sleep being affected much and if anything I had more baths as it was something to start the day off with.

Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing'. Mass-Observer W633 describes themself as female; age 78; retired journalist; married; 'one daughter, 44, not living at home'.;The Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing' was issued on 27 November 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their opinions on and experiences of health and wellbeing, in particular 'health, wellbeing and the healthy body'; 'identity'; 'growing up and learning about health and wellbeing'; 'growing older'; 'health, wellbeing and appearance'; 'getting ready to leave the house'.
Contents: W633 Female, 78. Retired journalist. Married Living in Darlington. One daughter 44, not living at home Autumn directive part 2 Everyday Health and Wellbeing Health to me means having no ongoing or chronic conditions, feeling able to eat well, being physically fit and able to undertake any activity necessary or enjoyable. Five words: weight, mobility, diet, attitude, knowledge. The person who comes to mind is a schoolfriend who trained as a PE teacher and emigrated to Australia. She now lives, alone since her husband died, in a fairly remote part of Queensland. She is a keen folk dancer, plays pickleball (whatever that is, it sounds energetic), is a volunteer firefighter, and a great traveller, preferably by the most obscure route or method of travel she can find. She is about 5ft 6ins, no spare flesh and still with the same, short boyish haircut she had at school. Identity I suppose my health has been influence by my sex, in that I had gynaecological treatment at one time. Then there’sheredity –skin problems and migraine. I don’tthink any of such illnesses as I have had are influenced by ethnicity or social class. I do have problems with anxiety but have never taken them to the GP, just learned to live and cope with them and I think they are the result of upbringing. Growing up and learning about health and wellbeing Health was always around, in the sense that my mother enjoyed ill health and from any age at all I was aware that she regarded her health as fragile. Wellbeing wasn’t a word I was really aware of, I don’t think it was a word in common currency in the 1940s and 1950s. You were either ill or well. The older of my two younger brothers was a neo-natal death and the younger was never well so he was always to the forefront of any care that went on. He spent his first five years trying to die of various things like croup, pneumonia and pleurisy then aged about 11, his acute appendicitis was not diagnosed until the organ was almost gangrenous. I had the usual childhood infections and was looked after in bed by my mother with meals and calamine lotion. I do remember going to secondary school feeling very under the weather because I didn’t feel it would be acceptable to ask to stay at home. There was no talk about health or staying healthy. At junior school, the girls has a talk by a very embarrassed deputy head about “growing up”, with instructions to tell our mothers that this had taken place. I did, and wished I hadn’t as it unleashed a stream of her own worst experiences. At the girls’ grammar I attended, those of us in the A stream, where the timetable did not include biology as that was for the B stream (!), had a year of something called “hygiene” which did include general health advice but was mainly to ensure we understood human reproduction. At this distance, 60-odd years, I can remember nothing about what we were told, only the chain-smoking PE teacher who took the class. Key moments Bodily changes – when the girls in the final year of junior school all took a terrific interest in who was developing a bust. Inspections were conducted in the class storeroom -2­W633 I suppose the first period is a significant moment for girls. I was staying with my grandmother but, in a kindly moment, my mother had packed me some protection “in case”. I couldn’t talk to Granny or ask questions, home was nearly 200 miles away so I just coped. Growing older I’ve been lucky inthat I don’tput onweight, though I lose it easily in times of stress. I do, however, try to eat a healthy diet and,, oncewe became aware that heart attackswere a heredity problemin my husband’sfamily, our diet was framed by that. We eat a lot of fruit and vegetables and tend to have much less red meat than we did in our 30os and 40s. We walk to destinations in town, rather than take the bus or car, unless there was a time factor or heavy shopping involved and we have always been keen folk dancers, though that has been somewhat curtailed by Covid-19 this year. My husband isn’t a worrier, I am, but we are both practising Anglicans and church and the church “family” has a beneficial effect, again hit by Covid this year. I read and listen to the radio rather than watch television so I tend to get health information and advice from newspapers and magazine or programmes like You and Yours. I’ve always beenconscious of having thighs likejodhpurs in spite of a BMI of 21.5-22 and I still look at them and wonder why no amount of specific exercise to reduce them has ever had the tiniest effect. As I get older, given that I am now 78, I expect to carry on with the régime that has got me thus far, hoping that I stay physically and, more important, mentally OK. Health, wellbeing and appearance. People who feel well probably walk head up and looking cheerful. The popular ideals of appearance as they appear in glossy magazines, on TV and the like are models, or templates, of what we should aim at, men and women. Some people achieve “the look” of the moment. Most people pick what they like, adapt other aspects and just make the best of ourselves. I would hear my mother comment on fashions but was never aware of her being influenced by ideals. My father, after an illness when he could not shave for some time, found that, in spite of his black hair, his beard grew white. Years later he said, “I should have kept that beard,2 feeling that the distinctive appearance might have gained more attention in his career. On a desert island, given thatI couldn’thave the medication for myskin, I’d have to have the largest possible bottle of a rich body lotion. Getting ready to leave the home I don’t think my parents had rituals, more a routine. My father always wore a suit, shirt and tie for work and for going out. My mother never went out to work, going to the shops was just a matter of tidiness and a bit of lipstick. When it came to social events, she always found some excuse for backing out, usually health, so I never saw her getting dolled up. After she died, my father asked if I would accompany him to his formal engagements and I realised how much her presence would have meant to him. For that reason, I always tried to look my best because I felt my appearance reflected on him. I never leave the house without basic makeup – moisturiser, some sort of foundation or solid base, eyeshadow, liner and lipstick, a matter of habit partly because I had to look my best every day at work and partly because I take after my father’s sisters. end.

Mass-Observer M6787 describes themself as female; age 60; living with partner; 'not working now, but previously worked in shops, offices, garden centres, with horses'.;The Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing' was issued on 27 November 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their opinions on and experiences of health and wellbeing, in particular 'health, wellbeing and the healthy body'; 'identity'; 'growing up and learning about health and wellbeing'; 'growing older'; 'health, wellbeing and appearance'; 'getting ready to leave the house'.
Contents: M6787Female Age 60Living with partner WimborneNot working now, but previously worked in shops, offices, gardencentres, with horsesAutumn Directive 2020Part 2: Everyday Health and WellbeingHealth means having no significant illnesses or ailments. Wellbeing means being healthy and fit, and not being stressed or worried.'A healthy body' - pain-free, supple, active, motivated, self-aware.Identity.I suppose as a female you are more aware of your appearance and looking after your health and wellbeing.Growing upo and leaerning about health and wellbeing.My nmother was a nurse and I grew up living in 'old people's homes' so things to do with health, or lack of it, were a part of daily life. She was the main person looking after me, I don't remember my father being influential in my upbringing in any wasy.I can't remember any health education in school at all, but it is nearly 60 years ago now. The internet wasn't around then so information and advise on heatlh and wellbeing was gleaned from magazines and friends or relatives.Key moments.As a nurse, my mother told me about periods etc. I started mine at the age of 12 and we were all prepared - I can remember that day vividly, nothing really prepares you for it.My first bra was a red and blue check cotton bra from 'M&S' I always remember it.Growing older.When you're yuoung you have a parent or someone to look after your health, making sure you visit the dentist or doctor when needed, keeping you clean, eating the right foods etc. In adulthood all the responsibility is on you and it's often easy to neglect areas of your health and wellbeing.Over the years I have had issues with my mental and physical health, which I have dealt with nby myself, particuaarly mental health, and medical concerns I have had investigations for and eventually minor surgery, but have not kept up to date with monitoring and screening afterwards, due to reluctance and fear on my part.At 60 I think I am totally familiar with my body and can recognise any changes in how I look and feel. In the future I think I will still be as aware of my health and wellbeing, but will probably still be a bit blase about it.M6787Female Age 60Living with partner WimborneNot working now, but previously worked in shops, offices, garden centres, with horsesAutumn Directive 2020Part 2: Everyday Health and Wellbeing Health, wellbeing and appearanceIf your health and wellbeing are not as they should be it can show in your expression or the way you walk - slower and with not enthusiasm, if you're in some sort of pain or feeling stressed or worried.When you're feeling good in yourself you move more engrgetically and look up and ahead, with more purpose.I have never been influenced by popular ideals of beauty or physical appearance, and I don't think my parents were.My 'Desert Island' itwm would be talcum powder - 'Johnson's Baby' powder - as I use this daily and love its soft, delicate smell, but I could live without it 'Getting ready to leave the houseGrowing up, my parents always worked where we lived so there was no 'going out to work.'They rerely went out, only to work-related 'dos' when they'd dress up in a nice shirt and tie, or a sparkly dress.I no longer work, but when I go out to socialise I'll have a shower and put on something other that my usual scruffin about at home clothes.Comb hair, clean teeth, mouthwash, no make-up of any sort - I use to when I was younger, but not for years now, I prefer the 'natural look8 for myself.

Mass-Observer M6787 describes themself as female; living with partner; 'not working now, but previously worked in shops, offices, garden centres, with horses'.;The Directive 'COVID-19 (Update)' was issued on 27 April 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their experiences of the COVID-19 pandemic, in particular 'health'; 'the government'; 'news'; 'work and home life'; 'technology'; 'shopping and food'; 'entertainment and leisure'; 'personal hygiene' and 'sleep'.
Contents: M6787FemaleLiving with partner WimborneNot working now but previously worked in shops, offices, garden centres, with horsesSpring D rective 2020Part 2: Covidl9 (Update) HealthMy partner and I have had no physical health issues during lockdown, apart from me having a couple of bouts of sore throat, swollen glands and feeling tired, but I'm used to these and they don't last more than a day or two.I have a history of depression and anxiety, so at first I did find the whole situation of the virus and lockdown a challengeat times, but luckily it didn't overwhelm me and it hardly affect me at all, I've got used to it.The GovernmentI think the Government have been slow in making sure that there were adequate supplies of PPE equipment for the NHS and other sectors in the caring professions, but I think this is being resolved now.As I write this some restrictions are being slowly loosened, now we are allowed to take as much exercise as we like each day and can drive more or less anywhere within England. Next week on the 1st of JUne, outdoor markets and car showrooms will be alllowed to open and from the 15th of June all shops will be allowed to open. There is some debate whether schools, or atleast primary schools will open on the 1st of June, but a lot of parents and teachers are against this as it will be difficult to maintain safe distances between young children. There have been a few cases of hypocrisy among Government officials where they have flouted the very rules they have imposed on the general publicby travelling great distances themselves to see family when it was deemed unsafe to do so.NewsWe buy a daily newspaper but don't watch the television for news, we're not ignorant or complacent but don't need to saturate ourselves with it. We also see updates on our mobile phones­ national and local news. I think there should definitely be a sig sign language interpreter at the briefings and am surprised that there is only now a petition under way at this late stage.Work and home lifeMy partner and I are both retired but being restricted in our movements and things being closed or suspended for a while we are confined to home more that we normally would be. We moved just before lockdown, me to a place I've known all my life si I've returned to 'old' friends and family, which is a comfort even though we can't yet meet up as we used to.02.Q)M6787FemaleLiving with partner WimborneNot working now, but previously worked in shops, offices, garden centres, with horses.Spring Directive 2020 Part 2: Covidl9 (Update)TechnologyI keep in touch with family and friends by phone, email, text or on Facebook - in the first few weeks of lockdown I felt a need to ring up people I haven't spoken to in years, we usually keep in touch by email but you can't beat talking to each other on the phone, it feels more personal and spontaneous. Facebook I only us use for groups I belong to, a local one of my town past and present, and a couple of Nature and wildlife photography groups, they take you away from the real world as it is now.Shopping and FoodIn 'normal' times we would usually do a 'big shop' once a weeek or fortnight, going to either of the cheaper supermarkets. At the very beginning of the lockdown we went in one of the designated early morning slots for the vulnerable but found this to be a horrendous experience as, although there was 2 metre distancing outside the store, they were not limiting the number of people being let in so it was all crowded and people not keeping their distance at all.So since then we have just used local shops and supermarkets which are within easy walking distance of home. I think our eating/cooking habits are more or less the same, surprisingly we haven't been eating more unhealthy foods such as chocolate or crisps, but in moderation as usual.Entertainment and LeisureWe haven't taken up any new hobbies but probably increased the amount of time we spend on our current ones, whcih are drawing aa and painting in my partners' case, and writing and photographyin mine.My exercxise has definitely increased as I was bought a bicycle for my birthday and am out on it at least once a day. Walking to town is also a new activity which we do most days.I spent my 60th birthday in lockdown so it wasn't quite how I'd planned it to be, when I would've got together with friends and maybe had a picnic at a local park. My partner and I did drive ou out to a nearby village and walked and took photos. I will probab-ly have a belated 69th celebration with friends when it's possible.I took out 6 books from the library just before they had to closeand I've read 5 of them, ranging from Terry Wogan's writings Helen Lederer's novel, 2 murder mysteries and a true story inspired novel about a woman in America who refuses to move when a shopping mall is being built all round her.M6787FemaleLiving with partner WimborneNot working now, but previously worked in shops, offices, garden centres, with horsesSpring Directive 2020 Part 2: Covidl9 (Update)CONTD: Entertainment and LeisureAs usual I've been listening to Radio 4 Extra, which is a mixture of drama and classic and new comedy. I thought I would use the opportunity of lockdown to watch or re-watch DVD's that I have - comedies and countryside ones - but this hasn't happened - yet.Television has been the usual things I'd watch,- 'Sewing Bee', 'Great British Menu8 ', 'Grayson Perry's Art Club', 'QI’ but as usual I can take it or leave it, I'd rather be outside if it's fine enough.Personal HygieneWHere we live now, having moved here in early March, we have a much better shower, so it is a pleasure to use it. Like most people my hair is growing like mad and well past its usual cutting date - it was last cut in December, so I'm  longing to get it done. I bought some big hair clips so I can make a short pony tail or clip it back at the sides. The warm weather doesn't help !SleepI never sleep much at the best of times, so at the beginning of lockdown I found it very hard to get to sleep and if I did would keep waking up. This has luckily diminished, maybe helped by the increase in exercise I'm having. If I can't sleep I'll put my earphones in and listen to the radio until I drop off. Or I'll ge get up and make a milky drink and read until I'm tired.

Religion Free Text: Originally I was brought up as a Methodist but now we have a beautiful cathedral here, I feel I belong there now Church of England.

Contents: F.218PROFILEI am a 74 year old Mum to two sons 48 yrs. and 49 years respectively.We live in a small market town in Suffolk. My eldest son has just begun to work as a civil servant as a regulating body for safety of lorries, buses, horse boxes etc. and a whiz on computers. He lives with his partner of 24. years.My youngest son is married with stepdaughters and their own son who is 23 years.of age. He is an electrician. And is a granddad to 6 boys.I have retired 12 years from an elderly persons residential home	I am the secretary for the Womens' Section of the Royal British Legion (I do fmd it a bit stuffy) but do enjoy meals and outings with them, so it has to a certain extent broadened my horizon. What I have found in this organisation that there is a lot of bickering and back stabbing - which I find atrocious in that the main aim is to raise enough money to give to HQ for their much needed funds for the soldiers and families of those stricken by the wars in Afghanistan. Syria etc.I have written ever since my children were very small and have had a few articles published. As I get older, I want to record social history more.I still live in a 3-bedroomed house and manage to keep it decorated and would quite happily spend all day in the garden. Have acquired a bichon/poo dog from the dogs trust now nearly 5yrs old who although a challenge in the beginning has opened up the countryside to me and is loved by all.My sons help me out ifl go out for a long day, in letting him out when necessary. He's cream and tan cute, frisky, very destructive but everything is kept high and out of reach.,JF.218EVERYDAY HEALTH AND WELLBEING.I have felt disturbed with things going on during this pandemic.Unfortunately there are failings around Govt. decisions. Latterly with the vaccinations for all by Spring is slowed down by supplies low in numbers and the delivery to the services that do injections not happening as they should. I remember the elation felt when vaccines had been tested but now we are tired and still mourning losses that have hit so many.Not enough hospital beds yet 3 new Nightingale hospitals yet to be filled. The truth is that there are not enough staff with nurses and doctors going sick and in many cases dying whilst serving the public. It is totally out of control.My sleep pattern in general is less and spasmodic. I am eating twice as much as normal which I know is comfort-eating. I feel the stress within the family. Yes, we value each other more. 'We will get through this together Mum' meant something in the beginning but wears thin because the light at the end of the tunnel is fading.I do not enjoy shopping - its just basics and you feel everyone is staring at you for mask, hand disinfecting - not getting too near, make sure you are on the line and being shouted at...F.218I enjoyed my own hours in the garden - I could still swim inbetween lockdowns. I could go on a bus most days to explore.Buses are still running - empty - very high disease in market town Ipswich, Suffolk. Cars are being stopped and fined where rules are being breached.Library books - friends and family are helping me out but they are few and far between.I am allowed to walk the dog twice a day - good for us both - but we have floods and mud everywhere. And I am besieged with workman next door who don't clear up after themselves! I know this is all petty but major irritations along with cutbacks, very stressful.Physically I am ok. Mentally under stress. I am not the most calm person in ordinary times.When I was a young child because I was under the umbrella of Social Services there was a channel of safety but in effect, I never spoke to them - they came and went.Wellbeing etc. at primary and secondary was general health about changes in bodies at certain stages. We did exercise with games and outdoor swims- freezing and unenjoyable because staff had many layers of clothes and we froze.. ,....F.218I have always exercised during every part of my life - necessity and enjoyment. I do everything in moderation. I am mid-70's now, an observerFreedom has gone in every sense of the word. 1st lockdown happened in our glorious hot summer in 2020. No hardship then.Having makeup and hair dye are things I cannot do without. I have a friend who unofficially cuts my hair even during lockdown. With these wretched face masks, I now use heavier eye makeup - have to take spectacles off a lot with them steaming up with winter weather. I find that I only need them for distance and reading prices in shops etc.The only change in leaving the house is that I must not forget masks, keys, dogs paraphernalia and right money cards etc. I no longer use a handbag as I did visiting other shops, outings etc.

Disability Free Text: In January 2020 I was on a cruise in the Canaries when my toe caught on the leg of a chair causing me to tumble. I fractured the back of my right femer and had a replacement in Madeira. When I came back here they found a bone cyst on my left hip so I had a total replacement. in October 2020. A routine pre-op revealed irregular heart rhythms so now I am on Beta blockers which increases any travel insurance.
Living Arrangement Free Text: As a student I lived in a hostel and married after my finals. I never learned to drive. Living in London till I came here I did not need a car. When I came here my husband dropped me off at stations etc or we travelled together - so now I am an expert on public transport and good taxis. WE also have a voluntary Help Centre where drivers charge 44p per mile and wait for you if you have a hospital appointment. They will even take older people shopping.
Relationship Status Free Text: I am happy being alone because I think I would always be comparing another relationship with any (happy) marriage. I am 6 years widowed and I think one becomes more selfish living alone because of the freedom it gives.
