Mustgetagrip Sleep This is the worst. I have never beena goodsleeper andhad therapy for it but my in­somnia is now worse than it has ever been.I’mlucky if I get 3 hoursa night. I getup, makea herb teaand go to the spare room. Noting works. I have some old sleeping pills but they don’twork either. SoI often have to havea nap in the afternoon. Conclusion WhenI read over this, it looks like one long moan. ButI am very mindful thatI am fortunate.I’mnot poor or ill and I’ve gota big garden. There are peoplea lotworse off than me. A lot. I try to help by doing 2older  people’s shopping and by givinga lot of money to homeless charities. And by phoning people I know are lonely. I hada bet with one of my friends thatBoris would die in the ICU. I wish he had.I stood to wina big box of chocolates if he did. Joking apart, he is an unmitigated disaster for the country. And heis the reason why i don’t sleep. Well, that, and the fear of dying.

Keywords: COVID-19 pandemic (2020-);Lifestyle, health and well-being;Personal appearance;Society and social behaviour;Physical health conditions;Family members;Family life;Adolescence;Schools;Bereavement;Partners (personal);
Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing'. Mass-Observer B7418 describes themself as male; age 64; married; retired lecturer.;The Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing' was issued on 27 November 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their opinions on and experiences of health and wellbeing, in particular 'health, wellbeing and the healthy body'; 'identity'; 'growing up and learning about health and wellbeing'; 'growing older'; 'health, wellbeing and appearance'; 'getting ready to leave the house'.
Contents: M-O Number B7418 Male, 64, married, Wallasey, retired lecturer Autumn Directive 2020 Part 2: Everyday health and Wellbeing Health, wellbeing and the healthy body I find 'health' and 'wellbeing' hard words to define, despite their frequent use. Health I see as “an absence of illness” (my five words), and secondarily as the capacity to resist ailments and ensure reasonable functioning. A healthy body is, in my imagination, one that does not suffer from disease or excessive infirmity. I may be unusual in not placing any aesthetic views of a 'healthy body' or pejorative views of an 'unhealthy body'. I feel that there is a great deal of judgement around this use of the word, invoking prejudice rather than sympathy or empathy. On the other hand, 'health' in the National Health Service is about the curing or amelioration of disorders, and gets public support because it is free and does not (usually) make judgements about patients. 'Health' is also sold by various organisations as a commodity, with associations of superiority that I find offensive; this is less about health than about cosmetic 'health' and 'beauty'. 'Mental health' is rarely sold as a commodity, and poor mental health carries considerable stigma. The term 'well-being' also bears an ambiguous air to me. I studied the concept of 'well-being' decades ago, but this was then used as a means of assessing the extent to which particular social orders provided and enabled satisfactory lives for their members. For some time, I have been involved with the Canal & River Trust; this regards 'well-being' provided by being 'by water' as central. I feel that this is somewhere between propaganda and a means of seeking public support for those benefits brought by the presence of canals and navigable rivers that cannot generate direct revenue. (I support the general idea of this, but am critical of the term). The third meaning focuses on individuals and their physical bodies, and their mental capacities to deal with the world's challenges. This is close to a wider definition of individual 'health', and I am torn between finding this a helpful term and seeing it as ideological. Identity I am not sure how and whether my perspectives as a white middle class heterosexual male differ from those of different backgrounds. I suppose for some, health (perceived, positive or problematic) is seen to be reflected in personal appearance. I do gain clues about people from their appearance, but try neither to judge people's appearance or apparent health, and am not concerned to provide signals to others. I am aware, from the media (mainstream and social) and everyday talk, of the deep prejudices that seem to attach to appearance and perceived health, with a great deal of negative judgement. I am appalled, frankly, by the prevalence of 'diets', the associations of 'fitness' with superiority, the 'beauty' industry, and much of the mumbo-jumbo of new-age approaches to health (often lucrative ones). It is not that I am not sympathetic when people have general health problems, and feel that they should have significant and non-judgemental support, but the promotion of 'fat-shaming' and the like, with the psychological consequences of feeling personally and socially inadequate, is greatly offensive. Growing up and learning about health and wellbeing I suppose my first experiences of the idea of health would be when I suffered a number of childhood diseases like chicken pox and measles. I also suffered from childhood asthma and digestive problems, but did not feel that this was about 'health', perhaps because these did not involve visit to the family GP, but various concoctions. My mother and the family GP were responsible for health when I was growing up. I don't recall too many conversations with either parent, although there was concern about the dangers from falling over and other accidents. My mother was in poor health in my childhood, with the invocation of vague threats hanging over her, but the details and consequences were never explained. B7418 I don't recall much health education from primary or secondary schools. I recall getting a polio vaccination and a bcg at secondary school, but with no real discussion. I did not study biology, while the physical education teachers were brutal violent men who enjoyed mocking boys whose bodies and activities did not conform to their ideals. There was no discussion of health and minimal warnings about the avoidance of accidents. I don't recall many conversations about my own health in childhood, but I was influenced by my grandfather's leukaemia (he survived 15 years) and spondylitis, which made him infirm. But I did not find out what this meant -this was felt to lie with doctors. Key moments I recall no discussions about puberty, although I was aware that my older sisters' forms were changing in early adolescence. I mainly recall that facial hair was starting to appear, and a degrading 'joke' by a teacher ridiculing the signs of puberty that this provided. I was aware of my voice breaking but, frankly, didn't incorporate this into any sense of personal progress. I should stress that in early adolescence I was resigned to the idea of simply enduring, avoiding trouble and surviving until I could escape from school. Growing older I come from long-lived ancestors (one lived to 101), and from an early stage expected both myself and my family to live well into our 80s. Whether this is realistic -my father died at 64 -is another matter, but it did frame my concerns about the future. I had no general pattern of looking after my health until I was 30 (q.v.). I have been concerned less about longevity than about pain and discomfort, having inherited a mild version of a digestive disorder. I was a casual smoker until I was 28, gave up all alcohol at 30, became a vegetarian at 48, and gave up sugar in beverages at the same age. The latter was largely influenced by dental health -my generation (and those older) had good reason to be afraid of dentists, and I wanted to minimise the need for treatment. I have been conscious of the need for greater roughage and the minimisation of processed foods. The event that did change my outlook was the sudden death of my father, through a heart attack, at the age of 64. My father was an ultra-heavy smoker, and when I raced down to ask my then GP whether I too would only live to 64, he pointed out that if I did not smoke at all, I could expect to live a lot longer than my father. (His mother, also a lifelong heavy smoker, survived him and lived to 91). I would trace concerns for my health from that time, but I would experience this mostly in terms of diet than some sort of fitness concern or regime. I was greatly affected when my first wife died of cancer, but it did not feel that this was something that could happen to me; I had somewhat underestimated the danger to her health presented by a long-term condition. I have become much more conscious of mortality since that time – and more worried. I do check online life expectancy calculators, which suggest that I will still be around in my 80s or beyond. My main concern is for my second wife's health, and the need for me to be able to look after her should she become ill or infirm. I anticipate taking greater care over what I eat, in the future. With regard to mental health and wellbeing, I already find the prospects of old age, further bereavements, growing infirmity and unrealised ambitions and fulfilment as quite daunting, and I suspect that I will find these worsening as I and others age. I'm not sure if these concerns can be placed under categories of mental health and wellbeing, nor that there are any cures or amelioration. I will find out! Health, wellbeing and appearance I think I have covered many of my views on appearance above. B7418 I think that far too much emphasis is placed on appearance, and often external appearances can mislead. I do not feel that I have been influenced by popular ideas about personal physical appearance, although I have to confess that one signifier, that I am a decided non-conformist who is no longer in employment, is that I have a long grey pony tail. I suppose this also seeks to tell myself (and others) that I am not too old to rebel against public assumptions as to how a man in his 60s should look! I'm not sure if my parents were influenced by popular ideas or figures, but more by their class, and the way in which they presented themselves to their friends. My father was very self-conscious about their reactions ­he was particularly worried about whether he had shaved sufficiently. My mother had that odd practice of 'putting your face on' (q.v.). They were horrified by the reactions that their friends and families might have to any adverse appearance that I might present. My parents both came from middle-class backgrounds, and shared many of the inhibitions and insecurities about appearance that many middle-class people had into the 1960s. I think that one product I would need is moisturiser, but this is for dry skin and psoriasis (thus prescribed for medical purposes). Daktacort would be particularly useful! Getting ready to leave the house My father did go through a ritual before leaving the house to go to work. He would get up early, in dressing gown, make toast and tea, smoke, and then go into the bathroom and cough violently for several minutes. My mother would get up late -she was a housewife and didn't go out to work. No coughing from her, but she put on elaborate make-up, a great deal of face powder, and lipstick. My own routines vary, but in the morning I generally wash and get dressed, after sitting in the kitchen eating breakfast (which I make). I sometimes lay out clothes the night before. I always do dress in outside clothes; I do not sit around in pyjamas or dressing gown. I would not describe any of this as a ritual. What has changed since the time that I was employed is that I wear more casual clothes; before retirement I would always wear a jacket and tie for work. It is also the case that my late first wife was very particular about clothes and would often expect my appearance to conform to her ideals -rather fruitlessly, sadly! My second wife is not concerned about appearance -there is noone to impress -and we both dress accordingly. The only exception now would be if I was doing some sort of external lecture -I would 'dress up' for this, often with jacket and tie. This may seem odd, but I feel the need to differentiate myself from the audience.

Keywords: COVID-19 pandemic (2020-);Lifestyle, health and well-being;Society and social behaviour;Schools;Gender inequality;Emotional states;Health services and medical care;Reproductive health;Family life;Personal hygiene;Adolescence;Family members;Physical health conditions;Employment and occupations;Personal appearance;Leisure time and social activities;
Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing'. Mass-Observer W7422 describes themself as female; age 45; cohabiting with children; academic librarian.;The Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing' was issued on 27 November 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their opinions on and experiences of health and wellbeing, in particular 'health, wellbeing and the healthy body'; 'identity'; 'growing up and learning about health and wellbeing'; 'growing older'; 'health, wellbeing and appearance'; 'getting ready to leave the house'.
Contents: Part 2: Everyday Health and Wellbeing The challenges of COVID-19 mean that in recent months, there has been a lot of reflection on health and wellbeing in unprecedented circumstances. But what about health and wellbeing in everyday life? We learn about health in many different ways, and it can mean different things to different people depending on their circumstances. In this Directive, we want to find out what health and wellbeing means to you (and what it meant before COVID-19) but particularly where your ideas about health and wellbeing came from, and what has influenced your own experiences of health and wellbeing in everyday life. Health, wellbeing and the healthy body What does “health” mean to you? What does “wellbeing” mean to you? How do you define these words? What do you think about when you imagine “a healthy body”? Please share the first five words that come to your mind when you think of this term. Is there a particular person or image that comes to mind? Please describe, or draw, this person. Health to me means the quality of your physical and mental state – whether you’re suffering from any illnesses and how fit you are. Wellbeing to me means looking after your mental and physical states in order to ward off poor health, for example by taking exercise, eating tasty, nutritious food or spending time doing tasks you enjoy. That it’s often cloaked as “taking time for yourself”, to me implies that there’s something selfish about doing something for you and nobody else and therefore, it’s to be frowned upon. It’s only in recent years, that I’ve actively sought to do things that I want to do rather than things to help or please others. A healthy body: fit, glowing, happy, toned, energetic. Weirdly when thinking of the “healthy body”, I only ever imagine a woman in her early 20s, long brown hair, size 12-14, T-shirt and shorts, glowing tanned skin, running. Identity How do you think that your own experience of health and wellbeing has been influenced by your gender, ethnicity, social class, or sexual orientation? Do you think your experience of health has been influenced by these or other aspects of your identity at all? My own experience of health and wellbeing has certainly been influenced by my gender, for example, the embarrassment and self-consciousness I felt doing PE at school, in a tiny pair of sports knickers whilst going through puberty, and with boys making leery comments, put me off of participating in sport for many, many years. Indeed, as an adult the first time I tried running to improve my fitness, I’d only been out of the house 20 seconds when two teenage boys started pointing and laughing at me. I just turned around and went back into the house and didn’t run outside again for well over a decade. I don’t for one second imagine they’d have behaved like that towards a man. For the same reason, it took me a while to find a gym I didn’t feel leered at in. Maybe it’s because I am now middle-aged and off the sexual radar of most men, but it’s been great to exercise without feeling objectified or ridiculed at my current gym! I’m also, as a woman, reluctant to go out in the dark alone for fear of being attacked, so I don’t have much time during the day, around work to fit outdoor exercise in, so it’s awkward during the current pandemic, with the gyms closed. Another major problem is related to sex (as opposed to gender). Many medical studies focus almost exclusively upon men, with the assumption that women’s bodies, cells, muscles, hormones etc. react in the same way as men’s – but they don’t. There are so many examples of drugs which don’t medicate women as well as men, for example, which begs the question, how many treatments have been dismissed because they don’t work on men, but haven’t even been tried on women? The most well known sign of a heart attack – pain in the left arm – isn’t actually that common in women, and women are often denied treatment because typically female signs of a heart attack aren’t being recognised. I am on blood thinners and statins following a TIA 2 ½ years ago, and I do worry that they’re not benefitting me as much as a man in the same situation. An image went viral a couple of years ago of the milk ducts in a woman’s breast. It went viral because nobody had seen it before – it’s so staggeringly rare to see this kind of image of a woman, and yet we all have this inside us, and most mothers will have produced milk in them! They’re hardly an obscure part of the body! If you see images of the biological structure of a human body, beyond the reproductive system, they’re almost always male. This is also the case in academic textbooks, so it’s no wonder doctors are often ignorant about women’s health when they’re not being taught about it! And again, related to sex, I’m currently peri-menopausal, as are many of my friends, but trying to uncover information and advice beyond mention of hot flushes is incredibly difficult! I’ve friends whose GP has just responded with “it’s normal, you just have to put up with it”, when they can’t function due to brain fog and exhaustion, providing no information let alone medication, about anything that may help. Even just trying to find more biological detail about what’s happening to my body, in a similar way as you get about puberty, is proving impossible – that information just seems non-existent. Growing up and learning about health and wellbeing When and where did you first become aware of “health” or of “wellbeing”? Who had responsibility for looking after your health and wellbeing when you were younger? Do you remember your parents, or other caregivers, talking to you about health? If so, what did they talk to you about? Where did these conversations take place? Did you receive any education about health in school? And/or did you learn about health and wellbeing in other ways – from friends, magazines, or the internet, for example? I don’t remember when I first became conscious of “health”, but “wellbeing” is a recent term, although the concept of taking time for yourself is old. Certainly, as a child my mum was very conscientious in ensuring I washed my hands after going to the toilet, I brushed my teeth, washed my face, bathed, and brushed my hair! She was very strict in not allowing us to wear other people’s hats for fear of nits. It paid off – I never had nits and at 45 I’ve still no fillings! I’ve no recollection of being educating about health and wellbeing at school, other than the nit nurse coming around, disinfectant trays at the swimming pool to help prevent verrucas and later learning about puberty. My mum told me about puberty in advance of the lessons at school – I’m presuming that was prompted by a letter home. Somehow, I was completely oblivious to anything at all to do with menstruation and sex, so it all came as quite a shock! I’d never noticed the sanitary products in the bathroom cabinet or supermarket, and jokes and reports on the TV or in the papers had gone straight over my head! Aside from the shock though, I mostly remember the horrible smell of a small book my mum had got from a sanitary towel company, which still exists in the sanitary product aisle of my local Tesco and still makes me gag! It wasn’t a great introduction to womanhood! I never had a sex education lesson. Mum gave me a book by Claire Rayner about various aspects of the human body, for example, following a raisin through the digestive system. The final chapter though was about reproduction, and frankly, it scared the life out of me! The illustrations really made me feel very uncomfortable, and made me very nervous of sex and the attentions of men going into puberty myself. Key moments As an adolescent, when did you first become aware of bodily changes associated with puberty? Are there any moments or rituals that you think are particularly important for young women or men? These might include, but are not limited to, first period, voice breaking, buying the first bra, or shaving, for example? How did you feel about these moments if/when they happened to you? After mum had told me about puberty, I started noticing my body was changing. I’d initially noticed what felt like 10ps under my nipples when I was about 8 or 9, with pubic hair following soon after. I remember feeling very self-conscious as time progress and my breasts grew larger, and I desperately didn’t want to grow up. Key moments were buying my first bra, which mum managed to make into a frankly, humiliating experience as she started measuring me in the middle of a busy M&S where everybody could see what was going on, and insisted I wore a really horrible white bra like an old woman would wear, and not the coloured, teenagers’ one I’d preferred. (I never wear white underwear now!) I certainly wasn’t the mother-daughter bonding experience some people have! My first period was less traumatic, although I was very disappointed by its arrival when I was 13. I irritatedly, left the bathroom said to mum, “Guess what?”, she gave me some sanitary towels and we didn’t discuss it again. A key personal moment though occurred shortly after I’d had my appendix removed when I was 16. Needing to pull my knickers up tightly to hold the sanitary towel in place, I asked mum to get me some tampons as my knickers were rubbing on the incision stitches and were very uncomfortable. In all honesty, it wasn’t as bad as I was making out, but I’d had enough of the unhygienic nappy feeling of towels and wanted to wear tampons. Mum absolutely freaked and started claiming that tampons would take my virginity. Then came an almighty row during which I called out her lie, which she didn’t like. She did eventually go to the shop, but rather than buying tampons inexplicably returned with one of those old-fashioned sanitary belts! Even in 1991 I couldn’t imagine when on earth the local shop had bought those in! The mid-1950s, surely! I was livid, and eventually she gave in and bought me tampons. However, I was so angry and tense I couldn’t insert one, so was forced back to the grotty towels. It did have a serious impact upon my already ropey relationship with my mum, as I simply couldn’t trust her anymore. After that I started using my own money to buy myself tampons. Growing older Throughout your life, what if anything, have you done to actively maintain your health both physically and mentally? Has this changed at all over the years? If so, was this due to a particular event in your life? Where do you get information about health and wellbeing now? Would you say you are you more or less aware of your body now? Why do you think this is? In future years how do you expect your approach to health and wellbeing to change? I’ve done little for most of my adult life to actively maintain my health, maintaining high hygiene standards, but really doing little regular exercise and although I have always eaten mostly healthy food, I’ve also eaten a lot of sweets and crisps and drunk a lot of alcohol. I really have been fortunate not to have piled on weight. During my late teens and early 20s I worked in shops and spent much of the day on my feet, rushing around, so I think that probably helped keep the weight off. Once I gained my first job as a librarian, I became almost entirely desk-bound, so started putting on weight. Shortly after this I joined a gym, but as often happens, my initial enthusiasm waned, life got in the way and made it awkward to visit and once I fell pregnant with my first child I stopped going for a few years. 2 ½ years ago I had a TIA and whilst there’s been absolutely no indication of what on earth caused it – I don’t smoke, I was slightly overweight, but not enough to be triggering strokes, my blood pressure was fine, bloods and heart fine, it did scare me. The occupational therapists encouraged me to get more exercise, and whilst I was initially fearful of my heart rate increasing too much in case it caused another stroke (a totally imagined fear!), I started doing the 0-5k running programme, which worked a treat, until the weather got too hot and I couldn’t bear to run in the heat! After that I joined the local gym. Recovery from the TIA also made me more aware for the first time since I had children (and therefore had less time for myself), of the importance of my own wellbeing, and of the need to relax and spend time doing tasks I enjoy doing and which distract my mind from my worries. Consequently, I’ve got far better at refusing to do things I don’t want to do, and actively taking time to do things I want to do, and if others wish to join me, all the better, but I’ve been prioritising myself for once. It has also made me more conscious of my body, and when I can maintain a routine it’s relatively easy for me to regularly exercise and to eat (mostly) healthily. Unfortunately, during the Covid pandemic I’ve found it very difficult to maintain that routine, and my strongest desire when I’ve time away from work is to read, research my family tree, or sew – something I can do quietly on my own, curled up in a comfy chair. I do need to start undertaking more exercise, as I am putting on weight and I am concerned that it’ll impact upon my health. Health, wellbeing and appearance In your view, how are health and wellbeing related to external appearance? Have you ever been influenced by popular ideals of beauty or physical appearance? Do you think your parents were influenced by these kinds of ideals? If so, in what way? Are there any health or beauty products (excluding medicines) that you couldn’t live without? What would be your Desert Island item? I think there’s definitely a relationship between health and wellbeing and external appearance – you can often tell when people are ill or depressed by their physical appearance or demeanour, but I don’t think it’s a given that if you look healthy you are. Many people who exhibit that healthy glow are struggling with their mental health and when I had the TIA, you’d never have known it’d happened because I seemed, even to me, healthy and happy! When it occurred, I was less stressed than I’d been for a long time, so eternal appearance isn’t always a good indicator of health and wellbeing. I do feel I’m influenced by popular ideals, in that I’d love to have a flat stomach and achieve that healthy glow. I pluck my eyebrows and remove unsightly hairs, pre-Covid I always wore make-up outside of the house, but I don’t feel the need to have Botox, colour my eyebrows in with a marker pen or cover myself in fake tan, as many people currently are. Although, I do feel better about myself when I do have a slight tan, maybe that’s just the benefits of getting the sun on my skin and a Vitamin D boost! I’ve never been particularly interested in fashion and am aware I dress quite conservatively and dully. Much of that is down to having had a lack of money to spend on clothing throughout the years, so I tend to buy clothes I know I’ll get plenty of wear from and can wear both to work and around home, and the plainer they are, the less self-conscious I’m likely to feel as they get older. My parents definitely weren’t influenced by popular ideals. Mum made the mistake in her teens of shaving the small amount of hair she had on her top lip, and has spent the last 55 years trying to tackle that, which is probably as far as she goes with beauty ideals. Dad regularly visits the barber, but again, little more! There are two health and beauty products I couldn’t live without: a firm Reach toothbrush and any Colgate toothpaste. I am 45 with no fillings and I’m convinced these products have played a huge part in that! If my desert island items need to be health and beauty-related, I’d choose the Reach toothbrush and Colgate toothpaste; if not I’d go for a full Kindle and means of charging it. Getting ready to leave the house Do you remember your mother or father getting ready to go out for work, or for the evening? If so, can you describe their rituals? What is your own routine when getting ready to go out for work or for socialising? Has this routine changed over time? I don’t remember too much about my parents getting ready to go to work or out. Really it was the basics for both, little extra effort when they were off out. Dad worked shifts, so on earlies he’d get up about 5.00, go straight downstairs and set a full kettle going, chuck some teabags in the teapot and get the ingredients out for his sandwiches, before heading upstairs for a shower. He’d dress, come down make a tea, breakfast, packed lunch and flask of tea, head up to clean his teeth then head to work. On lates he’d grab some lunch, make a packed tea, get changed for work, clean his teeth and head out. Then going for a night out, he’d shower, shave (usually cutting himself and covering his face in bits of toilet paper to mop up the blood), put on his clothes, add a splash of after shave and clean his teeth. Dad always cleans his teeth right before he leaves the house. Mum would usually have a million things to sort out before going to work, such as my sister and I, so after showering, cleaning her teeth, dressing, eating her beloved Shredded Wheat for breakfast, making our packed lunches and ensuring we were ready and had everything, she’d take us to school then head to work. Going out, she’d usually shower, clean her teeth, dress, add a minimal amount of makeup and a splash of perfume, then head out. There’s certainly no all afternoon preparations with either of them – so long as they look presentable, that’s fine. I don’t think I’m hugely different. One odd thing though, is that if they’re going out in the morning, they don’t initially put on the clothes they’ll wear for the day. So, if they’re heading out say, 10am, they’ll put on clothes when they get up, say, 7am, but will then change before going out at 10am. I’ve never understood this. Sometimes they change clothes after just an hour! It seems pointless to me. At least they don’t immediately put the 7am clothes in the wash. My pre-Covid weekday routine was to wake about 6.45, brush my teeth, shower (always shaving my armpits and shampooing and conditioning my hair), wash my face, dry, moisturise, dress, brush my hair, head downstairs, put on the kettle, make packed lunches for myself and F, make a cup of tea, make poached eggs on toast for breakfast, nag F to get into the shower, make F’s breakfast, nag F to sort out his school bag and brush his teeth, put on some makeup, shoes and coats on, take F to school, then head to work. This has changed since L started at secondary school in Sept 2020, as I previously had them both to chivvy along in the mornings, but as L now needs to leave the house earlier to catch the bus, D has been getting up and into the shower before me and sorting him out. Before children, my routine was much the same except for there being no nagging of children. Socialising, my routine is much the same. I may shower before heading out, but probably not, I’ll likely make do with putting on more deodorant, washing my face, re-doing my make-up – I may put on some heavier eye makeup – brushing my hair, sometimes trying and failing to style it in some way, put on my going-out clothes, sometimes wearing heels which I rarely wear during the day, grab a little handbag which again, I don’t use day to day, and head out. This routine has changed very little over the years. JS/KP Autumn 2020 Directive/No. 120

Keywords: COVID-19 pandemic (2020-);Lifestyle, health and well-being;Partners (personal);Employment and occupations;Physical health conditions;Schools;Emotional states;Family life;Health services and medical care;Food;Reproductive health;Friends;Adolescence;Family members;Personal hygiene;Leisure time and social activities;Communication;Mental health;Personal appearance;
Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing'. Mass-Observer M7453 describes themself as female; age 51; 'School support / housewife'.;The Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing' was issued on 27 November 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their opinions on and experiences of health and wellbeing, in particular 'health, wellbeing and the healthy body'; 'identity'; 'growing up and learning about health and wellbeing'; 'growing older'; 'health, wellbeing and appearance'; 'getting ready to leave the house'.
Contents: Isle of Wight School support/housewife Part 2: Everyday Health Please start each part of your Directive reply on a new sheet of paper with your MO number, gender and Wellbeing identity,  age, marital status, the town or village where you live andThe challenges of COVID-19 mean that in your occupation or former recent months, there has been a lot of occupation. reflection on health and wellbeing in Remember not to identify yourself or unprecedented circumstances. But what other people inadvertently within about health and wellbeing in everyday life? your reply. It is best to use initials We learn about health in many different instead of real names. ways, and it can mean different things to different people depending on their circumstances. In this Directive, we want to find out what health and wellbeing means to you (and what it meant before COVID-19) but particularly where your ideas about health and wellbeing came from, and what has influenced your own experiences of health and wellbeing in everyday life. Health, wellbeing and the healthy body Health, to me, largely means physical health. Wellbeing is more to do with one’s mental state. What do you think about when you imagine “a healthy body”? The first five words that come to your mind when you think of this term-Movement, painless, trim, supple, normal Is there a particular person or image that comes to mind? Please describe, or draw, this person. A healthy person who comes to mind would be Michael Moseley for my age group or Joe Wicks. Isle of Wight School support/housewife Identity How do you think that your own experience of health and wellbeing has been influenced by your gender, ethnicity, social class, or sexual orientation? Do you think your experience of health has been influenced by these or other aspects of your identity at all? I’m female, white, straight and working class. It will have affected my health experience and how it has been treated. Certainly the fact my husband has a good job has meant I have not had to work full time since our son arrived 19 years ago. As time has gone along my health has deteriorated, having several chronic health conditions. I had worked as an administrator in the NHS, but due to a chronic bad back I simply couldn’t do the job anymore so I resigned. I know other people in a similar situation have had to carry on in pain because they couldn’t afford to leave work. The same goes for my wellbeing. I know I am very lucky to have a husband who would rather I was not suffering physical pain by having to work when he knows how much that affects my wellbeing. He is an absolute rock to my mental health. I suppose my social class has had an effect too. The class system, in this country, I believe will never go away. I’m working class because my husband works. However, even working class has its own separate sub divisions depending on what kind of job you have and what you can afford. I have been able to go to the gym to try and maintain any physical health I still have (whilst they were open!) and certainly as a child I was afforded the chance to take part in activities such as dance and any clubs I wished to join which would have been good for my mental health. Isle of Wight School support/housewife Growing up and learning about health and wellbeing When and where did you first become aware of “health” or of “wellbeing”? We did PE in school which was simply part of the curriculum. I don’t think I ever really was aware of it is being a healthy thing to do. At primary school I enjoyed it, but moving on I absolutely hated it. With my physique, I was never going to be an athlete! I would say teachers had a big influence on my wellbeing and choices of how to be healthy. I had one teacher who would use me as the example pupil of how not to do things. Not a great way to improve someone’s wellbeing. If anything, his lack of encouragement made me dislike any physical activities at all. I had only one PE teacher at secondary school who took an interest in the pupils who “couldn’t” rather than those that “could”. She really boosted my mental wellbeing, confidence and attitude to healthy pursuits. She encouraged us so much and in the one year she was my PE teacher she really built up my stamina. I went from being one of the students who would splash around pathetically in the baby pool whilst the athletic ones were diving and swimming lengths to one who could swim nearly 40 lengths in one lesson. She had taught me to focus on what I could do rather than what I couldn’t. I can still remember the students good at PE being somewhat put out that she praised us for what we could do rather than those that were naturally talented all the time. My mother sent me to dance classes as a child which I attended at least two or three times a week. I didn’t always like it, but it never occurred to me not to go! In later years my mother told me she had sent me to try and build up some muscles on my body, in particular my legs. They were like sticks although I have to say she never ever criticised or body shamed me as she had been the Isle of Wight School support/housewife same physique as a child and didn’t want me to go through the same bullying as she had as a child. Who had responsibility for looking after your health and wellbeing when you were younger? I would say 100% my parents. If anyone else chipped in I would say it was only because my parents asked them to. I never felt anything other than completely safe and loved by my Mother and Father. That’s a pretty good memory to leave an offspring isn’t it? I wasn’t a particularly sickly child, but I did have a weight problem which my parents never made an issue of. My mother, at the recommendation of the doctor, gave me any “naughty” food I wanted because I just didn’t grow and I was so thin. My mum used to to tell me I was slender as I was growing up, she never called me skinny and we never had any arguments about what I did or didn’t eat. She always looked out for my mental wellbeing and boosted my self esteem. Do you remember your parents, or other caregivers, talking to you about health? If so, what did they talk to you about? Where did these conversations take place? I don’t really remember my parents talking about my health directly. I think my Mum was a very clever parent! If I was ill she’d take care of me physically and mentally. I had a routine operation in hospital as a young teenager and became dangerously underweight whilst I was there. I was always underweight anyway and I certainly didn’t have any reserves to get any smaller. The food was absolutely disgusting and one day I even had a huge earthworm in my salad. I existed on crackers and cheese for three weeks. My Nan would smuggle Isle of Wight School support/housewife strawberries and cream in too which was probably the only thing that kept me alive. My parents must have been beside themselves with worry as I was under three stone and not healing. Looking back on it I know I would never have mentally coped if the same situation had occurred with my son. They never showed their concerns to me. I was always such a worrywart (and still am) that it wouldn’t have done me mentally any good to realise how ill I was. In the end I was discharged because it was clear staying in hospital was making me worse. Within two months of being back home, and a lot of input from my parents, my mental health and physical health were back to normal. I do remember the “facts of life” chat which naturally in those days came from my mother! She got a book out of the library and let me read it before asking me if I had any questions. I know I never discussed things like that with my father. When my own son got to that age I told my husband he could do it, but my son came up with something wrong that children so often do and we had a perfectly normal conversation about it then and there. Even to this day he will rather ask me the “embarrassing” questions than mention something to my husband. My son knows I am very matter of fact about issues like that and I like to think that that was something I got right. Did you receive any education about health in school? And/or did you learn about health and wellbeing in other ways – from friends, magazines, or the internet, for example? We had the “facts of life” at primary school, but my Mum had already covered that so it came as no shock. I can still remember watching the TV programme about giving birth and can even hear in  my mind the Scottish presenter saying it takes about 40 weeks to grow a baby which is as long as starting school in September until Whitsun holiday. One poor girl was actually sick watching it! In secondary school the PE teachers did “the talk” in just one lesson. Lots of embarrassment blushing and silly questions. Girls and boys obviously taught in separate classes. Nowadays, I know PSHE is on the curriculum far more than Isle of Wight School support/housewife just the one lesson. I don’t ever remember being taught about our mental health and wellbeing in school and I think it’s a good thing that it has been recognised as being something important so that children have the opportunity to grow up as well rounded healthy individuals who can thrive and contribute to society. I did learn a little from friends and it was only through a friend that I learnt fully about periods and had to go and ask my Mum to check the facts. I guess my Mum just thought I wasn’t old enough and didn’t really to know that bit yet. Ironically, when that friend started her periods it was my Mum she came to see what to do rather than her own mum. I suppose my age group did have magazines such as Jackie and later on Just 17. I don’t know that it really taught me anything, but I do remember reading the problem page “Cathy and Claire” in Jackie and knowing that some of the problems my age group were going through were normal. By the time I’d graduated onto Just 17 the problem page was interesting, but bore little resemblance to the safe life I was living. Key moments As an adolescent, when did you first become aware of bodily changes associated with puberty? I was something of a late developer being so small and I was probably one of the last in my year to hit puberty. I wasn’t in any rush anyway, but I did find it annoying that I didn’t have an excuse to miss going in the showers after PE! Actually, I think I probably lied once a month just to look normal. Isle of Wight School support/housewife Are there any moments or rituals that you think are particularly important for young women or men? These might include, but are not limited to, first period, voice breaking, buying the first bra, or shaving, for example? How did you feel about these moments if/when they happened to you? My Mum bought my first bra long before I needed one. She told me it was a modesty bra, and I would one day have something to put in there. It was something she did to increase my self esteem. I don’t think I really needed one until I was about 16. Getting your period was an incredibly important thing as a young girl and you didn’t fit in with your peers fully until you got it. I had to wait a very long time, but I was very prepared for it carrying around the necessary products for at least 4 years before I needed them. When I did get my first period I remember feeling quite special and at last I was normal. Ironically my mother was away on holiday and I felt quite disappointed that I couldn’t tell her about it, and being so far behind my friends I didn’t dare tell them. I think for a lad, their voice breaking is an awkward but important thing on their journey into adulthood. My brother’s voice broke speaking just two words. My dad came in from work and my brother said “Hello Dad”. The first word came from a child the second started high, then cracked higher and finished down in his boots as a man! He blushed, we all laughed together rather than at him and I think he was quite pleased especially as he got over it in one sentence. I remember my son starting to shave. We bought him an electric razor. A long time later he asked why my husband had never taught him to wet shave. We reminded him that he was always late when going out and electric shaving meant he could multi-task! Isle of Wight School support/housewife Growing older Throughout your life, what if anything, have you done to actively maintain your health both physically and mentally? Has this changed at all over the years? If so, was this due to a particular event in your life? I do enjoy walking and it is something I can do for quite a long period of time. With my bad back I have to be careful with what I can do and there is a fine line between over exercising and doing just enough. I used to do keep fit, which I did really enjoy. It was good for my mental health too as it was very sociable and I met several very good friends through it. Sadly it is not something I can safely do now. Mentally keeping fit has not always been so easy. I am a worrier so I choose pastimes that I can really absorb myself in. Before I hurt my back I did enjoy gardening. I could totally lose myself in just doing a bit of weeding. Nowadays I do a lot of crafting. I know it has become a bit of a national obsession with making things especially during lockdown, but I was into crafting long before Kirstie Allsopp was on TV singing the praises of craft! I love crochet as I can stand, sit or even lie down doing it. I also love sewing, but I have to be careful not to sit at my sewing machine for too long. I can’t really say what triggered my sudden passion to start crafting, but it has developed over the years and has certainly helped my mental health and gives me a feeling of wellbeing when I achieve something. It can also be counter­productive when things go wrong though. My sewing machine was nearly defenestrated when it kept jumping stitches on a facemask I was making last year, so I have to know when to stop and come back to it or I’ll feel more agitated than when I started. Crafting has also led to something else that has greatly improved and maintained my sense of wellbeing. I enjoy crafting, but I do like to at least have a reason for making something. I discovered a few competitions locally and it Isle of Wight School support/housewife has given me the impetus to take part and try to make things that I would never normally have considered. As I wanted to develop my interest further I found a local WI that was very proactive in crafting and this has made a huge difference to my wellbeing. This has been even more important during the lockdowns as we have kept in touch with each other through “zooming” at least once a week either having a chat or playing beetle drive or bingo. I’m not a massive fan of social media, but it has been an absolute godsend for mental health to keep in touch with close friends. It’ll never take the place of real contact, but in these times it at least softens the blow and makes us realise that people are still there even if we can’t physically touch them. Where do you get information about health and wellbeing now? I suppose without realising I get a lot of information from the TV and the internet. Being a worrier I do NOT consult Dr Google, he has no qualifications at all! I do, however, look on the NHS site for health issues. I will watch documentaries on health issues such as weight and mental wellbeing. I think the campaign saying “it’s OK to not be OK” has lessened the stigma of mental health issues and also possibly broadened the ideas of what people consider to be a mental health issue. Not that many years ago, people’s idea of what it was to have a mental health issue would not have included anxiety or low mood. If someone was depressed then it would not have been talked about. I think we are less fearful to ask how someone is when not necessarily thinking of their physical health. I also keep up to date with medical issues that affect me through specific magazines (e.g. the national Osteoporosis magazine) or the national recognised websites. Isle of Wight School support/housewife Would you say you are you more or less aware of your body now? Why do you think this is? I’m more aware of my body now as it ages and the aches and pains are increasing! I have osteoporosis which was diagnosed nearly 20 years ago. I put it to the back of my mind, but I am aware my body will begin to change and the disease may affect me more. I also have degenerative disc disease so I can’t see me “getting away with” no further complications to my spine as I get older. In future years how do you expect your approach to health and wellbeing to change? I expect I will still worry. I can’t see that ever changing now. I will try and maintain what health I have and resist the medication to help with the pain as long as I can. I have a high pain threshold and I want to know there will be something I can take when it gets too bad. Health, wellbeing and appearance In your view, how are health and wellbeing related to external appearance? If you don’t feel good physically then it will affect your external appearance even if you try not to let it. When my back “went” for the second time I tried so hard to carry on as normal and, with hindsight, I should have stopped some of the things I was still trying to do. It was only when a work colleague told me I looked really rough and said I had to go the doctors that I listened and within 24 hours I was in hospital. If she hadn’t told me I probably would have tried to carry on. However, I do think with some mental illnesses it is possible to hide your inner feelings so nothing shows externally. I think the late actor Robin Williams was a prime example of someone who could disguise what was happening on the inside. He said “I think the saddest people always try their hardest to make people happy because they know what it's like to feel absolutely worthless and they don't want anyone else to feel like that.” Isle of Wight School support/housewife Have you ever been influenced by popular ideals of beauty or physical appearance? Do you think your parents were influenced by these kinds of ideals? If so, in what way? I probably have been influenced unconsciously. I did note fashions growing up and recognised what were popular ideals of beauty. Although being slim has been the popular norm for many years I wasn’t slim, being brutally honest I was skinny and there was nothing I could do to conform to the ideal shape. As I’ve got older middle aged spread has crept in and I wish my GP would tell me now I could eat whatever I fancied without any concerns! My mother dressed classically and always wore clothes that suited rather than conform. My Dad was very thin too. Are there any health or beauty products (excluding medicines) that you couldn’t live without? What would be your Desert Island item? Before the pandemic I couldn’t possibly leave the house without lipstick on. I have incredibly pale lips and without a slap of “lippy” on I look dead. It has taken months to get out of the habit of popping upstairs to put some lipstick on before I go out. Nearly all of my homemade masks still have a lipstick mark on them although they are boil washed after every use. Before every zoom I still go and put some on! Lipstick would definitely be my desert island item. Getting ready to leave the house Do you remember your mother or father getting ready to go out for work, or for the evening? If so, can you describe their rituals? I loved watching my mother getting ready to go out for the evening. Her dressing table was wonderful, full of lots of lotions and potions and her makeup. She had a pot of moisturiser that smelt like limes and I always wanted to taste it, but never did. She also had different perfumes for evening or Isle of Wight School support/housewife daytime. In the evening she would wear Norman Hartnell perfume but during the day she wore Heaven Scent by Helena Rubinstein. It’s not made anymore, but I still have one bottle left and if I’m missing my mum (she died 14 years ago) one whiff will take me back to a feeling of safety. My mother stayed at home with the children once we arrived, but she would still ensure she was made up for the day and wouldn’t dream of answering the door without her face on. She always put on eye shadow and eye liner and, like me, lipstick. That’s probably where I got it from. My father was up and out in the morning pretty much at the last minute! Woe betides if anyone was in the bathroom when he needed to be in there as he always cut it so fine. He would get his breakfast ready the night before so all he had to do was to put the milk on his cereal in the morning. Mum always did his sandwiches the night before too. Mum and Dad also had a teasmade so that would wake them up. I always left for school or later on work before my Dad did so I never really saw much of any other rituals. What is your own routine when getting ready to go out for work or for socialising? Has this routine changed over time? I only work part time and at the moment not at all because of covid restrictions. When I was working I would have to be first up even though my husband left for work before I did (he is working from home now). I always had to have a shower and wash and style my hair before going down for breakfast. If I was working I’d always put my face on, lipstick, foundation, eye shadow, mascara and eyeliner. I actually enjoyed getting ready for work and making an effort. Now I am working I’m still usually the first one up because I like to go and make my husband a cup of tea before he gets up. I also need to sort our dog out as he gets too excited with my husband in the mornings. Generally I go back to bed to drink my tea and then get up once my husband has gone to work (along the landing) to his office. When socialising my routine is quite similar. I’ll always have a shower and do my hair etc. Even now, with no physical socialising I will go and make sure I Isle of Wight School support/housewife look OK if I’m face timing with someone. I think it’s a bit disrespectful to look a mess and its better for one’s moral and wellbeing to feel good about yourself. Please post your response to: Freepost: RTGU-AYJE-YSSC, The Mass Observation Archive, The Keep, Woollards Way, Brighton, BN1 9BP (please note that the MOA team are currently working from home and unable to respond to directives sent by post) or by email to: moa@sussex.ac.uk. JS/KP Summer Directive/No. 120
