Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing'. Mass-Observer M6082 describes themself as female; age 43; married; writer and educational note taker.;The Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing' was issued on 27 November 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their opinions on and experiences of health and wellbeing, in particular 'health, wellbeing and the healthy body'; 'identity'; 'growing up and learning about health and wellbeing'; 'growing older'; 'health, wellbeing and appearance'; 'getting ready to leave the house'.
Contents: MO Number:M6082 Sex: Female Age: 43 Marital Status: Married Town: Belfast Occupation: Writer and Educational Note Taker Part 2: Everyday Health Please start each part of your Directive reply on a new sheet of paper with your MO number, gender and Wellbeing identity,  age, marital status, the town or village where you live andThe challenges of COVID-19 mean that in your occupation or former recent months, there has been a lot of occupation. reflection on health and wellbeing in Remember not to identify yourself or unprecedented circumstances. But what other people inadvertently within about health and wellbeing in everyday life? your reply. It is best to use initials We learn about health in many different instead of real names. ways, and it can mean different things to different people depending on their circumstances. In this Directive, we want to find out what health and wellbeing means to you (and what it meant before COVID-19) but particularly where your ideas about health and wellbeing came from, and what has influenced your own experiences of health and wellbeing in everyday life. Health, wellbeing and the healthy body What does “health” mean to you? What does “wellbeing” mean to you? How do you define these words? What do you think about when you imagine “a healthy body”? Please share the first five words that come to your mind when you think of this term. Is there a particular person or image that comes to mind? Please describe, or draw, this person. I think being healthy means having a body that works and is fit enough to do what you want it to. Wellbeing is probably more about mental health and mood. A healthy body is fit, functioning, active, strong, flexible I’d probably think first of an athlete, but I don’t think you have to be an athlete to be healthy, I think as long as you look after your body and keep in reasonable shape you could be considered healthy. Identity How do you think that your own experience of health and wellbeing has been influenced by your gender, ethnicity, social class, or sexual orientation? Do you think your experience of health has been influenced by these or other aspects of your identity at all? I think women’s sexual health hasn’t had nearly as much attention as men’s and it’s quite common for women to have health problems that the medical profession just hasn’t a clue about and isn’t interested in, and women just accept it and suffer in silence because they’re used to it. I think if men had endometriosis or painful periods or pain during sex they wouldn’t rest until they had the problem sorted. But women experience all of this all the time and there’s very little interest in tackling it or even educating GPs about it. Growing up and learning about health and wellbeing When and where did you first become aware of “health” or of “wellbeing”? Who had responsibility for looking after your health and wellbeing when you were younger? Do you remember your parents, or other caregivers, talking to you about health? If so, what did they talk to you about? Where did these conversations take place? Did you receive any education about health in school? And/or did you learn about health and wellbeing in other ways – from friends, magazines, or the internet, for example? No one really talked about health or wellbeing when I was young (in the 80s and 90s). My mother worried if you didn’t eat, and she dieted a lot herself but we weren’t told about healthy eating or exercising. I think we covered health in PE classes in school. It was mostly about getting enough protein and which fats were good or bad. I remember having a ‘health test’ of some sort where they measured your pulse before and after exercise and pinched you to measure body fat. The girls worried about the body fat and I don’t think that was a good thing to do to us in front of everyone. Mental health was never mentioned. A couple of teachers at school were rumoured to have had ‘nervous breakdowns’, which seemed a very dramatic thing that was only whispered about but we had no idea what it actually meant. In my head it involved complete collapse, possibly screaming! In fact it was only much later in life, looking back, that I realised they’d just suffered from depression or something. I was quite an angsty teen and I think these days I’d have been sent to a school counsellor or something. In fact my parents did occasionally ‘threaten’ to send me to a psychologist. But I did take this as a ‘threat’ rather than an offer of help, and possibly they did partly mean it as a way to scare me into being normal. Looking back, I think my only problem was that I was a very introverted person living in a noisy house and I liked being alone. A counsellor might have been able to explain that to me and my family and save me many years of thinking there was something wrong with me. There must have been lots of kids at my school with issues but it just wasn’t a thing that was talked about. I’m not sure the school saw it as their responsibility to look after that part of our lives. Key moments M6082 As an adolescent, when did you first become aware of bodily changes associated with puberty? Are there any moments or rituals that you think are particularly important for young women or men? These might include, but are not limited to, first period, voice breaking, buying the first bra, or shaving, for example? How did you feel about these moments if/when they happened to you? I’ve always been a very ‘in my own head’ person and fairly unaware of myself from the neck down so I barely noticed puberty. But I do remember getting a bra, and the girls in the school changing room laughing at it because it was so tiny (I really didn’t need it). I remember another girl being laughed at because she developed quite early. I had no idea about shaving and my mother never talked to me about things like that. I had to ask her which bits to shave! When I got my first boyfriend at 16 I still had hairy armpits and he didn’t care at all. This was the late 90s. But there was no internet or social media so we weren’t comparing each other to models etc. In a way I think the internet is great because kids today are much more clued in about sexuality and diversity and consent, but I also think we were lucky because our body image wasn’t so affected by things like porn and Instagram. I found my periods an annoyance and couldn’t understand why I was supposed to feel ‘grown up’ when they started. It didn’t seem like something ‘special’ to me. It felt monstrously unfair that I had to endure them and boys didn’t. Growing older Throughout your life, what if anything, have you done to actively maintain your health both physically and mentally? Has this changed at all over the years? If so, was this due to a particular event in your life? Where do you get information about health and wellbeing now? Would you say you are you more or less aware of your body now? Why do you think this is? In future years how do you expect your approach to health and wellbeing to change? I’ve never thought much about my health or wellbeing. I’ve been lucky in that I’ve never been overweight or had any major health issues, mental or physical. But I’m in my 40s now and starting to notice aches and pains and sagginess. I walk a lot, because I enjoy it, but also to keep fit. And I garden a lot but my garden is on a slope and I’m becoming aware that when I’m older it may be too hard for me to manage on my own. I put on about a stone during the first Covid lockdown, and put some effort into losing it and I’m aware that my weight has crept up a little bit over the last decade and I suspect this will continue. I never thought about mental health until my husband suffered from depression 5 years ago. I’ve since had quite a stressful job myself and did consider counselling at one point. I think if things got worse I would go to counselling. Health, wellbeing and appearance In your view, how are health and wellbeing related to external appearance? Have you ever been influenced by popular ideals of beauty or physical appearance? Do you think your parents were influenced by these kinds of ideals? If so, in what way? Are there any health or beauty products (excluding medicines) that you couldn’t live without? What would be your Desert Island item? I find external appearance a bit of an annoyance and one that’s particularly onerous for women. I hate having to bother with makeup and wear it as seldom as possible. I’m not very interested in fashion or hairstyles and I spend very little on beauty products. I’m interested in being slim and flexible, mostly because it makes life easier, and I’d put more effort into that than into my face and hair. My mother has spent most of her life on a diet and has always been slim and has bleached blonde hair, and my sister trained as a beautician and they and my cousin all love shopping for clothes, so I’m considered a bit odd in my family. My dad complains about and laughs at the millions of products my mum uses, but I know he likes her to be blonde and look nice so I think it’s a bit hypocritical and I wouldn’t put up with that from a man. My skin is a bit dry and I use moisturizer every day and lip balm most days, and I use a lot of hand cream. So my desert island product would be Nivea Face, Hand and Body Cream. I have a very basic makeup kit that I’d happily live without. I think one of the best things about Covid has been not wearing makeup. I like perfume but I’m as likely to wear it at home just for myself as out in public. Getting ready to leave the house Do you remember your mother or father getting ready to go out for work, or for the evening? If so, can you describe their rituals? What is your own routine when getting ready to go out for work or for socialising? Has this routine changed over time? I remember my mum getting ready to go out because her perfume would fill the house and I loved that smell. She always seemed very glamorous. She had sliderobe wardrobes with mirror doors and would spend ages doing her hair and makeup. She still has several drawers filled with more makeup than you could ever wear in your life. If I need new makeup I still raid them rather than buying stuff. She loves buying products. My dad would shave with an electric razor but he never used any products. I think he even considered deodorant girly. If I’m going for a night out or an important work thing I’ll wear makeup but I wear very little and it takes me about 5 minutes. When my hair was short I’d curl it a bit, when it’s long I straighten it with straighteners but that doesn’t take long either. I like looking nice but I wouldn’t go to the trouble unless it was for something important. I’m aware that people are nicer to you when you look nice, particularly men, and if I go to a pub where all the girls are dolled up and I’m not I feel a bit self-conscious and frumpy, but most of the time it’s not worth the effort. In the future I can see myself going grey because I wouldn’t be bothered keeping up with hair dying. But I might also feel more self-conscious and end up dying my hair and wearing more makeup, I don’t know yet. Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing'. Mass-Observer M6737 describes themself as female; age 48; married; planning enforcement officer.;The Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing' was issued on 27 November 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their opinions on and experiences of health and wellbeing, in particular 'health, wellbeing and the healthy body'; 'identity'; 'growing up and learning about health and wellbeing'; 'growing older'; 'health, wellbeing and appearance'; 'getting ready to leave the house'.
Contents: Autumn Directive 2020 Part 2: Everyday Health and Wellbeing The challenges of COVID-19 mean that in recent months, there has been a lot of reflection on health and wellbeing in unprecedented circumstances. But what about health and wellbeing in everyday life? We learn about health in many different ways, and it can mean different things to different people depending on their circumstances. In Please start each part of your Directive reply on a new sheet of paper with your MO number, gender identity,  age, marital status, the town or village where you live and your occupation or former occupation. Remember not to identify yourself or other people inadvertently within your reply. It is best to use initials instead of real names. this Directive, we want to find out what health and wellbeing means to you (and what it meant before COVID-19) but particularly where your ideas about health and wellbeing came from, and what has influenced your own experiences of health and wellbeing in everyday life. Health, wellbeing and the healthy body What does “health” mean to you? What does “wellbeing” mean to you? How do you define these words? Health to me means ‘in the absence of illness’ and includes both physical and mental health. Wellbeing is the padding to health. Like cushions on a comfy sofa. The sense of being in a position to enjoy life without mental or physical illness. But I think wellbeing encompasses much more than just an absence of infliction and needs to be expanded to incorporate physiological needs such as enough to eat, somewhere safe to live, heating, hot water, enough clothes to wear, access to sanitary products. In addition, a sense of belonging and access to companionship which has become even more apparent in the last year.  What do you think about when you imagine “a healthy body”? Please share the first five words that come to your mind when you think of this term.  Mobile, strong, free from illness, functional, radiant. Is there a particular person or image that comes to mind? Please describe, or draw, this person. Identity How do you think that your own experience of health and wellbeing has been influenced by your gender, ethnicity, social class, or sexual orientation? Do you think your experience of health has been influenced by these or other aspects of your identity at all? I am a white, female, middle class, straight(ish) child of the 80’s growing up in North East England. We never had conversations in our house about health. We only had conversations about fatness. Not being fat = healthy; Being fat = not healthy. Nearly every conversation I had with a health practitioner at that time also revolved around the same equation. It was the time of constant dieting. Low fat, high carb. Skimmed everything. Liver once a week because ‘it was good for you’. Weight watchers. Diet sheets. My experience of health and wellbeing has been an exploration. I’ve learned a lot from peers and friends about what it looks like. I’ve learned that self-care is essential, not a luxury or an act of selfishness. I’ve learned health is way more than a number on a set of scales or a dress size.  Growing up and learning about health and wellbeing When and where did you first become aware of “health” or of “wellbeing”?  I cant really remember. As a concept it was probably when I first started my personal trainers course when we discussed the inter connection between physical and mental health.  Who had responsibility for looking after your health and wellbeing when you were younger? I lived with my parents until I was approximately 14. But both were relatively absent in their own misery. School teachers contributed but ultimately the responsibility fell to me. Do you remember your parents, or other caregivers, talking to you about health? If so, what did they talk to you about? Where did these conversations take place? We never really had a conversation about any aspects of health other than weight. I didn’t know to wash my hands after going to the toilet, or why I had to brush my teeth or coping strategies for stressful situations. I would go and sit in the woods until I felt better – I didn’t know why that worked or the benefits of being in nature per se. I didn’t know what to do when my period happened (I was 15).  Did you receive any education about health in school? And/or did you learn about health and wellbeing in other ways – from friends, magazines, or the internet, for example? All of my education around health came from friends and the school. We were extraordinarily lucky to go to a school with amazing teachers who look after our welfare as well as our education. I learned about the concept of ‘being kind’ from them first and foremost. They showed us such kindness and generosity. Among other things they taught us about sex ed, fitness, mental health and the importance of freedom. I’m still learning about health and wellbeing now. The internet has facilitated the access and means to more information than we can possibly digest and lockdown, the time to access and consider more of that information. At 48, I’ve finally been able to experiment with mindfulness and explore what that means. And I’ve started to understand what constitutes a healthy diet, the role of sleep, mindfulness and meditation, breathwork, stress relief techniques, functional fitness and a healthy work/life balance actually looks like.  Key moments As an adolescent, when did you first become aware of bodily changes associated with puberty? Age 10 when the girls started to develop breasts and the talk in the school yard turned to wearing bras.  Are there any moments or rituals that you think are particularly important for young women or men? These might include, but are not limited to, first period, voice breaking, buying the first bra, or shaving, for example?  I find the whole thing almost unbearable to think about. I understand in certain cultures these examples can feel like a right of passage and a time to celebrate. To be embraced by the sisterhood. It just served to make me aware of how alone I was. How did you feel about these moments if/when they happened to you? I spent the whole time embarrassed and bewildered. Growing older Throughout your life, what if anything, have you done to actively maintain your health both physically and mentally? Has this changed at all over the years? If so, was this due to a particular event in your life? I’ve always been active. I discovered endurance events and loved the mental positivity of long distance. I love being outdoors, exploration and the feeling of freedom. Being in the  weather has a way of making you feel alive like nothing else. I take care of myself in a much more constructive way now. I’m curious and will ask questions to seek information rather than remaining passive.  Where do you get information about health and wellbeing now? The internet is a great place to start. I will consult with experts and authorities on subjects now. I’ve also studied a lot as it really interests me. I’ve got a degree in sports physiology, done a personal trainers course and am now studying counselling.  Would you say you are you more or less aware of your body now? Why do you think this is? I’m much more aware of my body these days. Conscious of its wonders and limitations. I think the awareness is part wisdom and part realisation that it starts to fall apart if it’s not being looked after. For example, I’ve noticed it appears to be much more sensitive to nutrition these days. Less tolerant of gluten and dairy. It’s something my friends of a similar age have noticed and so I wonder if that is a product of aging.  I also notice I tend to have a few more niggles now than I used to and clambering off the couch seems a little more difficult of late .. In future years how do you expect your approach to health and wellbeing to change? I hope that I’ll be able to maintain health and wellbeing. I suspect that ‘be more kind’ might need to be applied to myself more than I did in my youth. I suspect there may also be an increased change from physical fitness to functional fitness. I find myself identifying what I would like to be able to do in my old age (work on my allotment, get up from a chair without using the arms, get up from the floor if I fall over, be able to move around under my own steam rather than relying on a wheel chair or motorised chair) form much more of my thoughts now than being able to cycle for 100 miles.  Health, wellbeing and appearance In your view, how are health and wellbeing related to external appearance? Only in regard to self confidence (There is a rider here in that morbid obesity obviously will affect health and as a result wellbeing). In the health and fitness industry I see lots of gorgeous women who radiate with well-being who are vilified for being ‘fat’. The connection of health to external appearance is in the most part judgmental and damaging.  Have you ever been influenced by popular ideals of beauty or physical appearance? As a young person I longed to be thin. Not to be idolised but rather to become invisible. Fatness has the most amazing ability to render you both invisible and incredibly visible at the same time. Do you think your parents were influenced by these kinds of ideals? If so, in what way? My mum was always on a diet. We never discussed the reasons behind it so I have no idea why the drive was there. That said, it was 70’s and fat in food was vilified in those days. Are there any health or beauty products (excluding medicines) that you couldn’t live without? What would be your Desert Island item? Does toothpaste count as a medicine? Getting ready to leave the house Do you remember your mother or father getting ready to go out for work, or for the evening? If so, can you describe their rituals? Both parents had a going out routine. Mum = bathtime, blow dry, eyebrow pluck, draw them back in (?), make up applied, clothes on and out the door. Dad = bathtime, shave in the downstairs mirror, aftershave applied (Old Spice), clothes on and out the door. Dad often used to boil water from the garden water butt to wash his hair – he believed it was purer than from the tap. Bearing in mind we lived in a mining district and all most of the areas domestic heating was fuelled by coal – I had my doubts.  What is your own routine when getting ready to go out for work or for socialising? Has this routine changed over time? I have the same routine I have always used. Shower, dry, clothes on, go. I don’t wear make up. I wouldn’t know what to do with it. When I got married my husband bought and applied my make up. He certainly knows a lot more about it than I do. I have always figured that I was quietly rebelling against the system.  Please post your response to: Freepost: RTGU-AYJE-YSSC, The Mass Observation Archive, The Keep, Woollards Way, Brighton, BN1 9BP (please note that the MOA team are currently working from home and unable to respond to directives sent by post) or by email to: moa@sussex.ac.uk. JS/KP Summer Directive/No. 120

Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing'. Mass-Observer M6749 describes themself as female; age 65; married; retired university administrator.;The Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing' was issued on 27 November 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their opinions on and experiences of health and wellbeing, in particular 'health, wellbeing and the healthy body'; 'identity'; 'growing up and learning about health and wellbeing'; 'growing older'; 'health, wellbeing and appearance'; 'getting ready to leave the house'.
Contents: M6749, Female, 65, married, Oxford, retired university administrator Part 2: Everyday health and wellbeing Health, to me, is the capacity that an individual or a group has to eat well, sleep well and be adequately active. Someone who is healthy can do all these things in daily life without too much difficulty, and if you can’t do one or more of these things, you are not really healthy.  Wellbeing, to me, is the consequence of using this capacity for health – a comfort or sense of ease. There are both physical and mental aspects of wellbeing. Words that come to mind when I think of a healthy body:  resilient, efficient, natural, balanced, sound. There isn’t a particular image that comes to mind when I think of these qualities. My own experience of health has been influenced, firstly, by my age. For my parents’ generation the threat of disease was real, as were pre-NHS medical costs. My father nearly died of diphtheria when he was four; my mother of pneumonia in her twenties just as the first antibiotic treatments became available. In my generation we caught measles, whooping cough, chicken pox and mumps one after the other, whole classrooms at the same time.  The exceptions were polio, for which a vaccine had just been developed; tuberculosis, for which the BCG vaccine had been available for some time, diphtheria, tetanus and smallpox.   As a small girl I recall having to go with my family to a sort of portacabin where we had chest X rays: a case of TB had emerged at the school where my father taught and the local authority was vigorous in tracing contacts. I also remember attending ‘sun-ray sessions’ on Friday afternoons. Fifty or sixty small children sat in a darkened room with vests removed and wearing googles against the light of a sun lamp. This was supposed to help us fight colds and coughs by increasing our Vitamin D levels. Class has also influenced my health. It was a long time before I realised how childhood diseases which to us seemed routine are very serious for disadvantaged or poorly nourished children; or how privileged we had been that our mother didn’t work outside the home and so was able to nurse us when we were unwell. This meant that we had enough time off school to recover properly from an illness before going back into the fray. A third factor has been gender. When I was old enough to become a feminist (1970s and 1980s), women’s health and sexual health were big topics: like many women at the time I took active steps to understand how my body worked and what could go wrong.  At the time this felt like an obligation: we saw the medical profession as male-dominated and not especially informed about or supportive of women’s health. The moment when I realised that I could inform myself and take charge of my own health was definitely a key moment. Everyone I knew bought a copy of ‘Our Bodies Ourselves’. I reached puberty quite late (I started menstruating at thirteen and a half) but had read books given to me my mother and knew roughly what to expect. Looking back, at the time I don’t seem to have been very interested in bodily changes. I was much more affected by a tendency to faint, which I’m now sure was hormonal. It was very embarrassing. As I was growing up health (and particularly nutrition) was taught by my parents around the kitchen table. We ate our cabbage, not to remember the starving children in the world, but because cabbage is nutritious. All cooking at home was done from scratch and until I was in my teens, my mother’s menus followed second world war rationing principles – wholegrains, plain vegetables, fresh fruit, raw food, fish, and not much meat or dairy except milk. By today’s standards, though, there was too much sugar, which may explain why our teeth needed to be filled from the age of six.  In my mother’s mind this diet had kept people healthy and it would do the same for us. Mum was particularly keen on digestive health: syrup of figs, a fennel-tasting laxative and liquid paraffin were all kept in the medicine cupboard and dispensed freely.  M6749, Female, 65, married, Oxford, retired university administrator There were also many stories at home about the difference that the coming of the NHS had made. One of my father’s favourite novels (and now one of mine) was The Citadel by A.J.Cronin. I picked it out of his bookshelf when I was seven or eight and was horrified by its account of the impact of poverty, poor living conditions and an incompetent and corrupt medical profession on ordinary people’s health.  I would say that this novel has been a very strong influence on me. My father’s family were quarrymen and canalmen in a Black Country industrial village: injury at work or sickness usually led to unemployment or premature death. Both my grandfathers died, I think, from overwork. All my father’s family told stories about the coming of the NHS and how grateful they had been to have long standing conditions treated at last. By contrast, my mother’s middle class family could afford to pay for medical treatment when needed. She kept a slightly snobbish preference for private medicine until the end of her life. Both my parents were keen on exercise: on team games and sports of all kinds (they were both teachers, so could hardly advocate otherwise); and on walking. My mother cycled and attended aerobics classes until her mid eighties. I’ve inherited an enjoyment of walking and yoga from her but have learned that I can’t handle anything too competitive. No one at home was any good at sleeping and I have inherited that too. I now think that both my parents were susceptible to stress and found it difficult to relax. In my house 3am was often a busy time – people talking to each other downstairs in the kitchen, clunking the biscuit tin, opening and shutting the fridge, making milky drinks and cups of tea. My father’s mental health was often poor: he had periods which would now be diagnosed and treated as anxiety and depression, which made him withdrawn and irritable. At home this was described as ‘worry’. When I was working, not only did I smoke cigarettes, but I had appalling sleep patterns and day after day would get up and drive a long commute on three or four hours’ sleep.  Now that I have retired one of my greatest pleasures is to know that I can wake in the light for almost all the year and will not have to get up immediately and drive. I value good sleep. I’m generally much more aware of health and wellbeing now. Five years ago I had a period of depression. I was lucky enough to be offered a new talking therapy called interpersonal therapy (there were studies going on locally). I learned how to take care of myself on an ongoing basis to help prevent it happening again. I know that I have to be aware of who makes up my network of family and friends, particularly those who give me support, and to give them regular time and attention. I have to take some kind of physical exercise and to eat properly on a daily basis. Looking back, this was an unpleasant enough event in my life to make me change my behaviour. I hope that I’ll continue to be able to look after my health. At the moment I am overweight, although not obese. I know that reducing by two stones will be helpful and that I need to take it seriously over the next year.  I get most of my health information online: for example, the NHS website, which is informative and, in my opinion, reliable. I’m astonished at the amount of ‘health advice’ available online and on social media and tend to regard it all as rubbish. I have never really understood a connection between health and wellbeing and external appearance. I haven’t bothered about looking ‘young’ since the age of about 25 although I did dye my hair until I turned 50. I have never regretted stopping that. I fell in love with my wife because to me, she is the most beautiful woman I know, both in appearance and in personality, and that’s enough. However I do have really dry skin and worry that if I were cast away without lip balm my lips would crack like badly cast concrete. Perhaps if my desert island had sheep I could gather lanolin from their wool. Otherwise I’d suffer. M6749, Female, 65, married, Oxford, retired university administrator My routine for leaving the house is very basic. If I’m leading a visitor tour at the library or welcoming visitors at the church, I try to look neat and respectable, and that’s it. That’s very similar to how I saw things when I was working, since I was lucky enough to work for most of my career in marvellous organisations which didn’t judge women’s contribution by their appearance. I know my mother would be horrified; once her Baptist mother died she was free to wear lipstick and never left the house without it. I’m not going to worry about whether that really is freedom.
