Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing'. Mass-Observer P5940 describes themself as female; age 49; married; business consultant.;The Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing' was issued on 27 November 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their opinions on and experiences of health and wellbeing, in particular 'health, wellbeing and the healthy body'; 'identity'; 'growing up and learning about health and wellbeing'; 'growing older'; 'health, wellbeing and appearance'; 'getting ready to leave the house'.
Contents: P5940: female, 49, married, York, Business Consultant Part 2: Everyday Health and Wellbeing Health, wellbeing and the healthy body For me, health means if you have issues or illnesses that you need to be treated for. Wellbeing is a more holistic term which takes into consideration all of your illnesses – mental and physical – and looks at treatments that can include things like healthy eating, connecting with others, learning, being mindful etc. What do you think about when you imagine “a healthy body”? Please share the first five words that come to your mind when you think of this term. Water, vegetables, walking, nature, air Is there a particular person or image that comes to mind? Please describe, or draw, this person. Joe Wicks! But also, people like Emma Mitchell who share their mental health challenges but use nature to overcome them. Identity I grew up in the 70s with a mother who was interested in alternative approaches to wellbeing and that has rubbed off on me – being an educated woman, raised as I was, I’m interested in wellbeing and have tried many different approaches to healthy living. I think it’s probably easier for women to be open about trying new approaches to wellbeing. Wellbeing is discussed so much in relation to family, menopause etc. It’s always seen as being integral to whichever stage of your life you’re at, I think. I am a person who likes trying new things and this certainly drives me to try different approaches to mental and physical wellbeing. Growing up and learning about health and wellbeing I learnt from an early age as my mother was interested in being healthy, not eating processed food etc. I had a lot of allergies as a child and so we avoided eating artificial additives and processed foods. We’ve always been keen to get out of the house and I made the link with ‘doing’ and ‘feeling better’ from an early age. My mother and I talked about eating healthily and getting plenty of fresh air. At primary school, I remember talking about how much sugar was in foods and that wasn’t good for us. I certainly read magazines when I was a child/teenager but often the articles were about how to look better/be thin through healthy eating. Latterly, I read newspapers or watch the news for information about health and wellbeing. My workplace is very focussed on wellbeing and there are lots of resources and classes we can access to support wellbeing. It’s very different from 5 or 10 years ago when you probably would have found this information in specialist magazines. Key moments When I was about 10 or 11, my body started to change. My periods started, I became spotty and my body shape changed. I don’t think I thought these stages were important – maybe I was bit embarrassed about the changes?  Growing older I have always eaten healthily, drunk a lot of water, spent a lot of time outside but I was never very sporty – although I always liked swimming. I swam a lot and when I became forty, I trained for triathlons, I think that is when I started taking my fitness more seriously. Now, I exercise at least three times a week, normally I would be swimming twice a week as well. I also meditate three times a week and walk as much as I can. I spend time learning and P5940 connecting with family and friends. I write as I think that contributes to wellbeing too. I get information about wellbeing from friends, the media – probably the Guardian – and from various forums, like the Menopause Forum. I’ve had to be more aware of my body over the past 5-10 years as I’ve suffered very badly with the menopause. It’s only in the last year, after seeing a specialist, that I’ve really been able to feel like I have more control over my wellbeing. Health, wellbeing and appearance I think that, growing up in the 80s, everything -for a woman – was about how you looked, your body shape etc. I worried all the time about being fat, being wrinkly, spotty etc. It was such a waste of time. Now, I think there’s a focus on wellbeing and then, hopefully, your looks and appearance will follow and will improve. In the past, I have been drawn into fads about ‘clean eating’ but these seem too obsessed with weight loss and looks and so now I take a more measure view of health and wellbeing. I think my Mum has never been influenced by ideals although other members of my family were very influenced and ate little, focussed on looks obsessively, to the point of becoming unhealthy. Years ago, I started making my own skin care items and use oils and essential oils to moisturise my skin. If I had to go to a desert island, I would take a big flask of some baobab and rosehip oil with petitgrain and Melissa oils! Getting ready to leave the house. My mum had a very quick routine, nothing extravagant. My grandmothers both were obsessed with looks and beauty and spent a lot of time and money on skin care and clothes. One of my grandmothers had beautiful, fine skin – like porcelain – she wouldn’t go out in the sun. It was unlined and clear until she died. I have worn makeup since I was a teenager. My routine really hasn’t changed a lot. I shower every day, moisturise my body with (homemade) oil. Put on makeup then leave my hair a while and then dry it. I probably use less products than I used to – I try to get ready as quickly as I can now, I don’t spend a lot of time massaging my skin or putting on eye cream. None of it makes a difference anyway.

Keywords: COVID-19 pandemic (2020-);Lifestyle, health and well-being;Family life;Food;Family members;Adolescence;Reproductive health;Emotional states;Pregnancy and early maternity;Personal appearance;
Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing'. Mass-Observer S4002 describes themself as female; age 42; married; manager.;The Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing' was issued on 27 November 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their opinions on and experiences of health and wellbeing, in particular 'health, wellbeing and the healthy body'; 'identity'; 'growing up and learning about health and wellbeing'; 'growing older'; 'health, wellbeing and appearance'; 'getting ready to leave the house'.
Contents: Autumn Directive 2020 S4002 Female, 42 Married, Cardiff Manager Part 2: Everyday Health and wellbeing In my job, I often help people apply for government funding, so terms like ‘health and wellbeing’ are banded around a lot. It seems to me that pretty much any project from any field or discipline can claim to positively impact on health and wellbeing! To me, ‘health’ is a straight-forward term that relates to health of the body. So, I guess I see this as pretty medical, but one that includes preventative measures – such as regular exercise – as well as more traditional medical approaches. I see ‘wellbeing’ as a much broader term, that includes things like mental or emotional wellbeing, environmental factors that affect mental or emotional states, social and creative inputs – basically all the stuff that makes people happy and makes living comfortable or even pleasurable. When I think of a healthy body, I guess the main thing I think about is balance – not too fat, not too thin, not to muscular, not too flabby, sun kissed, but not too tanned. I think extremes of fitness can be as unhealthy as extreme unfitness. I don’t spend a lot of time imagining healthy bodies, but I guess now I’m thinking about it a yoga teacher kind of physique springs to mind. Someone who is strong and fit but not necessarily there showing off their six pack. I think my attitude to health has largely been formed by my mum. She was a nurse, and as a kid we always had home cooked food, we always ate plenty of vegetables and we weren’t allowed things like fizzy drinks or Findas crispy pancakes in the house. Which always really upset me as a kid! We weren’t deprived all treats though. I usually had a penguin chocolate bar or similar in my lunch box every day, we always had pudding after dinner and chocolate bars on Friday nights. When I left home, I then tended to cook in the same way and me and my husband still do. We rarely have processed or pre-packaged food and make most things from scratch. I guess social class might have something to do with it, but in a round-about way. I suspect, after my dad died and as a single parent to two young children, home-cooked meals were cheaper than ready-made meals in the 1980s. But my mum and grandparents were definitely middle class in their outlook if not their professions, so it may also have been part of an aspirational outlook? Similarly, my dad was a very active person, as is my sister – if she feels like she’s got a cold coming on, her solution is to go for a run! I think because of that, for most of my life I thought of myself as being pretty lazy. Swimming is really the only physical activity I enjoy and have, at various points been a member of gyms and swam at least two or three times a week to justify the membership fee. I haven’t really been able to do that since having children as there just aren’t the hours in the day – but I figured that was ok because I get my exercise from my 20min bike ride each way to work four or five days a week. It was only in the last year or two that I realised no one else thought I was lazy and that, out of a group of 6 friends, only two of us regularly did any form of exercise. In terms of being conscious about my own health and wellbeing, I honestly don’t know when I first started thinking about and taking responsibility for it. I come from a relatively healthy family and learnt about cooking and nutrition at school. I guess the first real introduction to the idea of health and wellbeing was through my stepdad. He had bad knee joints when I was younger, and he went on the Hay System which talked about not mixing carbohydrates and proteins in the same meal. So that made me think for the first time about what nutritionally went on my plate. He also then started looking into some posture and wellbeing thing that was popular at the time – the something Method – I can’t remember, but that took a more holistic approach to health. And I think it did all solve his Autumn Directive 2020 S4002 Female, 42 Married, Cardiff Manager knee problem as he doesn’t have it now! My family aren’t hippies by any stretch, but at some point, all of us have tried things like acupuncture, massage and other forms of alternative therapies, so I guess we all believe that wellbeing is an important part of health. And all of that has just informed where I am now. In terms of key moments, I guess the one I remember most is starting to wear a crop top. It happened shortly after I'd been in hospital with an asthma attack, so the rib cage area was generally uncomfortable at the time. I was in primary school, so maybe 10 at the time. I had my first period on the 1st January 1990 – a memorable date rather than a memorable experience. At the age of 12, moving into a new decade was a really big deal. When I got my period, I just went and got the free sanitary towels we’d been given at school and then told my mum. It wasn’t really a big deal to me then and I wasn’t that happy about puberty. At the time, I didn’t really want to change and saw it as a real chore and inconvenience. A more memorable moment for me – well significant – was when I was probably somewhere around 20 give or take a couple of years, and when I realised that my body would never stop changing. It’s kind of talked about like you go through puberty at like 14 or something and then that's it. But it isn’t. My body has continued to change and some of that is down to hormones and not diet. With that realisation, I felt a bit freer but also a bit pissed off that I wasn’t properly informed. Instead, we’re kind of made to feel bad about our bodies changing is negative and to do with ageing or ‘filling out’ when it’s something we literally have no control over. But I think we live in a society that likes to think it has control over a lot of things we don’t – just look at responses to Covid-19. Another key moment for me was when I stopped taking the pill. In my early 20s I swapped to a coil and felt like a totally different person. I became much more aware of my body and more in tune with its cues. Emotionally, I suddenly felt reconnected with my body. It’s difficult to describe, but it felt a bit like I hadn’t realised my head was floating a couple of inches above my body and when I stopped taking the pill, the two reconnected. I think I became more of a whole person for it and more stable emotionally, which in turn, made me feel more confident making decisions and trusting my judgement. Part of me did (and does) think the pill is part of the patriarchy’s way of keeping women under control! At the moment, I am more aware of my body than ever. I have a 5 month old baby, so I am amazed by my body’s ability to grow, give life to and sustain another human being, for the second time. It is an incredibly empowering feeling and I don’t think I will ever doubt my body’s ability to do anything. As I am exclusively breastfeeding a very hungry little baby, it makes me very aware of my body’s own functions, from the feeling in my breasts when it’s time for a feed, to the feeling in my limbs and lack of concentration when I haven’t eaten or drank enough during the day. It makes me acutely aware that the human body is a finely balance machine that needs to be looked after. Unfortunately, because I my lack of sleep, my diet is terrible at the moment. I can’t stop eating and craving utter shit, like cake and biscuits. I keep trying to eat more healthily but it is always easier to snack on junk food. It is almost Christmas, so I’ll make sure my diet improves in the new year! The other thing about having a baby later in life makes you realise how knackered out you are. I don’t think there’s a part of me that doesn’t ache from all the lifting and carrying. And I am bone tired all the time. I think it's the same for all parents of young babies, but I can’t help thinking someone who is 10 years younger must bounce back faster and creak less. Autumn Directive 2020 S4002 Female, 42 Married, Cardiff Manager I have and haven’t given much thought to my future health and wellbeing. Having lost two parents, one to an accident and one to cancer, anything could get me at any time. I hope that doing Pilates will help to keep me mobile and grounded, as I find focussing on the exercises gives my mind a break from whatever is going on in my life. I hope cycling to work will help to keep me generally fit, as will running around after 2 children, so I think I’m laying some good groundwork to keep me healthy in the future. In terms of diet, I don’t think it will change that much as really, I start to feel sluggish and a bit sick if I have a week or two where I don’t eat lots of veg. I’m afraid that I am a bit of a fattist. Which is not very kind, but overweight people do make me feel uncomfortable. Not many people know that because it isn’t one of my best qualities, but I’m really bad for it. I’m not talking people who could do with losing a pound or two, I’m talking people who are really obese. Part of the reason is that I think I find it uncomfortable is that it says something about a person’s internal mind. I kind of believe in the idiom of ‘tidy house, tidy mind’ and I guess I sort of assume that if people aren’t willing to look after themselves physically and are making themselves ill (mobility issues, diabetes, etc) then it says something about their mental state. And it’s not the kind of mental state I want to get involved with. Generally, I try not to be too judgemental about people and the choices I make, but it all just falls apart a little when it comes to people who are overweight. Isn’t that awful -I don’t like it but I can’t help it. And I’ve got worse since being pregnant. Going through the physical process of carrying the extra weight and being a larger body shape is bloody hard work. I know that pregnant and overweight bodies operate differently, but just fitting behind a desk or sitting at a table is hard work when you are a larger size. Why would someone do that to themselves? In terms of my own appearance, I make a bit of an effort, but not much! My beauty routine takes about 5 minutes to complete. Put on a bit of moisturiser, whack on a bit of foundation, concealer, blusher, lipstick, eyeshadow, and mascara and I’m done. I haven’t found it difficult to keep up my beauty routine with a newborn baby because it takes me so little time to get ready! That being said, I do like to look like I’ve made a bit of an effort. Not in the sense that I dress up a lot, just that I look together. I work in an art school, but I like wearing clothes that make me feel like a professional and not a student, so personal appearance is important to me. I think I get this from my mum, who was always very concerned about how she looked and what others thought. She always looked smart, made an effort and loved to dress up for occasions. I think I was a bit of a disappointment to her on that front as she was always trying to get me into some frilly dress or other, but using clothes to project the image that you want has stayed with me. But I will go out without makeup on when I’m not working, and I don’t make that much more of an effort when I’m going on a night out-maybe put on a top that I’ve actually ironed rather than let the wrinkles fall out. In terms of desert island items, I’d probably have to go with suncream, because I burn to a crisp, and my eyelash curler, because otherwise my eyelashes irritate my eyes. I think I’m just too practical and tight-fisted for fashion!

Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'COVID-19 (Update)'. Mass-Observer T6654 describes themself as female; married; age 70; former secretary.;The Directive 'COVID-19 (Update)' was issued on 27 April 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their experiences of the COVID-19 pandemic, in particular 'health'; 'the government'; 'news'; 'work and home life'; 'technology'; 'shopping and food'; 'entertainment and leisure'; 'personal hygiene' and 'sleep'.
Contents: MO Number: T6654 Sex: Female, Married Age: 70 Warwick Former Occupation: Secretary Part 2: Covid-19 (Update) Health I live with my husband (aged 73) and so far we have both been healthy during lock down and haven't needed to access any help. Fingers crossed! My emotions were very steady for the first 5 or 6 weeks, but just lately I have been experiencing some ups and downs. I realise there is nothing I can do to change the situation we are in, apart from to stay and home, go out rarely and avoid other people as much as possible.  I feel very sad that I am unable to go over to Paris (which we have been used to doing every couple of months or so) to visit our son, daughter in law and grand daughter. As time as gone on I have realised that this situation won't get much better for a long time, and find the prospect of not seeing our grand daughter (who was 2 at Christmas and is growing up very quickly and at a very interesting stage) or “normal” life returning for a very long time rather depressing.  However, I manage to talk myself out of that, as there is no point in getting low.  My main emotion is anger at the way the government is mis-managing the whole situation. The Government I'm afraid many of my thoughts on the political decisions that have been made are unprintable! However, I'll give it a go: The government was very arrogant at the beginning, refusing to take any notice of the growing pandemic. They were so caught up with Brexit, going it alone and with the Brexit narrative of “Unleashing Britain's Potential”, they refused to listen to warnings or to take advantage of offers of help from the EU. Johnson missed several COBRA meetings, taking lengthy breaks at his country home, and then, after boasting of having seen his mother on mother's day and shaking hands with people when he visited a hospital treating Covid patients, he himself was taken ill with the virus and ended up in intensive care. His time was also taken up with finalising his divorce while preparing for the birth of his son.  He is a complete disaster as a Prime Minister and quite frankly, I despair. It seems that Boris Johnson, when he did start to take notice, took advice from Dominic Cummings (who is an unelected advisor and apparently an advocate of eugenics) which was to “take it on the chin – be prepared to lose members of our families before their time – let it rip through the population” to produce a so-called “herd immunity”. They followed this programme for two to three weeks, allowing large public gatherings like international football matches, and the Cheltenham racing programme to take place before eventually seeming to take notice and start to bring into action some plans – closing shops, pubs, clubs, restaurants and businesses urging people to stay at home, stay safe and protect the NHS.  It soon became apparent that the NHS was woefully underprepared for what was to come, particularly in the areas of PPE and testing etc. All these failures led to far more deaths than were necessary, and to us being the country with the worst death toll apart from USA. What has happened to NHS employees and the people working and living in care homes throughout the country is a total scandal, verging on criminal neglect. As to what the government will do in the coming months is anyone's guess. They have already decided to ease some of the restrictions, encouraging people to go back to work. Their new approach was announced by the PM by means of a TV speech on Sunday night. This was anti-democratic and not the way it should have been done. Any announcement should have been made in the House of Commons where it could come under proper scrutiny and the details worked out, before being shared with the public. He brought in new measures regarding going to work, without having told work places that they should start preparing themselves to provide safe working environments, and told people they should not use public transport to get to work... the whole thing was totally confusing and muddled – leading to a dangerous situation where eventually the public was just told to “use your common sense”. This, Iam sure, willlead to a further spike in the numbers of positive tests and deaths when presumably everything will be locked down again. News I watch the BBC news, read the i newspaper, The Guardian and the Observer. I also look at the BBC website, Byline Times online, The European and Twitter. I do watch the daily press briefings most days, but find them totally useless. The media seems hamstrung by the fact that they are asking questions via screens and seem unable to take the government spokesmen properly to task or interview them with any rigour at all. The questions from the public are fatuous. The spokespeople say the same things over and over and never give a straight answer to any questions.  Most of them, quite frankly seem entirely out of their depth. I have no problem getting access to the news, but I can imagine that having signing interpreters would make it easier for people with hearing problems, and should be introduced across the board. Work and Home Life I am extremely fortunate in this regard.  Being retired and a pensioner I have no need to go to work and have found that being made to stay in my home was no real hardship at all. I am missing out on my volunteer work, and other regular social events that I was used to attending regularly, but I have a comfortable home with a garden (which is a real godsend) lots of books to read, knitting and tapestry work to do; I get on very well with my husband and we've had no disagreements or problems with being together all day every day. I am very lucky. Technology This is invaluable and the whole situation would have been a lot worse without it. We are used to emailing, texting and WhatsApping our friends and family on a regular basis.  But these occasions have increased greatly. We have also learned how to use Zoom, through which I can still take part in my weekly Tai Chi lesson, have meetings with my family who are in Paris and London and meet up with friends who we've not seen for quite a long time! I don't use Facebook really, but am a great fan of Instagram and Twitter, both of which have been great for distraction and education. Shopping and food This has been slightly challenging, though we've not been as badly affected as some people, because I always keep a big stock of food etc as a general habit, and was particularly well stocked this year because we'd recently bought a chest freezer and filled it as a way of stock piling in advance of a no-deal Brexit which my husband was sure would happen and would lead to various shortages. We have a small M&S Simply Food shop in Warwick, which has been very well stocked with most things and is well organised as far as social distancing is concerned so I have been popping in there every now and then. Otherwise I have had vegetables delivered from one of the Warwick market stalls, and had deliveries from a small deli in town.  Now I have finally managed to work the Waitrose click and collect slot system and will be collecting my second big grocery shop this weekend! Our eating habits haven't changed greatly but I seem to be thinking much more about what I will cook each day and whether I've got the necessary ingredients. We are, however, drinking more wine – particularly as each evening comes we are left despairing by the news or the government briefing, and the only solution seems to be to have a glass or more of wine! Entertainment and Leisure I'm afraid I have been pretty idle during the lockdown so far. I haven't learned any new skills, but have been doing things I normally do to a greater or lesser degree, such as knitting and tapestry. At the beginning I found it hard to concentrate enough to read (very frustrating as I am usually a great reader) but now I find the habit is returning and I have been able to take pleasure in reading again. A particular favourite book has been the latest biography of the Beatles “One Two Three Four The Beatles in Time” by Craig Brown. It is a fascinating overview of the 60s decade and the Beatles part in it. We haven't done much film or tv watching of any particular note, apart from two films starring Jeff Bridges, both of which we've seen before but which we thoroughly enjoyed ­“Come Hell or HighWater” and the remake of “True Grit”. I have watched one or two art programmes on iPlayer such as a BBC programme which Michael Palin made on the Danish painter Hammershoi.  I have been continuing to listen to my favourite pod casts, the ones I have enjoyed most are “Older and Wider” with Jenny Eclair and Judith Holder, “Fortunately” with Jane Garvey and Fi Glover and “Backlisted” the books podcast by John Mitchinson and Andy Miller. I find podcasts particularly helpful in bed at night. We have been doing a couple of jigsaws and have been sowing seeds and plants and raising seedlings for a vegetable garden. I have been doing some exercise most days – but probably not enough. I walk round town for half an hour or so about 5 days out of 7. Personal Hygiene My habits regarding this haven't really changed. I tend to stay longer in bed in the morning than I would have done before, and sometimes don't change out of my night clothes until late morning, after a shower, but I have continued to wear makeup most days and attempt to make my hair look ok, though that is getting more and more difficult since I cannot get to a hair dresser to have my hair cut! This is going to be more and more distressing as the time goes on, I'm sure – but there's no alternative other than getting my husband to cut it, which I really don't fancy! Sleep My sleep, surprisingly, hasn't been too badly affected by the situation.  In fact, generally speaking I think I'm sleeping a bit better than usual.  I have had a couple of nights which were filled with nightmares, which I found rather distressing, and which affected me during the day afterwards, but otherwise I have no real problem, so far.  If I do find it hard to get to sleep, or if I wake in the night and can't go back to sleep I tend to listen to my podcasts and find them very helpful, just to prevent my mind wandering somewhere where I don't w a n t t

Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing'. Mass-Observer T6740 describes themself as female; age 40; 'Married, although living alone as husband currently in prison. No children'; global bid manager for a large insurance company.;The Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing' was issued on 27 November 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their opinions on and experiences of health and wellbeing, in particular 'health, wellbeing and the healthy body'; 'identity'; 'growing up and learning about health and wellbeing'; 'growing older'; 'health, wellbeing and appearance'; 'getting ready to leave the house'.
Contents: SEX: FEMALE AGE: 40 STATUS: MARRIED, ALTHOUGH LIVING ALONE AS HUSBAND CURRENTLY IN PRISON. NO CHILDREN. LOCATION: BORDON, HAMPSHIRE OCCUPATION: GLOBAL BID MANAGER FOR A LARGE INSURANCE COMPANY Autumn Directive 2020 Part 2 – Everyday Health & Wellbeing Health, wellbeing and the healthy body “Health” means to me more of a medical term. So everything in the body is functioning as it should. “Wellbeing” is more of a spiritual term, incorporating the brain and the other senses of the body. A healthy body in 5 words: . Supple . Fruit . Vegetables . Slim . Active Gwyneth Paltrow springs to mind when I consider a healthy person. Identity I grew up in the 1980s, where we lived a reasonable comfortable middle-class existence in a suburban town. There was always food on the table, mainly home cooked. We didn’t indulge much in biscuits and puddings. We weren’t particularly into fad foods. My experience of health has been influenced by social class and ethnicity. But I can’t say it is has been influenced particularly by gender or sexual orientation. Growing up and learning about health and wellbeing I first became aware of health around the time of secondary school. But wellbeing was a bit later, perhaps not until in my twenties. It seems to be everywhere now, but wellbeing was a relatively new term for me. My parents had responsibility for looking after my health when I was a child. Mainly my mother. She cooked the meals. And we had a balanced diet. I don’t recall being a fussy eater. I went through a brief stage of being a vegetarian when I was about 13, but Mum just served me the potatoes and vegetables. She didn’t buy vegetarian foods for me. I quickly got bored and went back to a normal diet. But that wasn’t for health reasons. I think I just wanted to be different. SEX: FEMALE AGE: 40 STATUS: MARRIED, ALTHOUGH LIVING ALONE AS HUSBAND CURRENTLY IN PRISON. NO CHILDREN. LOCATION: BORDON, HAMPSHIRE OCCUPATION: GLOBAL BID MANAGER FOR A LARGE INSURANCE COMPANY It wasn’t until I was about 14 that I was diagnosed with a glucose intolerance. My sugar levels would crash constantly, leaving me sweating, weak and shaky. I realised that I couldn’t eat chocolate and sweet things, only in moderation after a meal. So from there, and to this day, I rarely touch sweet things. I don’t have a sweet tooth. My parents attitude to diet was reasonably healthy. I can remember my Mum being shocked to hear that my Dad grew up on meals (during the early 1950s) such as white bread sandwiches with Mars Bars. My maternal Grandma too used to love sugar sandwiches. And I think my Mum from a young age had a much healthier approach to food than her own parents. Perhaps influenced by magazines of the time. She insisted on only eating brown bread for instance. I remember when Mum switched us all to skimmed milk – we thought it was horrible and watery, but we got used to it begrudgingly. Key moments Breasts and periods were definitely key moments in growing up. I first become aware of adolescence when I was about 10. Two very hard lumps appeared on my chest. I told my Mum and she took me to the GP and she said it was the breasts forming and it was perfectly normal. I think we were a bit shocked and embarrassed, as looking back now it was obvious what they were! I started wearing crop tops because all the other girls at school did, you could wear cool, different patterned ones. It was clear I was more advanced in the breast department than some and I needed more ‘support’. Mum went out and bought me my first bra from Tammy Girl. AA. It was non-underwired and nylon, and it was so itchy. I was upset because I wanted to wear the crop tops like the other girls as they had better patterns on them. I didn’t want the boys to see I had a bra on under my school shirt in case I got teased. I remember she told my Dad (by this time they were separated). He tried to bring it up with me in McDonalds, said something like “You’re a woman now…” and I almost died of embarrassment. I started my periods at 11. I remember my Mum was out for the evening. We had a babysitter but I didn’t want to tell her. I left a note in my Mums bedroom for when she got home. It said “Mum I’ve started by Ps. Please get me some things”. When she got home, she crept into my room to talk to me, but I pretended to be asleep. I was too embarrassed to discuss it. But she did buy me some things. SEX: FEMALE AGE: 40 STATUS: MARRIED, ALTHOUGH LIVING ALONE AS HUSBAND CURRENTLY IN PRISON. NO CHILDREN. LOCATION: BORDON, HAMPSHIRE OCCUPATION: GLOBAL BID MANAGER FOR A LARGE INSURANCE COMPANY My sister didn’t start her periods until she was 14. And I remember being very unkind to her because I thought she was a late developer compared to me. And I was therefore far more “wordly wise” than she was. Growing older Over the last 10 years, I have seen my weight creep up to around 10 stone. I’m 5’ 1. So this is considered overweight. I’m usually a size 10 trousers and a size 12 top. And my clothes still fit me, but some are a bit tight now and I don’t wear them for that reason. I have never done any form of exercise. But I started running 2.5 years ago. I joined a running club with a friend and started Couch to 5K. I did it in 12 weeks, although I found it tough as I was so unfit. My husband had just been sent to prison, and my options for coping were: a) Sit around and mope. b) Find religion c) Start running So I chose option C. I was doing fairly well and even considered a 10K, until I fell over and smacked both knees on the pavement. Weeks of bruising meant my running fell behind. So then I joined yoga and did that for a year before Covid-19 came along and put a stop to most classes. I could have continued online but I don’t have much space in my house to do it. I started running again about 6 months ago, but lost the impetus after a few weeks. Since then I’ve done nothing. And now it’s the start of 2021, I’m into a new year and I’m wondering what I’ll do as currently all the gyms in my area are closed. Maybe I’ll try again with my running. I’m much more aware of my body now. About what goes in. I try to eat fruit and vegetables every day, and like my Mum, I only buy wholemeal bread. I don’t care so much about being slim, but I do want to remain healthy. I lost a friend to cancer a couple of years ago, she was only 41. And another friend of mine has recently recovered from bowel cancer. So you to tend to be more conscious of what you put your body through. I haven’t stopped drinking alcohol, and I’ve been known to drink a bottle of wine a night, but I’m aware that its not healthy and I would like to cut back. In future years, I expect to be even more careful with what I eat and drink. Health, wellbeing and appearance SEX: FEMALE AGE: 40 STATUS: MARRIED, ALTHOUGH LIVING ALONE AS HUSBAND CURRENTLY IN PRISON. NO CHILDREN. LOCATION: BORDON, HAMPSHIRE OCCUPATION: GLOBAL BID MANAGER FOR A LARGE INSURANCE COMPANY For me, good skin is an indicator of health in a person. I’m lucky I have always had clear skin, although I have developed melasma since my late 30s which I can conceal. I was influenced quite heavily by magazines such as Just Seventeen, which used images of young, thin, tall models. When I tried to emulate the same look, I didn’t understand why things didn’t look that good on me and I would feel down about myself. I know my Mum was very influenced by beauty and make-up. I asked her recently what influenced her and she said she remembered getting the bus to school (Ashford Grammar School), with her hockey stick and frumpy school uniform. She remembers seeing these ladies get on the bus to go to work and they were immaculately dressed. She remembers studying their make-up, their eye liner and wanted to be just like them. She was a big fan of magazines like Mandy in the early 1970s when she was growing up and she put a lot of importance on how she looked. She still does to this day, wouldn’t leave the house without make-up but I don’t remember her trying to teach my sister or I. And we weren’t that interested in learning either. The one thing I couldn’t live without is a moisturiser with a good SPF in it. Getting ready to leave the house Before she went to work (as An Executive PA), my Mum would get up at 6am just to do her hair and make-up. I never understood why she didn’t want to spend the extra time in bed. But she genuinely enjoyed doing her and make-up. She always looked immaculate with her hair done with a hot brush, her make-up done expertly and painted nails. My Dad too was a stylish man, they look quite the pair when they were first married. Mum even won a beauty parade whilst she was on holiday, she was pregnant with her third child at the time. She would spend her evenings in front of the TV, filing and painting her nails. I don’t think I own a nail file. I’ve never done had the inclination to do that, my nails just chip or break. She still takes a lot of pride in her appearance to this day. Always immaculately made-up when she goes out. Recently she told me she cried because she’d run out of hair mousse and she was going to a party and all the shops were closed! I have never spent much time on my appearance, I like to look nice but I don’t spend hours doing it. I didn’t really wear make-up until I was in my late 20s. And I’ve never styled my hair to any great degree. Although I invested in a pair of GHD Hair Straighteners a year or so ago. Over the last few years I’ve been losing a lot of my hair, probably due to stress. Or low iron. So, I’m trying to take vitamins to help with that. MO NO: T6740 SEX: FEMALE AGE: 40 STATUS: MARRIED, ALTHOUGH LIVING ALONE AS HUSBAND CURRENTLY IN PRISON. NO CHILDREN. LOCATION: BORDON, HAMPSHIRE OCCUPATION: GLOBAL BID MANAGER FOR A LARGE INSURANCE COMPANY For work, in normal times I would spend about 20 minutes doing my hair and make-up before leaving the house. Foundation, concealer, blusher, mascara. I would only bother with eye shadow and lip gloss if I was going out for the evening. Now I’m working from home due to Covid, I only put make-up on if I have video conference calls. Often I just use foundation and blusher, so I barely spend my 5 minutes doing it. And as no one is going out at the moment, I hardly ever get to wear a full face of make-up. *End*

Keywords: COVID-19 pandemic (2020-);Lifestyle, health and well-being;Employment and occupations;Health services and medical care;Mental health;NHS (National Health Service);Schools;Family life;Adolescence;Reproductive health;Personal appearance;Society and social behaviour;Personal hygiene;
Description: Response to the Mass-Observation Project Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing'. Mass-Observer V3773 describes themself as female; age 58; cohabiting; 'NHS Clinical Coder, ex-bookseller, Psychology graduate'.;The Directive 'Everyday Health and Wellbeing' was issued on 27 November 2020 and asked Mass-Observers about their opinions on and experiences of health and wellbeing, in particular 'health, wellbeing and the healthy body'; 'identity'; 'growing up and learning about health and wellbeing'; 'growing older'; 'health, wellbeing and appearance'; 'getting ready to leave the house'.
Contents: Mass Obs Autumn 2020 Directive  Part 2  Everyday Health and Wellbeing V3773 Female, 58 co-habiting in Solihull, NHS Clinical Coder, ex-bookseller, Psychology graduate Health, wellbeing and the healthy body I probably used to think that health and wellbeing was purely an absence of illness or an absence of the need for medical attention.  I’ve always tended to think of health as being a physical thing, and wellbeing more a psychological thing, to do with happiness and ability to cope with life.  I have more recently come to realise that the physical and psychological are inextricably linked and heavily depend upon each other – physical exercise can be tremendously helpful when battling mental and physical health problems, but the same problems make it very difficult to find the motivation or energy for it. My ideas about health have also been influenced by working in a job that involves reading hospital patients’ medical notes, which have taught me what a very specific balance of systems is required to maintain a healthy body and mind, and surprised at just how many inpatients have suffered from psychological problems long-term, especially anxiety and depression, and require medication and counselling for them. I don’t think I can cover a healthybody in five words, but maybe I can have a go in five phrases: Well-maintained systems such as clear lungs and blood vessels Ideal balance of chemicals such as hormones, vitamins and minerals Right balance of muscle, fat and other components A musculoskeletal frame all of which is frequently exercised (dependent on the person’s abilities) A hygienic body and environment When I think of a healthy person, I think of someone who is strong enough to carry out every daily activities (perhaps cleaning, cooking and dressing) without tiring too quickly, with a mid-range Body Mass Index (proportion of weight to height) – somewhere between lean (not skinny) and a little bulky (but not too much), who exercises most days, including working out at the gym if they can’t achieve it through walking, cycling, dancing, playing sport or even vigorous chores such as cleaning. They are largely, if not entirely, vegetarian or vegan, and don’t eat much in the way of sugary, fatty or processed foods.  They don’t smoke, or take any other recreational drugs, or drink much alcohol.  They are able to cope with most of the things life throws at them, and are not overwhelmed for too long before they bounce back and manage to get on with things. Identity I can’t thinkof many examples of how my health or wellbeing is influenced by my identity. I was born and bred in the UK, so I am very lucky to have always had access to the NHS, which is fantastic, and the best way to provide healthcare, and apart from waiting lists in some areas, which are usually down to lack of funding (and of course, recently, COVID), I believe they easily match the medical care given in private hospitals, especially for more serious illnesses and treatments.  A large part of who I am and what I do, in the last couple of years, has been strongly guided by anxiety, so I have some experience of what NHS has to offer in mental health. Working in a hospital, and a lot of the anxiety being linked to my work, I was lucky enough, just before COVID struck, to be able to access a therapist from the Psychology department, and was offered about 6 sessions which mainly focused on learning mindfulness techniques.  Around the time I finished those, I had also finally reached the top of a waiting list (which took 8 months, but I gather that it’s not uncommon for under-16s to have to wait much longer) for six Cognitive Behavioural Therapy sessions (by phone, because of COVID) offered by the Local Health Authority. CBT was the only treatment they offered for anxiety, although they said that if my main problem had been depression they would have been able to offer counselling, which would have allowed me to talk things through, and would have been less dependent on symptom management techniques. Although mindfulness and CBT have helped, to a certain extent, the exercises also had the effect of overloading me with even more with stuff to do, and didn’t remove the chaos from my brain, and I only turned the corner and managed to focus on my work more effectively once I started mild anti-anxiety medication (suggested by my manager, not a therapist). The therapist then told me that such medication can help with CBT, helping a person to focus on their new coping strategies. I realise that the hospital and local health authority can’t afford endless sessions of therapy for everyone who wants it, and that their treatments need to be measurable, recordable and accountable, which is why the patient is taught coping mechanisms rather than just chuntering on for weeks about how and why and their own way forward etc., which would be less likely to show tangible results, so in this one area, I might seek out a private therapist to help with the scribble in my brain. Growing up and learning about health and well-being I can’t remember anything about health education at school except for a talk for the girls, when I was 10 or 11, which may have covered puberty generally, but all I can remember was the bit intended to prepare us for the onset of periods.  We weren’t taught about the value of hygiene, nutrition or exercise, even as part of P.E. or domestic science (which mostly seemed to involve baking cakes), at any stage of school, as far as I can remember. I don’t think I remember my parents talking to me about health, although they certainly led by example, with balanced meals, clean house, clothes and family members, and encouragement of physical exercise, like walking, or participating in sports. It has taken me many years to take responsibility for my own health, and am very lucky that my lack of exercise, especially in the last couple of years (desk job), and a lifetime of unhealthy snacks haven’t, so far, resulted inany major illness (that I’m aware of –I can’t see myarteries or the state of my digestive system). Until the last few years I hadn’t looked for information about health, and all I can remember in the media, as a young adult, was advice against smoking, but now there is a wealth of advice to be seen on the Internet and television, in magazines and newspapers, as well as hundreds of books, on different aspects of health, and there now seems little excuse for anyone with access to these sources to claim ignorance of the importance of a healthy lifestyle.  A significant proportion of patients that I code suffer from heart, lung or liver disease – often avoidable conditions (though of course there will be exceptions, like genetic conditions) if people eat sensibly, exercise, avoid smoking and excessive alcohol. Sometimes a family history of heart conditions is mentioned in a patient’s notes, but in some cases, not all, it may be a result of a family history of poor diet. Key moments I can’t remember much about bodily changes at puberty.  I don’t remember my first bra, or my first period, but I remember the pain of periods, and how awful it was to be at school when they made me feel so ill. I also remember the awkwardness of tampons and early attempts at following the instructions and illustrations. Don’t laugh unless you’ve tried it! Growing older It’s only in the last couple of years that I’ve made much of an effort with my health, partly because so much of what I read in patient notes acts as a health warning – heart disease has such a negative impact on people’s lives, if it doesn’t kill them.  Also partly because I sit at a desk and don’t get much exercise, and feel out of breath after shorter bursts of physical exercise, and partly because of increased anxiety and depression. I now make sure I have a certain amount of fruit (apples ready cut up –the brownness doesn’t affect the taste – and grapes at the ready), nuts and vegetables every day.  This has become easier, since starting to work on this response, because I finally made the decision not to even buy any chocolate or crisps –it’s so easy to snack on the wrong things, working from home, in a job that’s not ideal for me. I desperately miss crisps – rice/corn cakes are OK but just not the same.  The chocolate bars I bought were very small, but it was difficult to have just the one.  I do have some Rich Tea biscuits if I get a real yen for something sweet, and they are quite enjoyable but neither they, nor the rice/corn cakes, call to me very often, which is good. My attempt to improve my diet is not just about body weight, or being pre-diabetic, or clogged arteries, but because the right intake, along with exercise, seem to make a huge difference to my energy levels and state of mind the next day. This isn’t because I know the theory and expect it –it’s actually taken me years to realise that I feel absolutely drained and fuzzy-headed the day after I have had sugary foods or missed out my fruit, nuts, vegetables or water intake. Within the last three years, I have struggled with routinely getting exercise.  I stopped going for daily 20-minute walks because I wanted to get a bit more work done, and putting music on before work in order to so-called dance for 20 minutes because although sometimes it’s enjoyable, and I still occasionally do that, sometimes I just feel a bit stupid, especially if I feel particularly tired or low. After lockdown I would like to find something like a local aerobics class, and even better if I find someone to go with, but they’re usuallyat times that don’t suit me – either during work hours, or mid-evening (I have quite an early night). I really enjoyed a regular Zumba class held at the hospital for a while, a few years back, but the instructor stopped it (because she couldn’t rely on enough staff attending regularly, what with shift patterns).  Now, I’m pleased to say, I made the decision to have a 20-minute every lunchtime regardless of how my work is going, on the basis that it will help me feel better for work the next day, and it helps enormously that usually my partner comes too, as it fits into his schedule.  I usually look for health information online these days, though I feel I know the general principles involved, because this sort of information has been pushed (and it’s welcome) at us for severalyears now.  Health, wellbeing, appearance Popular ideals of beauty have often been linked to the image of a healthy body, but also an exaggerated image of a healthy body, which can make people obsess about certain aspects of their appearance.  I have said, above, that a medium build (healthy proportions of muscle and fat) tends to indicate a healthier body than an underweight (which suggests under-or malnourishment) or overweight build.  However, because of the media persistently showing “perfect” (slim) bodies, going to the extent of airbrushing them, and companies trying to sell beauty or health products, people who are insecure worry far too much about being thin, to an unhealthy extent.  A clear skin, smooth and hydrated, suggests cleanliness and good nourishment, but this is so ingrained that a spot on the face (which unfortunately happens mostly in adolescence, a crucial time for developing self-confidence) can seem like a disaster, although I was lucky in this area and had fairly good skin. There is also muscle-building – again, based on the feeling that a strong-looking body is a healthy and therefore attractive body, but often, I think, becoming some people’s main focus in life, when they build themselves up into something that looks ridiculous and out of proportion, and sometimes leading to steroid addiction.  The other example that occurs to me, that illustrates how a healthy look can develop into an obsession, is a sun tan.  Paleness is often a fair-skinned person’s natural look, but it also seems to have been associated, by many, with an unhealthy, indoor lifestyle, and a tan has been associated with a healthy outdoor lifestyle, and thus perceived as attractive.  Yes, exposure to the sun gives us Vitamin D, and most of us do perceive a little colour rather than complete whiteness as suggesting an active, healthy outdoor life, but once it develops into an obsession to look brown, too much sun, especially for a fair-skinned person, very often causes skin cancer, which is clearly not good, and although people perhaps think that a skin cancer is easy to remove, it can also travel and cause metastases in less accessible parts of the body. When I was young I thought a good tan a very desirable thing to have, and I still wish that my legs would brown more easily, so I am clearly still influenced by that popular ideal of physical appearance, but now, quite apart from the fact that I know burning skin is a bad idea, I am too uncomfortable sitting in strong sun, and if I can be bothered, will use a bronzing cream for my legs rather than sunning them excessively. Neither of my parents was obsessed by sunning themselves, though it seems to have been the case for many years that most fair-skinned people would prefer a little bit of tan and would sit out in the sun for that purpose.  (It hasn’t always been that way – I think that way back in history it used to be a sign of good breeding tobe pale, as a sign that one didn’t have to work outdoors.) If, as children, my siblings and I were always around medium build, it was because we were given a healthy (and very tasty) diet, rather than because we worked hard at it in an attempt to be physically attractive.  Mum and Dad were also never what would be considered overweight or underweight, although Mum often still seems to eat slightly less of the main course than the rest of us. When I was trying to think of health or beauty products that I rely on, and thinking of the skin care and make up that so many women use daily, I struggled to think of any that were a must for me. I do shower or bathe, or at the very least have a good wash and a scrub, occasionally with exfoliating product, but I don’t have a skin care routine, unlike the majority of women seem to.  I think I’ve been spoiled in the past by having good skin, and looking young for my age, though fewer people comment on this, these days, so I should clearly be taking more care of myself, especially as I resent the speed at which old age seems to be creeping up on me.  I really should be using a moisturiser more often, at least on my face, but the only things I can think of that I use daily without fail are a face flannel, soap and underarm deodorant, and most days, a carefully chosen perfume.  Within the last 15 years I also got in the habit of wearing foundation for a while, especially on work days, because an ex-colleague noted that I go very pink if faced with a difficult situation, and he was someone who created uncomfortable situations himself, and the pinkness would spur him on to make me more flustered. But my pinkness is now slightly less of an issue, so I seldom use foundation these days. I need tweezers for the occasional surplus eyebrow or facial hair, and other depilatory products for legs. Don’t know what would be the single Desert Island product – perhaps some form of soap or antiseptic, although I get a lot of enjoyment from a lovely fragrance.  Getting ready to leave the house Leaving the house, Mum and Dad would be clean in body and attire, their clothes pressed, and I’m fairly certain there would always be aftershave and perfume (Dad and Mum respectively, obviously!) Mum would always apply a subtle and understated amount of make-up including powder and lipstick. I didn’t used to put much effort into mypresentation when I left the house, being lucky with good skin and hair, though sometimes I might have put mascara or eyeliner on, and clothes that were marginally more flattering (or I thought!) for a party, disco, or theatre, or if I was hoping to impress someone in particular.  For meeting friends in the daytime, or going to school, or shopping, I look back and realise how unflattering my shapeless t-shirts must have looked, and how little thought I gave to whether shapes or colours worked together. This was despite Mum trying to persuade me that a pretty blouse with a nice smart collar was the way to go. For many years I worked in bookshops, before there were company polo shirts with a logo, and people wore pretty much what they liked, so for me it was usually jeans and a t-shirt.  I was briefly a teacher, and of course aimed for a professional look at that time, and when I worked in a pharmacy, there was a uniform. It wasn’t until I got this office job, three years ago, that I went out and bought smart clothes, and actually made an effort to look extra nice, partly to look professional, of course, but also because I’ve started actually wanting to look good. Not sure why, maybe because it requires more effort when you’re older, than just relying on the gifts of good skin and good hair. Or it might be because I’m working on self-respect. It might also be because, with the gift of hindsight, I realise I must have looked, for years, as if I never made an effort. For this job I even made myself buy some clothes that were full price, if I thought something suited and fitted me well (although that doesn’t seem to happen very often), rather than waiting for something cheaper in sales or TKMaxx, which would generally result in finding nothing I liked. Even paying full price, there’s still not that much I like. Whilst I’m working from home, I don’t wear such smart clothes, although I’m clean and neat and not too casual, because of daily video meetings. Actually, whilst it’s cold, I often wear a fleece jacket and a scarf, which isn’t exactlyoffice wear, but the other home-working people wrap up warm, too. I seldom wear make-up these days, although I wore foundation a couple of times for work Teams meetings, and for family Zoom sessions, but now I don’t bother. I try to make my hair look normal, smooth and not too middle-aged, and occasionally, when I fail badly, I turn off the camera for work meetings – a few of us do that, and theydon’t seem to mind.
